HEADLINE: Union Heads Get Apology On Dinkins's Layoff Plan

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A day after he announced he might have to lay off 15,000 New York City workers to close yawning budget gaps, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday apologized to the union leaders who were among his strongest allies for failing to warn them that he intended to make the bad news public.
''The need to speak to the possibility of layoffs and to do it soon was required by the overall circumstances, and so I did,'' Mr. Dinkins said after a speech to the City Club of New York in Manhattan. ''The mistake we made, if any, in that regard, was a failure to advise'' union leaders, that we were doing so, ''so that they didn't get the information from the media.''
Mr. Dinkins announced he was considering the layoffs, recommended by his budget director, at a hastily called news conference on Thursday, after he had pleased unions in the preceding four days by agreeing to a 5.5 percent wage increase for teachers, called for the hiring of thousands of new police officers and proposed that special taxes be levied to pay for them. 
 
Teamsters Call Meeting
One of the union leaders, Barry L. Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has scheduled a meeting of several hundred shop stewards for this morning. His spokesman, Frank Mazza, said Mr. Feinstein would seek authorization to take further steps to gain a new contract, including calling a strike. But that does not mean a strike is imminent, Mr. Mazza said.
The Mayor said the teachers' agreement, the call for more police and the tax proposals were not inconsistent. He also said that the layoff warning was not meant as a tactic in union negotiations.
''These things are dynamic,'' he said. Events do not ''stand still and let you patiently, quietly go about your business. Some of the information on the revenue downturn is very recent, like yesterday.''
In response to questions from reporters, he insisted: ''The city is not falling apart. We are on the case.''
At the same time, other politicians and fiscal experts puzzled over the meaning and cumulative effect of Mr. Dinkins's actions over the week.
''It's stunning, because it looks as if everything is handled seriatim, and when you're dealing with fiscal matters, you just can't proceed that way,'' said Alair A. Townsend, a former city budget director and deputy mayor for finance who is now publisher of Crain's New York Business.
''I honestly don't think it's an overreaction,'' she said, but added, ''He doesn't look like he's out in front on this one but running to catch up.''
Mayoral aides said that Mr. Dinkins's actions were a result of a swift confluence of events that might have left anyone huffing and puffing.
''I think that we have put forward the strategy the Mayor has always said he had,'' said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch. ''That is to be as fair to labor as he possibly can, to keep the fiscal house in order, and to have a very strong anti-crime program. We're trying to move those agendas forward.''
 
Setting His Own Deadline
Aides noted that the Mayor had been locked in to presenting his anti-crime plan by Oct. 1, since he had pointed to that date to mollify those who had clamored for him to act sooner. Then, last weekend, he faced the possibility of a teachers strike.
Unable to reach agreement with Mr. Feinstein's union as he had hoped, the mayoral aides said, Mr. Dinkins had little choice but to reach a contract agreement with teachers - whose raise he had wanted to make higher all along but not have it set a pattern -and then proceed with his police plan on Tuesday.
But on Wednesday, the budget director, Philip R. Michael, learned more bad news about revenue collections and changed his economic forecasts based on shifting national models. Mr. Michael began pressing for an immediate hiring freeze and a study of far more drastic cuts, including at least 15,000 layoffs, to help close an expected gap of at least $1.4 billion in the coming fiscal year.
The administration had been talking of a gap that size for weeks, and had even suggested layoffs might be a possibility. But it had never sought to hammer home to the public just how real a possibility such actions would be, especially since the current budget was balanced with more than $800 million in higher taxes and hundreds of millions of dollars in service cuts.
 
Keeping the Budget in Order
Mr. Michael said his recommendation was a way of giving life to the gloomy predictions he had been making for months.
Another senior aide said: ''We didn't want to hide the numbers. We wanted to say we were starting a drill to keep the budget in order, as much to give ourselves a little breathing room in the rush of events as to absorb new information.''
But Mr. Dinkins took the unusual step of simply making Mr. Michael's recommendations public, without endorsing them himself, on the same day that Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman warned of even bigger budget gaps and called for a ''summit'' of city officials and business and labor leaders to discuss the problem.
That left many wondering whether the Mayor was simply trying to ward off such a spectacle and waving a club over the heads of unions in a concession to fiscal monitors who had criticized him for the teachers' pact, which would be financed through a mix of previously budgeted money and other uncertain sources.
 
A Call, and Loud Words
Mr. Dinkins said that was not his style, and fiscal experts said the Mayor's estimates seemed realistic. But his handling of the situation rankled union leaders.
Mr. Feinstein and other leaders had reacted with fury to news of the layoff proposal, which many said they first heard of from reporters seeking their comments.
When the Mayor made his apologetic phone call to Mr. Feinstein's office, a Teamsters' aide who was in a hallway at union headquarters at the time said the response was loud, though the exact words were inaudible.
 
Unions in a Quandary
Now the unions find themselves grappling with the quandary of trying to match the teachers' raise while also avoiding layoffs. The greater the raises, the greater the risk of layoffs.
''It makes the bargaining positions of all the unions much weaker,'' said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
Alan J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, would not say whether pressure had been put on the Dinkins administration since the teachers agreement and police hiring plan were announced. He said that the announcement of a job freeze and possible layoffs was ''terrific'' but that he was waiting to see the details.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
The Tiny Compromise

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
The peril is economic. Awareness of it is what's behind the whining about Japan's supremacy and what makes best sellers of pamphleteers' warnings that it's all up with the U.S.A. It fuels the incessant doomsday talk on radio call-in shows: American no longer No. 1. Could be No. 23 unless we wake up fast.
 What to do? The obvious anser: Get out of debt. You usually get out of debt5 by cutting costs, increasing income and using the savings and added revenue to pay the bill collector. Government, however, can't do it this way anymore. 
 Why? Because of the politicians' terror of raising the taxes needed to pay for all the things taxpayers demand. In the 1980's taxes became political death.
 The Republic, which was born crying "No taxation without representation," began demanding "Representation without taxation." Politicians who opposed the latest increase in benefits for Social Security recipients were doomed just as surely as politicians who proposed new taxes to pay for it.
 No surprisingly, politicians discovered the wisdom of giving the voters more while fighting all efforts to pay for the new boons with real money.
 Needing a philosophy to justify themselves, the politicians were blessed by the arrival of the Reagan economists bearing a theory worthy of the Wizard of Oz. The way to fill the Treasury to overflowing, they said, was not by raising taxes, but - get this, folks! - by cutting taxes.
 This would free so much money for the private market that business would boom and tax collections rise despite lowered rates. Here was a politician's dream of Paradise. Despite the much-ballyhooed impending calamity, politicians still cannot give it up.
 Nor can you blame them. Though many may now privately concede that the theory didn't work, the public still seems to detest returning to the old idea that when governments distribute boons somebody has to pay.
 Chief among those determined to keep shunning reality has been President Bush. In 1980 before becoming Mr. Reagan's Vice President, he described the Reagan argument that tax cuts would enrich the nation as "Voodoo economics."
 Eight years later, though, Americans were so wedded to the get-rich-by-cutting-taxes theory that he offered them his "Read my lips" pledge of "no new taxes" as assurance that he would never abandon the tried and beloved old policy simply because it had failed.
 Earlier this year, finally confronting the potential calamity, he agreed to consider tax increases. The deal reached last weekend - the tiny compromise, if you like - was the result. It was denounced by some Democrats as a soak-the-poor budget, but this overstates the case.
 Weighed against the potential national calamity - loss of Number Oneness, for Heaven's sake! - the taxes involved were too slight to constitute even a good soaking. it was only a dunking. Sure, the poorer classes would continue to bear the heaviest tax burden, as in the Reagan years, but it was more accurate to call it a dunk-the-poor budget.
 You might have expected conservative Republicans to congratulate the President for his cunning in persuading the Democrats to join him in this assuault on their natural consitutency. But no.
 The ineffable Newt Gingrich, House Republican whip and the very embodiement of "Representation With No Taxation Whatsoever," promptly said he and all who still cherished the old Reagan way thought the President had gone too far. And so they voted against him.
 Perhaps the conservative defection will have long-term benefit for the country. Suppose it persuades Mr. Bush that nothing he does will ever win him conservative support. Gosh, it might persuade him to give the country a break by dropping the conservative Dan Quayle from the ticket in 1992.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS;
Historic Bookends to Texas Blues

BYLINE: By ROBERT PALMER: Robert Palmer, former chief rock critic for The New York Times, is writing a book on the roots of rock-and-roll.

 BODY:
It is tempting to think of Mosaic's new boxed set, ''The Complete Recordings of T-Bone Walker 1940-1954,'' and the Vaughan brothers' ''Family Style,'' just released on Epic, as historic bookends to the modern Texas blues tradition.
There was blues in Texas long before T-Bone Walker's first recorded electric guitar solo in 1940, and blues will undoubtedly live on there. Indeed, since the idiom's ultimate source has never been pinpointed, some authorities have taken literally the old blues line ''The blues came from Texas, loping like a mule,'' and asserted that blues must have originated there.
But the image of Texas blues as a distinctive regional form has long centered on the hornlike, single-string lead-guitar style pioneered by T-Bone Walker. And before his death in a helicopter crash in August, Stevie Ray Vaughan - who shares billing on ''Family Style'' with his older brother, the guitarist Jimmie Vaughan - had made Texas-rooted, virtuoso blues guitar-playing, revved and leavened with rock, an important part of the commercial pop-music scene for the first time since the heyday of white blues in the late 60's. A further connection links Walker and the Vaughan brothers: the three guitarists grew up in the same Dallas neighborhood, Oak Cliff.
Mosaic - long known for its high-quality, limited-edition boxed sets of hard-to-find jazz recordings - is making its first foray into blues with the T-Bone Walker set (MR9-130 for LP's, MD6-130 for CD's; available from Mosaic Records, 35 Melrose Place, Stamford, Conn. 06902). But it isn't a very big jump, given the jazz milieu Walker worked in during much of the 30's and 40's.
As a child, Walker often led Blind Lemon Jefferson, the first Texas blues recordings star, from bar to bar in Dallas, watching while he played and absorbing his style. In fact, a young Walker made his recording debut in 1929 as Oak Cliff T-Bone, which is not included in the Mosaic box. But on that record he was featured mainly as a vocalist, as he was when he recorded again, in 1940, as a member of the Les Hite Band in Los Angeles, where the Mosaic set begins.
In the meantime, Walker had become friendly with the then-unknown guitarist Charlie Christian, who later set the jazz world on its ear and became the first electric guitarist in modern jazz. One can only imagine what Walker and Christian sounded like playing together on Dallas street corners in the 30's. But while Walker's dry-toned, spidery guitar lines owe much to the style of Blind Lemon Jefferson, his friendship with Christian, and the years he spent playing in jazz and dance bands before becoming a solo star, also had an impact.
Walker often introduced his slow blues with jazzy chord voicings, and the occasional pop ballad performances on the Mosaic collection demonstrate that he was a well-rounded musician. But blues was his forte and first love, and he stayed with it. Virtually every modern blues guitarist, from B. B. King to Stevie Ray Vaughan, has named Walker a prime inspiration. Walker's influence was so inescapable that blues guitarists from the Mississippi Delta to Chicago and from New York to Los Angeles had adapted elements of his approach by the early 50's.
Mosaic's boxed set covers the years of Walker's greatest fame within the black community and catches him at the height of his powers. It is also, incidentally, a fascinating history of changing rhythms in black popular music. On some of the earlier selections, his sense of timing seems at odds with the swing-jazz orientation of the backing musicians, especially when he uses some of the hammering, repeated one-note riff figures most rock-and-roll fans associate with Chuck Berry, another Walker disciple.
Once he signed a contract with Imperial Records in 1950 and was able to use bands more in his groove, almost everything he recorded had an easy, relaxed rhythmic flow, from aching, slow blues to the most up-tempo boogies. One also hears the gradual development of the shuffle rhythm, long a mainstay of Texas blues and possibly a result of rhythm sections trying to reproduce, in an ensemble setting, some of the propulsive left-hand riffs introduced by boogie-woogie pianists. For a mammoth one-artist collection, the T-Bone Walker box is remarkably consistent and engaging, whether listened to intensively or piecemeal.
One might guess from the pervasiveness of the Walker influence that the Vaughan brothers would have grown up playing similarly, but this was not the case. Jimmie Vaughan, a founding member of the Fabulous Thunderbirds until he left the band last June, has never concentrated on developing flash or virtuosity. He is, rather, one of the great band guitarists, able to suggest lead and rhythm figures while anchoring the swing of the group and filling out its sound. This style certainly has its Texas precedence - Frankie Lee Sims comes to mind. When Jimmie Vaughan is soloing, he tends to play tricky, highly syncopated lead melodies spiced liberally with hard-riffing chordal figures; even out front, he plays like a member of the band, not like a hot-shot soloist.
His younger brother was the very epitome of the hot-shot soloist, so much so that most of the criticism he received during his lifetime concerned his abundance of bravura and flash. But during the last few years, Stevie Ray Vaughan had matured considerably. It is still difficult to mistake one Vaughan for the other on ''Family Style'' (Epic 46225; all three formats), but both brothers play with an effectively taut economy throughout, and their interaction as rhythm players is a special treat.
The solo honors, of course, go largely to Stevie Ray Vaughan, who turns in two of his most spectacular solos on record on the songs ''Brothers'' and ''Long Way From Home.'' But this album also finds the brothers expanding from their blues roots into more varied musical terrain, with touches of Cajun, soul, 50's rock-and-roll, modern funk and even gospel music.
At the time of his death, Stevie Ray Vaughan seemed to have been moving toward a more eclectic style of playing, incorporating more of his brother's incisive rhythm. ''Family Style,'' the last studio album he recorded, serves as a worthy testament to his talent by placing it in a specifically Texas-rooted, family context. In the meantime, Jimmie Vaughan plays on, as exciting, unpredictable and underrated as ever. And Mosaic's T-Bone Walker set is now available to bring the sound of the Vaughans' musical godfather to a new generation of listeners.

GRAPHIC: Photos: T-Bone Walker circa 1943 - blues pioneer (Frank Driggs Collection); Stevie Ray Vaughan - Texas-rooted, virtuoso playing on his last studio album (Ebet Roberts)

HEADLINE: Former Klan Figure Loses to Incumbent In Louisiana Voting

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Incumbent Senator J. Bennett Johnston Jr. defeated State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, tonight in a race that had become a troubling window on race relations in the United States.
With 70 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Johnston had 53 percent of the vote as against 44 percent for Mr. Duke. Edward Renwick, director of the Institute of Politics at Loyola University, said his polling of selected precincts around the state indicated Mr. Bennett would win the race.
Mr. Duke, a Republican whose appeal to white resentment dominated the race, was never given much chance of winning. But his strong showing in incomplete returns indicated that despite condemnation by national figures in the Republican Party there was a strong groundswell of support for his racially charged agenda. 
 
Mood Against Incumbents
Some analysts said he was also benefiting from a mood against incumbents which has shown itself in elections from Massachusetts to Oklahoma.
Despite Mr. Johnston's apparent victory, opponents of Mr. Duke said they had mixed feelings because of his relatively strong showing. It was thought a vote total below 30 percent would have indicated Mr. Duke had failed to reach out beyond his core constituency. Few analysts expected him to get more than 40 percent of the vote.
Mr. Renwick said if Mr. Duke's performance remained above 40 percent it would indicate that he was receiving around 60 percent of the votes of whites in the state.
''This has been a battleground for the educated white middle class vote and Duke has lost it,'' said Lance Hill, executive director of the Louisiana Coalition, a group opposing Mr. Duke .
But, he added: ''I'd like to see a wider margin.''
 
An Unusual Campaign
The election culminated a race, unusual even by the baroque standards of Louisiana politics, in which a powerful three-term Democratic incumbent and the official nominee of the Republican Party were completely overshadowed by a one-term state representative who has yet to sponsor a single bill passed by the Louisiana Legislature.
Republicans considered Mr. Johnston vulnerable a year ago because of Lousiana's slumping economy and what they considered an overly liberal voting record.
But the race was turned on its head when Mr. Duke, who first ran as a Republican a year ago in the state legislative election, decided to stay in the race after he failed to gain the Republican nomination.
Under Louisiana's election laws, candidates run in a nonpartisan primary. If one candidate wins 50 percent of the vote or more, he is elected. If no one wins 50 percent, the top two finishers meet in a runoff, regardless of their party affiliation.
 
Nominee Withdraws
Mr. Duke's racially charged appeals to white resentment over affirmative action policies, welfare, and other issues almost from the start shoved aside the official Republican nominee, State Senator Ben Bagert of New Orleans. Mr. Bagert spent the race struggling to reach double digits in the polls.
By early summer it was apparent the only question in the race was whether Mr. Johnston could win enough votes to avoid an embarrassing runoff against Mr. Duke.
Mr. Bagert, to the relief of the national Republican Party, announced Thursday that he would drop out of the race, making it essentially a two-man contest. It was expected that the move would insure a primary victory by Mr. Johnston, avoiding a runoff that could hurt Republican candidates nationally and help Mr. Duke by giving him a national audience for his far-right agenda.
Votes cast for Mr. Bagert today did not count. Two other minor candidates were also on the ballot.
Mr. Duke tried to turn Mr. Bagert's withdrawal to his advantage in the race's final days, calling it a ''back-room deal.''
''It's obvious that there's been a deal in the works for a long time,'' Mr. Duke said Friday. ''The fact that one of the major candidates withdrew just a couple of days before the election is unprecedented in Louisiana politics.''
He and his supporters hoped that the national mood of frustration with the political status quo would fuel a backlash that would make the withdrawal work for him.
But Mr. Johnston, campaigning Friday, said he was confident the withdrawal would work for him.
''The message that will go out to the nation is there is no place for racism, no place for Nazism in this state,'' he said.
Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, joined the growing list of prominent Republicans who have taken the extraordinary step of working to insure the victory of the Democratic incumbent. Earlier eight Republican senators had called for Mr. Johnston's re-election.
''I was for Bagert, but now I'm asking my conservative friends to vote for Bennett Johnston,'' Mr. Kemp said. ''There's no place in the Republican Party for someone who has practiced and practices racism, bigotry and anti-Semitism.''
For Mr. Johnston, Louisiana's senior Senator, the race was in keeping with an electoral career that has been marked by a fair amount of good fortune.
In 1972, he narrowly lost the gubernatorial primary to Edwin Edwards. A few months later, he was the only major politician to file against United States Senator Allen Ellender, who had held the seat since 1936 and was a political protege of Huey Long.
Mr. Ellender died after the filing date but before the primary. In 1978, Mr. Johnston was opposed by an arch-conservative state legislator, Woody Jenkins, who got 40 percent of the vote in a poorly financed effort. In 1984, despite the landslide for President Ronald Reagan that hurt other Democrats, Mr. Johnston drew only token opposition.
In running against Mr. Duke, this time he drew a candidate who attracted enormous attention, but was never given much of a chance of winning the election.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator J. Bennett Johnston, accompanied by his daughter Mary Johnson Catallo, arriving at his election night headquarters. Mr. Bennett won a fourth term, beating State Representative David Duke. (Associated Press) (pg. 38)

HEADLINE: Seeking Cash and Silent Victims, New York Thieves Prey on Asians

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
As Min Su Yoo, a 42-year-old waiter who works in Chinatown, waited for the No. 6 train at the Canal Street subway station last month, two men dressed in jeans and dark jackets approached him, pulled out knives, and demanded his wallet.
Fearing for his life, Mr. Yoo, who immigrated to the United States from Seoul, South Korea, five years ago, handed over the wallet, which he said contained a week's pay - $300. Mr. Yoo said he never reported the crime because ''the police never catch the thieves.''
Hundreds of Asian New Yorkers like Mr. Yoo have been robbed in the subway system in the last year in what law-enforcement officials describe as a growing and disturbing trend of subway attacks against people of Japanese, Chinese, Korean, Filipino and Vietnamese descent.
 
Tourists Also Victimized
''For the experienced criminal, Asians have become easy pickings,'' said Paul Yee, the president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, a community organization based in Chinatown. ''The muggers know that most Asians do not use credit cards and usually have cash in their pockets and jewelry around their necks. They also know they will not report crimes.'' 
Another reason that Asians are often the victims of crime is that they are perceived as less likely to resist, Mr. Yee and the police said.
For those same reasons, tourists from Asian countries have become frequent targets of taxi and limousine scams at New York City airports in which drivers grossly overcharge for trips to Manhattan.
Law-enforcement officials in other major cities with large East Asian populations, like Los Angeles and San Francisco, said they had not experienced a similar increase in robberies and schemes aimed at Asians.
But in New York, the number of subway robberies and airport transit schemes involving Asian victims is rising so quickly that the transit police and Taxi and Limousine Commission are placing Asian decoys in the subways and airport terminals to catch thieves.
The total number of subway robberies increased 56 percent to 8,269 in 1989, up from 5,290 in 1987. But the number of reported subway robberies against Asians nearly tripled in the same period, to 905 in 1989 from 304 in 1987, according to the transit police.
The actual number of robberies of Asians may be more than three times the reported figures, Mr. Yee said, because for a variety of reasons many Asians are reluctant to report crimes to the police.
Some, especially recent immigrants, do not trust the police because they associate them with often hostile police and military forces in their homelands, Mr. Yee and other Asian community leaders said. In addition, many Asians, like many other New Yorkers, feel that reporting a robbery is a waste of time since they think it is unlikely that the police will recover their property.
Often Asian victims do not speak English, Mr. Yee said, and it is difficult to find a police interpreter who speaks their language or dialect.
 
Trend Seen Continuing
Because of the reluctance of Asian victims like Mr. Yoo to report crimes, the police and community leaders may learn about them only through word of mouth, if at all. Still, transit police officials said they expected the number of subway robberies involving Asians to continue to increase this year.
Since the Asian decoy unit of the transit police went into operation on Aug. 10, officers have arrested 20 suspects, 18 of whom have been indicted. The decoy unit, which consists of men and women who pose as Asian tourists, businesspeople and shoppers, patrols mainly in Chinatown, midtown Manhattan, and Flushing, Queens.
''We want to put fear in the minds of criminals that the next Asian person they rob in the subways might be a cop,'' said Lieut. Jack Maple, commanding officer of the transit police's central robbery division.
Decoy officers work in groups of three or four, with one officer as a potential robbery target while the others serve as backup, Lieutenant Maple said. He declined to say how many officers were assigned to the unit, but inspectors from the Taxi and Limousine Commission estimated that there were about 20.
 
Judging Body Language
''The decoy more or less presents himself or herself as a target,'' he said. ''If we see some guys standing on the staircase displaying body language that is suspicious, we would pass a decoy by them.''
The transit police force is also conducting an outreach program in the Asian community to encourage victims of crimes to report them. Lieutenant Maple said that the force holds seminars in the community to distribute information on subway safety measures. He credits the outreach program for a rise in the number of subway crimes reported by Asians in recent years.
Community leaders said that while they feel the subway and airport decoy programs will deter attacks against Asians, more police officers, better lighting and safer subway stations are also needed. ''The best deterrent to crime is the visible police presence,'' said Mr. Yee of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association.
He said the Benevolent Association is conducting an education campaign in Chinatown to encourage residents not to wear expensive jewelry or carry large amounts of cash in the subways. ''Asians like to pay by cash, but we are trying to convince people in our community that there are better, safer ways to complete transactions,'' Mr. Yee said. $75 Cab Fares For the last year, the Taxi and Limousine Commission has stationed decoys, many of whom are Asian, at the terminals at Kennedy International Airport to catch taxi and limousine drivers who either overcharge patrons or illegally solicit fares. The decoys dress like tourists or foreign businesspeople, and many carry several pieces of luggage, fishing rods and cameras.
Thomas Ng, a Chinese inspector who has posed as a foreign businessman at Kennedy Airport, said that in a single day five separate taxi drivers told him that it would cost at least $75 to take him into Manhattan.
Shoon Mack, another inspector who is Chinese, said: ''Asians have a reputation for being rich and spending money - that's why they go after us. In the midst of the crowd and confusion, many Asian tourists just pay the exorbitant rate so they can get on with their vacation.''
Typically, a scheme artist goes to the baggage claim area of an Asian airline and gets a passenger's name from luggage. He then holds up a large sign on which he has written the passenger's name, and convinces the passenger that a friend or hotel has sent the car to take the passenger to the hotel.
An unsuspecting tourist, who may be accustomed in other countries to being met by a driver from a hotel, sees the sign with his or her name on it falls for the ploy, the inspectors said.
Once the tourist is in the car, the scheme artist charges anywhere from $100 to $300 for a ride that would normally cost about $30. Many Asian tourists agree to pay because they often do not know the exchange rate or they are used to paying several hundred dollars for airport transportation in their own countries, the inspectors said. If a tourist refuses to pay the fee, the scheme artists sometime threaten to hurt him or to take his luggage.
Some Asian community leaders see the increase in crime against Asians -particularly against immigrant workers - as part of a rising tide of anti-Asian sentiment in the United States.
''We are in a bad period economically, and Asians are often scapegoated as people who have no right to be here and work here,'' said Monona Yin, a spokeswoman for the Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence, a local group formed to increase awareness of the issue. Such hostility, she said, is even reflected in Washington, where lawmakers engage in ''Japan-bashing'' over the issue of fair trade practices.
''But the truth is,'' Ms. Yin said, ''most Asians in New York are not wealthy. They work in garment factories and restaurants in jobs that other people don't want.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''Asians have become easy pickings,'' said Paul Yee, president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association. He waited at the Canal Street subway station, the site of a recent robbery, one incident in what law-enforcement officials describe as a growing and disturbing trend of attacks against Asians. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times) (pg. 42)

HEADLINE: Irish-Americans Praise New Immigration Bill

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
In the heavily Irish community of Woodside, Queens, they are already celebrating new immigration legislation approved in the House last week, as if it were raining green cards.
''We're euphoric at this juncture,'' said Claire O'Gara Grimes, publisher of The Irish Echo, who said she hoped some 30,000 illegal Irish immigrants would receive the much coveted permanent residence cards under the bill, known as the Family Unity and Employment Opportunity Immigration Act of 1990. The bill, whose chief sponsor was Representative Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of Connecticut, seeks to open the nation's doors to three-quarters of a million foreigners a year - particularly family members of American citizens or permanent residents. The bill raises the ceiling to 775,000 aliens a year from 540,000 and also makes it easier for workers with technical and managerial skills to immigrate. 
For the Irish, the most important part of the Morrison bill is the section that gives virtual amnesty to all the illegal Irish immigrants in the country, and to aliens from some other Western European countries.
Opponents of the bill, headed by the lobbying group, the Federation of American Immigration Reform, complain that it significantly increases the number of legal immigrants.
''The reform will be a shot in the arm for New York, whose economy has always thrived on immigration,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who serves on the House immigration subcommittee.
 
Support From Broad Coalition
In New York City the bill has been supported by a broad coalition from labor, business, church and civil rights and neighborhood organizations.
The Irish Immigration Reform Movement, an organization based in Woodside that has led support for the bill, is optimistic but cautions that there are still ''two more hurdles'': a House-Senate conference later this week to resolve differences between the House bill and a similar one adopted by the Senate last year and a possible Presidential veto.
Major corporations and hospitals have shown considerable interest in the immigration bill. Eileen Rowland, the assistant director for nursing recruitment at Beth Israel Medical Center, expressed approval of ''the spirit and intent of the legislation that will enable us to access foreign health providers from abroad.'' She said that New York City had a shortage of registered nurses and other medical personnel.
Some companies applaud changes in the law because it would be easier to recruit aliens who are in the United States to get advanced degrees.
Other New Yorkers appear less enthusiastic and have expressed reservations.
Arthur Helton, who heads the political asylum project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, described the bill as ''good news for an immigrant city like New York,'' but he said that it had ''an element of bias'' in favor of northern Europeans. Mr. Helton, however, applauded a provision granting safe haven to political refugees, specifically those from El Salvador, Kuwait, Liberia and Lebanon.
Some community and ethnic organizations, critical of the ''regional diversity'' provision favoring western Europe, have been won over to the bill because of its family provisions. ''We support the family side of the bill, which is beneficial to Asians,'' said Stanley Mark, a leader of the Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund.
''We think the bill is positive overall because it preserves and improves the family-based immigration system,'' said Marla Kamiya, a staff member at the Center for Immigrants Rights. The Manhattan advocacy group recently voiced support for the Morrison bill. But it objected to special visas for the 36 mainly European countries. Those countries, it said, were ''adversely affected'' by the 1965 Immigration Act. But before the 1965 Act those countries had historically been favored.
Although the City Bar Association in New York has not taken a stand on the change, Allan Wernick, chairman of the association's Committee on Immigration and Nationality Law said the legislation reflected ''an important shift in public understanding.''

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Nominee for California Governor Steers Careful Course to the Center

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTECITO, Calif., Oct. 6

 BODY:
The setting could not have been further from the urban scourge of crack babies. But it was here in this wealthy coastal enclave that Pete Wilson, United States Senator and Republican candidate for governor of California, brought his oft-repeated message of compassion.
He and his wife, Gayle, had seen ''children so tiny you can hold them in the palm of one hand, in the agony of withdrawal from drugs,'' he told the nearly all white, mostly elderly or middle-aged,members of the Channel City Club the other day in this community of huge Spanish-style homes, lush gardens of bougainvillea and swimming pools. ''That is a very sad sight.''
Those comments were followed by a call for 15 years extra prison time for the ''terrible scum'' who sell drugs, a line that got a round of applause for the 57-year-old lawyer, politician and Yalie standing before the microphone in his natural-shoulder gray suit (buttoned), pale blue shirt and red-striped tie. 
This is the man the national Republican Party is counting on to capture the biggest electoral prize of 1990, the leadership of the most populous state. Mr. Wilson is a politician who defies easy ideological definition, who has steered a skillful course over the political shoals, left and right, and emerged in the center as the quintessential California Republican: liberal on issues like the environment and social matters, conservative on crime and economic policy.
 
Polls Are Close
Some call him bland and lacking in charisma, some say he is a chameleon, an opportunist ready to change color with the political seasons. But nobody underestimates Mr. Wilson, least of all his Democratic opponent, Dianne Feinstein, former Mayor of San Francisco, who offers herself as the ''agent of change'' against the white men in charge, Senator Wilson and the other ''suits,'' as she calls them.
As the campaign enters its final month, nearly all the polls suggest the two have dueled to a draw. A turning point could be a televised debate, the first of two, scheduled for Sunday night.
In a way, the two are mirror images, both hewing close to the political center, but trying to keep enough distance from each other so voters can tell the difference. Ms. Feinstein repels from the Democratic left, offering a message of toughness on crime. Mr. Wilson, also a former big-city Mayor, of San Diego, steers left of the Republican mainstream, frequently clashing with Republican Administrations on matters like oil drilling off the California coast and abortion. While distinct differences have emerged recently, both support abortion rights, both favor the dealth penalty and both pose themselves as advocates for the environment and foes of offshore oil drilling.
''I am very much what California Republicans are,'' Mr. Wilson said in an interview. ''They are fiscally conservative - the tax revolt is far from dead - and very much concerned about crime and drugs. They are also pro-choice, pro-environment, strong on national defense and big for education and the death penalty. I am a pro-business environmentalist who is not afraid to tell the Sierra Club when they are wrong.''
 
Somewhat Indistinct
But after 23 years in California politics, the last eight as Senator, Pete Wilson remains a somewhat indistinct face to voters.
Before Ms. Feinstein decided to run for governor, her strategists reportedly showed voters pictures of Mr. Wilson, Lieut. Gov. Leo T. McCarthy and Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp, whom she defeated in the Democratic primary. They found that few could identify any of the three men.
Senator Wilson and his close aides are acutely aware and resentful that Ms. Feinstein has captured the national publicity on the race. ''She's telegenic,'' conceded Mr. Wilson, but added that he felt that her ''bonanza'' of national media attention would not translate into votes in California.
Political insiders say Mr. Wilson has the clear advantage when it comes to organization. His is a loyal, battle-tested campaign staff, far smoother than Ms. Feinstein's. And he has raised far more money than Ms. Feinstein, a factor that could be critical in the final media blitz, although a recent ruling by a Federal judge invalidating California's limit on individual campaign contributions might narrow that gap.
 
A Subdued Style
His style could not be more different from the mercurial, sometimes authoritarian Ms. Feinstein. Calm, pragmatic, almost serene on the campaign trail, Mr. Wilson is dogged, orderly, organized. ''He spends a lot of time being prepared,'' said one of his closest aides, Otto Bos. ''He does not like to go in without the facts. We works late at night. He delegates authority well.''
His wit is quick, dry and often self-deprecating. He has said his campaign for the Republican nomination for governor in 1978, which failed, ''became a haven for those who despise crowds.''
He based his first campaign for mayor in 1971 on a platform of controlling growth, and he succeeded in ''striking a maintainable balance between the forces of no growth and the business community,'' said Samuel Popkin, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego.
But Mr. Wilson tempered his moderate instincts during the Reagan era and became more conservative, Mr. Popkin said, and since has ''shown a real hestitancy to get out front.''
But Mr. Wilson promises to be an active governor, to lead the state out of deepening problems with education, pollution and crime. ''I do not intend to come back to wear the governership as a boutonniere,'' he said recently. ''Nor do I intend to come back to be a political survivor. Pardon me, but I intend to come back to make waves.''
 
Drugs Are a Top Priority
A top priority is the drug problem, particularly crack addiction, not an issue near and dear to the Republican rank and file. He has proposed establishing a state program to provide $1,750 worth of prenatal care to pregnant women and has called for a program to rehabilitate pregnant addicts, compelling those who refuse to enter such treatment to give up their children, although he has been vague about how to pay for this. Mr. Bos says Mr. Wilson and his wife have been moved to tears by visits with crack babies.
Lest he seem too liberal, he combines this with calls for tougher sentencing for violent crime and drug dealing and he attacks the ''arrogant liberals'' in the State Assembly who have blocked such laws.
He also has an education platform, which calls for merit pay for superior teachers, a statewide program to provide adult mentors for poor children and ''alternative credentialing'' to allow people without conventional teaching backgrounds to teach.
He differs with Ms. Feinstein on a number of issues.
For example, to cover what is expected to be a large shortfall in the new governor's first budget, she has called for increasing state income taxes for individuals making more than $100,000 a year and couples earning more than $200,000. Senator Wilson has flatly rejected any income tax increase.
 
Difference on Environment
On the environment, Ms. Feinstein has endorsed a sweeping voter-initiated referendum to ban many pesiticides and set up a new state environmental ''advocate'' with special legal powers independent of the Governor. Mr. Wilson calls for its defeat, saying he would prefer to consolidate environmental authority into a ''California E.P.A.,'' headed by a Cabinet secretary who reports to the Governor.
The candidates also differ on how best to break the perennial logjam on drawing up the state budget.
In all this, Senator Wilson is expected to make inroads into traditional areas of Democratic strength. He has won wide admiration among Jews for his staunch support for Israel and has earned credits in traditionally liberal Hollywood circles for backing the motion picture industry in its regulatory battle with the television networks over syndication of reruns.
But even top Republicans acknowledge that Mr. Wilson is facing a tough fight. ''The problem Wilson has is getting people to know what he stands for,'' said Steven A. Merksamer, former campaign manager and chief of staff to the incumbent Governor, George Deukmejian, a Republican. ''With Ronald Reagan, you knew where he was. With Deukmejian, you know where he stands. But with Pete Wilson, there have not been such bold colors. He is less of a lightning rod.''
He continued: ''Feinstein is a formidable candidate. This election is not going to turn on abortion, taxation, death penalty or any other myriad issues, but on leadership - on who the voters perceive as having that amorphous quality to reach out to the hopes and aspirations of the average Californian.''

HEADLINE: The Uproar at Dartmouth: How a Conservative Weekly Inflamed a Campus

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 5

 BODY:
For a decade, many students and professors at Dartmouth College have watched with quiet dismay - and occasional anger - as a handful of writers at a conservative weekly shaped a public perception of Dartmouth as hostile toward blacks, women and Jews.
But Dartmouth erupted in fury this week after The Dartmouth Review, the off-campus weekly, carried an anti-Semitic quotation from Hitler on its masthead on the first day of Yom Kippur, the most solemn Jewish holy day.
''Our decadelong silence is over,'' Brian V. Ellner, a junior from New York who is president of the student government, told a rally of 2,500 people, more than half the student body, at a rally on Thursday. ''We have come together at last to tell the world that The Review does not represent Dartmouth.'' The crowd roared its approval. 
 
'A Week of Infamy'
And James O. Freedman, the college's president, told the rally, ''This has been a week of infamy for the Dartmouth community.'' In an interview later, he said the university's reputation and recruitment efforts were being jeopardized by The Review.
''I am very angry,'' he said. ''What I feel most of all is a deep sense of embarrassment. When I am off campus, The Review is all people want to talk about, and they don't realize The Review doesn't have any real influence here at Dartmouth itself.''
But Mr. Freedman acknowledged that the outside world's perception of Dartmouth is now hurting the school, making it harder to recruit faculty members and black students. ''I also think this latest incident will have a damaging effect on Jewish admissions,'' he said.
The situation has been particularly painful for Mr. Freedman, who is Jewish and who is widely credited here with making a series of changes to raise Dartmouth's academic stature.
Supporters of The Review, which is financed by prominent conservatives and foundations, have responded angrily to the attacks from Mr. Freedman and others. At first the editors apologized for the quotation from Hitler, which included the sentence ''By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' They said they did not know how it had been inserted, and they promised to track down whoever was responsible.
But at a combative news conference on Thursday, Dinesh D'Souza, a trustee of The Review who is a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, called the insertion ''a criminal act of sabotage'' and added, ''I do not rule out that it was done by a mole, a saboteur, someone who did not have The Review's best interest at heart.''
Mr. D'Souza, a former Review editor who was a policy adviser in the Reagan White House, charged that the incident was ''being cynically manipulated by the college leadership in order to ruin the lives of many innocent students.''
In part, the current furor represents a culmination of anger at a long series of slurs or attacks by The Review since its founding in 1980. The paper was started to combat what it has called ''the twisted idealism of the 60's, a bastard brand of liberalism'' that supports co-education, affirmative action, and a weakening of Dartmouth's old image as a hard-drinking, all-male school.
In its first year, The Review sponsored a free lobster-and-champagne feast to coincide with a campus fast for the world's hungry. In 1981 it published a list of members of the school's Gay Students Association. Then in 1982, it ran a column in ''black English'' suggesting that black students were illiterate. As an editor, Mr. D'Souza once wrote, ''The question is not whether women should be educated at Dartmouth, but whether they should be educated at all.''
For years The Review campaigned against William S. Cole, a black professor of music who has since left Dartmouth, saying he ''looks like a used Brillo pad,'' and sending students to harass him in class. ''A goodly number of Cole's students are black,'' The Review wrote in one article. ''Some allege that these are affirmative action kids looking for a course they can handle.''
Now many at Dartmouth say such incidents have tarnished the reputation of the whole campus. Dr. Freedman said that last spring, a survey of high school seniors who were accepted at Dartmouth and three other prestigious New England colleges showed that Dartmouth was overwhelmingly viewed as the most conservative and the least intellectual.
Allen Drexel, a senior from San Antonio, said, ''You constantly hear stories about teachers telling their minority students not to come here.''
The number of blacks in the freshman class is 51, or 4.7 percent, down from 91 two years ago.
 
Raising Campus's Stature
The Review, which is distributed to students free, has an advisory board that includes the columnist Patrick Buchanan and the economist George Gilder. Its masthead offers ''special thanks'' to William F. Buckley Jr., who stepped down tonight as the longtime editor of National Review. The Review's current editor-in-chief, Kevin C. Pritchett, has worked for three summers for the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal.
Lost in the debate over The Review, many here say, are Mr. Freedman's measures to raise Dartmouth's academic stature. It still loses five out of the six students it accepts if they are also accepted at Harvard, Yale, Princeton or Stanford. So Mr. Freedman, who became president in 1987, has set up a special program to have juniors and seniors work more closely with professors, and has succeeded in hiring a number of well-regarded scholars and deans.
The Review has derided these actions, saying Mr. Freedman is trying to ''Harvardize'' Dartmouth.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 15, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 7 about The Dartmouth Review misattributed the quotation "The question is not whether women should be educated at Dartmouth but whether theyshould be educated at all." Dinesh D'Souza, a former editor of The Review, was not the author; the remark first appeared in The Review in 1980 as part of a compilation of provocative quotations. It was attributed then to Keeney Jones, who was not further identified. Mr. D'Souza referred to the comment in a 1986 Review article as an example of the paper's "outrageous streak" in its efforts to stir debate on campus. The misattribution was called to The Times's attention by Mr. D'Souza in mid-October; publication of this correction was delayed pending research by The Times.

HEADLINE: Mosquitoes' Threat Disrupting Florida Nightlife

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VERO BEACH, Fla., Oct. 6

 BODY:
Phyllis Capece, a nurse, forfeited four hours' pay and showed up at the game with her beeper. Her husband, Pete, left his athletic store, Active Feet, three hours early. Matt Parris, a college freshman in Orlando, cut his English class and made the 90-mile drive home in record time. Mary Ann Driskell was stuck: she had to babysit.
Friday nights in this citrus town on Florida's east coast revolve around the Vero Beach High School football game. This Friday, however, the fans had to rearrange their lives to get to the stadium in the afternoon. The reason: an outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis that began about a month ago, carried by mosquitoes that prefer to bite at night. On the advice of health officials, kickoff time was moved from the traditional 7:30 P.M. to 4:01. 
Although only 26 instances of the disease have been reported throughout central and south Florida, it can be fatal, so a multitude of nighttime acivities have been scrapped by officials, merchants and families. At Walt Disney World, evening water pageants have been canceled, and pools are closing before sundown. The Treasure Coast Boy Scouts have canceled their October Jamboree.
Vero Beach is in Indian River County, which has 11 of the state's 26 cases. No deaths have been reported. 'How Dare You Change?'
There are some who apparently feel that it should take more than mosquitoes, however deadly, to disrupt Vero Beach's cherished Friday night tradition. Rosemarie Livings is an assistant principal at the high school, and the wife of the coach, Billy Livings. ''People were calling up and saying, 'How dare you change the game?' '' she said Friday afternoon, as she cheered the Indians on from her usual spot, under the press box. ''They were acting like their lives were ruined. What can you do? You just go on.''
St. Louis encephalitis is one of about 10 types of the disease transmitted by mosquitoes. It is caused by a virus that is injected into the blood when the insect bites. Symptoms may include high fever, headache, nausea and dizziness, and the elderly are likely to be most seriously affected. In general, about 15 percent of victims die.
Neither a treatment nor a preventive, such as a vaccine, exists for encephalitis. Health officials are urging Floridians who go outside in the evenings to wear clothing that covers the arms and legs.
 
More than a Waiting List
But in Vero Beach, which has the only high school in the county, there is a waiting list for season tickets, at $5 a game. ''We've had divorce settlements held up over who gets the tickets,'' Mrs. Livings said. ''People die on a Friday, and on Monday people call up asking if they can have their season tickets.''
The population of the town is 17,000, and more than 7,000 fans pack the stadium for home games. Football brings everyone here together; black and white students play together and black and white fans sit together.
This Friday the Indians, who were 3 and 1 for the season, faced Coral Gables High School, undefeated and ranked third in the state. Coach Livings was worried that his boys would be playing before an empty stadium.
''We've never played an afternoon game,'' he said. ''This is a working town. You'd think on a Friday afternoon at 4 o'clock a dead goat couldn't draw flies.''
 
The Regulars Arrive
But somehow the fans made it to the Citrus Bowl, as the stadium is called, in the center of town. The Rev. Julius Rice of the United Church of Christ was there, one row down from Mrs. Livings, where he always sits. Elva Agise, an economics teacher at the high school, was in her seat nearby. So was Dr. Phil Morgan, a surgeon who was the Fighting Indians' doctor for 20 years, and Bob and Jo Orton.
Mr. Orton played tackle for the Indians 30 years ago. That was in another era, predating the arrival of Billy Livings, who had been a high school coaching legend in Montgomery, Ala., before he arrived here in 1980.
''They said I had to produce in three years or I was gone,'' Coach Livings, 54 years old, said. ''The first year we went to the semifinals. The second year we won the state championship. The third year we went to the semifinals.''
Matt Parris, who graduated last year, played quarterback for Coach Livings. ''He's the head man,'' Mr. Parris said yesterday, in the stands with his former Indians teammate, Robbie Crawford. ''He's the most important man in town.''
In Vero Beach, Mr. Parris is known as the son of Gary Parris, a star wide receiver for the Indians more than 20 years ago. Gary Parris went on to play professional ball. Eventually he came home and he makes his living as a citrus salesman. But on Friday nights he returns to the stadium to report on the game for a local radio station.
The Indians' team colors are red and white, and yesterday the stadium was awash in red and white. Mr. and Mrs. Capece moved here six years ago from Staten Island. They had never heard of the Fighting Indians.
''We'd be out at a restaurant on a Friday night, and everyone would be wearing red and white,'' Mr. Capece said. ''We said, 'What's with the red and white?' Then we found out.''
A lot of the fans said the game wasn't the same somehow, played in the afternoon sunlight instead of under the stadium lights and a sky full of stars.
But the change didn't seem to hurt the Indians; they beat Coral Gables 24-7. The Indians' star tailback, James Stewart, known as Elbow, rushed for 200 yards. Charles Morgan, a defensive back, plucked off two passes.
Still, after the game, some fans looked a little lost. They said they weren't sure how they would fill their Friday night without football.
''Maybe we'll go to the mall,'' Mrs. Orton said.
''What should we do, Phyllis?'' Mr. Capece asked his wife plaintively.
No one reported having been bitten by a mosquito. No one, apparently, had even seen a mosquito.
''I've been coming to games here for 11 years,'' Mrs. Livings said, ''and I've never been bitten by a mosquito.''

Rosemarie Livings sprayed insect repellant on her granddaughter, Lindsay, at the Vero Beach High School game. (Joe Skipper for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Weighing Balance Between War and Diplomacy

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Two months after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Bush Administration's policy in the Persian Gulf hangs between war and peace, balancing on a few key issues that will determine whether the United States uses military force against Iraq.
At this unpredictable point in the crisis, President Bush and his senior advisers insist that they are not committed to a particular course of action, are considering several new diplomatic moves that could avert the threat of war, and are beginning to make tentative plans for what Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd calls a ''new political order'' for the region.
But interviews with senior officials suggest that Mr. Bush and his top aides have concluded over the last nine weeks that as much as the President may want to avoid war, a conflict with Iraq would be an acceptable risk since they believe that Iraq could be defeated, and perhaps relatively quickly.
''We have the means and the will to address any further Iraqi aggression,'' said one of the officials, all of whom spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
Some U.S. Assumptions
Behind American policy in the gulf is a set of judgments and assumptions that guide Mr. Bush as he seeks to maintain the precarious balance of his policy. They will also help determine when and if he has to face the ultimate decision about sending American troops into combat. 
There are forces drawing the Administration toward war: the Iraqi Army's dismantling of Kuwait; Administration officials' confidence that the alliance against Iraq would hold together if Iraq started a war and that United Nations approval could be obtained quickly, and their suspicion that the Iraqi Army might not stand up long against the modern force assembled in Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Bush and his advisers are increasingly grappling, as well, with the notion that a peaceful solution may work only in the short term and that President Saddam Hussein's withdrawal from Kuwait under economic and diplomatic pressure would not resolve the question of how to neutralize his army as a power in the region.
Weighing against these pressures are the success so far of the economic sanctions; the prospect of heavy Arab, American and European casualties; the potential economic disruption that could be caused by a war in the oilfields, and the possibility that Israel could be drawn into the fighting and threaten Arab unity.
 
Limiting Options
''It's premature to say that war is becoming inevitable,'' a senior official said. ''The completion of the military buildup does not foreclose the President's options; it simply completes them. Some people argue a la Napoleon that you can do anything with a sword except sit on it. I say that's wrong.''
The critical factors in the equation of war and peace are Mr. Hussein himself and the manner in which war might break out.
Administration officials will not discuss military options for quotation in news articles, but they have left the impression in recent weeks that there are clear redlines: an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia or its oilfields, terrorist or military attacks on American, Arab or European forces stationed in Saudia Arabia, or an attack on Israel.
In such cases, Mr. Bush would be able to order military action relatively freely, officials believe. But it would be harder for the President to decide that there had been enough cumulative provocations by Iraq and that he could no longer wait for the economic sanctions to force Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait.
 
Some Possible Provocations
''There is a broad category of things that could start to add up,'' one official said, ''like actions against Americans who are held in Kuwait or Iraq, actions against the foreign community in general, the events in Kuwait themselves.''
He added, however, that ''there is no clear time line for when enough is enough.''
Administration officials said they are confident that if there is a clear aggression by Iraq, the United Nations would authorize military action. ''One circumstance could be if someone walked in and said a missile attack had just been launched on Saudi Arabia,'' an official said.
He said the United States is confident that it could respond militarily to a clear aggression, and then seek United Nations approval. ''Under a clear evidence of aggression, you could probably get a resolution at the United Nations in a matter of a couple of hours,'' the official said.
Although the United States believes there is ample legal justification in the United Nations Charter for the use of military force, the official said, ''If at some point action has to be taken, it obviously would be politically useful to have U.N. sanction.''
 
What Moscow Might Do
The Bush Administration believes that the Soviet Union will not oppose or interfere with provoked military action, even if it does not take part, officials said. But they said any military operation would have to have a multinational character.
The United States could, for example, carry out the air portion of a war with Iraq on its own. But officials here believe that any attempt to force Iraq out of Kuwait militarily would require a ground war, and that such an operation must include Arab soldiers.
The officials said they are calculating that the Arab coalition, as well as the alliance with European countries, would hold together if the United States responded to a clear aggression by Iraq. That is less likely if Mr. Bush decides that he cannot wait any longer for the sanctions to work. The coalition also could rupture if Iraq drew Israel into the fight.
Officials declined to discuss the issue of casualties, not just of United States forces but also among the Arab and European troops in Saudi Arabia, and how that might affect a decision to use military force in the gulf. But officials said there is genuine fear that Iraq might use poison gas or biological weapons, and they leave the impression that military planners are concerned that casualties might be high.
 
The Sanctions Work
The hand of those in the Administration and in other countries who argue that the sanctions against Iraq should be given time to work is strengthened by the success of those sanctions so far, which has come as a surprise to Mr. Bush and his top aides.
Administration officials say they still do not have a clear idea of how long the sanctions should be given. But the issue has been complicated by the Iraqi Army's efforts to eradicate Kuwait as a state, including what American officials say has been large-scale plundering of property. American planners fear that there may soon be nothing left to restore in the emirate.
''There's a race between the sanctions and the dismantling of Kuwait,'' an official said. ''The sanctions obviously won't have had their effect before the dismantling takes place.''
Administration analysts who closely follow the events in the gulf said the global embargo on exports to Iraq of food and other goods is unlikely to visibly affect Mr. Hussein's Government until next year. They said it may be possible for Iraq to increase its farm production to partially offset the loss of agricultural imports.
 
A Decision Required
An official said the events in Kuwait ''put us up against a wall.''
''That doesn't mean we use military force right away,'' he said, ''but we have to make a decision about what we are going to do here.''
Officials said the options still available short of war include United Nations resolutions that would impose sanctions on those who violate the existing sanctions, denounce Iraqi attempts to destroy Kuwait, call for Iraq to pay reparations to Kuwaitis and, as a last resort, make direct reference to parts of the United Nations Charter that allow for the use of military force.
A senior official said the United States must prepare for the possibility that the Iraqi Army would be formidable. But he said there is also a suspicion that the Iraqi forces, which have been tested in battle only against an equally ill-equipped Iranian Army, may buckle after a relatively short period.
 
U.S. View of Iraqi Leader
The Administration's diplomatic strategy gambles that Mr. Hussein simply does not want a war and will eventually agree to withdraw from Kuwait.
But some officials argue that this is far from a perfect solution. ''The bottom line is that if Saddam survives this, even if he leaves Kuwait, he's still the superman of the gulf,'' a Government analyst said. ''He keeps his army, gets the Palestinian debate going. Kuwait is forever destabilized.''
Working on the assumption that they will be able to force Iraq out of Kuwait without a war, Administration officials have started to craft Mr. Baker's ''new political order'' for the Middle East.
But even that prospect has some potentially troublesome aspects, since it raises the politically hot question of a more or less permanent American military force in the Gulf.
An Administration official said the United States was giving preliminary consideration to plans that would store large amounts of equipment, weapons, ammunition and even planes in Saudi Arabia.
''You could create with the Saudis some facilities and a sort of skeleton structure so that if you would have to go back in to help, you could do so quickly,'' an official said. ''That kind of thing would make it easier for United States troops to be withdrawn quicker, and it would be very much in keeping with the overall view of all the players that Western forces, particularly United States ground forces, should not be kept in Saudi Arabia.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordanians Resentful as Tourism and Business Fall

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERASH, Jordan, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Close by old columns that have soared since Roman times beneath a bowl of sky in this north Jordanian town, two men played slow chess, a policeman watched, half-interested, and Ibrahim Mustafa Smaaly, a vendor, counted his take for the day: three postcards at 50 cents each.
A year ago, he said, his shaded stall, which offers carved wooden camels, guidebooks, checkered headdress, cheap daggers and much more besides, would have produced a turnover 100 times greater.
But the crisis in the Persian Gulf has driven away foreign tourists from places like the forum and amphitheater of Jerash and put pressure on Jordan's economy. In the process, it has built a growing sense of resentment and injustice at what people like Mr. Smaaly see as a Western urge to punish his land for what he calls a ''noble stand'' in the crisis - a position that Americans and other Westerners have interpreted as a clear siding with Iraq. 
''We can't understand this,'' he said. ''Jordan has taken on the greatest responsibility of all, and we are criticized far more than we deserve.''
 
'What Is Our Crime?'
In the Lebanon House restaurant, the Lebanese owner, Antoinette Salebah -who once boasted packed tables and a three-day wait for reservations - gestured to empty tables in the orange slant of the afternoon sun and seemed more impassioned.
''What is our crime?'' she asked. ''What is the bad thing we did? People are very resentful. I can remember times when people in the mosques and churches prayed for Americans, but now they curse them.''
Since the crisis erupted with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, Jordan has angered both the Bush Administration and the so-called moderate Arabs led by Egypt and Saudi Arabia by refusing to support the deployment of foreign forces in Saudi Arabia and by making it clear that its geography and economic problems preclude total enforcement of the international embargo on trade with Iraq.
On the highway leading east from Amman, 40 miles south of here, tanker trucks with red Kuwaiti plates rumble into Jordan carrying Iraqi oil, the main source of supply since Saudi Arabia cut off oil supplies in a display of pique at the positions adopted by King Hussein of Jordan in response to the strong pro-Iraqi sentiment of his predominantly Palestinian population.
 
Refugees Coming In
On the same highways, however, buses carrying Asian fugitives from occupied Kuwait head for Amman, too, carrying the refugees destined for the emergency airlift that uses Jordan as its principal staging point. And, at the same time, Jordanian officials maintain that promises of humanitarian and economic aid have not been fulfilled to help this kingdom of three million people cope with the crisis caused by the sanctions it says it is imposing on Baghdad.
Crown Prince Hassan said in New York recently that Jordan is enforcing the sanctions ''with complete loyalty.''
''Is it expected that Jordan commit economic hara-kiri?'' he said. ''Are we expected to commit economic suicide?''
Other countries in the region, including Egypt, Israel and Turkey, are also experiencing a drop in tourism because of the crisis, but the effect is particularly severe here, and the Jordanians feel singled out.
''If you look at the history of Jordan, you will find that our country has always stood for justice, dialogue and reason,'' said Ali Hawandeh, a legislator from the Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan's Parliament. ''This element is being overlooked these days.''
Because of the embargo on produce other than oil, he said, ''our exports have suffered, our industries are being closed, and our unemployment rate is going up. Our country is small and it simply cannot withstand it.''
 
Livelihoods in Jeopardy
In places like Jerash - one of the points on the tourism circuit that runs from the beaches of Aqaba to the Dead Sea to the ancient ruins of Petra -such sentiments find their echo among people who, like Mr. Smaaly and Mrs. Salebah, have suddenly found their livelihoods in jeopardy.
Overall, according to Finance Minister Basel Jardaneh, Jordan has lost about 750,000 tourists this year, mainly Western Europeans scared off by the crisis in the gulf and Jordan's intimate association with it. Lost revenues are estimated at $250 million.
Officials at the national air carrier, Royal Jordanian, said all tourist flights had been canceled and transit traffic was down 30 to 40 percent. ''It is a disaster,'' an official said.
In her restaurant, Mrs. Salebah said tour operators had canceled advance table reservations for 1,800 Italian tourists for October and November. At his prime spot before the archway that guards Jerash's Roman sites, Mr. Smaaly said: ''No one comes any more, and we depend on tourism.''
As the afternoon wore on, Mrs. Salebah, a widow who fled Lebanon 15 years ago to escape mayhem, first delivered a broadside. ''There are people here who have 12 kids. They can't even get them a bottle of milk. People come here and say: What did we do? Why is all this anger directed at us.''

HEADLINE: Sadly, a Salvadoran Will Leave His Country

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 6

 BODY:
For 15 years, Roberto braved the horrors of this country's civil strife. One by one, friends left or were kidnapped and killed. But he stayed and built his businesses.
But now he has given up. In August, he sold his Mercedes, rented his comfortable house and moved his wife and their three children to a Florida suburb. Now he alternates weeks between San Salvador and Miami and is planning to move to Spain as soon as a job there becomes available. 
''I can't accept the fact that if you're born a peasant here, you die a peasant and your children are going to be peasants,'' said Roberto, who asked that his full name not be used. ''There's no vision that kids of farmhands should be going to Harvard and running this country one day. There's no vision of a modern society.''
Roberto's decision to become a refugee, albeit a comfortable one, provides a vivid glimpse into the attitudes that fuel this country's civil war. Despite a decade of American efforts to remake El Salvador in its own image, this society remains strikingly feudal in outlook.
Over canapes served by hovering waiters at a party, a guest said she was convinced that God had created two distinct classes of people: the rich and people to serve them. She described herself as charitable for allowing the poor to work as her servants. ''It's the best you can do,'' she said.
The woman's outspokenness was unusual, but her attitude is shared by a large segment of the Salvadoran upper class.
The separation between classes is so rigid that even small expressions of kindness across the divide are viewed with suspicion. When an American, visiting an ice cream store, remarked that he was shopping for a birthday party for his maid's child, other store patrons immediately stopped talking and began staring at the American. Finally an astonished woman in the check-out line spoke out. ''You must be kidding,'' she said.
 
Pampering Is Unnecessary
''I don't mind being waited on any more than the next person,'' Roberto, who went to an Ivy League school and worked as a Wall Street banker, said in explaining his decision to raise his children abroad. ''I like having a maid. But I want my children to learn they can wash their own dishes. I don't want them to become typical, rich Salvadorans.''
The country's wealth is less tightly concentrated than 20 years ago, when a writer described the handful of Salvadorans who ran the country as ''the 14 families.'' But extreme differences of wealth still exist.
Shacks made of mud and scrap lumber line the steep ravines under the high walls that surround San Salvador's luxurious estates. While the wealthy pay $5 for a box of imported raisin bran, the poor have begun calling beans, a staple of their diet, ''rich people's food.'' While the wealthy invest in Miami, the poor can only dream of a full-time job.
Salvadoran society is not entirely static. A small group of civic-minded employers pay more than the minimum wage and provide myriad employee benefits. Political space has also opened. Leftist politicians allied with the guerrillas have returned from years of exile. Popular organizing no longer is tantamount to suicide. Repression is less pervasive and much less deadly. Political debate is broadening.
Those successes have served to highlight the failure to change many of the underlying attitudes. Roberto noted that the country enjoyed sustained growth in its gross national product from the 1960's through the end of the 1970's, but never invested heavily in education or health care. The attitude, he added, was that ''schools don't create jobs, hospitals don't create G.N.P.''
''We're still back in the Middle Ages,'' he said. ''We've got to begin to think about the country not just in terms of G.N.P., but also in terms of developing this society. That's just not happening. This society is very sick.''
