LENGTH: 2197 words

HEADLINE: What Did One Comic Say to the Other? Read On

 BODY:
Veterans of acclaimed one-man shows in New York, Jackie Mason and Calvin Trillin will be back on stage this week and next for fresh runs in new solo performances. On Thursday, Mr. Trillin, the author, raconteur, writer for The New Yorker and columnist for The Nation, will open Off Broadway in ''Calvin Trillin's Words, No Music'' at the American Place Theater on 46th Street. On Oct. 17 ''Jackie Mason: Brand New'' will open on Broadway at the Neil Simon (previews begin Tuesday). Having lived and learned during their earlier shows - Mr. Mason in ''The World According to Me'' in 1986 and Mr. Trillin in ''Uncle Sam'' in 1988 - the pair recently got together to talk about their new acts and what works and what doesn't out there alone in front of the footlights. Here are excerpts from their conversation. Trillin: So what are you doing this time that's different? Mason: Everything I do is different. You have fans who come to see you again. Usually you can't depend on new customers because the new ones are guys who didn't like you in the first place or they would have come to the first show. So you're playing to the same people. It has to be a whole new show. I do the newest situations - politics, economics. I talk about the contradictions and the ridiculousnesses in the way people behave, about luxury apartment buildings that have fantastic lobbies without apartments. The new politics up to and including crime in New York and oil and the Gulf situation. Like how you can't find a cop to help you in New York, but if Iraq threatened to bomb the filling stations you'd have the Army here in a second.
Trillin: I try to get really sexy subjects. My last show was about places, geography. So I was going to do this next show about . . . Mason: Arithmetic. Trillin: Exactly. Our minds work exactly the same way. This show was going to be about math. But math was my worst subject because I could never persuade the teacher that my answers were meant ironically. So I can't do math but I'm doing words, language. There will be politics, certainly some mentions of a few Presidents. There's something about free speech. Not too much about eating, except, of course, a discussion of duck tongues and bull foot soup. Probably some talk on teen speak - how, for instance, teenagers can get along for protracted periods on just the word like. And then some poetry, even harking back to my father's poems about pie when he kept a restaurant in Kansas City and had some poems on the menu.
Mason: Everybody asks me the source of my material. How do you get your ideas?
Trillin: I read the newspapers, but they're less valuable now. In my column I do a lot of political commentary, but this Administration is bad for that. In the last Administration we had James Watt and Alexander Haig - those guys were interesting in their own bizarre way. Now we can't even name the Cabinet. Also I'm in the embarrassing position of liking Mrs. Bush.
Mason: I've never known anyone not to like Mrs. Bush - except Mr. Bush. He's the only guy who's not that crazy about her. Every time she shows up, he's playing tennis. His main thing is running. If he's not running, he's on the boat.
Trillin: And a cigarette boat at that. Talk about a traitor to your class. He's an old WASP; he's supposed to be on a sailboat.
Mason: His boat is for Jewish people from the garment center.
Trillin: That's what happens when he tries to be a regular guy.
Mason: He's a swinger; he's an athlete. It's all part of the image that he's not getting any older. Every time you see him he's panting and passing away, but he's always trying to look healthier. He's got short pants, short jackets and tight suits and he's running and he looks like he's about to collapse.
Trillin: But all runners look like that. The only people who look worse than runners are people who work in health food stores.
Mason: In my new act I do a routine about jogging and health food stores. Whenever you go into a health food store they all look sick. Their shirts look bad. Their jackets look bad. Trillin: Are you going to be in sweats? Mason: I don't get involved in costumes, because clothes are an irrelevance. People don't care what you look like. The only person who cares is your manager or someone who is making a living off your career and who has to do something to be creative. Trillin: This jacket is my costume. Mason: That's not a costume. You paid a dollar and a quarter for that jacket. I paid $1,200 for the jacket I wear in the show. For that I could get seven chairs, two tables, a building in Philadelphia and a candy store for your mother. You're telling me I'm an idiot for paying $1,200 to look the same way you look.
Trillin: Where I got this, it was $4. In my first show I also talked a little about health food stores. I know you're committed not to use anything I had in my first show, but I'm not committed not to use anything you had in yours. Mason: You can use the whole thing. Trillin: On stage, can you see the audience at all?
Mason: I only see one row. What do you see? About the second or third?
Trillin: Yes, and I find in about the second or third row there's always one guy . . . Mason: Who's not clapping, no matter what. Trillin: Not laughing, no matter what. Mason: I know that guy; he comes to my shows, too. Trillin: I was doing the show and I looked at this guy. He had this awful expression on his face - not that he didn't like the material; he hated me personally. And you wonder: I don't think I know this guy, but I could have done something, late in the evening or something . . .
Mason: True. No matter how I'm tearing the house down, there's always this person sitting there. In my case it's two - I'm not going to lie to you.
Trillin: Sometimes I hope they're going to seat him in the dark. Then I think it's always the same guy wearing disguises. I try to look away from him. He's not going to laugh no matter what I do. He doesn't understand jokes. He just got off the boat. He doesn't even speak English. Why should I try to entertain him? I'll look at somebody else. There's a lady over there who's having a great time. I'll watch her. But I can't do it. My eyes go back to him every time.
Mason: I've heard this from a million performers. They like to pretend it doesn't disturb them, but the thing that makes you become a performer also makes you the most likely candidate to be disturbed. It's the insecurity that makes you become a performer. Talent is incidental. What you really need is someone hollering how much he loves you. You know what he thinks by the way he looks at you. This is what you have to find out. Subconsciously we basically believe him. Trillin: Otherwise we'd look away. Mason: Right. We keep asking ourselves, Is he right? He must know something I don't. Who needs him to remind me I stink in the first place?
Trillin: And the thing is, you can't defend humor. If the lady in the second row doesn't laugh, it isn't funny. You'd like to say, ''Madam, many more intelligent and interesting people than you are laughing very hard at that joke,'' but you can't. It's not funny. Well, if they don't laugh, I'll send them over to you. You've got plenty of room over there.
Mason: I have 800 seats. Not only that, but I have a two-hour show and it's hard to remember it all.
Trillin: My first show was an hour and a half, and one time I forgot a bunch of it. I was talking along and I said to myself, hey, I forgot a whole section of this show. So I thought, O.K. I'll stick it in here, what the hell. But then I thought, what if I've already said this? Well, if the people in the first couple of rows get puzzled looks - ''Hey, didn't this guy just say this?'' - I can stop. But what do I do then? The good thing is that you're not doing Shakespeare when the guy in the back row knows you're wrong. Here nobody knows what you wanted to say, so you can stick in something else. Mason: Were you always a performer? Trillin: It's more of a sideline. A lot of writers do it. We like to say we do it because Mark Twain did it. He always needed the cash; he was broke half the time. Mason: Do other writers resent it? Trillin: Some do. They try to be tolerant the way, say, members of the classics department would be tolerant of a tenured professor appearing as a male stripper.
Mason: I get a lot of complaints about my ethnic jokes. Some say it's an interesting study of ethnic life styles and traditions, but others say I perpetuate negative stereotypes.
Trillin: I'm not one of those bothered by that because you tell jokes on yourself basically. Mason: Well, I don't always. Trillin: True. There's some Italian and Puerto Rican stuff, but it sounds like fun to me.
Mason: I notice when you generalize about anything that's not ethnic people find it's funny whether it's negative or positive. And if it is ethnic no one complains when what you say is positive, but if it's not a compliment they say it's stereotyping. But then we live in a democratic society. People can accept jokes about themselves without falling apart.
Trillin: But if you were a WASP comedian - is there such a thing as a WASP comedian? Mason: Surely there are gentiles making a living. Trillin: I mean a high WASP, an Episcopalian who does a stand-up routine without moving his lips and he says things about Jews. Wouldn't that be offensive? Mason: If there's such a degree of anti-Semitism in this country that we think a gentile is automatically anti-Semitic, then we can't accept it as a joke. We accept it depending on who it comes from; if you believe in the spirit of the man, you don't think of him as someone who will attack you. It's only when there's an attitude of basic hate that you think any joke comes from hate. You'll notice if people like each other they don't get upset. When gentiles tell jokes in this country, nobody can believe it. Trillin: Is this anti-gentile humor? Mason: No. The only time you're never criticized about the taste of your comedy is when you're attacking gentiles. When people are really secure they're the majority. Nobody ever comes up and says you're picking on gentiles. Blacks pick on white gentiles, Jews pick on white gentiles, but gentiles don't get threatened. Jews get self-conscious right away because there's such a tradition of persecution and you always assume the persecution is going to start again. The whole thing becomes a problem of paranoia.
Trillin: You talk very quickly. I talk very slowly. Your show is two hours. If I did your show I'd only have to do half the jokes you do. I also do my show for only two weeks. But you have $1,200 jackets.
Mason: But I'm trying to appeal to people who come to shows in much greater numbers. I think your material depends on a higher level of intelligence. You have to be more erudite, more learned, more concerned and involved. In my show I try to be as simplistic as possible so everybody understands it. I don't want to be a mystery to anybody. I try to talk to the guy who never went to school, who understands English and nothing else. It's very obvious comedy that everybody experiences and can identify with. If a guy has to know what's going on to enjoy something in my show, I take it out.
Trillin: I ordinarily have three jokes that require intelligence to understand them, and I'd be glad to take them out for an 800-seat theater. Mason: You don't aim for a more intelligent audience? Trillin: I do the same kind of jokes in The Nation as I do on Carson.
Mason: I get the impression from reading your columns that the way you write takes more intelligence than the way you tell it on Carson.
Trillin: When you write, it's more complicated, but it's the same joke. I was once told if you ever get to Broadway, don't do de Tocqueville jokes.
Mason: But if your material isn't aimed at an elitist audience, why are you playing only in a smoker? Trillin: Because I'm not as funny as you are. Mason: But your reviews were brilliant. They were like a celebration of a genius of comedy. They loved the stuff, and I think I might be educating you into making a lot more money than you do. I deserve a commission.
Trillin: Well, I think you're right. I'll have to give up the writing. Do I have to play the clubs too? Mason: You never played in a nightclub? Trillin: I never had the courage. What's it like playing clubs compared to playing shows on Broadway?
Mason: It's one fifth as hard to get a laugh in a theater as it is in a club. In a theater you have an audience waiting to hear what you say; in a club you have one waiting for you to finish. The whole idea of doing a show in a nightclub is stupid in the first place because a nightclub is a place for a couple to get together and there's a whole ritual going on about how he's going to start this affair with her. He's not paying $300 just to watch a Jew talk for nothing. The reason he's spending all this money is that he's trying to attack this girl.The better I am the worse he's doing because if I'm really funny he can't get out of there. So basically I'm a pimp.
Trillin: You don't have a de Tocqueville line in your new show?
Mason: I took it out. I have a Noriega line.

HEADLINE: The Cure for the Deficit Isn't More Taxes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Henry Kaufman's advice to raise taxes as a solution for the budget deficit is mindless and bureaucratic. (''No (Painless) Cure for the Budget Deficit,'' Sept. 23) On the contrary, taxes should be lowered. Congress, not the Federal Reserve, is constricting monetary stimulus. To eliminate our budget deficit and dependence on foreign financing, taxes must be lowered and major aspects of tax benefits associated with debt must be eliminated.
I agree with Mr. Kaufman that the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law is not an answer to the budget deficit. However, the Government has to lower its expenses somehow. This can be done by lawmakers rewarding corporations and individuals who save, not providing benefits to those who borrow. Here are some suggestions:
* Substantially reduce taxes on interest earned from savings.
* Establish a 50% maximum deduction for corporate debt.
* Eliminate other ''debt related benefits,'' excluding home and car ownership debt.
Within five years the country would realize a strong economic recovery.
In the last two decades, hundreds of billions of dollars have been made available for leveraged buyouts, mergers and acquisitions, real estate developments in weak markets and other irrelevant transactions that benefited only the Wall Street deal makers and a few corporate egos. The ordinary taxpayer has neither caused nor benefited from this madness. Yet Mr. Kaufman suggests that the American taxpayer should pay for it. It's insane.
 
RICHARD NYMARK
New York, Sept. 24

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Stock the Market Sneered At

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
To Wall Street, the Tandy Corporation has become the Rodney Dangerfield of the technology scene. The Radio Shack people? (The sniggers start.) Selling computers to giant Japanese companies? (Roars of laughter.) And yet, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company quietly announced last week that it will be selling, under its own brand name, a new ''notebook'' computer made by Tandy. Matsushita already sells larger Tandy personal computer models in the United States under its Panasonic nameplate.
In fact, as Wall Street sneers, technology industry experts are taking a fresh look at Tandy. And many of them like what they see: the Model 1500 HD, Tandy's sleek new entry in the burgeoning notebook computer market; the Gridpad, a new ''clipboard'' computer that accepts handwritten characters; and, still in the wings, the THOR-CD, the first ''blank'' compact disk that might develop into the CD equivalent of blank audio tape. 
''Increasingly,'' said Richard A. Shaffer, the editor of Technologic Partners' Computer Letter in New York, ''Tandy exhibits all the characteristics that make the big Japanese companies such formidable competitors around the world: manufacturing muscle, vertical integration, broad distribution power and the ability to forge successful strategic alliances.''
The pattern traced by Tandy's stock price in the United States certainly would look familiar to the bear-mauled traders in Tokyo. As high as $55 a share in mid-1987, the stock has fallen more than 50 percent, despite steady stock purchases by the company itself. But at Friday's price of $25.875 a share, the stock is trading at about seven times its recent annual earnings - a ratio that would be seen as a misprint in Japan, where the typical computer company still trades at nearly 40 times earnings.
Lately, Tandy has attracted a few bargain-hunters. ''We started buying at $26 a share and have been buying on the way down,'' said Scott Black, the patient but picky president of Delphi Management in Boston, who buys no stock trading at more than 10 times earnings. He has bought more than 150,000 shares in the past few weeks, he said. ''They've got a powerhouse balance sheet, and even in a soft economy, I think their nominal revenues can grow 5 to 6 percent next year.''
That sounds puny beside the high double-digit rates that retailing analysts once expected from Radio Shack. But, like everyone, Radio Shack slowed down as it matured, and its computer line was never a world-beater. Tandy's early computers - the TRS-80 series and its popular Model 100 laptop - were eclipsed, and Radio Shack shoppers have not adopted the computer as a pet.
Tandy is trying to change that with its new 1000 RL model, featuring built-in software designed to make it the computer equivalent of the ''point and shoot'' camera. But critics say the machine may be too clunky for the upscale buyer and too expensive for the Radio Shack crowd. Besides, they argue, how can Tandy compete with the International Business Machines Corporation and Apple Computer Inc., which are also going after the home market?
Mr. Shaffer of the Computer Letter notes that the new Tandy home unit is easier to use and cheaper than the I.B.M. rival, and that Apple's new machines are not ready yet. Meanwhile, all the advertising hoopla attending the I.B.M. roll-out seems to be helping Tandy, with Tandy's sales particularly strong in the three I.B.M. test markets.
At any rate, there is more to Tandy these days than Radio Shack's computer sales. While trying to spruce up the somewhat dowdy image of its stores - now promoted as ''America's Technology Stores'' -Tandy has also started diversifying to reduce its reliance on Radio Shack.
It has added name-brand electronics outlets, including the Video Concept and McDuff stores. It has expanded into new markets by buying Grid Systems, a portable-computer specialist serving business and government customers, and Victor Technologies, a Swedish computer company with a solid European base. And it is expanding sales of unbranded computer equipment to vendors like Matsushita and the Digital Equipment Corporation.
The results, after some early stumbling, are beginning to show up on Tandy's bottom line. While Radio Shack sales in the 1990 fiscal year, which ended June 30, were about 2 percent lower than in the prior year, sales through all other outlets jumped more than 30 percent. Those sales accounted for about 35 percent of Tandy's total sales in fiscal 1990, up from 28 percent in the prior fiscal year and 22 percent in fiscal 1988.
To be sure, the profits are lower on products sold outside the Radio Shack environment, where the legendary gross margins have been around 50 percent. But the overhead is lower, too, and Tandy's growth in sales at its established name-brand stores compares favorably with other electronics retailers, noted Mr. Shaffer.
Even when measured as a computer vendor, Tandy looks better, thanks in part to its acquisition strategy; it sold more than a half-million computers in the 1990 fiscal year, up 26 percent over the prior fiscal year.
Of course, computer vendors, as well as electronics retailers, are likely to suffer in a recession. ''It's true that you've got to be a hardy soul to be making buys in computer stocks these days,'' said Mr. Shaffer. ''But look across the valley and notice what happens to capital goods spending a few months after a recession - it surges. That's when institutions will return to the technology stocks, and they will rush first to the big companies with lots of shares outstanding.''
Not even Tandy's trip through the threatened recession worries Mr. Black of Delphi Management. ''Look, of more than 2,900 items in the Radio Shack inventory, about 2,000 of them sell for less than $10 a unit. Sure, I wouldn't want to be Neiman Marcus this Christmas. But I wouldn't mind being Radio Shack.''

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Strategies for a Bear Market

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
With threats of recession looming and bears leaving pawprints on Wall Street, managers of mutual funds are maneuvering through treacherous territory. How are they coping? Many are buying again. To be sure, cash reserves at stock funds remain larger than usual. In August, the most recent period studied, cash made up 11.9 percent of the funds' portfolios, according to the Investment Company Institute. There have been months recently when cash holdings were larger, but that August increase was the largest one-month rise since October 1987.
But one thing seems clear from an informal survey of top-flight fund managers: Many are scouting bargains and their slow move from the sidelines, with bags of cash in hand, could help invigorate a market looking for any bit of good news. Here's a look at the strategies of some managers who have been among the top 25 performers in the last 10 years and who have worked through markets good and bad. 
Bob Chesek, who manages the $700 million Phoenix Growth Fund in Hartford, Conn., said his cash levels are below 10 percent today, from 20 percent a couple of weeks ago. ''Most stocks are down to levels that make them great values,'' he said. ''Some growth stocks represent good value, even in a weak economy.'' Favorites include I.B.M. and Pepsico. Yet he remains cautious, expecting that the economy will grow slowly for ''a long time,'' as individuals and corporations pay off debt.
Melville Strauss, who manages the $200 million WPG Tudor Fund, is holding 40 percent of his fund in cash, its highest level since the 1973-74 market rout. But not for long. ''I'm buying stocks every day now,'' he said. He is betting heavily on oil service stocks, which make up more than 10 percent of the fund's portfolio. Two favorites: Offshore Logistics Inc. and Global Marine Inc.
The best bargains around, according to Shelby M.C. Davis, who manages the $300 million New York Venture Fund, are quality growth stocks. Although he is sitting on 8 percent cash - double his usual position - he believes ''this is a time to upgrade quality.'' Among his recent purchases is AIG, the big insurance company, and Golden West Financial, the California saving-and-loan association whose ''stock is beaten down to half price and has enormous opportunity to grow as the industry gravitates into stronger hands,'' he said.
Ken Heebner, who manages the $575 million New England Growth Fund, is hot on growth stocks, too. ''Companies with high growth prospects are selling at discounts to the market, and that's where the opportunities are,'' he said. Some favorites: SciMed Life Sciences, a medical device manufacturer; Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, a national retailer, and Dillard Department Stores, a low-cost retailer in the Southwest.
Another bargain hunter, Robert Lange, who co-manages the $670 million Lindner Fund, said ''we're buying stocks every day,'' but refused to name names. He said that pace of buying would probably pick up ''the lower the market goes.''
Some managers are siphoning off cash more slowly. James Craig, who manages the $1 billion Janus Fund, is holding 75 percent of the fund's assets in cash against a usual reserve of about 10 or 15 percent. The huge stash ''will make me aggressive when the time is right and when everyone else is hiding under their desks,'' he said.
For now, he is waiting for earnings reports to stop depressing stock prices and he believes the next several weeks, when third-quarter reports are released, will be critical. Meanwhile, he said he buys when he spots companies where ''earnings will be solid over the next year or two, and stock prices have dropped so price-earnings ratios have compressed.'' Two buys: Smith Food and Drug, a Salt Lake City-based grocery chain, and W.R. Berkley, a Greenwich, Conn.-based property and casualty insurance company.
Michael Price, who manages the $2.6 billion Mutual Shares, said he is ''finding more and more opportunities as prices fall.'' More than 25 percent of the fund is in cash. Among Mr. Price's recent buys: Time Warner and I.T.T.
Some managers argue that it is still too early to move back into the market. Harry Hutzler, who manages the $600 million AIM Weingarten Fund, usually keeps his fund fully invested but now its cash cushion is 10 percent. ''There's always the possibility that cheap stocks get cheaper,'' he said. ''While most of the damage has been done, it's better to be cautious.''
Perhaps an even bigger bear is Foster Friess, who manages the $250 million Brandywine Fund. He usually keeps 10 percent of his fund in cash, but he has raised that to a staggering 71 percent, a level he has approached only twice before, during the oil crises in the 1970's. And he intends to stay on the sidelines. ''There are so many imponderables - the Mideast crisis, the budget process and the banking environment -that could turn pretty nasty,'' he said.
 
IN MONEY MARKETS, SIZE MATTERS
Large mutual funds should be cheaper to run because they spread expenses over a bigger base, right? Well, not always, as mixed results among stock and bond funds show. But when it comes to money-market funds, the theory holds. In that group, lower expenses translate into higher yields.
The reasons: Larger money-market funds usually have lower management fees because fees are scaled back as fund size increases. They can get better returns by buying enormous chunks of commercial paper and certificates of deposit for their portfolios, and bigger size gives them economies of scale in day-to-day operating expenses. And the market for money funds is very efficient: investors buy the higher-yielding funds and that allows these funds to grow even larger -and to produce higher yields.
When it comes to money funds, ''size matters,'' said Norman G. Fosback, editor of Income and Safety, an investment newsletter based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

HEADLINE: Uruguay: Unlikely Capital For Antique-Car Sales

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay

 BODY:
Parked in the open door of a workshop on a nondescript Montevideo side street, the low-slung pale yellow car created its own Art Deco time warp. Its cockpit-style dashboard, interior radiator, retractable headlights and front-wheel traction - decades ahead of their time - make Errett Lobban Cord's dream machine as alive today as it was when it drove the Indiana auto maker into bankruptcy after the 1937 model.
''We are creating beauties out of junk,'' said Eduardo Ponce de Leon, vice-president and sales manager of Coronal S.A., an automobile restoration company that aspires to gain control of the world market in restored Cords over the next 10 years.
Carefully lifting the hood of a 1936 sedan, now priced at $200,000, Mr. Ponce de Leon points to its glistening airplane engine, faithfully rebuilt with original Cord parts - down to the sparkplug wires - from the quarter-million dollars' worth of original components imported from supply houses in the United States. ''This car is 55 years old; it runs 110 miles an hour,'' he said with awe, but is ''too advanced for its market.'' 
Before a car goes out to a buyer in the United States, Japan, or Europe, a small brass plate will be installed under the hood saying the car comes from the ''collection of Prince Rodrigo D'Arenberg,'' who is president of Coronal and heir to the title of a European duchy.
There are two reasons why Uruguay has long been known as an antique-cars center. Early in the century, its prosperous wool and beef producers were quick to import cars from Europe and the United States; and the downward spiral of its economy since the 50's has forced consumers to take care of their cars and try to drive them forever.
Mr. Ponce de Leon and Mr. D'Arenberg, whose parents moved to Uruguay after World War II, are buying unrestored cars from wherever they can, taking advantage of Uruguay's low wages and the mechanical abilities of its workers.
''The skills here are good,'' Mr. Ponce de Leon said, ''because cars that are kept running a long time have to be repaired a lot.'' When you see an old Ford in the streets, it is not in a sense an antique, he said, ''because it's been actually running for 50 years.''
He said the best mechanical and body workers earn about $700 a month, making the cost of a Cord restoration here about $40,000 compared with about $150,000 in the United States. The shop, with 25 employees, is now restoring 20 Cords the partners bought as little more than piles of rust when they set up business two years ago on $1 million in capital from Mr. D'Arenberg.
Although specializing in Cords, the company also does individual restorations of other makes and intends, eventually, to move to other cars in volume.
In a warehouse across the street, where the remains of about 40 old cars are stacked, are 11Chryslers made in 1929; two of them, which have rumble seats and were found on a farm, may bring as much as $350,000 when their restorations are finished, Mr. Ponce de Leon said.
The lone 1929 Cadillac - the ''Al Capone-type'' - in the warehouse is thought to be worth about $190,000 once restored.
One special order, almost completed, sits in a corner of the two-story factory: a 1931 Ford coupe, with a gleaming forest-green body, black fenders, yellow spoke wheels, a wood floor and leather upholstery. A brass plate had been attached near the motor saying the car has been restored for Hubert Guerrand Hermes, the French fashion accessory maker. Mr. Hermes will also receive an album of color photographs of the steps in the restoration. ''He can see,'' Mr. Ponce de Leon said, ''that it wasn't a cosmetic job, but a 100 percent restoration.''
The price? ''Thirty thousand dollars, but I think we'd charge more for the next one,'' he said.
If the Ford breaks down or is in an accident, the company will send someone to France to fix it, Mr. Ponce de Leon said, and if the damage is extensive it will be brought back here for repair.
The Uruguayan company grew out of the partners' longtime interest in classic cars, but from different perspectives. Mr. Ponce de Leon, along with other business interests, had been buying unrestored old cars for 15 or 20 years. They now comprise much of the stock in the warehouse across the street.
Mr. D'Arenberg was a collector. Alfredo ''Cacho'' Penza, a former bank employee who runs the technical side of the business, had worked with Mr. D'Arenberg for years restoring cars as a hobby.
''He's a Rembrandt,'' Mr. D'Arenberg said of Mr. Penza. ''If he leaves I close the plant.''
When the partners decided that Cords would be their first big undertaking, Mr. Penza went to the United States and spent time with auto restoration specialists.
He and Mr. Ponce de Leon went on a parts-buying binge. They learned that several dealers in the United States stocked original Cord parts. One, Glenn Pray, of Tulsa, Okla., who had also built Cord replicas, became what Mr. Ponce de Leon calls ''my adviser - for anything I'm unsure about I call him.'' They've gone 9 or 10 times to Wellington, Kan. - ''3,000 people, two coffee shops and nothing at night,'' in his words - to buy parts from another dealer, Stan Gilliland. And the trips to the United States produced original Cord blueprints, which now hang on a wall of the factory.
In addition to making 2,030 Cords, the one-time manufacturer in Auburn, Ind., produced 700 more-expensive Duesenbergs. The Duesenbergs, which sold originally for about $20,000, today bring $2 million to $3 million restored. Cords originally sold for $3,500, and the 451 restored in the world are said to be worth $150,000 to $200,000 each.
Coronal has now delivered two restored Cords to buyers in Switzerland and Italy, and has sold an additional six: three in the United States, two in Japan, and one in Australia.
Would-be buyers usually learn of the Coronal offerings through advertisements in Hemmings Motor News, an international antique-car magazine. Then they are likely to send a telex or fax message requesting the engine and body numbers to confirm that these are original cars, not replicas. They follow up with a letter of credit for upward of $200,000 and ask to see a finished model here or abroad.
Mr. Ponce de Leon foresees one problem: ''The good men in car restoration in Uruguay are mostly old,'' well into their 70's. This manifests itself in repairing frames for cars made before 1930, which he says were wooden frames: ''You can teach bodywork to the young - but only the old can do good woodwork.''
 
A HAVEN FOR HISTORIC WHEELS
 
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay
Old cars are so much a part of the landscape here that the Government declares them ''historic patrimony.''
That means a permit from the Commission on Historic Patrimony is required to ship abroad any car manufactured before 1940, but permission is generally not difficult to obtain, according to Alvaro Casal Tatlock, the curator of the antique-car museum here.
''One may have to prove that there are still others in the country of the same model,'' he said. ''But in the case of the 1928-31 Model A Fords, for example, there are so many that there's no problem.''
Another consideration in granting export permission is whether the car in question ever belonged to a leading figure of Uruguay, such as a president.
Mr. Casal estimates that Uruguay exports 100 to 150 old cars a year, restored or unrestored.
Most of the old cars here are not in museums or carefully protected, to be brought out only on Sundays, but are still running on a daily basis. Mr. Casal drives around town in a 1946 Citroen.
''Many people think it is a shame to lose these old cars,'' he said. ''I would like to see them stay, too, but I believe in the right of property. After all, after World War II, the Americans bought a lot of old British cars in England; now the Britons are buying them back. It's world commerce.'' Mr. Casal says that one thing that has made Uruguay a good source of old cars is that such a wide variety of automobiles were imported during the first half of the century. They came from most of the American makers as well as most European manufacturers, but he says there were relatively few of the most expensive brands - no Duesenbergs, for example.
Even in Uruguay's wealthier days, the duty and transport made prices high in relation to income, so the cars were kept running a long time.
''This climate is relatively benign,'' he said. ''The majority of cars die because of corrosion, not mechanical problems, and there's not much of a problem from rain, snow or salt here.''

CITY: MONTEVIDEO, URUGUAY (88%);

HEADLINE: All About/The Spice Business;
Ancient Industry Catches Up With the Microwave Generation

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
As 1992 nears and Americans prepare to celebrate 500 years since Columbus's voyage, they should prepare to pay tribute to spices. When he bumped into America, after all, Columbus was on a mission for the King and Queen of Spain to locate a new and speedier route to a place called the Spice Islands, now part of Indonesia.
In the 15th century, any country that dominated the market in spices from the Far East - the equivalent of controlling massive oil reserves today - was rich.
Today, the effect of spices on the balance of trade is inconsequential, at least in the United States, and competition in the spice market is between companies, not countries.
But the fortunes in spices are still substantial. Their use has more than doubled in the last 20 years, to 762.1 billion pounds in 1989. Last year, Americans spent an estimated $2 billion on dried herbs and spices for cooking, according to the American Spice Trade Association in New York. 
While Europeans 500 years ago needed spices to mask the taste and aroma of food that was often putrid, Americans are now using spices to add zest to dishes that are underseasoned, having little or no salt. The increased interest in highly seasoned ethnic cuisines like Cajun, Mexican, Indian and Chinese has also boosted demand.
To further pump up usage, manufacturers are coming out with new varieties of blended spices, even some special concoctions for microwave cooking. Some are also trying to tap the fastest-growing segment of the market, food processors.
 
A Rich History
Pepper Price Was Like the Dow
In the trade, spices include all the plant material used as seasonings in dried or shelf-stable form. That includes the spices derived from tropical trees and plants like black pepper, cinnamon, cloves, turmeric, ginger, nutmeg, cardamom and allspice, as well as dehydrated onion and garlic, and capsicums like dried chilies and paprika.
Fresh herbs like parsley and dill are not considered part of the industry. And while table salt is not included, seasoned salts are, as are oleoresins, like oil of clove, which are extracted from spices.
Historically, the quest for rare tropical spices, not the culinary herbs gathered from nearby hillsides, led to the race for the most efficient trade routes. Cutting a few months from a two-year voyage or reducing the likelihood of shipwreck could give a spice merchant an advantage, and at various times, Venice, Portugal and the Netherlands all reaped fortunes from trading in spices.
In early times, black pepper was the most valued spice, and at one point, accounted for 25 percent of the world's trade. When Alaric, the Visigoth, first arrived at the walls of Rome in 408 A.D., he demanded not only gold and silver as tribute but 3,000 pounds of precious pepper. In Antwerp, Belgium, by the mid-1500's, the price of pepper had become the Dow Jones of the day.
 
American Retailers
Processed Foods Cut Into Sales
 This country's biggest spice manufacturers are also the oldest. McCormick, Schilling and Durkee brands date back to the late 19th century. McCormick & Company, the nation's largest spice maker, bought Schilling in 1947 and has since marketed the McCormick brand east of the Mississippi and Schilling to the west. The R.T. French Company bought Durkee Famous Foods of Cleveland in 1985 and today, its Durkee-French division is the No. 2 producer.
Manufacturers are secretive about their sales, making it difficult to estimate their share of the market. Besides McCormick and Durkee-French, the other major spice marketers include Spice Islands, Lawry's, and such supermarket chains as Kroger, Safeway and Winn-Dixie, which are believed to control 17 percent of the market.
While the overall demand for spices is growing steadily, the increased use of prepared and packaged foods at home has caused retail sales to decline. ''Until about 10 years ago, 60 percent of sales were retail,'' said Marshall Neale of the trade association. Now, they account for only about 40 percent, or roughly 305 billion pounds, worth an estimated $1 billion in sales.
''The consumer spice category is flat because people are doing less cooking,'' said Mark Peters, director of marketing for Spice Islands in San Francisco. ''Where there is any interest, it's in the exotic spices like cardamom because the cooking that is being done tends to be more sophisticated.''
To compensate for the drop, many spice manufacturers are looking for growth from the wholesale market - the food processors and food services that last year spent about $1 billion on spices.
With retail sales of about $30 million and 115 items in its product line, Spice Islands is one of the most recent entrants into food services, taking the jump about three months ago. It faces its retail rivals - McCormick and Durkee-French - as well as Ryckoff/Sexton, one of the biggest suppliers to food services, its specialty. The attraction: McDonald's, for instance, uses 10 tons of sesame seeds a day - about 25 percent of what is imported.
Vernon Sankey, the chairman of Reckitt & Colman Inc., which owns Durkee-French, has also mounted a campaign to build its food services business. Last year, the company bought the part of the Durkee enterprise from Hanson Industries - Durkee Industrial Foods, which serves food vendors - not included in its 1985 deal. The new division is pinning its hopes on a new product for food vendors, called Flavor-Flo, a seasoning in a liquid base that promises more consistency in mixing and more intensity in taste.
McCormick and Durkee also count food processors among their customers and expect bigger volumes from this business. A dash of chili powder or coriander can turn a plain product into a crowd-pleaser.
''Think about all those prepared salad dressings, spaghetti and barbecue sauces,'' said Mr. Neale of the association. ''They all need spices, and manufacturers are using the fact that they're spicy as a selling device. This would never have happened 30 years ago.''
 
Rejuvenating Interest
Ethnic Blends and Salt Substitutes
 In the retail segment, spice makers are trying to stoke lethargic sales by making their products easier to use. McCormick-Schilling has come out with some spices in small, one-ounce-sized jars, half the size of conventional packages. Although the company was targeting smaller households, the new product may have broader appeal: many spices lose their intensity long before they can be used.
Manufacturers have also come out with a bevy of spice blends - convenient, pre-mixed combinations of seasonings. Of course, curry powder has been around for centuries, first concocted as a way for the British Raj to replicate Indian dishes easily. Chili powder, apple pie spice, poultry seasoning and crab boil are among the other popular blends.
More recently, an outpouring of seasoned salts, lemon-pepper mixtures, Italian seasonings, Cajun spices and barbecue seasonings have hit the shelves. ''People are intimidated by spices; they don't know how to use them,'' said Mr. Sankey of Reckitt & Colman. ''They understand the blends because the names suggest the use.''
For consumers who can't be bothered measuring their spices, much less mixing them, many companies are marketing foil packages with enough seasonings for portions of sloppy joes or taco sauce. McCormick-Schilling has introduced Bag-N-Season for microwave cooking, and Durkee-French is about to unveil a similar product.
Health concerns also account for a proliferation of blends. ''Once you reduce or eliminate the salt you have to replace it with something,'' said Tom Burns, president of the American Spice Trade Association.
Alberto-Culver's Mrs. Dash is the leader among the salt-substitute herb blends. Spice Islands has just introduced a trio of salt-substitute blends. McCormick-Schilling has come out with the salt-free Parsley Patch line. Durkee-French has several salt-free blends and Lawry's, which made its name in seasoned salt, has added a salt-free seasoning blend to its line.
 
STILL TRADING WITH THE TROPICS
Many spices indigenous to the Far East are now cultivated in the Western Hemisphere, which originally was a source for only allspice, vanilla and the capsicums. But with few exceptions, virtually all aromatic spices used in the United States are still imported from the tropics in the East, some directly by companies and others through brokers.
''I suppose there are some that could be grown here, like coriander seed,'' said Tom Burns, president of the American Spice Trade Association, ''but it doesn't make sense economically.'' Canada supplies mustard seed, a cheap spice. Herbs native to temperate regions are grown domestically, mainly in California.
While volatile political situations are a potential threat to the international spice trade, the weather is a bigger peril, according to Mark Peters of Spice Islands, a leading manufacturer in the United States. ''This year there will be a very short crop of arrowroot from St. Vincent's so the price will be sky-high,'' he said.
Drought conditions in many producing countries led to shortages in 1988 - the only year in decades when consumption of spices dropped in this country. Mainly because of the decline in imports, which account for two-thirds of the spices used in the United States, consumption fell in 1988 to 640.8 billion pounds, from 685.6 billion pounds the previous year.

HEADLINE: A Soviet Bank Takes Up Capitalism

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
From its base in the heart of London's financial district, a Soviet-owned bank that has never had to worry much about making money is trying to turn itself into a profitable institution by helping the Soviet Union become a capitalist country.
Moscow Narodny Bank Ltd. has been striving to become an investment bank that plays a leading role in getting Western companies to invest in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
In the last two years, it has helped to arrange deals involving more than $1 billion of Western money for projects in the Soviet Union. Those involving American companies include an Estee Lauder cosmetics shop in Moscow and the modernization and expansion of polyethylene plants whose output will be sold in the West by Union Carbide.
Other projects include a furniture factory in Leningrad involving Finnish companies and banks; a hotel at Sheremetyevo 2 Airport in Moscow involving French and Belgian companies and banks and Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, and a joint venture with a British company to make commercial vans. 
Moscow Narodny has been recruiting experts in areas like project finance, joint ventures and countertrade from such Western banks as American Express Bank, Manufacturers Hanover, Amro Bank of the Netherlands and Austria's Creditanstalt.
''The purpose of my being recruited from American Express Bank was to enable Moscow Narodny to take the lead on deals and by doing so earn higher fees on transactions,'' said Malcolm Magee-Brown, an Englishman who heads the 12-person project-finance team.
Previously, Western investment banks like Morgan Grenfell & Company, the British merchant bank with whom Moscow Narodny has long worked, had taken the lead in structuring deals. Moscow Narodny's main contributions were its important contacts in the Soviet Union and its considerable knowledge of the Byzantine Soviet system.
''We know the system and we even know the psychology of the people on the Soviet end. This is our biggest asset,'' said Alexander S. Maslov, the Soviet banker who has been chairman of Moscow Narodny since 1987.
Mr. Maslov, a 54-year-old chain smoker, joked that he personally does not feel like a capitalist because his Soviet-scale salary does not enable him to accumulate capital - especially with the high cost of living in London. But Mr. Maslov is willing to pay the capitalist wages needed to attract Western talent - although a Briton who had been the bank's general manager for two years left earlier this year.
Moscow Narodny traces its origins to 1915, when Russia's first cooperative bank established a London agency. It was incorporated as a British bank in 1919, two years after the Russian Revolution, to help finance trade between the Soviet Union and Britain. While it has also helped the Soviet Union with foreign exchange, trade finance remained its primary mission until a few years ago.
For the Soviet Union, Moscow Narodny is mainly trying to obtain Western investment in projects that produce goods that can be exported, can replace imports or which enable the country to exploit more profitably its vast natural resources by processing them itself. Current areas of concentration include oil, gas, forest products and telecommunications.
More pointedly, Moscow Narodny has been trying with some success in putting together deals that depend on little or no government financial support.
The bank has no choice. The Soviet Union's economic problems have limited its ability to provide loans or financial guarantees for trade deals and commercial ventures. Western executives have also grown jittery about the Soviet Union's credit-worthiness. Although the Soviet Union had a long history of paying its bills promptly,many Western companies have had trouble getting paid in the last year or so.
Moscow Narodny's main shareholders are Gosbank (the State Bank of the Soviet Union), which is the country's central bank and which was, until recently, its main commercial bank, and Vneshekonombank (the Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs), which has overseen and often financially guaranteed the Soviet Union's commercial dealings with the outside world.
But with upheaval sweeping the Soviet Union, the importance of the bank's Moscow connections is rapidly diminishing. The authority for striking deals is increasingly being transferred to the Soviet republics and the enterprises themselves.
Moscow Narodny Bank also aspires to play a big role in helping the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe to attract Western investment. But experts at Western investment banks and companies question whether these countries, after so many decades under the Soviet Union's heel, will be so eager to do business with Moscow Narodny. Why, they ask, would Eastern Europeans turn to a Soviet-owned investment bank to attract Western funds?
Moscow Narodny executives say with their extensive network of contacts, they should be better able than anyone to keep on top of the changes in the Soviet Union. The breakdown of centralized authority, they say, may even work to their benefit, with Western companies turning to Moscow Narodny for help in finding those with the authority to strike a deal.
So far, Moscow Narodny has encountered no hostility in Eastern Europe, its executives add. Mr. Maslov also noted that the bank holds about $450 million in sovereign debt from Eastern Europe, including East Germany, and is interested in swapping some of it for equity stakes in state businesses that are turning into investor-owned enterprises.
The changes at Moscow Narodny reflect those in the Soviet Union in recent years. During the Brezhnev years, the bank stagnated. ''Profitability was not a matter of considerable concern to our shareholders,'' said William L. Newman, an English assistant general manager who joined the bank in 1968.
Beginning about five years ago, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power, that began to change. The bank's board of directors was replaced with a relatively young, talented crew of Soviet bankers, who typically serve about three years before returning home.
All seven members of the current board came from the Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs, where Mr. Maslov was previously deputy chairman, and will probably go back.
It was under Mr. Maslov that the bank adopted its current strategy.
Last year, the bank's income before taxes, bad-debt provisions and transfers to inner reserves, totaled 21.5 million (about $34.6 million) up from 15.4 million ($27.9 million) the previous year. Fee income, which the bank is eager to increase, accounted for 37.5 percent of earnings. But provisions set aside for shakey or nonperforming sovereign loans to Eastern Europe reduced earnings to 290,000 ($466,900). The bank also has about $1.61 billion in sovereign loans to the Soviet Union, Mr. Maslov said.
Moscow Narodny's limited ability to lend or invest in deals could undermine its competitiveness in the Soviet market, Western bankers say. Morgan Grenfell and leading German, Italian and French banks have been the most active in the Soviet Union. But many Western banks are expected to enter the fray, increasing competition.
Mr. Maslov said he is not worried. He sees Western banks as potential allies that will need Moscow Narodny's contacts in the Soviet Union and knowledge of its complexities.
Besides Morgan Grenfell, Moscow Narodny has long had relationships with the First National Bank of Chicago, the Bank of Scotland and Postipannki, one of the largest Finnish banks. Although there have been no formal talks, Moscow Narodny executives are thinking about teaming up with Western banks or accounting firms to help the Soviet Union turn state-owned enterprises into investor-owned companies.
President Gorbachev has given those favoring a short transition to the market and advocates of a more conservative approach until mid-October to fashion a compromise. In the meantime, many negotiations over ventures involving Western investors have been put on hold.
Mr. Maslov said he is optimistic about the Soviet Union's future. ''You can't be pessimistic, with such a huge potential in such a huge country.''

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Bear Market: Gentle Ben Or Real Grisly?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Just as the world has accepted the fact of a bear market, Wall Street is facing a new puzzle: What kind of bear is it?
Most analysts think this market is being driven by a ''cyclical'' bear, one that will hang around for less than a year and will pull stock prices down by another 10 percent or so. But what if this is the dreaded ''secular'' bear, one that will last more than a year and will drag prices down another 20 percent before it finally lets go? 
''That is the critical question,'' said Byron Wien, the portfolio strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company. ''The first thing I do, at every meeting I go to, is to ask the people where they stand on this issue.'' So far, Mr. Wien himself stands on the side of the cyclical bear, and he has a lot of company - perhaps because it is a far less scary place to stand these days.
The market made some soothing gestures of its own last week. Despite the traumatic collapse of the Federal budget pact late Thursday night, the Dow Jones industrial average closed a turbulent week at 2,510.40, up 57.90 points for the week.
But that wimpish rally won't be enough to cure the unease that will develop this week if the budget impasse is not resolved. Progress on the deficit front was one reason Mr. Wien had concluded that this bear is of the gentler, briefer variety.
''My view assumes that the safety nets will work,'' he explained on Friday. ''One of the safety nets is Congress. There was a belief that Congress would see that we have problems and would pass a budget compromise bill - and it did not.''
The reason that is so worrisome, of course, is because of the link in the market's mind between the size of the deficit and the level of interest rates. Lower rates could cushion the recession haunting Wall Street - but the Federal Reserve's hands are tied. With higher rates abroad and a weak dollar, it cannot act to lower rates without making it hard to attract the foreign capital Washington needs to finance its deficits. ''The Fed can act independently,'' Mr. Wien said, ''but it can't act unilaterally.''
The Fed's limitations were highlighted last week, as the dollar hit a new low against the German mark. The likely balance between the dollar and the British pound will be clearer this week, as the markets adjust to Britain's announcement that it is ready to join the European monetary system.
Meanwhile, the Tokyo market had a bear-market rally of its own. [World Markets, page 15.] And Tokyo may offer a clue to where the American market is heading. Justin Mamis, a quantitative analyst for Gordon Capital in New York, suspects that the Nikkei Dow ''is one major swing ahead of the United States bear market.'' It is a scary comparison: On its first plunge, the Nikkei fell to its early 1989 level before bouncing up between April and July; since pivoting downward again in August, it has fallen to its 1987 post-crash lows. ''Thus,'' said Mr. Mamis, ''a comparison with the Nikkei votes for a deep second leg down into next spring.''

LENGTH: 1202 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/September 30-October 5

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Bitterness and Bravura as Washington Tries for a Budget
 
The House of Representatives went ahead and made President Bush's day early Friday. Defying the President's heavy-handed lobbying - and taunts - the House, led by an unlikely coalition of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats, rejected by a 254-to-179 vote a package unfurled in the Rose Garden last weekend to cut $500 billion from the Federal budget. A month away from elections, the conservatives were uneasy about supporting the plan's heavy tax hikes. Liberals viewed the package's military cuts and its demands on the rich as much too modest. Legislators spent the day patching together a temporary measure to keep the Government from coming to a halt at midnight Friday, the deadline for the across-the-board spending cuts to balance the budget. But the Administration has evoked Clint Eastwood's ''make my day'' dare, promising to veto anything short of a budget accord. 
 
Oil Retreats
 
In a rare occasion since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, oil prices closed down for the week, a sign that traders view war in the Persian Gulf as less likely. Crude closed Friday at $37.99, down $1.52 for the week.
 
The Wan Economy
 
The latest evidence of a sickly economy: Unemployment in September was at its highest level since early 1988. The continued sluggishness in manufacturing helped push the rate to 5.7 percent, its third consecutive monthly rise. Economists were surprised by the weakness of the service sector, a sign, they say, that the virus is spreading. Actually, a recession may already have arrived. The last time unemployment rose three straight months was in the depths of the 1980-81 recession.
 
Policing Children's TV
 
Is ''Sesame Street'' educational or simply a vehicle for plugging Bert and his gang - and the toys and novelties based on their characters? The Federal Communications Commission may have to decide - if a bill, which has now passed the House and the Senate, wins White House approval, which is dubious. The measure calls for cutting commercials on children's programs by almost two minutes each hour, to no more than 12 minutes. Broadcasters whose educational programming is deemed lacking could also risk losing their license. How would a program's merits be evaluated? The F.C.C. would be the judge.
 
The Bears Are Everywhere
 
The world's major stock markets just finished the worst quarter since 1974. Wall Street was not spared. Of nearly 4,200 stocks tracked by Media General Financial Services, 3,744 were down for the third quarter; 370 were up. Broad-based equity funds fell an average of 15.52 percent, their biggest drop since the 1987 fourth quarter, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc.
 
INTERNATINAL
 
When the German Party Is Over
 
East Germany disintegrated amid a flurry of fireworks on Wednesday as the two Germanys celebrated unification. But the message of the republic's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, that ''a difficult path lies ahead,'' was sobering. The post-party hangover: Economists expect unemployment to reach 30 percent next year, up to a fourth of the 8,000 state companies to close and the makeover to require at least $600 billion in investment. The hardships have already chilled some German officials to the idea of monetary unity in Europe before the kinks are worked out at home.
 
The cost of German unification has caused higher inflation in Europe. Another hurdle to a speedy monetary union is London's plans to join the European Monetary System on Monday to link the value of the pound to other European currencies. That is expected to roil currency markets for months, but will put Prime Minister Thatcher in a better position to voice her opposition to a single currency.
 
Trying to Rescue the Nikkei
 
To arrest the free fall of the Japanese market, Tokyo took symbolic steps on Monday that, combined with a decline in oil prices and the budget accord in the United States, produced a weekly advance of nearly 9 percent in the Nikkei index. But it may be a futile exercise. A bear is not easily caged.
 
Victory for Chip Makers?
 
The American semiconductor makers were hopeful, but the agreement last week by Japan to further open its $20-billion-a-year chip market seemed a Pyrrhic victory. A new pact will likely give Japan one more year to meet its pledge of a 20 percent market share for foreigners promised under the current contract, which expires in July. But Americans would also have a shot at something closer to 30 percent of the market.
 
COMPANIES
 
Nynex Rebuked
 
The Nynex Corporation was hounded on two fronts last week. First, the New York State Public Service Commission voted to consider forcing it to spin off the New York Telephone Company to prevent pricing abuses that are the subject of an agency investigation. A day later, Nynex settled similar charges with the Federal Communications Commission, agreeing to pay a fine of $1.4 million and to lower charges for interstate calls for one year by $35.5 million. The F.C.C. claims that Nynex padded expenses and that the New York Telephone Company bought equipment at inflated prices from an unregulated Nynex subsidiary, artificially reducing profits and thereby qualifying for rate hikes. Nynex did not admit to wrongdoing.
 
A Humbled Apple Computer
 
Apple Computer is swallowing its pride and lowering its prices - and profit margins - to gain market share. It will switch from a high-priced, low-volume strategy by introducing three relatively low-priced computers this month. In another turnabout, Sony confirmed that it was in negotiations to produce an inexpensive laptop computer for Apple, which has long prided itself on making its own products. Why the sudden changes of heart? Apple's share of the personal computer market is shrinking, in part because of Windows 3.0, the new software that gives I.B.M.-compatible machines some of the graphics gusto of the MacIntosh. ''If Apple doesn't do something, it will be squeezed out, just as Betamax was by V.H.S,'' said Stephen K. Smith, an analyst at Paine Webber.
 
Sematech's Surprising Choice
 
For a group with such a high-powered mission - revving up the American semiconductor industry - Sematech picked a relatively low-profile new chief last week in William J. Spencer. Faced with threats of budget cuts, the Government-industry consortium set out to hire an industry leader with a hot line to Washington. But Mr. Spencer comes from outside the industry, with far fewer credentials and connections than his predecessor, the late Robert N. Noyce, founder of the Intel Corporation and the father of the integrated circuit chip.
 
G.M.'s Strategy for the 90's
 
The General Motors Corporation makes a deliberate attempt once a decade to win over imported car buyers. While neither the Corvair, Vega, nor Pontiac Sunbird held enough sway in the 60's, 70's, or 80's, respectively, to meet that challenge, G.M. holds out hope for its snappy new Saturns. They will be rolled out next week, some at Japanese-style prices: a base of $8,000, down from the $12,000 G.M. had entertained.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Hidden Pep in America's Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In their determination to sharply cut the budget deficit during the next five years, Congressional leaders and the President may be ignoring or overlooking important strengths in the American economy that over the long term could lessen the need for such drastic medicine.
These strengths show up with surprising regularity in reviews of how businesses actually conduct their operations.
Even so, business leaders and economists generally endorse the budget proposal now before Congress, at least in its initial stage, though many believe it may drive the nation toward recession. They do so if only to demonstrate that Government spending can be controlled.
''Even someone as much in favor of deficit reduction as I am must agree that this package is initially contractionary,'' said Benjamin Friedman of Harvard University. 
But locking the nation into repeated cuts - taking $500 billion from the budget between now and 1995, as the President and Congressional leaders are proposing - could sap the country's productive strength and cut off potential for growth, making matters worse.
Risking the hardship requires great faith in two interlocking economic theories that are widely espoused by economists but have not been fully tested since World War II, and they are often challenged by American corporations in daily practice. One theory is that during periods of economic difficulty the United States loses the capacity for robust economic growth; the other is that a budget deficit limits national growth.
''The whole exercise in cutting the budget deficit and endangering the economy is based on the perception that the long expansion in the 1980's has pushed the economy close to its capacity to expand efficiently,'' said Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a Nobel laureate in economics. ''If that is not true, then we are forcing ourselves into a hardship that might not be necessary.''
The theories go something like this: Just as a grocer who takes in $10,000 in sales but pays $5,000 in store rent has little left over to invest in a second store, so Americans, after loaning billions of dollars to the Government to pay all its bills, lack enough cash to invest in new sources of wealth. Neither the high rent nor the Government's outlays for weaponry, food stamps and many other programs are considered particularly wealth-producing.
 
Lay the Blame on Spending
 In the news media, these theories show up in various forms. One is the criticism that Americans don't save enough, so there aren't enough funds available in the private sector to invest in new machinery and other wealth-producing devices - without help from the Japanese and the Europeans, who have become big American investors in the last decade. Sometimes consumers are blamed for the savings shortage; they're dismissed as profligate spenders. But mostly the Government is accused of dipping too heartily into the national savings pool for what amounts to wasteful consumption. Or borrowing too much from the Japanese and the Europeans, who in the future will drain billions of dollars in interest payments from the country. (In fact, Government debt held by foreigners ranged between 15 and 18 percent of the total in the 80's and is now 16.5 percent.) Another outcry is that the low civilian unemployment rate, 5.3 percent until recently and now only 5.7, is evidence that the nation lacks enough skilled workers to expand production and generate great new wealth. There simply aren't enough skilled people to open a new factory or expand an existing one without luring workers away from another operation, which then has to shut down. ''I don't know whether full employment is 5.1 percent or 5.5 percent, but compared with the early 80's, when it reached 9 percent, we are at full employment now,'' Mr. Friedman said.
No economist doubts that the United States economy, or any economy, for that matter, has a growth ceiling. Many hold that the American ceiling today is roughly 6 percent a year, before adjustment for inflation. In other words, the United States can only add $300 billion in 1990 to a gross national product that generated $5.2 trillion last year in new manufactured goods and in payments for the numerous services that Americans performed. The $300 billion, in theory, is the nation's maximum growth capacity.
The upshot is that the deficit - $149 billion in 1989 and more than $250 billion in 1990 - is growing at 67 percent, eating up potential investment funds in an economy that today is expanding not at its 6 percent maximum, but at only 4 percent. If allowed to grow unchecked, such deficits will choke off economic growth altogether. That's the theory, but ask business executives about these deadly growth ceilings and a much more amorphous picture emerges, one suggesting that deficit reduction might be an oversold solution and the deficits themselves an exaggerated danger.
Even with very little Government belt-tightening, the economy might be made to grow faster than the deficit, the businessmen seem to suggest. Or as Richard Ayers, chairman and chief executive of the Stanley Works, the tool manufacturer, put it: ''If people ask me, 'Is Stanley operating at full capacity,' I say to them, 'that is a crazy question.' I don't know what full capacity means.''
 
Dynamics of Growth
 Four corporate experiences help to illustrate the dynamics of economic growth:
* The Stanley Works, whose network of factories includes a Dallas operation that manufactures sockets and wrenches, found that bottlenecks had developed last year in heat-treating and plating, two of the 20 or so steps that go into making these tools. A relatively small investment in new equipment for these steps increased overall production capacity by more than 20 percent, Mr. Ayers said.
Theoretically, high interest rates - corporations often pay 9 percent or more to borrow for investment - should have discouraged Stanley from making the investment. The high rates reflect the shrunken savings pool in the private sector, and they do discourage many companies already deeply in debt. But in thousands of investment decisions, they aren't an obstacle. In Stanley's case, ''given the big increase in output, the cost of the capital was a minor factor,'' Mr. Ayers said. A limited supply of labor is also often a minor factor. Stanley makes steel tape rules in Norwalk, Conn., its headquarters, and in Besancon, France; the former for the American market and the latter for Europe. But when demand surges in the United States then, rather than increase the work force in Connecticut and perhaps bid up wages in a tight labor market, Stanley imports extra tapes from Besancon. And the line vanishes between America's labor supply and the world's.
''One virtue of capitalism is that it is very adaptable,'' said Richard Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard. ''A tight labor market leads to all sorts of inventive solutions.''
* Gillette, operating a factory in South Boston that makes razors and blades, has found that applicants for the 2,000 factory floor jobs are, increasingly, immigrants whose English is weak. Many know enough English to hire on as packers, at more than $8 an hour, but not enough to move up to machine operators, said Timothy Horan, director of human resources for Gillette's manufacturing group. So the company is beginning to offer courses in English, in effect upgrading each immigrant worker's productivity.
The machine operators are also drawn from impoverished South Boston neighborhoods, and many are school dropouts. To do their jobs, Gillette requires that they carry out various math calculations to monitor the efficiency of their machinery. Many can't do the math, so the company runs math courses. Gillette still scours the Boston area for skilled machinery repair people, who can earn $14 an hour, but here too standards are changing.
''Our engineers might be asked to find ways to simplify repair work, or we might soon set up a training classification,'' Mr. Horan said, challenging the economic thesis that Gillette has hit its labor-supply ceiling. As Rudolph G. Penner, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, explains the theory, ''The more you press, the more the cost in training people or in paying higher wages to get trained people.'' As labor costs rise, so does the national inflation rate, diluting the value of the new production. That's how ceilings work.
Mr. Horan doesn't quite agree. ''The training classification would be costly,'' he said, ''but in the end you might get good value because you wouldn't pay these people as much as a skilled mechanic. In the end, it wouldn't be inflationary because you get a payoff.''
* The National Mutual Life Insurance Company, faced with growing competition for life insurance sales, invested $1 million in new computer equipment and software to automate many tasks. In addition, work was reorganized. Service departments, for example, that might once have responded to any customer's telephoned request, no matter how time-consuming, were given guidelines that required them to ''ration'' their replies, said Frederic H. Bertrand, chairman and chief executive.
As a result, without any loss in revenue, employment at National's Montpelier, Vt., headquarters has fallen to 1,009 today from 1,450 in 1987, and two of the five management layers have been eliminated. ''Computerization gets data faster to decision makers,'' Mr. Bertrand said.
Why wasn't National so productivity-minded five years ago? Competition was less. Fluctuating interest rates gave the numerous life insurance companies offering policies the opportunity to compete on the yields their policies earned for their customers. ''People shop for life insurance as if it were certificates of deposit,'' Mr. Bertrand said. Such shopping has shrunk profit margins at National and other companies, prompting much effort and outlay for productivity.
National did not borrow the money for its recent investment. It simply drew on retained earnings. Such corporate income, held at the bank, is part of the nation's savings pool. National in effect financed its investment in labor productivity, increasing the capacity of its work force, by ''borrowing'' from this pool. But the investment wasn't made because the savings existed. Investment does not automatically and instantaneously equal savings, as economic theory often suggests. The driving force in National's case was competition and lower profit margins. The money might also have been distributed as dividends and spent on consumption.
''Capacity is a nebulous notion,'' said Edward F. Denison, a senior fellow and a specialist in productivity at the Brookings Institution. ''Until you test the system, you don't know what the capacity is. When a company has to do something to survive, to compete, it thinks of ways to get what it needs.''
* Penney's, faced with weak department store sales as the economy has grown sluggish over the past year, has invested in a computerized cash register system for its network of stores. Its main feature is a simplified way to ring up a sale, whether the purchaser pays cash or offers a credit card, buys one shirt, or an assortment of shirts and ties.
''There isn't the necessity of a separate credit-card imprint; you just sign the receipt,'' said Ira Silver, Penney's chief economist. ''The machines cut the cashier process from two or three minutes to 30 seconds, and we keep better sales records.''
 
Increased Productivity
 The equipment takes time to install, but as it goes in, Penney's work force shrinks and becomes more productive. The sluggish economy, even a recession, prompts some companies to make their workers more productive - in effect, to expand the capacity of the American labor force.
''When an economy goes through a shock, a boom or a recession, many opportunities are created for a business to reorganize in a different way,'' said Albert Wojnilower, a senior economist at the First Boston Corporation.''
Many factors, then, dictate how quickly and by how much the American economy will grow. Recession plays a role. So does competition. And government policy, including cuts in the budget deficit. As Mr. Solow of M.I.T. notes, the $35 billion or so in first-year budget cuts under the five-year package now before Congress, shifted to the private sector, would add substantially to the nation's array of plants and equipment, if the money were fully invested.
Such a sum could add 7 percent to the $510 billion in gross investment in plants and equipment that is expected this year. The proportion climbs to 17 percent, if the $35 billion is compared with the $200 billion in new investment only, leaving aside replacements of plants and equipment.
The problem is that the investments might not be made; the banks might have the money, and interest rates might fall to lure borrowers, but with national demand way off, many companies will shy away from new investment. Why should the Stanley Works invest in heat treating and plating equipment to remove a potential bottleneck in the production of wrenches and sockets at its Dallas plant, when demand for these tools might be insufficient and production at the factory moves along too slowly for bottlenecks to occur.
Many economists recognize the irony of cutting the budget deficit in the midst of a weak economy. ''If I were God, I would not have picked this moment to cut the budget deficit,'' Mr. Solow said. ''If I were George Bush, who is not God, I would have tried to pick a couple of years ago, when the economy was stronger. But it is better to cut the budget now than not at all.''
 
The Uses of Spending
 But in the years to come it is also conceivable that increased Government spending and involvement in the economy could be helpful, not harmful. Subsidizing corporate research, for example, might help Gillette develop automated razor-making machinery that can be repaired in some simple fashion. Incentives, perhaps tax breaks or trade rules, might convince Stanley to invest in enough new equipment in Norwalk to increase tape rule production there when demand in the American market surges. The new capacity, replacing imports from Stanley's French plant, in effect increases the rate at which the economy can grow.
The main engine for economic growth, then, seems to be the steady demand that comes when both consumers and the Government are in a mood to spend. And objections to Government spending, even deficit spending, subside when the economy manages to grow at a faster pace than either the deficit or the total national debt.
That was the case in the late 80's, when the deficit fell to 3 percent of the gross national product from 6 percent in 1983, and it was also the case in the 50's and 60's. Robust economic growth made the nation's debt a minor concern, although in the 50's and 60's, the debt was 45 percent or more of the gross national product Today it is 44.5 percent. Budget deficits, of course, surge during recessions. Tax revenues fall as income declines, but Government outlays remain strong. The deficit rose beyond the $200-billion-a-year level after the 1981-82 recession, and the cry went up for reform. Now as the economy weakens again and the annual deficit moves toward $300 billion, deficit cutting once more becomes an American obsession.
The nation was similarly driven to seek a balanced budget in 1932. As the Depression began to unfold, the budget went from surplus into deficit.
The switch came just before the Presidential nominating conventions, alarming both Democrats and Republicans. With Franklin Delano Roosevelt in agreement, the Hoover Administration and Congress, in a display of bipartisan accord, doubled income tax rates and cut spending sharply - all in the name of fiscal integrity.
