HEADLINE: Design;
Risky Business

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
As showrooms are being readied for the international Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C., talk in the industry centers around the poor housing market, slow sales in retailing and the uncertain economy in general. ''Most manufacturers are running scared because business has been so bad,'' says Carl Levine, senior vice president of home furnishings at Bloomingdale's. ''Conservative styling and keeping prices down are very important now. Personally, though, I'd like to see some creativity for a change.'' 
But creativity means taking risks, something few manufacturers are willing to do this fall. Indeed, when the largest wholesale furniture fair in the nation opens for nine days on Oct. 18, experts are predicting a dull show. ''There's a cautious feeling in the air,'' says John Mascheroni, a furniture designer for Swaim and for Jeffco. ''Buyers coming to High Point don't have the money to spend, so manufacturers are purposely holding back.''
Still, there are a few adventurous ones. ''Unlike the others, we're going to be extremely agressive,'' says Ben Dawkins, vice president of marketing for the Hickory Chair Company. The company is adding 20 new pieces to its Historical James River Plantations Collection, a group of about 400 reproductions of furniture found in the plantation homes along the James River in Virginia. The collection, which includes Queen Anne, Chippendale, Hepplewhite and Sheraton designs, marks its 50th anniversary this year.
Paul Hanson, another brave manufacturer, has hired Vicente Wolf, a New York interior designer, to create a 16-piece line of lamps, many of them whimsical. ''Because of these tougher economic times,'' Wolf says, ''designers have to learn that people can't totally redo their homes. We have to introduce pieces that can work in existing environments.'' At the same time, designers must also continue to be innovative, Wolf says, adding: ''High Point needs to get out of the past and deal with the present.''
Mascheroni agrees, and his own furniture designs prove the point. His inspiration is the work of the contemporary Italian avant-garde. Mascheroni's upholstered pieces for Swaim, for example, have exaggerated curves, strong colors and exposed wood legs, all reminiscent of 1950's designs. ''This is a climate where one dares to be different,'' he says. ''It's a great time to test the waters. And I'm hoping that by making a splash we'll pick up what little business there is.''

GRAPHIC: Drawings: In his new line of lamps for Paul Hanson, Vicente Wolf, an interior designer, used images from nature. One example. The chair, above, created by the furniture designer John Mascheroni for Swaim, was inspired by the contemporary Italian avant-garde. The desk, left, is part of the new Perimeter Collection created by the interior designer Jay Spectre for the Century Furniture Company.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Pirates' Owners Pleading Poverty

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
The Pittsburgh Pirates won a division title and set an attendance record this season. But financially, the Pirates' management says, the team is languishing in the second division, and could actually suffer from rather than be helped by its success.
With total revenue of about $44 million, the team had lost $5 million this year as of Sept. 18, its owners say, and will at best break even if it wins the National League Championship Series and goes on to the World Series.
What particularly concerns the nine Pittsburgh-based companies that bought the Pirates in 1985 is that because several of the team's young stars had outstanding seasons and will be eligible to move to other teams as free agents in the next few years, they are likely to press for far larger salaries. (Players with more than six years' experience in the major leagues can sign with any team.) The Pirates' management, which is chosen by a board on which the nine owning companies are represented, says it is afraid it can't afford to re-sign young stars like Bobby Bonilla and Barry Bonds and may lose them to wealthier teams in larger markets with more lucrative local broadcasting contracts. The team's owners say they will not tolerate further financial losses. 
''I'd hate to see this game become a game of migration,'' said Douglas D. Danforth, the former chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation who serves as the Pirates' chairman. (The Pirates' owners include Westinghouse, the USX Corporation and PNC Financial.) The owners' complaint - that teams in smaller markets cannot compete on equal economic footing with those in larger ones - is hardly new. What is striking is that the theme is being sounded by a team that has had such a successful season. The city's population dropped 14 percent, to 370,000, in the last decade. According to preliminary 1990 census data, about 2.2 million people live in the Pittsburgh metropolitan area, down from about 2.4 million in 1980.
But others say that if the Pirates have financial problems, management is to blame.
Donald Fehr, the head of the players' union, says that baseball is a profitable business and that many teams in small markets are doing better than they let on. He said the Pirates' possible loss of young stars reflects the failure of management to sign them to long-term contracts before the players built strong bargaining positions. ''That's going to cost them,'' Fehr said.
Baseball teams are not publicly owned and have no obligation to release financial data. That has been a sore point with the players' union, which has argued that owners selectively release numbers that make their plight seem far worse than it is.
But the owners say the Pirates have been losing money for years and posted an $8 million loss in 1985 that helped pave the way for the team's sale. The team says it had a small profit in 1988 but lost money in 1989.
In the current year, the Pirates say, revenues of about $44 million include nearly $14 million from Major League Baseball's contracts with CBS and ESPN (in which the 26 teams share equally); about $5 million from local television, cable and radio rights, and $15 million in ticket sales. Concession sales and parking also provide revenue.
The team's costs are harder to gauge. The owners say that the players' payroll is about $16 million, that minor league operations cost $6 million to $7 million and that the team is liable (like other major league teams) for a one-time multimillion-dollar payment - the exact amount is unknown - as a result of an arbitrator's finding that team owners colluded to restrain salaries offered free agents.
Other costs include travel, putting on games, advertising and marketing, and taxes. The Pirates say these costs are sufficiently high to preclude any profit.
The Pirates' payroll, which rose from $12 million last year, could go as high as $22 million should Bonds and other young teammates be re-signed at market value, the management says. Bonds, the Pirates' left fielder and a candidate for the National League's Most Valuable Player Award, will become a free agent at the end of the 1992 season. He earns $850,000 a year, and players with statistics like his this season - 33 home runs, 114 runs batted in and a .301 batting average - are signing for contracts for $3 million to $5 million annually.
Clearly, playing in a smaller city does not mean that an organization cannot afford to build a winning team. Indeed, the teams in the National League playoffs this week - the Pirates and the Cincinnati Reds - come from the 16th- and 29th-largest broadcast markets, respectively. Meanwhile, some of the weaker teams in baseball, including the New York Yankees and California Angels, play in some of the largest markets.
The owners of the Pirates and other teams from smaller cities are calling for an overhaul of how Major League Baseball does business. They say they cannot remain economically viable in the face of rising salaries. Teams in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and other large cities have much greater revenue from local cable and broadcasting, which permits them to more easily pay multimillion-dollar salaries and still make money - even without on-field success.
''The Yankees get $50 million a year in local TV revenue and Pittsburgh gets $5 million,'' Danforth said. ''That would be fine if there was some restraint on how the Yankees could spend that money.''
In an earlier effort to control salaries, baseball owners agreed to refrain from hiring one another's best players. But in 1987, an arbitrator ruled that the owners were colluding to violate their contract with the players.
Danforth and some other baseball owners would like to limit player salaries by linking them to revenue. The players' union objected and the proposal was put aside in negotiations earlier this year.
The players union and the owners agreed earlier this year to a yearlong study of baseball's economics, which the owners hope will convince the union that keeping salaries in line with revenues will benefit both sides.
Fehr, who is participating in the study, said he was skeptical. ''I don't think any team is in dire financial straits,'' he said. Indeed, a team as good as the Pirates are this year may sell many more season tickets next year and have a higher per-game attendance. That, in turn, would produce more revenue at concession stands and parking lots. This year's attendance - 2.05 million - was up from 735,900 in 1985, the year the team was sold.
And success on the field might also translate into larger radio and television audiences, which would enable the team to negotiate higher fees for the rights to its games.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas D. Danforth, chairman of the Pirates, at Riverfront Stadium before Game 1 of the National League playoff in Cincinnati. (Associated Press for the New York Times)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1472 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Middletown

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Before the Colonies became the United States, Middletown was a major port city on the Connecticut River, its deep, wide channel accommodating ships bound for China, the West Indies, Europe and Africa. Shipping, shipbuilding and farming made it one of the richest communities in the region.
Industrialization replaced shipping in the 1800's and subdivisions replaced farms in the 1900's. But with the 1970's exodus to the Sunbelt, the city declined.
Then, in 1984, the Aetna Insurance Company built its employee-benefits division in the north end, bringing 3,000 employees and new hope to Middletown. Developers put up 3,500 units of moderately priced condominiums and rentals between Interstate 91 and Route 217. With housing costs rising in Hartford and its suburbs, young professionals flocked to the new developments. 
In the last 10 years, the town's population, now 47,000, has increased by 11 percent. Hundreds of moderately priced single-family homes have gone up, tipping the tax base from commercial to residential. The resulting increase in homeowners' real-estate taxes was cushioned by spreading it over five years.
''Now, when things look bleakest in many areas, we are seeing business up and a revitalization of the town,'' said Mayor Paul Gionfriddo.
Lawrence McHugh, director of the Middlesex Chamber of Commerce, based in Middletown, said unemployment was just over 3 percent, below state levels. ''We have a good mix of service and high-tech manufacturing,'' he said.
Pratt & Whitney Aircraft employs 5,000 people, and the Middlesex Mutual Assurance Company built its new headquarters downtown. A 1.6 million-square-foot office complex off Route 117 has been approved by the town, and more than 30 additional commercial and manufacturing enterprises occupy the northern industrial park west of I-91 and the southeast corner of the town.
In the development boom of the 80's, two downtown blocks were demolished before a coalition of town officials, citizens and preservation agencies decided to preserve the rest of the mile-long, six-lane Main Street. The street is lined with stores owned by the same families for generations, banks, churches and offices and its Victorian buildings are on the National Register of Historic Places.
While speculative residential building has stopped and custom building is slow, four three-bedroom homes on small lots and priced at $129,000 were sold last month from plans at South Farms on Randolph Road. Old Farms, an equestrian subdivision on Atkins Street with a community stable and trails, sold five four-bedroom, custom-built homes, each on an acre and a half, for $290,000 to $500,000.
''Prices are down by 20 percent from a year ago,'' said Enza Cubeta, head of Century 21-Cubeta Realty, ''and are still falling.''
''We got a little gem of a two-bedroom house under $150,000 in a well-kept neighborhood,'' said Sandra Farrell, who moved into it with her husband, Mark, from Guilford last November. ''We didn't see this quality elsewhere and we liked the small city environment.''
 
Mr. Farrell is a physician's associate at a hospital in Hartford. His wife works as a commercial artist in Guilford. Middletown is in the middle.
Middletown had its beginnings in 1614, when Adrian Block, a Dutch navigator, sailed up the Connecticut River and founded a colony known as Mattabeseck, after the Indian tribe that sold him the land. The settlement was taken over by the English and named Middletown in 1653, identifying its location midway between Hartford and Long Island Sound.
''The river creates a great quality of life,'' said Mr. McHugh of the Chamber of Commerce, ''and Wesleyan University is a cultural anchor.'' Among the other amenities are Middlesex Community College and the fully computerized main library.
The Mayor has made reclaiming the river from decades of neglect a priority. ''We lost the riverfront when Route 9 was built in the 60's, cutting it off from the city,'' he said. At Harbor Park, a former yacht club has been converted into a restaurant called America's Cup. Boardwalks and plazas were built for festivals and concerts; excursion boats set out from the dock and on July 4th the area is crowded with people watching fireworks.
To accommodate the city's growth voters will consider a $40 million referendum next month, including provisions for $19 million in school construction, $14 million for an expanded municipal complex and a $7 million cultural center.
A wealth of cultural attractions is available at Wesleyan University and no more than a half hour away in Hartford, New Haven and East Haddam, with its Goodspeed Opera House. But, said Corrine Gill, coordinator of the city's Arts and Culture Commission, ''we need a cultural center to better understand and celebrate our ethnic diversity.''
More than half of Middletown's residents are of Italian origin and most trace their roots to the little mountain town of Mellili in Sicily. ''There are more people from Mellili in Middletown than there are in Mellili,'' said Leonard Marino, a plumbing contractor who arrived here in the early 1900's.
Middletown's eight public elementary schools, two middle schools and one high school accommodate a student population of 5,050, up from last year and expected to increase by 50 to 100 students a year through the next decade. Music and art are integrated into the curriculum from kindergarten through 12th grade.
The system offers all-day kindergarten, a gifted and talented program for grades 3 through 6, advanced placement in science, mathematics and language arts, and compulsory foreign language in grades 7 and 8. The schools operate two drop-off centers for working parents, where children stay from 7 to 8:45 A.M. and from 3:15 to 6 P.M. and are taken to and from school for low fees.
In addition, there is the Vinal Vocational Technical High School, three Roman Catholic elementary schools, a Baptist elementary school and two Catholic high schools.
Wesleyan offers advanced placement courses to selected Middletown High School students, many of whom later attend the university. Founded in 1831 by John Wesley, it has made a point of recruiting an ethnically diverse student body and faculty. The 120-acre downtown campus contains a handsome collection of period buildings, an observatory, a Center for the Arts and a 2.1 million-volume library. Tuition, room and board cost $21,600.
More than a dozen significant Middletown homes built from 1650 to 1850 may be seen on a self-guided walking tour catalogued by the Greater Middletown Preservation Trust, which produced a pictorial history book of the town this year. ''It defines our past and provides a guide for future development on the community's terms,'' said Ann Street, director of the trust.
On some 530 acres of public open space are 14 parks for swimming, picnicking and hiking, six tennis courts, playgrounds and 26 ball fields, including Palmer Field Municipal Stadium, which seats 6,000. More land is to be bought soon with a $5 million green-space fund. Golfers must go to neighboring towns until a 150-acre city-owned tract is developed, and boaters must use launches and yacht clubs in Cromwell and Portland.
The city has many inexpensive restaurants, including several serving Italian food. Among the better establishments is the Middlesex Opera House, which offers continental fare in a converted opera house just off Main Street. After-dinner entertainment is available at the Moviehouse in Waldbaum's Plaza on Route 66.
While many residents would like a department store or two to supplement shopping on Main Street and Washington Street, the city is reluctant to jeopardize its downtown by zoning for a regional mall that might attract a large store. ''We have no mall, and we are not looking for one,'' Mayor Gionfriddo said.

Scull Work: As in each October for the last 15 years, rowers in racing sculls will compete today - 2,500 in 500 sculls - in the Head of the Connecticut Regatta. The regatta is open to all.

LENGTH: 364 words

HEADLINE: East End Avenue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a former pastor of the Roman Catholic St. Joseph's of Yorkville on East 87th Street, less than two blocks from East End Avenue, I was intrigued more by what was omitted than by what was reported in your article on the East End community on Sept. 2. While area public schools received specific listing and mention was made of independent schools, the St. Joseph's School of my former parish, St. Stephen of Hungary School on East 82d Street and Our Lady of Good Counsel School on East 91st Street were completely left out.
Yet these three elementary schools are remarkably integrated economically, racially, and ethnically. Not too many years ago, a study showed a greater number of students enrolled kindergarten through sixth grade in the area parochial schools than in the area public schools. 
Much closer to East End Avenue than the Hunter College Campus School mentioned in the article is the St. Ignatius Loyola complex on East 84th Street consisting of an elementary school, Loyola High School and Regis - an all-scholarship high school.
While Holy Trinity Episcopal Church on East 88th Street and Temple Sharay Tefila on East 79th Street are properly acknowledged in the article as ''religious centers nearby,'' one can only be puzzled by the total omission of all these Catholic schools and of the three Roman Catholic churches within two blocks of East End Avenue - St. Monica's on East 79th Street, St. Stephen of Hungary on East 82d Street and St. Joseph's on East 87th Street. Three blocks away from East End Avenue is Our Lady of Good Counsel Church on East 90th Street and, on East 83d Street, St. Elizabeth of Hungary, a parish devoted to services and programs for the deaf. St. Joseph's where I was pastor from 1970 to 1982 was and remains a vital religious center in the area.
I can only wonder at the wholesale omission of St. Joseph's and every other Catholic educational and religious institution from what purports to be a profile of a neighborhood that even gets down to naming local coffee shops and Chinese restaurants.
 
MSGR. HARRY J. BYRNE
 Manhattan
 
Monsignor Byrne is pastor of the Roman Catholic Epiphany Church.

LENGTH: 1345 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Lake Tahoe;
Resorts' Residential Listings Growing

BYLINE: By Andree Brooks

DATELINE: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, CALIF.

 BODY:
''Whenever the Bay area gets a cold we get pneumonia,'' observed Doug Rosner, owner-broker of Century 21 South Tahoe Realty.
At present, however, though a weaker real estate market has given the Bay area around San Francisco a cold, there is no evidence of pneumonia here. At Lake Tahoe, which is 200 miles northeast of San Francisco, property prices have held firm, after reaching a peak early this year. Nevertheless, the fear of a downturn has led to an upsurge in property listings in some of the lakeside communities, including this one, brokers report.
But nobody expects values to be as severely hit as they have been on the West Coast or in the Northeast. Environmental concerns for the purity of the lake - folklore suggests that a dinner plate is visible 120 feet below the surface - have so tightly controlled the opportunity for development since 1983 that the supply of homes at any price is limited. 
Further holding off a plunge in prices is the buoyant effect of the foreign money pouring into what has become a world-class resort. ''We've had a strong international market for some time,'' said Adele Lucas, president of the South Lake Tahoe Board of Realtors. ''They hear about us on TV sports, on 'Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.' '' Typical buyers, she said, are from Japan, Mexico, Europe and South America.
Another factor is what some observers call ''the Nevada card.'' Market conditions on the more steeply sloping Nevada side of the lake seem to mirror the property boom elsewhere in Nevada. And this could further ameliorate the wider chill.
The Lake Tahoe basin encompasses more than 100 square miles over 6,000 feet above sea level. The lake itself is 22 miles long and 12 miles wide, with the border between California and Nevada slicing through its center. Five counties - three in California and two in Nevada - and some 15 towns make up the 71 miles of shore area, which has 72 beaches, 14 marinas and 950 boat slips.
More than a dozen cross-country and downhill ski centers rise from that shoreline, often hidden from view by the dense firs and pines that cover most of the surrounding mountains. Communities run the gamut from exclusive enclaves like Incline Village and Glenbrook on the steeper Nevada side to this one in the relatively flat, more populous area south of the lake.
More than 80 percent of the land area in the lake basin is owned by state or Federal agencies or land conservancies.
Brokers estimate that values at Incline Village are higher right now than anywhere else in the basin. Currently listed for sale there, for example, is a 5.9-acre lakeside estate with a main house, a guest house, a tennis court, 250 feet of beachfront and a pier. The asking price is $12 million, possibly the highest ever.
Moreover, figures compiled by the Incline Village Board of Realtors show that there have been only 425 homes in that village listed for sale to date this year, compared to 547 in September 1989, a 22.3 percent drop.
The numbers represent condominiums, single-family houses and estates, with houses averaging about $380,000 and condominiums around $150,000 each. Prices of comparable properties on the more southerly California shore tend to be 30 percent less.
In this city of 21,000 year-round residents, for example, a 4,600-square-foot Tudor mansion with 100 feet of lakefront in the exclusive Tahoe Keys development carries an asking price of $1.85 million. A few hundred yards inland, in the same complex, a new 2,400-square-foot house is priced at $375,000.
And even here residents are taking no chances. This city is in the initial phase of a $154 million commercial redevelopment plan that is already sweeping away the cheap motels, dilapidated gas stations and tacky retail shacks that gave Route 50 - the main thoroughfare through the town - a shabby look.
''We didn't have the upscale appearance of Vail or Aspen,'' said David G. Dobson, assistant executive director of the South Tahoe Redevelopment Agency. ''So unless we got rid of some of the older facilities and broadened the market we could have been left behind.''
Lake Tahoe's birth as a resort dates to the turn of the century, when some prominent Bay Area families carved huge estates out of the pristine hillside and made it fashionable to spend the summer here. More modest families quickly followed, clearing smaller lots for simpler cabins.
Even today, the resort caters to a vast demographic and economic spread, with vacation homes ranging from a $60,000 co-op to that $12 million estate and with luxury hotels standing side by side with the local Motel 6.
At first, development was heaviest on the more accessible California side, and it catered mainly to that sumnmer crowd. But as winter sports grew in popularity in the 50's, the resort began to capitalize on its superb slope and snow conditions, coupled with long, clear, sunny winter days. Adding to the natural bounty was the growth of the casinos on the Nevada side, which helped draw an even more broadly based crowd.
The housing needs of the growing number of service workers led to heavy demand for modestly priced homes. Cheap rental neighborhoods, many patched together from some of the original cabins, began to spring up and started an outcry for more affordable housing that even today dominates local politics.
But that was not easy to achieve. Worried that pell-mell development was blighting the lake's natural qualities, which was bad for the environment and suicidal for business and jobs, a coalition of local leaders established the bi-state Tahoe Regional Planning Agency in 1969 to impose rigid controls.
The agency now sets strict limits on the number of new homes that may be built each year and on which sites qualify. Today it is considered one of the few regional agencies with sufficent regulatory muscle to override individual state or municipal planning decisions and enforce its own regional plan.
The current program, started in 1986 and ending in 1991, allows for 300 new units a year, said David Ziegler, the executive director. The units are apportioned between the five counties making up the lake area and are generally awarded either by lottery or on a first-come, first-served basis. Only sites that already have an environmental score that puts them in an acceptable development category qualify. What will be permitted after 1991 is not yet decided, Mr. Ziegler said.
Partially as a result, a brisk, albeit controversial, market is developing for the transfer of development rights similar to the trading of air rights in New York City. Builders, for example, will buy an old cabin in a poor location for about $30,000, tear it down and transfer the ''right'' to that unit to a more desirable parcel where they may put up a luxury home many times its size. Or they will become partners with someone who owns land and won an allotment.
Chris Strohm, president of Strohm Construction and president-elect of the South Lake Tahoe Chamber of Commerce, for example, is currently using a client's 1990 allotment to build a four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 2,100-square-foot contemporary home on a third of an acre of steep hillside in an inland location here close to the casinos and ski slopes. To be completed in October, its asking price is $265,000, about the same as it might have done a year ago.
For the 90's Mr. Ziegler expects ''a lot more rebuilding and revitalization'' with bigger, more luxurious houses replacing many of the cabins and simpler homes of bygone years. Also, he predicts, dozens of still-vacant home sites are likely to be bought by state, local agencies and land conservancies as building permits become increasingly hard to get.
The much-needed multifamily housing for the service workers is expected to be about a half-hour inland from the protected lake basin, possibly in Douglas County, Nev. The current steel grip on expansion that has protected the lake and helped the resort flourish for more than a decade is unlikely, officials insist, to be loosened in the foreseeable future.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lakeside houses in South Lake Tahoe, Calif. The dwelling at left is selling for $1.8 million. (Andree Brooks for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1508 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY Q & A: STANLEY C. VAN NESS;
Acting as the State's 'Efficiency Expert'

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
STANLEY C. VAN NESS is no stranger to state government or to the complexities of the machinery that propels it.
As the Public Advocate for eight years during the administration of Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, Mr. Van Ness witnessed firsthand the delicate balance that must be constantly maintained by public agencies expected to deliver maximum service at minimum expense.
Those eight years as a Cabinet-level official also familiarized Mr. Van Ness with the nuts and bolts of governmental budgets and the sleight of hand sometimes used in preparing them.
Mr. Van Ness's experience has served him well in the months since Gov. Jim Florio chose him as chairman of the Governor's Management Review Commission, a seven-member, ad-hoc body charged with conducting an exhaustive audit of the finances of state government.
Indeed, Mr. Van Ness said recently, ''I know where some of the bones might be buried.'' 
Having established a reputation as a public-minded civil servant while serving as the state's first Public Advocate, and as the state's Public Defender, Mr. Van Ness is perceived by many as well suited for the delicate position of what amounts to the state's official ''efficiency expert.''
The 56-year-old lawyer graduated cum laude from Rutgers College and, after serving five years in the Air Force, graduated cum laude from the Rutgers University Law School. He became law secretary to Judge Sidney Goldman of Superior Court and was later appointed Assistant United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey.
After serving as counsel to Gov. Richard J. Hughes, Mr. Van Ness became the state's Public Defender, and then, in 1974, he became the state's first Public Advocate,a position he held until 1982.
Mr. Van Ness, who lives in Brielle with his wife, Eileen, and children, Brian and Elizabeth, recently joined the law firm of Picco Mack Kennedy Jaffe Perrella & Yoskin in Trenton.
Q. What has the Governor's Management Review Commission been asked to do?
A. We have been asked by the Governor to undertake an operational audit to determine how state government is operating and how it can be made to operate more efficiently and more economically.
Q. What is an operational audit?
A. People traditionally think of an audit as asking the question ''If the assets have been properly added, and the debits properly deducted, do the numbers even out?''
An operational audit, however, goes deeper; it looks at the performance of an organization and the philosophy behind the performance. It asks the questions ''Are they doing any things that they need not do?'' and ''Are they doing well the things that they are supposed to do?''
Q. Where will you be looking?
A. Our goal is to look at those 11 departments of state government that we decided to focus on, and to determine whether the people in this state are getting a dollar's worth of value for a dollar spent. There is no specific amount of money we are seeking to find. Wherever it leads us is wherever we're going, and we hope to call the shots as we see them.
Q. What departments will be audited?
A. We decided to look at human services, environmental protection, corrections, transportation, personnel, community affairs, health, law and public safety, treasury, commerce and banking.
Q. Why were only 11 departments chosen out of the 19 in state government?
A. We chose the ones we thought would give us the biggest bang for the buck. I think we decided not to do all of them purely because of constraints on time and resources. But to say we're looking only at 11 departments is somewhat misleading. We're looking at those 11 departments that spend 70 percent of the state dollars in a direct way. We're also looking at the entire state government in cross-sectional pieces - in areas such as sick leave injury, centralized training and motor vehicle fleet purchases. No department is going unnoticed, but we're focusing our attention on 11.
Q. What about autonomous agencies like the Sports and Exposition Authority and the Turnpike Authority; will you be auditing those?
A. We're not looking at them; they're not within our charge. I suspect someone ought to take a look at them, but we were not given that responsibility.
Q. Doesn't New Jersey already have an official state auditor? Does your job duplicate his?
A. There is a state auditor's office that is a creature of the Legislature. I'm sure that they do what they can do, but I'm not sure that they've ever gone into this kind of in-depth analysis of the effectiveness of specific programs. They can tell you whether people are following the rules, whetherthey're going on trips and haven't accounted for the payment properly and things like that, but they've never had the resources in that office to do the kind of thing that we're able to do with the help of people working from the outside.
Q. Have you set a time limit for the commission to complete its work?
A. I can see the end of this commission's participation probably by the end of this calendar year, but I'm virtually certain that one of our recommendations will be that there be an ongoing effort to conduct this kind of operational review on a regular basis.
Q. But wouldn't that cost additional money?
A. We think that out of the savings that we can find, some portion will be used in an ongoing effort to insure two things: one, that the recommendations that are put in place are in fact implemented, and two, that a continuing analysis be done, perhaps on those agencies that we didn't look at specifically this time.
Q. What happens after the commission makes its recommendations?
A. They would have to be implemented by the Governor; we have absolutely nothing more than an advisory role. We will make our recommendations to the Governor, and he will decide whether they make sense.
Q. Will the Legislature have to approve them as well?
A. Some of them. But most of the things that we're talking about can be done by executive order or even by less formal methods.
Q. Will you issue an interim report?
A. There will be a number of interim reports. We decided that rather than wait until the end of the process and come out with a complete report, we would make recommendations as they developed. We did that for two reasons: first, if something is worth doing, it's worth doing quickly, and secondly, if it's something worth doing it ought to be out there standing on its own merits and not be weighed down by controversial items that may appear in an overall report.
Q. Has the commission made any such interim recommendations?
A. Yes, we gave the Governor one on training about a month ago. He accepted our recommendation and implemented a centralized training program that we predict will save $5 million in the next budget. That's not a lot of money to start with, but it is a start. There are some other recommendations coming down the pike, too. I think we'll have some on how to handle the state automobile fleet in the very near future, and we'll have some recommendations on sick leave and sick leave injury for state employees.
Q. Have you set any monetary goal for the commission?
A. In terms of dollars saved, that's a little hard to say. We weren't given any target, but I suppose I did latch on to the $100 million figure that Assemblyman Haytaian said would be a minimal measure of our success.
Q. But $100 million, though a substantial amount of money, is still less than 1 percent of the entire state budget. What will a $100 million saving mean to taxpayers?
A. Not a great deal. First you have to realize that out of the $12 billion budget, only $4 billion is within state management control; the state really has no direct control over the rest. But even $100 million out of $4 billion is not an astounding number.
But I don't think we can measure success in X number of dollars. I think we can measure it in terms of how creditable a job we've done. If the job is creditable, then in addition to whatever modest savings the taxpayer will receive directly, he will have increased confidence that he's getting his money's worth.
Q. Sometimes, when a state department's budget is cut, the services lost as a result of the cut become an additional burden on local government. What will be done to prevent that?
A. We're not really looking at cuts in that fashion. What we're saying is if a department is spending $2 million on a program, and they could do it just a little more efficiently, then they might get the same results on $1.8 million. So the policy question of whether a service is going to continue to be delivered is really not something that we're focusing on.
Q. How do you think you are being perceived by the people in the departments that you are auditing?
A. We've gotten a great deal of cooperation from them, and from the commissioners of the departments. The people in the departments may feel that they may be injured in someway but, by and large, the cooperation has been very good. So far, they haven't thrown any stones.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Stanley C. Van Ness, formerly the Public Advocate and now chairman of the Management Review Commission (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1539 words

HEADLINE: Foes of Yonkers Housing Threaten Bank Boycott

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE threat by opponents of court-ordered low-income housing in Yonkers to picket or boycott any bank that finances the construction has added new complexities to the bitterly disputed project and may force the developers to seek financial assistance from outside the state.
Oscar Newman, the housing expert appointed by the court to assist in the ''remedy'' of earlier discriminatory practices, said that in August Chemical Bank had halted negotiations on a loan to the builder, a New York subsidiary of DeLuxe Homes of Berwick, Penn. Mr. Newman said the reason was that the bank was afraid its Yonkers branch ''would be picketed.''
But a spokesman for Chemical Bank, Kenneth Herz, disagreed with Mr. Newman. Mr. Herz said the bank had, in fact, met with DeLuxe officials to discuss the $16.1 million the builders would need to build the first 142 of 200 town-house style subsidized housing units. But the bank rejected the application, Mr. Herz said, ''based strictly on the basis of prudent banking practice.''
Mr. Newman said Donald Meske, the president of DeLuxe, ''told me on Aug. 7 that Chemical's board had agreed to approve the loan but had not yet defined the terms.'' Mr. Newman said he had also been told by Mr. Meske that the bank had appointed a >real estate lawyer to negotiate terms. 
A week later, Mr. Newman said, ''Mr. Meske said he was told by a vice president of Chemical, Lewis Jones, that the bank would not go through with the loan as planned because they had a branch in Yonkers and they were afraid it would get out that Chemical had made the loan and that the branch would be picketed.''
 
'Absolutely False'
Mr. Herz said that ''we never made a loan commitment'' and that the assertions by Mr. Newman about Mr. Jones were ''absolutely false.''
''Fear of a branch picket was never a consideration,'' he said and added that the matter ''never reached Chemical Bank's board, which had no meetings in the period under question.'' Several attempts to reach Mr. Meske last week were unsuccessful. The delay and the alleged reasons for it have angered Michael H. Sussman, a lawyer for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, one of the plaintiffs in the decadelong discrimination case, and others who had expected to see a groundbreaking this summer.
Mr. Sussman said he had asked the United States Justice Department to look into a possible violation of a Federal law barring banks from denying loans for racial reasons. He also criticized the city's elected officials for creating a climate in Yonkers that ''makes it prudent for Chemical to make the decision it did.''
Mr. Newman, in a letter to Thomas R. deRosa of Beveridge & Diamond, the law firm representing the city, said DeLuxe's negotiations with other banks ''to replace Chemical'' have since become ''increasingly protracted and complex.''
Mr. Newman said that in dealing with First Eastern Bank, a Pennsylvania bank that has worked with DeLuxe in financing other projects, the political aspect of the case remained high on the agenda. ''In discussing the exacting financial conditions that First Eastern Bank was now demanding,'' Mr. Newman said in his letter, ''an attorney from Baker & McKenzie, Jeffrey LeNobel, who was initially involved in representing Chemical Bank, had offered that 'the basic reason Chemical Bank had refused to finance DeLuxe was political.' ''
Mr. Newman, citing a telephone conversation with Mr. LeNobel on Sept. 2, said that ''when I asked him what he meant by 'political,' he replied that Chemical Bank was afraid it was going to lose its major accounts with the city of Yonkers, accounts that would make the loan to DeLuxe comparatively insignificant.''
 
Lawyer Disputes Account
But Mr. LeNobel said that he had had no conversation with Mr. Newman over the Labor Day weekend and that when they had spoken it was not on the subject of Chemical Bank having a Yonkers account. Chemical Bank did not finance the housing loan, he said, ''strictly for economic and business reasons.''
The incident became public just over a week ago when Mr. deRosa, the lawyer representing the city, wrote to Mr. Newman saying that there was ''a story circulating'' that ''an unnamed person, allegedly a city employee, had interfered with the financing'' by threatening ''to remove $300 million in funds from Chemical Bank if the financing was provided to DeLuxe.''
An investigation was conducted by the City Manager, Neil J. DeLuca, who could find no employee who had spoken to Chemical Bank and who said, in fact, that ''no one knew that Chemical was dealing with Deluxe.''
The City Manager further noted that ''the amount of funds the city has with Chemical Bank'' did not exceed ''$3 million to $4 million in a payroll account.''
Where then did the rumor start, and who would do the picketing or organize the boycott, Mr. DeLuca was asked early last week. He replied: ''I just heard Jack O'Toole over the radio saying that the Save Yonkers Federation would picket any bank that funded DeLuxe.''
 
'We Didn't Threaten Them'
Mr. O'Toole, who has headed the struggle by neighborhood groups to bar construction of the subsidized housing, laughed and said: ''It wasn't my idea. We didn't threaten them until after the story came out, although I think we would have gotten around to it.''
''The whole situation is on the verge of being turned out,'' or killed, Mr. O'Toole said, ''because they can't build the housing for financial, legal and environmental reasons.''
He said a major problem in finding a bank to lend DeLuxe the money is that the firm ''formed a shadow corporation, DeLuxe of New York, to bid for the contract, but I understand it has only four employees and no assets.''
''DeLuxe wanted to use the property as collateral,'' Mr. O'Toole said. ''But the city's lawyers say the sites should revert to the city if the developer doesn't finish the work, and not go to the bank. Chemical Bank must have looked at DeLuxe of New York and said, 'They're not worthy of a loan.' ''
The land, still technically the city's property, will be turned over to Deluxe for when the developer obtains the financing to build the public housing and signs a contract with the city. The land would belong to Deluxe during construction and would be turned over to the city's Municipal Housing Authority when construction is completed.
Mr. O'Toole said lawsuits and legal appeals concerning the proposed housing were pending in several areas. One suit, brought by John D'Agnillo, a Yonkers resident, sought to block the housing because it would overburden roads, schools and sewers and cause other environmental damage.
 
Environmental Considerations
A Federal District Court Judge, Charles S. Haight, ruled that city and Federal officials should study the effects of the housing-desegregation plan on the roads and sewer system, but that the study should not delay construction. That ruling is being appealed, based on regulations under the National Environmental Protection Act preventing the start of construction on any project under environmental review.
The city, meanwhile, is appealing a decision by Judge Leonard B. Sand in Federal District Court in Manhattan ordering the city to modify the permit issued by the city transferring the sites to DeLuxe from a designation of ''multifamily'' to ''single-family'' construction, still in the town-house style.
The difference is that a multifamily permit requires more extensive fire protection and accessibility for disabled people. DeLuxe had refused to accept the sites under the multifamily designation.
Mr. O'Toole said another suit would challenge the consent decree, in which the City Council agreed to accept the housing plan, as having been approved under ''duress'' because Councilmen were voting with threats of fines and imprisonment in the background.
He said that earlier legal attempts to challenge the consent decree had failed, but that recently there was a U.S. Supreme Court case involving firemen, in which the court ruled that ''anybody affected by a consent decree could sue if they had no input into the decree.''
The Yonkers consent decree was fashioned by Judge Sand, whose ruling in 1985 that Yonkers was guilty of four decades of discrimination in housing and schools set the ''remedies'' in motion.
 
'Seeing It My Way'
''I don't think this housing is ever going to be built,'' Mr. O'Toole said. ''Some people thought I was outrageous when I said a few years ago that it won't be built, but now some of them are seeing it my way.''
Mr. DeLuca said he assumed that DeLuxe would be going to an out-of-state bank to get the loan. ''Somebody's got to give them the money to start construction.'' He said that the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development was underwriting it, ''but it's a turnkey project, which means 'You build it, then we'll fund it.''
Maybe Jack Kemp, the New York Republican who is Secretary of H.U.D., ''will have to get involved,'' Mr. DeLuca said.
And how would Mr. O'Toole seek to bring pressure if DeLuxe found an out-of-state bank? ''All banks have correspondent banks,'' he said. ''So we'll find out the correspondent bank in Yonkers and picket them.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 7, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 540 words

HEADLINE: The Road to Ruin in New York

 BODY:
Lurching.
There's no better way to describe the kind of leadership Mayor David Dinkins gave New Yorkers last week. With the economy in deepening trouble, the city urgently requires a forthright voice and a steady hand. Here is what it got:
On Monday, he announced an unrealistically generous settlement with the teachers' union that rocks the city treasury in two ways. It will cost $236 million by itself. Worse, the 5.5 percent raise sent a gilt-edged invitation to other unions to seek similar raises for themselves. 
On Tuesday, responding to a wave of fear about crime and stray gunfire, he proposed an intelligent, ambitious law enforcement plan. It would cost the ordinary citizen only about $50 a year, the Mayor said. There's another way to do the arithmetic: the four-year cost would be $1.8 billion.
On Thursday, in obvious response to criticism of the labor settlement, he imposed a partial job freeze and suddenly raised the prospect of laying off 15,000 city workers.
New York may be wealthy enough to find funds to give teachers a healthy raise and to pay for an anti-crime program. Or it may be so broke it must contemplate laying off thousands. But how can it be both? And what assurance is there that the Dinkins Administration won't now lurch in some other direction, in response to some other bad news?
It's as if the business conducted in City Hall is day-by-day public relations instead of sober management of the politics of scarcity.
The Mayor's new initiatives are narrowly plausible in the sense that he does outline how he proposes to get the money for teachers and police. But such earmarking misses the point. His own officials estimate a budget gap of $1.4 billion in the next fiscal year; outside analysts think $2 billion is more like it; and now Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman says $2.6 billion.
None of this is meant to imply that teachers don't deserve more. It's not to deny that the city needs a crime program - and the one proposed by Police Commissioner Lee Brown is admirable. But it's no trick to tell the public what it wants. New York knows from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's that the road to ruin is paved with justifiable programs.
What makes Mr. Dinkins's initiatives so problematic is that they have emerged piecemeal. Does it make sense to give teachers a 5.5 percent raise if the price is truly 15,000 layoffs? Should the city hire all 6,479 new police officers if that means closing libraries or curtailing foster care?
Those may or may not be the choices. There's no way to know because Mr. Dinkins has yet to present them coherently. Indeed, last week's lurches impel some people to wonder if Mr. Dinkins wouldn't be wise to undo the teacher settlement, suspend the crime proposal and start over.
That would be a grave retreat, but the problems are grave. Real estate is in trouble. So are finance and insurance. Media and advertising are sagging. And this year, it is costing the city more to operate than it budgeted for. It is not too late for Mr. Dinkins to recoup. But to do that, he'll have to offer a steady plan the public can understand. If they know why, people will grumble but accept sacrifice. Otherwise the Mayor, and New York, will be left in the lurch.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Residential Listings Growing Around Lake Tahoe

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, CALIF.

 BODY:
 But nobody expects values to be as severely hit as they have been on the West Coast or in the Northeast. Environmental concerns for the purity of the lake -- folklore suggests that a dinner plate is visible 120 feet below the surface -- have so tightly controlled the opportunity for development since 1983 that the supply of homes at any price is limited.
 Further holding off a plunge in prices is the buoyant effect of the foreign money pouring into what has become a world-class resort.
"We've had a strong international market for some time," said Adele Lucas, president of the South Lake Tahoe Board of Realtors. "They hear about us on TV sports, on 'Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.' " Typical buyers, she said, are from Japan, Mexico, Europe and South America. 
 Another factor is that market conditions on the Nevada side of the lake seem to mirror the property boom elsewhere in Nevada, which could further ameliorate the wider chill.
 The Lake Tahoe basin encompasses more than 100 square miles over 6,000 feet above sea level. The lake itself is 22 miles long and 12 miles wide, with the border between California and Nevada slicing through its center. Five counties -- three in California and two in Nevada -- and some 15 towns make up the 71 miles of shore area, which has 72 beaches, 14 marinas and 950 boat slips.
 More than a dozen cross-country and downhill ski centers rise from that shoreline, often hidden from view by the dense firs and pines that cover most of the surrounding mountains. Communities run the gamut from exclusive enclaves like Incline Village and Glenbrook on the steeper Nevada side to this one in the relatively flat, more populous area south of the lake. More than 80 percent of the basin's land area is owned by state or Federal agencies or land conservancies.
Brokers estimate that values at Incline Village are higher right now than anywhere else in the basin. Currently listed for sale there, for example, is a 5.9-acre lakeside estate with a main house, a guest house, a tennis court, 250 feet of beachfront and a pier. The asking price is $12 million, possibly the highest ever. Moreover, figures compiled by the Incline Village Board of Realtors show that there have been only 425 homes in that village listed for sale to date this year, compared to 547 in September 1989, a 22.3 percent drop.
The numbers represent condominiums, single-family houses and estates, with houses averaging about $380,000 and condominiums around $150,000 each. Prices of comparable properties on the more southerly California shore tend to be 30 percent less.
In this city of 21,000 year-round residents, for example, a 4,600-square-foot Tudor mansion with 100 feet of lakefront in the exclusive Tahoe Keys development carries an asking price of $1.85 million. A few hundred yards inland, in the same complex, a new 2,400-square-foot house is priced at $375,000.
 And even here residents are taking no chances. This city is in the initial phase of a $154 million commercial redevelopment plan that is already sweeping away the cheap motels, dilapidated gas stations and tacky retail shacks that gave Route 50 -- the main thoroughfare through the town -- a shabby look.
 "We didn't have the upscale appearance of Vail or Aspen," said David G. Dobson, assistant executive director of the South Tahoe Redevelopment Agency. "So unless we got rid of some of the older facilities and broadened the market we could have been left behind."
Lake Tahoe's birth as a resort dates to the turn of the century, when some prominent Bay Area families carved huge estates out of the pristine hillside and made it fashionable to spend the summer here. More modest families quickly followed, clearing smaller lots for simpler cabins.
Even today, the resort caters to a vast demographic and economic spread, with vacation homes ranging from a $60,000 co-op to that $12 million estate and with luxury hotels standing side by side with the local Motel 6.
At first, development was heaviest on the more accessible California side, and it catered mainly to that summer crowd. But as winter sports grew in popularity in the 50's, the resort began to capitalize on its superb slope and snow conditions and long, clear, sunny winter days. Adding to the natural bounty on the Nevada side was the growth of casinos, which helped draw an even more broadly based crowd.
The housing needs of service workers led to a demand for modestly priced homes. Cheap rental neighborhoods, many patched together from original cabins, began to spring up and started an outcry for more affordable housing that even today dominates local politics.
 But that was not easy to achieve. Worried that pell-mell development was blighting the lake's natural qualities, which was bad for the environment and the economy, local leaders established the bi-state Tahoe Regional Planning Agency in 1969 to impose rigid controls. The agency sets strict limits on the number of new homes that may be built each year and on which sites qualify. It is considered one of the few regional agencies with enough power to override state or municipal planning decisions and enforce its own regional plan.
 The current program, started in 1986 and ending in 1991, allows for 300 new units a year, said David Ziegler, the executive director, with the units apportioned between the five counties making up the lake area and generally awarded either by lottery or on a first-come, first-served basis. Only sites that already have an environmental score that puts them in an acceptable development category qualify. What will be permitted after 1991 is not yet decided, Mr. Ziegler said.
 Partially as a result, a brisk, albeit controversial, market is developing for the transfer of development rights similar to the trading of air rights in New York City. Builders, for example, will buy an old cabin in a poor site for about $30,000, raze it and transfer the "right" to that unit to a more desirable parcel where they may put up a large luxury home. Or they will become partners with someone who owns land and won an allotment.
 Chris Strohm, president of Strohm Construction and president-elect of the South Lake Tahoe Chamber of Commerce, for example, is using a client's 1990 allotment to build a four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 2,100-square-foot contemporary home on a third of an acre of steep hillside in an inland location here close to the casinos and ski slopes. To be completed in October, its asking price is $265,000, about the same as it might have been a year ago.
 For the 90's Mr. Ziegler expects "a lot more rebuilding and revitalization" with bigger, more luxurious houses replacing many of the cabins and simpler homes of bygone years and dozens of still-vacant home sites likely to be bought by state, local agencies and land conservancies.
 The much-needed multifamily housing for the service workers is expected to be about a half-hour inland from the protected lake basin, possibly in Douglas County, Nev. The current steel grip on expansion that has protected the lake is unlikely to be loosened in the foreseeable future, officials insist.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lakeside houses in South Lake Tahoe, Calif. The dwelling at left is selling for $1.8 million (Andree Brooks for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 1, Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1874 words

HEADLINE: When Singles Meet, They Do More Than Party

BYLINE: By JUDY GLASS

 BODY:
IN the strobe lights of the Long Island Exchange at the Huntington Hilton, throngs of men and women danced to rock music while hundreds jammed the bars and aisles, watching the dance floor.
At a ''30's and Over Night,'' the people - ''mostly single,'' the management said - migrated to the buffet and jockeyed for an opening at the bar.
Scanning faces in the dark, they watched for a glimmer of interest, a responsive smile or a friendly gesture. The ear-shattering music did not allow for talk beyond an offer to dance or a suggestion to escape to the lobby to get acquainted.
In the midst of the scene was a table of Singles for Charities fliers, buttons and placards. Members sought volunteers to work with groups like the American Heart Association or the Cerebral Palsy Association. 
''A lot of people in our organization would not ordinarily go to a disco,'' said Jan Krivosheiw, president and founder of Singles for Charities, who said she did not usually go to discos. ''But the hotels invite us to hold our meetings in their conference rooms as an enticement, and some of our members go to their discos afterward. They usually have a good time, even if the women wind up dancing with each other.''
 
Number of Singles Tallied
The State Labor Department estimates that there were 526,000 never-married singles older than 16 and 288,000 divorced, separated and widowed singles last year on Long Island.
Catering to them has become an industry that did not exist 10 years ago on Long Island, said many organization leaders.
The hotel function and the charity group are among hundreds of social clubs, organizations and dance clubs that have sprung up on Long Island in the last few years to attract the thousands of single people who want more than to watch television and cut the lawn.
Some single people go out every night to a party, a meeting, a class or a disco. ''Most pick one or two functions a week, as it can get pretty expensive,'' said Miss Krivosheiw, a behavioral therapist who lives in Syosset.
Memberships in the organizations range from $25 to $500 a year, with additional charges for individual events and trips. The groups include highly organized profit-making businesses with paid administrative staffs to entrepreneurs who run house parties at $10 to $25 a person, sometimes attracting hundreds of people. Some organizations, like the Roslyn Country Club, sponsor ''gala'' cocktail parties, with a cash bar.
The activities attract mainly singles from their mid-30's to mid-60's, but all have members in their 20's, especially the more sports-oriented groups like those that hold tennis parties. The parties typically offer two hours of doubles arranged by playing level, with time in between for a buffet and socializing. The average fee is $25 a person for participants, and less for observers.
''Declarations of age limitations in the advertising should not be taken too seriously,'' said a disgruntled partygoer, who paid $12 to go to a dance advertised for singles from 35 to 55. Once inside, where there was a cash bar, the 40-year-old woman found herself conspicuously younger than the rest of the crowd, ''who more accurately ranged from 45 to 75,'' she said.
When she complained, the host at the door said that some of the partygoers had begun attending when they were under 55 and that he could not very well ask for proof of age.
Marital status poses similar problems. Some organizations try to limit themselves strictly to singles, divorced and widowed, like Divorced and Separated Catholics. Others present themselves as ''predominantly single.''
But it is generally recognized that single status may include people who are not legally separated. There are clearly no restrictions on age or marital status at the hotels, discos and bars.
The hotel functions have become especially strong competitors for the singles business, say the owners of local bars and lounges, which steadily lost customers in the health-conscious 80's.
The crowds may repel some singles, but they increase the odds of meeting someone. ''They give people a chance to dress up and look their best while they are out there,'' said Camy Covais, at the Hilton, who is also a member of Long Island Single Sailors Association.
Although the clubs may be organized around special interests like golf, tennis, sailing or skiing, ''they are, first of all, social groups,'' said John Bilella of Blue Point, past president of the Suffolk Skidaddlers, a predominantly singles club that has been meeting weekly for 30 years.
There are beach parties, hiking, bicycle or tubing trips and cruises. In season there are ski trips almost every weekend and an annual European excursion.
''It's an adult club where people aren't inhibited by the presence of children, as they are in more family oriented singles clubs,'' Mr. Bilella said. ''People become friends outside of club activities, unlike ski groups that just get together for a group rate and don't see each other in between.''
In organizations,'' said John R. Nelson of Oyster Bay, a builder and an organizer of Singles for Charities, ''people get to know each other in a relaxed spontaneous way, as opposed to the bar scene, where there's a lot of competition.''
Three-quarters of the club, which grew to 700 members in its first year and a half, is female. ''But men are learning to give as well as to take,'' said Mr. Nelson.
''Ten years ago it was common for singles to hang out in bars, drinking all night, and there were many more bars on Long Island,'' Mr. Bilella said. ''Then two things happened. People became more health conscious, and the Suffolk County police began to crack down on D.W.I.'s. There were a lot of pickup clubs and bars on Long Island then that are no longer in business. And the bar business in general has been suffering ever since.''
 
Reflecting New Pursuits
''Becoming single in your 40's or 50's can change your life style,'' said George Paterson, past commodore of Long Island Single Sailors' Association. ''Sailing is a fairly healthy activity. The people I want to associate with are into healthy pursuits, watching their diets, cutting down on alcohol consumption and exercising more.
''Being single is an added incentive to take care of yourself. If a married man loses 50 pounds, it might go unnoticed. It makes a real difference if you're single.''
Mr. Paterson, an educator who has been married two times, said many newly single people were so desperate to marry that they did it for the wrong reasons.
''It takes a good four or five years to become emotionally comfortable with yourself and to be able to look at marriage with some perspective,'' he said.
Lynn Thompson of Huntington, a partner in a pension-consulting business, said, ''Women who become economically independent and no longer have children at home can now choose partnerships that offer them friendships and enjoyment, rather than the protection and need that may have motivated them in the old days.''
 
'Friendship and Companionship'
The Skidaddlers group used to average seven marriages a year, ''but marriage isn't always the objective,'' said the president, Tony Calafiore of Selden, who met his wife on a club trip in 1985. ''People, especially those who are newly single, want friendship and companionship. They want to do something, and they don't always know what.
''Through the organizations, people meet others with similar interests. They may become involved in activities and sports they never would have tried when they were married.''
''Couch potatoes become downhill racers,'' said a Skidaddler at the weekly meeting in the Celebrity Lounge in North Babylon.
Long Island, as many singles in the area know, was nominated in a national poll as one of the worst places to be single, because women outnumber men 5 to 1.
 
Changes in 10 Years
''Also, getting around in the suburbs is much harder than in Manhattan,'' said Linda Grimaldi of Manhattan, who recently married a Long Islander she met on a Skidaddler trip. ''In the city there's far more flexibility, and you can always go to another club if you don't like the one you're at. Out here people go to one place and stay.''
Dancing is just as important an activity as sailing or skiing, said Ms. Covais, the nurse who is also in the sailors' association, which meets at the Australian Country Inn in Fort Salonga. But socializing has changed in the last 10 years, people in her group said.
''The AIDS epidemic has made people more selective in their choice of partners and more careful than they used to be,'' said Ms. Covais, who was interviewed with a group of friends at the Huntington Hilton. ''Women I know are taking the use of condoms more seriously and trying to find out more about a person's relationship history before they go out. The question is can you believe what people tell you?''
''Definitely not,'' said a friend, Inge Couteller of Huntington, who works in advertising sales. ''It's impossible to know unless a person has checked out O.K. on an HIV test, and even then you can't be sure. You have to use condoms until you're ready for total monogamy.''
 
'Like Crossing the Street'
''Adult singles are certainly not ready for total celibacy,'' a man in the group said. ''It's like crossing the street. You look both ways, but you still cross.''
The group was asked whether people still date in the traditional sense, when one person arranges a meeting and pays for the evening.
''Yes, but it doesn't mean the same thing,'' said a woman in her 40's who has never been married. ''You may think a man is really interested in you if he asks you to go away for a weekend. Then you find out that he took another woman away the weekend before and is seeing a third woman in between. There are just too many single women on Long Island.''
 
Friends of the Opposite Sex
''A lot of singles want to become part of a couple again, but a lot don't,'' said Miss Krivosheiw of Singles for Charities.
Many singles said they welcomed having friends of the opposite sex, a phenomenon that was not so common a few years ago.
''Long Island singles are definitely maturing,'' said Bob Matherson, owner of the Oak Beach Inn, a disco and restaurant on the beach between the Robert Moses Causeway and Jones Beach. The inn had been known for years as a gathering place for never-married younger singles who danced and drank until the sun came up or until they were stopped on a drunken-driving charge on the parkway, Mr. Matherson said. The inn now has an over-35 night every Monday and an over-25 night every Tuesday.
''My old customers are getting older,'' Mr. Matherson said. ''Younger singles can't afford Long Island, and the change in the legal drinking age has affected business.
The inn offers free drinks to women almost every night, a free barbecue, a sing-along, a band and two disk jockeys on its dance floors and outside deck overlooking the water.
''Competition among the dance clubs on Long Island has become fierce,'' Mr. Matherson said. ''About 10 hotels have opened in the last few years, and most have dance clubs and singles nights. You have to make sure people have a good time if you want them to keep coming back.''

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 24, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 775 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
It's 8 P.M. Do You Know Where Dinner Is?

BYLINE: By MARILYN A. GELMAN

 BODY:
THE dinner bell chimes a different tune for suburban single parents and their families.
The seven basic food groups of grade-school home economics never prepared us for the mealtime impact of our other basic dietary determinants: employment status, the children's ages and grandma's life style.
The single parent's employment status determines whether there's time to cook or money for groceries, the health of the family credit card and whether breakfast or dinner is the family's main meal.
The children's ages determine their chopping and stove permissions and their access to banks, supermarkets and the diner near the train station. 
Grandma's life style determines whether she cooks, invites or sends leftovers.
Our youngsters adjust to a variety of mealtime signals. In my house, early morning smoke-alarm sirens meant ''breakfast''; the shout of ''Dinner!'' sent the kids to the door to accept a delivery.
Eventually, children of working single parents develop self-defensive cooking skills. Often at odd hours, the family begins to have family meals.
By the time my sons were 9 and 13, I had asserted, ''The person who brings home the bacon shouldn't have to cook it or clean up after it.'' No more would I commute home to hungry birds chirping in the nest. No more would I bear the sole responsibility for making a single-parent family work. No longer would I see us as a broken home. I stuck to my guns. I didn't cook. I didn't order in. I didn't shop.
Finally, one evening, a warm smell greeted me at the front door. The table was set, pots were dancing on the stove and my sons were beaming with accomplishment.
We had tomato-pepper stew with brown rice and garlic bread. We forced down our ice-cream dessert. And so my sons began to help me paddle our canoe upstream.
In the following years, traditional fare gave way to the mysterious. The boys directed food shopping activities. If I worked late without calling, I was reprimanded for ruining meals.
We ate well-balanced vegetarian dinners cooked from scratch, using seasonal vegetables (some I had never seen before). Our complexions glowed, our hair shone and my food bill was cut in half.
No one told my sons that bechamel sauce was difficult or spinach lasagne too much work. The boys pretended that cookbooks were chemistry sets and measured and mixed their potions with precision. We had stuffed peppers, onions with a chocolate macaroon filling, and stuffed zucchini with cheese sauce. One son shopped, one son chopped; then, one cooked and one cleaned up. In every way, we were filled.
If the boys didn't cooperate, no one ate. The brothers formed a special bond.
All too soon, college breaks up the working single parent's kitchen staff.
Unlike the old days, when children moved on and the recipes stayed home, our kids take our favorite meals with them.
Free of meal plan bondage, the fledglings cook all the family specialties in their college dorms while their working single parents, willing to kill for a hot, home-cooked meal, count cholesterol and calories at fast-food restaurants' drive-through windows.
Hungrily, suburban empty-nested single parents anticipate college vacations. We yearn for familiar cooking aromas to greet us on the front porch and to descend on the diner near the train station as a gang again.
We're eager for family members to break bread together. We relish telling stories of our mealtime triumphs and tragedies.
The younger boy chortles over the evening he put his noncustodial on an outbound train after an early dinner date, then picked me up from the next inbound train for his dessert.
I remember the prepaid pizza I sent to the house on an evening I ate out, alone. My multiple roles had drained me.
They tell stories of my last kitchen efforts: the time the spaghetti sauce sprayed over the walls and ceiling, the time I put my thumb through the 45-year-old pipe under the sink, my conviction that there must be a fire in the house because my pancakes couldn't create that much smoke, the time I was unemployed and made them farm-fresh eggs and homemade biscuits from scratch and percolated coffee on top of the stove.
We remember the 4 A.M. trips to the diner for breakfast when our schedules had made us strangers and I missed them too much; and, in later years, the race to the train station. If they got there first, dinner was on my credit card; if I got there first, they cooked.
Now, at ages 20 and 24, they tell me about the candlelight dinners they prepare and encourage me with, ''But Mom, quiche isn't hard to make.''
Mealtimes: some of my most fulfilling memories of suburban single parenthood.
