SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1251 words

HEADLINE: Louisiana Tally Is Seen as a Sign Of Voter Unrest

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7

 BODY:
A day after J. Bennett Johnston was elected to a fourth term in the United States Senate, the talk here was of the degree of support for the man he beat, David Duke, a State Representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader.
In a year of widespread voter unrest, the fact that Mr. Duke won 44 percent of the vote and more than half of the white vote was viewed as a potent sign of the discontent and frustration among the electorate.
''The voters are really angry and volatile and looking for some kind of savior, some kind of outsider,'' said Lawrence N. Powell, a Tulane University history professor. ''Certainly, there's a strong racial backlash, but just as powerful is this anti-incumbency backlash.''
 
For Some, a Clear Message
For some, the message of Mr. Duke's surprising showing was clear. Several suburban youths in town for a night at the French Quarter said they did not know much about politics, but knew what they like. And they liked what they heard from David Duke. 
''The blacks are just taking everything,'' said Grenes Neyaski, one of a half dozen college-age youths jostling to voice support for Mr. Duke. ''They're taking everything from us, and the white race is going down the tubes. It's about time someone spoke up for white people.''
Mr. Johnston, who won with 54 percent of the vote, acknowledged that many of the votes cast for his opponent ''were protest votes.''
''People were venting their spleen,'' he said. ''They said, 'Well, I'm going to send old Bennett a message.' Bennett got the message.''
For his part, Mr. Duke said, ''This is an affirmation of my faith in the people of this state, their good heartedness and their Christian spirit,''
 
National Political Profile
The large showing for Mr. Duke invigorated his political career, but also highlighted his ability to build a national political profile on the back of an almost unbroken record of losing races.
Mr. Duke's ability to get 44 percent of the vote in the face of widespread condemnation of his extremist, racially charged political history overshadowed his defeat. But analysts voiced numerous caveats in analyzing it.
Joe Walker, a New Orleans poll taker, noted that in 1978 Mr. Johnston won by an almost identical margin against another extreme conservative, Woody Jenkins, who is now a state legislator.
''You take away Duke's notoriety, and philosophically, the races are about the same,'' he said.
Similarly, some analysts said Mr. Duke's vote totals may have risen because of the withdrawal of the official Republican nominee, Ben Bagert, two days before the nonpartisan primary. There is speculation that the appearance of a deal between the Republican establishment and Mr. Johnston helped Mr. Duke and that some voters, knowing Mr. Duke was not likely to win, felt comfortable casting a protest vote for him.
In addition, preliminary estimates based on the votes in selected precincts showed that blacks did not turn out as strongly as expected, with the rate 15 percent less than for whites. Had turnout been equal, Mr. Duke's vote would have been below the 40 percent level that analysts had expected.
 
Widespread Shock
Still, there was widespread shock here about the degree to which white voters supported Mr. Duke. While no precise figures were available, analysts estimated that the high white turnout meant Mr. Duke had received about 55 percent of the white vote.
And the election campaign, which played out in an atmosphere of fear and antagonism, added another dark note to a state and a city grappling with troubling racial divisions and an economy that slumped nearly a decade ago with the decline of the oil industry and never recovered. Many voters, still feeling the pinch of a tight job market, are resentful of what they consider Government giveaway programs to people who are unwilling to work.
Mr. Duke appealed directly to those fears, advocating an end to affirmative action programs and requirements that some Government contracts be set aside for minority contractors. His speeches were filled with menacing stories and anecdotes about what he called ''the rising welfare underclass.''
 
'Fed Up With Politics'
Mr. Duke's supporters gathered to watch the returns at the Lion's Club in suburban Harahan on Saturday. They said they were there not just to cheer Mr. Duke but also to thumb their noses at the establishment politics that Mr. Johnston represented to them.
''I have been so upset, fed up with politics,'' said Janet Driscoll, a Metairie woman who described herself as a conservative Republican. ''If I could cut it off and let it sink into the sea I would.
''The reason they fear Duke so much is because he is shaking the power structure of this nation. I am so furious, I could kill the Democrats myself.''
Many of the Duke supporters bitterly denied racist motives in supporting him.
''All over, people say, 'What a bunch of bigots in Louisiana,' '' said Chris Schade, a 30-year-old electrical engineering student from Metairie. ''I want you to know, I voted for him not because of his background, but in spite of it. We don't want to go back to segregation, we just want equal rights for everyone.''
Still, for many the line between grievance and racial hostility is a thin one.
Thus, the youths with Mr. Neyaski alternated between advocating fair treatment for whites and shouts of ''White power'' or the giving of Nazi salutes.
''My girlfriend had a 3.8 average in high school and there was a black girl that had a 3.2,'' Mr. Neyaski said. ''She got a scholarship to L.S.U., and my girlfriend didn't. That's bull. You give them an inch, they take a mile. They should be back in chains.''
Critics say Mr. Duke's followers are playing a dangerous game in thinking they can dissociate themselves from his history of extremist politics.
''The Duke voters think they can play with fire and not get burned,'' said the Rev. James Stovall, head of the Louisiana Coalition, a group of clergy and others opposed to Mr. Duke.
For some, the vague sense of menace that accompanied the race had an unsettling air of familiarity in a city increasingly touched by crime and economic problems.
Britton Trice, owner of a bookstore in the Garden District of New Orleans, received a bomb threat after distributing anti-Duke bumper stickers. Not long after, his wife, Ann, and their 4-year-old daughter were walking to return a videotape when a group of black youths on bicycles rode around them in circles, taunting them, she said.
The threat and the taunting incident brought home the degree to which the race reflected unsettling things about the current environment, Mrs. Trice said.
''I find Duke's support scary,'' she said. ''But I feel really disgusted with things, the level of crime in particular. I think I could have voted for him if it wasn't for his background.''
Immediately after the election, Mr. Duke's supporters began talking about a gubernatorial race. Skeptics say he has made a career of gaining publicity by losing races.
''He's not going to get elected to any statewide office,'' Mr. Johnston said. ''He may run. That's what he likes to do is run.''
But it was clear his showing and the fervor of his followers could make him a political force for years to come.
''My greatest hope is that the movement against racism in Louisiana continues,'' said Beth Rickey, a Republican committeewoman who was one of the founders of the anti-Duke alliance, ''because Duke is going to be around for a long time.''

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE/The Industrial Midwest
A special report;
Midwest's Heartbeat Still Heard In the Steady Hum of Factories

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCKFORD, Ill.

 BODY:
In the bleak winter of 1982-83, one of every four workers in this aging industrial city was out of work, and Rockford had the country's highest unemployment rate. Like other factory cities across the Midwest, crippled by competition from foreign producers of steel and machine tools and automobiles, Rockford was bleeding away its jobs and its people.
Seven years later, Illinois's second-largest city, like the rest of the industrial heartland, has made a slow, if sometimes uneven, recovery. Bit by bit, the Rockford area has gotten back nearly half of the manufacturing jobs it lost early in the decade. Help-wanted signs hang outside some factories, and new stores and shopping plazas push into the cornfields at the edge of town.
''I don't think we will ever take the kind of hits we did in the past,'' said Carl J. Dargene, the president and chief executive officer of Amcore Financial Inc., the largest bank in this city of 140,000. ''We have a lot of companies now that are just more capable of riding out any turbulence in the economy.'' 
Less than a decade after analysts wrote off the industrial heartland as America's ''rust belt,'' suggesting a forlorn landscape of cold, decaying cities and deserted factories, the region's economy is hanging tougher than those of other parts of the nation, and in many ways is actually faring better.
 
Steady Goes the Tortoise
As in the fable of the tortoise and the hare, much of the Midwest - left badly behind during the 1980's by the sprinting economies of the East and West Coasts - has slowly and surely plodded its way back by demonstrating that there is profit in doing what the Midwest has always done best: making things.
To be sure, the region's economy remains vulnerable, and the Persian Gulf crisis and soaring oil prices have taken their toll in the Midwest as in the rest of the nation. There are sharpened fears of layoffs and plant closings in Michigan and other states still heavily dependent on the automobile industry. Unemployment rates in Illinois and Michigan were 7.2 percent in September, well above the national average of 5.7 percent.
And the Midwest's rebound has not benefited everyone equally. While the volume of steel and autos and machine tools from the region's factories is as high as it has ever been, manufacturing employment will never regain the peaks of the late 1970's. That is because a growing emphasis on more efficient production techniques, including automation, has sharply reduced the need for less skilled blue-collar workers.
 
Mortgage Defaults Are Low
Still, in the larger picture, economists say the region's relative stability, including the growing volume of its industrial exports over the last three years, has helped keep the national economy from tumbling into recession.
While the Northeast and parts of the West reel from volatile real estate and labor markets, cutbacks in military spending and sharp reductions in retail spending, the cost of land and labor in the Midwest have remained fairly constant. Mortgage defaults are low and consumer spending has shown modest growth.
A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago last month said that although construction and real estate activity had slowed, they ''remained healthier in the Midwest than in the nation as a whole.'' Even manufacturers reported a slow expansion in recent months.
A major factor in the region's rebound over the last three years has been the weakness of the dollar in international currency markets, which drove down the cost of American products relative to their foreign competitors and, in turn, fueled demand for the steel and other durable goods that are the bedrock of the economy in the Midwest more than in any other region.
James E. Annable, the chief economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, said that even the impact of higher oil prices on the Midwest economy would be mitigated substantially by the fact that the turbulence in world energy markets would continue to depress the value of the dollar. Mr. Annable said changes now taking place in Europe would provide Midwestern manufacturers an even larger stage on which to work.
 
Remembering Hard Lessons
Meanwhile, Midwestern manfacturers stung by the recession of the early 1980's have cut costs, looked for market niches that other companies do not fill and invested in new technology to sharpen their competitive edge.
Ted Brolund, the president of the W.A. Whitney Corporation, a Rockford manufacturer that produces heavy-duty machine tools for makers of farm equipment and other manufacturers, said his company has invested several million dollars in recent years to automate its assembly lines.
When the farm economy began to turn around about three years ago and the dollar dropped in overseas markets, Mr. Brolund said, the company was positioned to respond. Now it does 40 percent of its business overseas.
In Cleveland, the Advance Manufacturing Company once employed 60 workers making dies for automobile and appliance manufacturers. But by the early 1980's, with the company down to five employees and swimming in red ink, it borrowed to retool, switching from industrial dies to making speciality parts for the steel, plastics and machine-tool industries.
Now the company employs only half the workers it did a decade ago, but Kenneth Bailey, the vice president, said it expects to turn a $246,000 profit this year on sales of $2.8 million, and expansion is under way.
The region's rebound over the last eight years, Mr. Annable said, has vindicated Midwestern bankers and businessmen, who clung to their faith in the region's manufacturing potential. ''As we used to say in the dark days of 1983,'' Mr. Annable recited, ''In rust we trust.''
 
Problems
 
If Not Decay, Then Stagnation?
Not everyone is so sanguine about the region's economic prospects. Although it is not declining at nearly the same rate it did in the early part of the decade, population trends in the region remain, at best, flat.
Sherwin Rosen, who is chairman of the economics department of the University of Chicago, says that while he too is impressed by the current vitality of the region's manufacturing sector, he believes that the Midwest will have a difficult time over the long run keeping pace with other parts of the nation.
''The decline of the Midwest is inevitable,'' Mr. Rosen said, repeating an argument he made at a regional economic seminar last year. ''There is nothing good or bad about it; it will just decline.''
Among other things, he argues that the region holds no special advantage for service industries, which continue to be the fast-growing source of new jobs, and that those jobs will follow people to other climates, other places. ''For many young people, the Midwest is a less attractive region to live and work,'' he said.
The shifts in the region's manufacturing economy have also forced some painful adjustments. While the Federal Reserve says industrial output from the region is at a level equal to that of the late 1970's, when industry was near its peak, Midwest factories employ far fewer workers than they did a decade ago.
Because of a growing reliance on automation and new technologies, some factories look as if they have been hit by a kind of economic neutron bomb, which left assembly lines running at full speed but eliminated most of the people who worked on them.
At the USX Corporation's huge plant in Gary, Ind., for example, the mills turn out nearly as much steel as they did in 1977, when production reached its all-time peak. But now they do it with only 7,800 workers, rather than the 21,000 of a decade ago.
The toll of such cutbacks has fallen mostly on the legions of unskilled labor. According to Donald R. Grimes, an economist at the University of Michigan, unemployment rates for managers, professionals and skilled technicians in Michigan are now running below 2 percent, while the unemployment rate for unskilled, basic laborers is about 13.5 percent. The national unemployment rate for laborers is about 10.5 percent.
''You can see the impact of these structural changes on the streets of Detroit or Cleveland or any of the major urban areas,'' Mr. Grimes said.
In Rockford, the number of people employed has climbed more than 22 percent since 1982, to a record high of 134,700. Yet only a small number of those who are closest to the bottom have been helped. In June 1983, near the nadir of the local economy, more than 13,000 people received public welfare grants in Rockford. Last year, the total was just over 12,500.
 
Opportunities
Some Areas Buoyed By Service Jobs
 While manufacturing remains the engine of the Midwest economy - the Federal Reserve estimates that 37 percent of jobs in the region are tied to manufacturing - most of the jobs created here, as in the rest of the nation, are in service industries.
Although service jobs in general pay less than manufacturing, the economies of several Midwestern cities have ridden a wave of business expansion. Minneapolis, Indianapolis and Columbus, Ohio, have reaped a windfall of new service industry jobs, in part as companies have moved to the Middle West to take advantage of lower land costs and a strong base of skilled labor.
Several major national corporations have moved their credit-card processing operations to Des Moines, creating more than 2,500 jobs there since the mid-1980's.
The American Electric Power Service Corporation, a holding company for utilities in eight states, said economics were a strong reason behind the company's decision to move its headquarters and 515 employees from New York City to Columbus in the early 1980's.
But quality of life - shorter commuting times, for example - was also a factor. Peter J. DeMaria, executive vice president for administration, said that when the company offered to move employees back to New York at company expense, only 10 took them up on it.
In Indianapolis, a surge in service-sector employment in the metropolitan area has added 116,000 jobs to the economy since 1985 - an increase of 21 percent. New jobs in health care alone grew by nearly 40 percent in Indianapolis between 1983 and 1988, the highest rate in the nation, according to a study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
Some of the new jobs have come from an unlikely source: Japanese companies. In 1989 alone, according to a report by the Consulate General of Japan in Chicago, the number of Japanese companies in Michigan, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota, Ohio and Wisconsin grew by 20 percent, to 1,048. At the same time, employment in these companies grew by 66 percent, or more than 103,000 workers, according to the report. Japanese companies have opened units elsewhere in the nation, but the trend is especially strong in the Midwest.
David S. Dahl, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said the Midwest's economy has benefited because real estate prices have remained relatively stable and below national averages. Bankers in Chicago say mortgage and loan defaults are at their lowest levels in years, in sharp contrast to the Northeast.
''Because the Midwest was not overextended, it now looks more and more attractive to companies on the outside,'' Mr. Dahl said.
A study by the First National Bank of Chicago pointed to another factor that has insulated the region from the problems afflicting parts of Southern California, the Rockies and the Northeast: the relatively low level of military spending in the Midwest.
Just as the sharp escalation in defense spending helped fuel the economic boom in New England and other areas during the 1980's, the change in Federal spending patterns is now pinching those same regions.
In addition, certain historical factors that helped push jobs and people away from the Midwest are no longer the negatives they once were, said Robert H. Schnorbus, the senior economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
For example, while manufacturing wage scales in the Midwest are still higher than the United States average, growing demand for labor in the South has driven up wages there, reducing the regional disparity.
 
Changes
Smaller Companies, Fewer Smokestacks
 As Midwest industry has adjusted, the changes are reflected in the landscape. There are many more smaller companies, working out of factories without smokestacks, set among grassy landscapes in new industrial parks along Route 271 outside Cleveland, or south of Rockford.
One of those companies is GMN-Torrington, a German ball-bearing manufacturer which opened its one-story plant here in the summer of 1989, with 20 workers. It now employs 50, on three shifts. Michael Beutel, the president and chief operating officer, said Rockford has the advantage, as do other Midwestern cities, of a good network of small shops, trained toolmakers and supply houses.
By most measures, the economy in Rockford - where unemployment of nearly 25 percent in 1983 was the highest in the nation - is doing relatively well. There has not been as much diversification as city boosters would like, since one in every three jobs is still in a factory. But unemployment hovers around 6 percent, sales-tax revenues jumped 8 percent last year and sales of new houses in the first six months of 1990 were running ahead of a year earlier.
Moreover, said Thomas J. de Seve, manager of the United States Department of Commerce branch office in Rockford, there has been a strong increase in the last six years in the volume of manufactured goods produced in Rockford and sold overseas. The total has grown from less than $10 million in 1984 to about $136 million projected for 1990.
Jack W. Packard, the president of Elco Industries, an automotive supplier, said ''I think it's going to get grayer before it gets brighter'' economically. But he says his company, like Rockford and the rest of the old industrial Midwest, is a survivor. It has spent $56 million in new capital investments, found new markets and is entering into a joint venture with a Japanese producer.
''As much as they talk about diversification and service jobs, this is still a factory town, and I say thank goodness for that,'' said Mr. Packard. ''Just think where the country would be right now if we had given up, if we had all let the rust belt blow away.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
New Proposal's Lack of Detail Leaves Room to Compromise

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The bipartisan budget plan that Congressional leaders outlined to rank-and-file lawmakers today would mean less severe cuts in the Medicare program than the plan rejected by the House early Friday. It would also leave room for a deal in which taxes on capital gains would be cut in exchange for raising income tax rates for the wealthy.
While the proposal includes no specifics about the Medicare program, lawmakers said it would allow the Congressional tax committees to take $18 billion less out of the program in the next five years than the $60 billion that had been stipulated in the rejected budget plan.
Legislators said this would mean smaller increases in monthly Medicare premiums for the elderly, to $47 a month by 1995, rather than the $54.30 a month in 1995 that had been stipulated in last week's budget agreement. The premium level is now $28.60 a month. 
Lawmakers said cutting less from the program would also require a smaller increase in the amount that recipients must pay in doctor bills before their Medicare insurance takes over. The deductible, now $75, would rise to $100 in 1991 and remain there, rather than rising to $150 by 1995, as proposed in the original agreement.
The increase in Medicare payments was a major source of opposition from a number of Democrats to last week's compromise, and today's effort was intended to reassure lawmakers who were under pressure from groups representing elderly Americans. Democrats said the groups had endorsed today's plan.
Lawmakers were also told that under the framework of today's plan a 2-cent-a-gallon tax on home heating oil that had been stipulated in the original agreement was likely to be dropped because of strong opposition from members in Northeastern states. Another provision requiring a two-week waiting period for unemployment insurance benefits is also likely to be dropped.
But the most important feature of the new plan is an absence of specifics, and Congressional leaders hope this will speed its passage.
 
Bitter Fights Are Seen
While such an arrangement may get Congress over the short-term hurdle of agreeing to a general deficit reduction plan, it also means that many of the bitterest fights over taxes and spending will now simply be waged in the committees over the next two weeks before they are sent to Congress and then to President Bush for approval.
Like the plan rejected in the House on Friday, the new proposal would seek to cut $40 billion from the Federal deficit in the current fiscal year and $500 billion over five years. Democratic leaders in the House spent most of today in conferences with their Senate counterparts and moderate Senate Repubicans trying to refine the agreement so that it could be adopted in the House tonight.
That agreement will not spell out any of the details on Medicare, but those given to House Democrats were designed to make the proposed package more acceptable to liberals who dominate the House Democratic Caucus. Although Democrats had initially demanded that any budget agreement be endorsed by a majority of Republicans as well, they now appear to have to pass the agreement in the House largely with Democratic votes.
Bitterly divided House Republicans did not attend the budget conferences and the senior Republicans on the House and Senate budget committees late tonight refused to sign off on the new budget plan. But Senate Republican leaders said that they were prepared to move the process forward and that their refusal did not necessarily mean they would not support the plan in the Senate.
Mr. Foley and Administration officials also hinted strongly today that the Congressional tax committees would be looking at a deal that would give Republicans the cut in capital gains taxes that President Bush has long sought in exchange for an increase in the top tax rate for those with the highest incomes. Democrats have argued that a capital gains tax cut would primarily benefit high-income taxpayers and that an increase in income tax rates for taxpayers with incomes over $200,000 would be needed to keep the tax system fair.
Neither capital gains taxes nor income tax rates were altered in the original compromise. Under the new proposal, the tax-writing committees will be told to raise $134 billion in new revenue over the next five years, and will be directed to find an additional $22 billion in either increased revenue or cuts in benefit programs.
 
Interest on Both Sides
''There seems to be interest in that on both sides of the aisle,'' Mr. Foley said.
Vice President Dan Quayle, in an interview on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' said the Administration was willing to ''explore all options'' and specifically declined to rule out the possibility that the President would accept such a trade.
A poll of House Republicans taken by their leaders at a closed-door meeting today showed that a large majority favored that trade, a stunning reversal from the House Republican position of a few months ago when the party's lawmakers said they would not accept any agreement that involved an increase in income tax rates.
Under the original compromise, devised in two weeks of closed-door negotiations between top Congressional leaders and the Administration, Medicare would have been cut by $60 billion over the next five years, with half the reduction coming in Government payments to doctors and other health care providers and the other half coming through higher premiums and deductibles for the 33 million elderly Americans covered by the program.
Such increases were the biggest single objection to the plan from lawmakers in both parties.

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1434 words

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
CONGRESS LEADERS SCRAMBLE TO FORGE NEW BUDGET DEAL IN MOVE TO BREAK DEADLOCK

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Monday, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Congressional leaders cobbled a new deficit-reduction plan together Sunday and took it before their colleagues in a scramble to end the budget deadlock and get the Federal Government back in full operation by the start of the workweek on Tuesday.
The House passed the measure early today by a vote of 250 to 164 and sent it to the Senate, which planned to take it up later today. The House vote was heavily along party lines, with Democrats in favor and Republicans against.
After the vote, which was completed at 2:30 A.M., the House immediately took up an interim spending bill authorizing the Government to resume normal operations while the details of the budget are completed.
 
'A Government in Crisis'
''We are tonight a government in crisis,'' the House Budget Committee chairman, Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, said in urging support for the resolution. ''The time has come for action to move this budget resolution. The country is waiting. The people are waiting.'' 
But Bob Livingston, Republican of Louisiana, said the plan increased spending and reduced taxes, giving no reason for Republicans to support it. ''This is a leftward budget,'' he said.
As the White House and Democratic leaders blamed each other for the weekend of fiscal chaos, negotiators for the Senate and the House fashioned a new budget plan from the wreckage of one that failed in the House on Friday.
Leaders of both parties in the Senate and the House began the day Sunday with what Congressional aides termed ''an agreement in principle'' on the revisions. But a group of House Republicans mounted a guerrilla war Sunday night to block the package over their opposition to new taxes and their fear that the plan would leave crucial details to committees controlled by Democrats.
 
No Word From White House
The new plan was designed to make more palatable, both substantively and politically, the most unpopular parts of a budget deal President Bush and the bipartisan leaders of Congress had announced a week ago in the Rose Garden of the White House, only to see it rejected four days later by the House.
White House officials offered no guidance on how the President would receive the new plan. House Democratic leaders abandoned their original plan of seeking half the House Republicans in support of a deficit-reduction plan and instead lined up as many Democrats as they could.
But Senate Republicans, who can block almost any action in their chamber, were being closely consulted as the plan took shape.
The new budget proposal, like the old one, is intended to reduce the deficit, projected at nearly $300 billion for this fiscal year, by $40 billion this year and by $500 billion over the next five years.
Under the new plan, Medicare premiums and deductibles would not rise as much, and members were assured that ticklish items like higher taxes on home heating oil and a longer waiting period for unemployment compensation would not be part of the final budget package.
The new agreement is far less detailed than the old one, meaning that many of the crucial decisions will be made by powerful tax and budget committees, whose members resented being left out of the original negotiations between the Bush Administration and Congressional leaders.
Democrats said the split among Republicans in the House was delaying a new package. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said the budget conference between the House and Senate had been stalled most of the day Sunday by the refusal of Republican House members to attend.
 
Waiting for Republicans
''We have had all the Democrats there,'' Mr. Gephardt said. ''We've had Senate Republicans there. We can't quite seem to get the House Republicans to attend the conference. We've been sitting there for six hours.''
Speaking to Republicans on the floor, Mr. Gephardt added: ''I hope someone will come from your side so we can do what the President has asked us to do for five months and what he asked us to do yesterday.''
Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican from Pennsylvania, said Republicans were angry beause they did not feel they had been ''well consulted'' on the latest budget plan.
The conference committee, composed of members of both chambers and both parties, was formed to produce a bipartisan budget agreement.
Late Sunday evening, the ranking Republican members of the budget conference, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, were refusing to sign the conference report, said the chairman of the House rules committee, Representative Joe Moakley of Massachusetts. But Mr. Moakley said this did not mean Senate Republicans had abandoned the new plan, quoting Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, as saying, ''A lack of signature doesn't mean a lack of support.''
 
Senate Meets Monday
Mr. Dole himself, in his Capitol office around 11 P.M., said: ''I'm supporting the process. My view is that we still have a pretty good bipartisan relation in the Senate.''
A Democratic spokesman said Senator Domenici had said he would consider signing the conference's plan today.
The Senate convened at 6 P.M. Sunday and soon after recessed until today, Columbus Day, meaning that the budget crisis can be resolved no sooner than that.
 
'Great Confusion'
With many details of the new plan now turned over to Congressional committees, it was unclear just what reductions would be made and how the $20 billion lost from the old plan in taxes and Medicare cuts would be made up.
''Yes, there is great confusion here in the House of Representatives,'' said Representative Sonny Callahan, Republican of Alabama, on the House floor.
Another issue turned over to committee, amid a gathering consensus that something would be enacted, was the debate over some form of reduction in the capital gains tax in exchange for an increase in the top income tax rate on the wealthiest Americans.
Across the nation, Americans watched their capital city with a mixture of disgust and bemusement, while here in Washington the frustration and bitterness reached such a level that one of the city's most mild-mannered men, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, displayed public anger at President Bush's efforts to blame Congress for the standoff.
 
Bush Aides Out of Sight
Mr. Bush spent the second day of the Government's partial shutdown at the Camp David retreat in the Catoctin Mountain National Park of Maryland, traveling by motorcade rather than helicopter to save money. Camp David, run by Navy personnel, remained in operation, but the park's visitors center, deemed a nonessential service, was closed.
Mr. Bush's senior aides were ''on the phone heavy,'' as one put it, to keep in touch with the budget situation, but were advised by Congressional leaders to stay out of sight of members who blame them for much of the budget breakdown.
The new budget plan, which shifts much of the decision-making back to committees, was a return to Congress's old way of doing business, before leaders, trying to overcome the deadlocks of a Government divided between Republicans in the White House and Democrats in control on the Hill, turned to deals cut by small groups of leaders and presented as a package to the rank and file. Whose Charm School? Mr. Bush's veto on Saturday of a stopgap spending bill precipitated the shutdown of all ''nonessential'' Federal services. Mr. Bush has said he would sign a continuing resolution if a budget to his liking had been approved or if the continuing resolution itself included budget cuts similar to those in the deal rejected by the House on Friday.
While they are persona non grata on Capitol Hill, Mr. Bush's aides appeared on Sunday television shows to continue the effort Mr. Bush began Saturday to blame Congress for the debacle.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, avoided negotiating directly with Congress because they had offended so many lawmakers by their behavior, which some in Congress termed high-handed. ''Some people have accused them of going to the Sam Donaldson charm school,'' said Vice President Dan Quayle of the two Bush aides on the ABC News program ''This Week.'' Mr. Donaldson, sitting next to the Vice President, replied, ''You could do worse.''
But Mr. Quayle added particularly of Mr. Sununu: ''He is not the problem. The problem is Congress.'' Speaker Foley, unusually angry, lashed back at the White House, saying the President was every bit as much a part of the budget-making process as Congress.

HEADLINE: A Russian Holds Forth On Reform

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAHWAH, N.J., Oct. 7

 BODY:
Stanislav S. Shatalin, one of the principal authors of the celebrated and contentious ''500 days plan'' to rescue the Soviet Union from economic decline, briefly broke away from high-level meetings in Washington and New York today to revert to his old profession.
On a Sunday afternoon, while students on the front lawn of Ramapo College engaged in a pie-throwing contest as part of homecoming festivities, the economist made his way to a lecture hall.
The former professor, dressed in a steel-gray suit and flanked by Soviet and American flags, met with about 200 students and faculty members and patiently explained what was and was not intended in a plan that, he said, ''has become part of me.''
''This time span of 500 days, for which this program is named, is too short to build a market economy,'' he said through an interpreter. ''We won't set up a market economy in even 900 days.'' 
''We are not setting up a program to create a functioning market economy,'' he said, ''just a program to stabilize the economy.''
 
Tapped by Gorbachev
The Soviet economist was catapulted from relative obscurity last year by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to a post on the Presidential Council and given the task of hammering out a free-market agenda.
He is now one of the driving forces behind the move to foster private ownership, create bank and stock-exchange systems, floating prices and business deals rooted in profit returns. In Moscow, officials are trying to work out a plan to satisfy both those, like Mr. Shatalin, who think that reform should be deep and fast, and those, like Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who want to move to a market economy at a slower pace. Mr. Gorbachev has said he wants reform, but has not specified how much.
Mr. Shatalin said he had come to the United States to ''evaluate possible ways and means to transfer to a market economy.''
Arriving on Sept. 29, he met in Washington with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney; the White House national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and with officials from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. He will meet with private banking and business leaders during his remaining three days.
 
Challenged by Russian Visitors
Two visiting Soviet teachers on the faculty at Ramapo College, as part of an exchange program the college has with the Soviet Union, greeted Mr. Shatalin, though with skepticism.
Aleksandr Yakovlev, a translator for Progress Publishers in Moscow who is teaching first-year English, intruded on Mr. Shatalin's sunny forecast.
''How many years more will people have to stand in line?'' he asked. ''How much longer will we have to live on a pittance of a salary? How many more generations will be lost before we have normal, decent lives?''
The Soviet economist said that, at best, there would be ''a small increase in the living standards'' after perhaps two years.
''When I was young,'' he said, ''there were many plans to catch up to the United States, to become a more powerful nation than the United States. Now we have given up this idea. Our task is to make the life of our people decent.''
''As for lines,'' he quipped, ''there are not too many products left to line up for.''
 
Perils Neutralized
The Soviet economist assured one questioner that the Soviet Union was no longer a threat to the United States, and thanked another who warned him about the dangers of American consumerism.
A questioner from the audience who identified himself as a professor of Marxist economics said he wanted the students to know why Mr. Shatalin was not meeting with labor union leaders, a question that the economist sidestepped.
Mr. Shatalin painted a bleak picture of the next few months, citing the serious food shortages, the lack of mobility by workers within the society to travel to jobs, the loss of centralized control over the republics which had eroded cooperation, the ''militarization'' of the economy, a rising crime rate and the declining value of the ruble, which he said is often valued less than a food coupon or a ration card.
''We have several currencies besides dollars,'' he said.
''I don't want to frighten you with any gloomy predictions on what will happen if my optimistic forecast doesn't come true,'' the economist added.

Scott, right rear, and Andre Ivanov, an interpreter, on the campus yesterday at Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Short of Oil and Supporters, Jordan Orders Fuel Savings

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 7

 BODY:
With fast-dwindling oil reserves and a deepening trade battle with its increasingly hostile neighbors, Jordan has ordered a series of sharp austerity measures designed to reduce the nation's fuel consumption by at least 20 percent.
Starting on Saturday, the Government workweek will drop from six days to five, and on those days working hours will be limited. Stores, businesses, restaurants and other commercial establishments will have mandatory closing times.
Urban commercial signs and street lights will have to be turned off at given hours each night. And Government vehicles will not be allowed on the roads except during working hours. 
If these and related steps do not quickly reduce the nation's fuel consumption, senior officials said, Jordan will soon have to introduce fuel rationing and other severe measures.
 
Result of the Trade War
The steps announced over the weekend are a direct result of Jordan's deepening trade war with Saudi Arabia, which cut off oil shipments on Sept. 19 and then banned commercial imports from Jordan a short time later, all because of displeasure with Jordan's seemingly pro-Iraqi tilt.
Jordan had relied on Saudi Arabia for just over half of its oil supply. The rest had come from Iraq, even after the United Nations imposed a trade embargo against Baghdad. Jordan has little money with which to buy oil on the open market.
Though the Iraqis certainly have more oil than they know what to do with, the Jordanians say they cannot substantially increase their imports from Iraq. The problem seems to be transport. Oil is ferried from Iraq in tanker trucks, and the roads between Baghdad and Amman are already crowded with the trucks.
But even the present level of oil purchases in violation of the sanctions certainly adds to Saudi Arabia's irritation at Jordan. On Friday Saudi Arabia withdrew its Ambassador from Amman. Jordan had called its own Ambassador home 10 days earlier.
 
King Hussein Meets Arafat
Jordanian officials have continually protested that the nation is only trying to remain neutral. But today King Hussein met with Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, to discuss the idea of linking a solution of the Persian Gulf crisis to a resolution of the Palestinian conflict with Israel. Saudi Arabia and most other Arab nations, along with the United States, want Iraq simply to withdraw from Kuwait, without any connection to other issues.
The Saudis had shipped oil directly here by pipeline and had been the largest purchasers of Jordanian agricultural products.
Late last month, the Saudis went so far as to forbid Jordanian trucks to pass through Saudi Arabia on their way to sell farm produce to other gulf states to the south.
Jordan retaliated last week and forbade Turkish and Syrian cargo trucks to pass through its territory on their way to Saudi Arabia. Shortages of produce immediately occurred in several gulf states, and that set off a round of international negotiations initiated by Syria late last week. At week's end, Jordan relented and allowed the Syrian and Turkish trucks to pass. In turn, Saudi Arabia allowed Jordanian truck traffic through its territory.
Still, Saudi Arabia refuses to buy any Jordanian goods. And now there are reports here that Jordanian truckers have been having trouble crossing into Turkey.
Since Jordan's trade with Iraq and Kuwait is cut off by the United Nations economic embargo and other regional markets are closed or closing, Jordan's economy has been driven almost to a halt. And late last month, Jordan's Energy Minister, Thabet al-Taher, warned that the country had ''only a few weeks of oil stock'' in the national reserve. That prompted the fuel conservation measures announced this weekend.
Jordanian officials have generally been circumspect in their open criticisms of the Saudis, out of concern that they would only make the situation worse. In a rare outburst during an interview late last month, Crown Prince Hassan complained that the Saudi authorities ''are opening our trucks and dumping our vegetables over the side of the road. I've kept mum about this before now because I don't want to run afoul of other disagreements with the Saudis.''
But now that Jordan has done exactly that, a senior Government official complained this evening that ''the Saudis are trying to strangle us, and if they're not careful they may succeed.''
 
Jordanians Feel Misunderstood
Jordanians say they feel wounded and misunderstood by their neighbors, as well as by the United States, where Jordan has few friends these days. After all, they say, King Hussein is only trying to be an honest, nonaligned broker in the gulf conflict.
But while the Saudis and officials of other governments in the region may appreciate that the King is trying to stake out a neutral position, it is difficult not to notice that this is not so true for some others in his Government and for the bulk of Jordanian people.
During Muslim prayer services on Friday, for example, Jordan's Minister of Religious Affairs, Ali al-Fakir, told 10,000 worshipers that they should attack the American and allied forces stationed just over the border in the Saudi desert.
''We cannot retaliate against the United States itself, because vast oceans separate us,'' the Muslim cleric and Cabinet member said. ''But we now have the opportunity to retaliate against the American troops and other crusaders who are a stone's throw from us. I assure you that we will take them captive and shackle them with chains as Muslims did with Crusaders.''

HEADLINE: Ford and Auto Union Reach Contract Agreement

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company reached a tentative labor agreement today covering nearly 100,000 workers in the No. 2 auto maker's operations in the United States.
Negotiators bargained through the night before shaking hands on the contract at 8:55 A.M. Both sides declined to disclose details of the contract, but Owen Bieber, the union president, said it followed the pattern of the contract that the union reached with the General Motors Corporation on Sept. 17 covering 300,000 workers in the United States.
So far bargaining between American automakers and the union, which began in mid-summer, has been relatively free of rancor. Labor experts have suggested that competition from Japanese automakers and their plants in this country would make a strike extremely detrimental to both sides by allowing the foreign companies to capture a bigger share of the domestic market. 
But the union may still face serious problems at the Chrysler Corporation, which has said it needs an agreement that acknowleges the company's weakness relative to Ford and G.M. The union has rejected the idea.
High-level bargaining at Chrysler is scheduled to begin once the Ford agreement is ratified by the union membership, which could take less than two weeks.
 
Strike Possible in Canada
Ford workers in Canada walked off the job for a week in late September before the company and the Canadian automobile workers union reached an agreement. G.M. is bargaining with the Canadian union, with a Wednesday deadline for a strike in that country.
The pattern established by the G.M. contract could benefit Ford's workers in this country in several ways. Besides a salary increase, the three-year contract between G.M. and the union promised to pay up to $4.5 billion in benefits to laid-off workers if necessary, while giving the No. 1 auto maker some flexibility in closing its excess plants.
Since Ford has little excess production capacity and has idled workers far less than has G.M., Ford may have been able to agree to a similar provision without its being very costly. Still, that could provide protection to workers in a severe economic downturn.
To keep layoffs to a minimum, Ford relies heavily on overtime work, a practice that the union opposes but that many workers like. The union, which has been losing members, would prefer that Ford hire more workers.
G.M.'s contract with the union contained a heavy financial penalty for relying on overtime. Under that provision, auto makers would be compelled to pay as much as $5 for every hour of overtime to an education fund administered by the union and the companies. Ford probably argued to soften the penalty, but whether the company was successful will not be evident until representatives from 79 union locals meet here Tuesday to examine the contract before members vote.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Tourists Lose Weekend, Others Their Patience

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The Government took a second day of leave from fiscal normality today, disrupting the holiday weekend for tourists and probably costing more than was saved by shutting down for lack of a budget.
As essential Government functions went uninterrupted and most nonessential workers stayed home as usual on a Sunday, the greatest effect of the continuing budget dispute was felt by vacationers, who found the nation's parks and monuments closed at a time when tourism is usually booming.
Members of Congress caucused to devise a budget that might be accepted in time to prevent greater disruptions on Tuesday, the first working day after the Federal observance of Columbus Day. Most civilian Federal employees would not work then, and normal administrative work, like auditing tax returns, signing contracts, answering phones and taking applications for new Social Security numbers would stop. 
As lawmakers met, tourists wandered disconsolately about Capitol Hill, having been shut out of Washington's popular Smithsonian museums. The reaction of people both in Washington and elsewhere in the country to the confusion seemed mostly to be one of anger against politicians.
 
Effects Quickly Spread
Thousands of people were inconvenienced, from Yosemite to the Everglades, and millions of dollars in camping fees, tolls on scenic roads, and sales at museum shops were lost, officials said.
Dianne Pilgrim, director of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in New York, which receives half its money from the Smithsonian Institution, called the museum's closure ''particularly painful'' because it cut into the other half of the museum's budget, which comes largely from admissions and shop sales.
And on a glorious autumn day, motorists on the Skyline Drive, atop Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains, did not have to slow down to pay the usual $5 fee because entrance stations were unmanned. About 25,000 people usually enter the Shenandoah National Park along the drive on fine weekend days, but today nobody was counting them.
In Atlanta, where the popular hiking and jogging trails along the Chattahoochee River were closed, pedestrians ignored the posted restrictions and denounced the politicians for imposing them.
 
Campers Are Evicted
''This doesn't affect the politicians,'' said Dennis Greenia, a marketing consultant dressed for a jog. ''They still have their private country clubs to go to.''
At the start of the weekend, campers had been allowed to stay in many national parks even though normal services, like lectures by rangers, were canceled, and visitors centers were closed. But today that changed.
At Yosemite National Park in California, filled to capacity both because of the long weekend and because the park is celebrating its centennial, more than 5,000 campers were told to clear out by midday. The same thing was happening elsewhere. In the most heavily visited national forest, the George Washington National Forest of Virginia, even the picnic areas were chained.
At Yellowstone, which is too big to shut down all at once, operations were being gradually reduced. ''I think it's horrible,'' Becky Vaccarezza, a camper at Yosemite, told The Associated Press. ''When you're at home, you deal with the bills and everything. But when you come up here, this is everybody's escape. This is how you're supposed to get away from budgets.''
At Muir Woods National Monument, just outside San Francisco, attendance was about 60 percent of the 6,000 who would visit on a typical Sunday in October, said Michael Hughes, a National Parks Service ranger who was one of three ''essential personnel'' working today at the park.
 
Price to Be Paid
When the Congress and the White House finally pick up the pieces of the budget disarray, experts said, the Treasury will probably have to pay the price for this weekend's disruptions. For example, thousands of employees of the National Park Service are likely to be reimbursed for their mandatory days off.
On three previous occasions when the brief lack of a Federal budget forced temporary layoffs, in 1981, 1984 and 1986, workers who were sent home without pay were reimbursed. In 1981, when the Government shut down on a Monday in November, the interruption was estimated by the House Civil Service Subcommittee to have cost the Government up to $90 million.
Stuart E. Eizenstat, who was President Jimmy Carter's principal domestic policy adviser, said today that the hidden costs of shutting down the Government come in many forms.
There are some physical costs for closing and securing Federal buildings, but these are relatively modest, he said. Then there are the costs of interrupting traveling Federal workers, some of whom actually have to be told to return home, at substantial expense.
 
Payment in Cynicism
Finally, he said, there are the incalculable costs to the work force, some of whom get fed up and quit; to the economy, which suffers indirectly when tourists and Federal employees decide not to spend their money, and even to the political psyche.
''The biggest cost of all is the cost in voter cynicism,'' Mr. Eizenstat said. ''It creates a mood of apathy, anger and bitterness.''
One of the angry citizens was Robert Jeffers, an-89-year old retired bell captain at the Parker House Hotel in Boston, who said, ''Sure, I'll write to my Congressman about the Federal budget cuts, but I don't think it will do any good.''
Even Federal workers who were not affected today were distraught by the uncertainty. Robert Gentry, employed on the building management staff at the veterans hospital on Chicago's West Side, said he had told his landlord that the rent check might be late because he is worried about a possible furlough next week, even though the hospital was fully staffed today.
''Am I disgusted with the Government? Yeah,'' he said. ''The Government has put a lot of strain and stress on us.''
 
Looking Toward Tuesday
Many officials continued to believe that before the long weekend was over the budget problems would be resolved. Federal workers are under instructions to report to work as scheduled no matter what happens, so they can be told whether to go back home.
But if the Congress and the White House cannot agree by then on terms for resuming the Government's business, the effects could be much more widely felt on Tuesday morning.
There are at least two possibilities. One is that the Government continue to function with no budget at all, meaning that only activities deemed essential, such as those involving national security, public health, safety, law enforcement and the protection of property would go one. Social Security checks also would still be paid, and the Post Office, which has its own source of income through postage stamp sales. would deliver the mail.
A second, less likely possibility is that a temporary budget would be enacted without achieving steep reductions in the deficit, causing across-the-board spending cuts to take hold under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law. Unlike the current shutdown, this would affect such things as air traffic control and meat inspections.

HEADLINE: Who Will Pay for the Gulf Crisis?

 BODY:
There's increasing reason to hope that Saddam Hussein will have to withdraw from Kuwait and accept restrictions on Iraq's military power, either because of the embargo or battlefield defeat. One way or the other, the United States will pay the biggest share of the costs, in blood and treasure. That's unfair and unacceptable.
If fighting breaks out, Americans will suffer far greater casualties than any of the allies. With its forces approaching 200,000, the United States will have more than three times as many troops in combat as all its partners put together, including Saudi Arabia. 
And even if there is no fighting, the U.S. already finds itself paying twice, once to defend Iraq's neighbors and again for oil at twice the July price. Saudi Arabia, whose oil profits are expected to jump by about $50 billion a year, has pledged $12 billion this year to reimburse Washington for its gulf-related military operations and to help defray the impact of the embargo on its poor neighbors. But that doesn't begin to cover the bill.
The allies may deploy between 25,000 and 40,000 troops (mostly Egyptian and not counting 40,000 from the Saudis). But that doesn't reflect their relative interest in stopping Iraq or their dependence on oil. Western Europe and Japan buy more oil from the gulf than the U.S.
How did this gross imbalance of responsibilities occur? And what can be done to right it?
The answer lies in the mindset of America's leaders and in the established expectations of our allies. Almost reflexively, the Bush Administration took over the crisis as if it were part of the old cold war confrontation with Moscow. Only the U.S. can do the job, Administration officials argued.
To be sure, President Bush had to move quickly to establish a credible U.S. presence of, say, 50,000 troops. But once they were in place, American airlift and sealift capacity could have been placed at the disposal of the allies to ferry their troops and their arms. And just as many allies sent ships, they could have sent hundreds of combat planes.
But Washington didn't press hard, and the allies contributed only the minimum necessary to placate Congress. With the exception of Germany and Japan, legally barred from deploying combat forces abroad, the allies have no good excuse. They can't credibly plead impotence, disinterest or poverty. Many of the allies are now better off economically than the U.S. What they lack is not the money or the military manpower, but the sense of responsibility and the will to take on their fair share.
Nor can they slide by with the argument that they're doing more now than ever before. They're contributing about the same proportion of troops to the gulf today that they sent to fight in Korea in the early 1950's, when their economies were in tatters and their interests distant. The U.S. suffered almost 34,000 killed and 103,000 wounded in that bloody war, compared with 4,700 and 11,000 for the allies and 70,000 and 150,000 for the South Koreans.
To set this situation right, Mr. Bush and allied leaders have to reappraise mindsets, manpower and money.
First, Washington has to demand much more from the allies, and they have to expect far more from themselves.
Second, every allied nation should deploy more forces, either in addition to Americans or as replacements.
Third, the allied steering group already established to coordinate economic aid should meet immediately to discuss increasing the $20 billion already pledged, principally by Germany, Japan and Saudi Arabia. This amount is grossly insufficient, especially for the Saudis.
Without such reappraisal, Americans will come, rightly, to bridle at the unfairness and will hesitate about future U.S. contributions to collective security. With these steps, Mr. Bush and allied leaders can truly establish a new model for post-cold-war peacekeeping.

HEADLINE: No Paradox Exists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In reply to Adam L. Schulman's Op-Ed article of Sept. 15: the terms ''conservative'' and ''radical'' - unlike ''left'' and ''right'' - have no intrinsic political meaning independent of the context in which they are used. ''Conservative'' merely designates someone who wishes to conserve the status quo, whatever that is, while ''radical'' refers to someone desiring radical change in any direction. Accordingly, there is no paradox whatever: in the Soviet context (which is not ours), Yegor Ligachev is a conservative, and Boris Yeltsin a radical.
Furthermore, in the long historical perspective, the view of human nature on which classical, free-market capitalism rests - namely, the view according to which man is fundamentally not a social animal at all; his natural and most efficient mode of behavior is competition rather than cooperation, and any cooperation that does take place among people outside the family is due to either compulsion or to selfish motives - is an extreme one and far from self-evident, as 18th-century conservatives like Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre recognized. This view would have seemed outlandish to our ancestors of, say, 300 years ago, and would seem outlandish even today to most people in the world outside the United States and Western Europe.
If Mr. Schulman knew more about anthropology he certainly wouldn't call this ''the sober and prudent acceptance of man as he is.'' If this view were correct, then the modifications we have applied to free-market capitalism to make it run more smoothly and humanely - Social Security, unemployment insurance, worker's compensation, redistribution of income through taxation and all the rest of it - wouldn't work.
 
STEPHEN P. DUNN
Director of Research
Highgate Road
Social Science Research Station
Berkeley, Calif., Sept. 20, 1990

HEADLINE: The Soviet Conservative Is a Communist

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Adam L. Schulman misses a fundamental point about political conservatism in his ''Soviet Paradox: Left Is Right'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 15). Conservatism, in the Soviet Union as in the United States, tries to protect the status quo. That is why conservatives in the Soviet Union are staunch Communists, and in the West, free marketeers and defenders of ''family values.''
Conservatives are uncomfortable with radical change in any direction. That is why so many conservative columnists in the United States were distressed over the rapidity with which freedom and democracy came to Eastern Europe in 1989. The change was in the correct direction, these columnists agreed, but it was just too fast. Conservatism prefers orderliness and predictability.
Friederich Hayek, a Nobel laureate economist whose observations on such matters are particularly cogent, addressed this issue in a 1960 essay entitled ''Why I Am Not a Conservative.'' The conservative, says Hayek, ''feels safe and content only if he is assured that some higher wisdom watches and supervises change, only if he knows that some authority is charged with keeping the change 'orderly.' '' Seen this way, the Communist conservatism of Yegor Ligachev and the ''moral'' conservatism of, say, Jesse Helms are entirely compatible. Both favor government imposition of a ''moral'' order, distrust spontaneity and cling to the past.
Liberalism, on the other hand (and I refer here to the classical liberalism of Locke and Jefferson) tolerates the unpredictability that accompanies individual liberty, favoring minimalist government in all spheres of life and, in Hayek's words, ''a political order in which both [liberals and conservatives] can obey their convictions.'' This too seems compatible with current liberal currents in the Soviet Union.
 
PHILIP D. HARVEY
Washington, Sept. 17, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Hail To Ginglock

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Do not be embarrassed by the closing of the Statue of Liberty for a little while; she will understand.
The derailing of budget summitry and the shutdown of nonessential services is not evidence that ''the system doesn't work,'' or that our representatives in Congress are too irresponsible to bite the tax bullet just before election.
On the contrary, the system has never worked more dramatically to demonstrate what can happen when government by elitist consensus puts forward a fake compromise and runs smack into the politics of principle.
Face it: a real disagreement exists in this nation about the direction of domestic policy. And don't buy conventional media wisdom: it is not between a little band of responsible leaders who favor balancing the budget versus a grubby swarm of populists who want to expand entitlements but are too hypocritical to vote the taxes to pay for them. 
The conflict is between politicians who want to do more for the people versus those who want people to be able to do more for themselves. In Presidential elections, the conservative philosophy wins on promises of tax restraint; in Congressional, the liberal philosophy wins on promises of expansion of services.
As a result, we look to Washington for a compromise. It does not mean we have a split personality, or that we all want something for nothing; it does mean that the people want as much as we have been getting in services for about the same we have been paying in taxes.
Because the cost of interest on our current course takes us into the red, most of us are ready to cut defense as the Soviet threat diminishes, put a cap on entitlement increases pegged roughly to inflation, and accept some sin taxes.
But a compromise was not struck between the contending philosophies. Instead, a deal was cut in the dead of a six-month night between Democratic liberals and Republican centrists that tipped the scales in the direction of a more active and expensive role of government.
That's when Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip in a House long dominated by Democrats, hollered foul. It is one thing to compromise; it is something else to lose. And the Foley-Darman-Dole deal was, by any conservative standard, a loser.
The whopping new taxes were front-loaded, imposed right away, while the nondefense spending ''cuts'' were to be end-loaded, not to kick in for years - and almost certain to be rescinded in a replay of the doublecross of President Reagan by Speaker O'Neill in 1982.
Moreover, the promised ''cuts'' were only paper reductions in the rate of increase, a far cry from actual reduction, and not even a leveling of expenditures after allowing for inflation.
With his point of view frozen out of the compromise, Mr. Gingrich gutsily said no. Every member of the House facing a tight race - lest we forget, that means those most closely attuned to the will of the people - voted with him to reject the leaders' lurch to the left.
Result: Ginglock. Newt rightly put loyalty to the party's principles ahead of Presidential discipline; Mr. Bush took a licking without flinching, later coming up off the floor with a no-contract, no-work position that holds Congress's feet to the fire.
Now what? Will the temporary furloughing of Federal workers for one day a week mean the end of civilization as we know it? Hardly; bureaucrats could volunteer to bring in the potato harvest.
As the House scrambles to find a true compromise, it may permit a partial sequester, or horse around with a soak-the-rich scheme until the election is over, or let the President exhume the Civil War's ''feed and forage'' act to run the country.
The red faces belong to those who thought they could precipitate a crisis to sell the taxpayer a bill of goods. These new Hoovers argued that only a huge tax increase could shrink the deficit and lower interest rates. But the deepening recession will lower interest rates; new taxes would make the downturn steeper and the deficit deeper.
The leadership lost because they led the nation in the direction of income redistribution, where the nation wisely does not want to go. The right way to reduce the deficit is to limit non-defense increases to the rate of inflation and to let real defense cuts sop up the red ink.
This resilient country will survive the shock of its refusal to be stampeded. Election Day is near; let's draw the tax-vs.-spending issue and put it up to the people.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
When You Believe In Lies

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
If you want to know why we have a paralyzing budget crisis, you have to go back to the golden days of Reaganism. That was the early 1980's, when the smiling President was telling us that we could cut taxes and still have it all.
A few right-wing intellectuals told the truth then. The real idea of those massive tax cuts, they said, was to bleed the Treasury white -so there would be no money for domestic spending. Ideologues like The Wall Street Journal's editorial writers said that with gleeful candor. They thought Government was bad, so we would be better off with less of it. 
Of course the official Reagan economists were not so candid. They said they had discovered a Philosopher's Stone called supply-side economics: reduce taxes, and we would have higher Government revenues and higher private saving and investment.
Those official explanations were lies. Water did not run uphill. Lower taxes brought lower revenues. The rich, made richer by Reagan policies, saved and invested less, not more.
But the American public loved the fairy story. When Walter Mondale said it was not true, the public put him down as a spoilsport. It voted for Ronald Reagan, and when George Bush stopped complaining about voodoo economics and said you could too spin straw into gold, it voted for him.
The trouble was that most Americans did not agree with the real aim of the right. They did not want a pygmy Government, they wanted the Government to do lots of things that cost money: provide medical care for the elderly, protect the environment, run national parks, control air traffic . . .
So there we are. The reality, as intended, is that the Federal Government does not have the resources it needs. But the voters will not let go of the fairy story. They want the Government to keep spending without raising taxes.
The result is political paralysis. The politicians who have to face the voters in a month - the members of the House of Representatives - do not want to deprive any citizen of a benefit or impose on any citizen a higher tax.
The problem is much harder to solve in the United States than in other democratic societies because of the nature of our political system. It is, first of all, a divided system, in which a President and Congress may - and now do - answer to different parties and ideologies. It is not a parliamentary system, in which the Prime Minister can tell her party members to toe the line or see their Government fall.
Then our system has always allowed interest groups to exercise great influence. It may seem logical to tax private airplanes when levying new taxes on luxuries. But the plane manufacturers in Kansas speak to Senator Bob Dole, and planes are exempted.
The politics of interest groups is frustrating. It tends to legislative inertia, because a few highly motivated legislators can block action. But the system, as Justice Brandeis said, was designed not to produce efficiency but to diffuse power.
In the old days there was one mediating influence. That was the political party, which could find a common denominator for legislators - a position on which a majority could stand. But parties have lost much of their meaning.
Republican members of Congress today do not have to look to President Bush. A Newt Gingrich, determined to protect the rich from even disproportionately modest tax increases, can vote against the President although he is a Republican whip. He looks for support to political action committees, and he will get it.
Does it matter? The sums involved are not very large in an economy as big as ours. But the demonstration of political will - or rather the lack of it - does matter. Europeans and Asians, the rising economic powers, are already finding confirmation of their suspicion that the United States is in decline.
Those who warn about American decline, like Prof. Paul Kennedy of Yale, are met with the indignant response that this is still the world's most powerful country militarily: Look at the Persian Gulf. But that misses Professor Kennedy's point, which is that we are not keeping our economic performance up to our commitments abroad.
One of Mr. Kennedy's critics, Prof. Joseph S. Nye Jr. of Harvard, wrote the other day that the United States need not fear decline if it simply addresses ''such domestic issues as the budget deficit, savings rate, educational system and condition of our cities.'' Exactly.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Slicing Columbus Into Two Pieces: Person and Event

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
''It is a great pity,'' The New York Times lamented on Sept. 15, 1892, ''that the weather yesterday should have interfered with the pageant projected for the laying of the cornerstone of the monument to Columbus. Our Italian citizens are not very numerous in comparison, but they know more about getting up processions than all the rest of us put together, whatever our origin may be.''
The 400th anniversary of Columbus's landing in the Western Hemisphere was very much a national celebration in the United States. Yet in New York and a number of other large cities, it also marked an opportunity for the growing number of Italian immigrants: They staked their claim to an American hero whom they helped elevate, despite the efforts of some native-born Americans to lionize Leif Ericsson as emblematic of an immigrant group and of a religion that seemed less threatening. 
Built largely with contributions from readers of an Italian-language newspaper, the 13-foot-high marble statue of Columbus atop a 26-foot granite column was unveiled in time for the city's Oct. 12 celebration in 1892. Nearly a century later, the monument, in Columbus Circle in Manhattan, is encased in scaffolding as it undergoes a $275,000 restoration paid for by the Columbus Citizens Foundation, an Italian-American civic and philanthropic group, and by P. Sasso e Figli, an Italian olive oil company.
While revisionists no longer credit Columbus with actually discovering America, and some argue that the chief consequence of his voyages was to open the Western Hemisphere to European plunder, he is still a hero to many Italian-Americans. In contrast with celebrations a century ago, the explorer is being claimed more aggressively, too, by people of Hispanic heritage.
Columbus was Italian-born, but Queen Isabella of Spain paid his bill.
The annual Columbus celebration is emerging as an opportunity for Hispanic-Americans to assert themselves culturally and politically. Moreover the Spanish Government views the Columbus quincentenary, coupled with the Olympic Games in Spain in 1992, as a vehicle to redefine its image in the Americas from one of conquest and conversion to one of a democractic partner in a revitalized Europe.
''The Spanish are in the process of trying to win Columbus back,'' said Joseph M. Laufer, who teaches at Burlington County College in New Jersey and publishes a newsletter about the quincentenary.
A separate Hispanic heritage parade is scheduled for Manhattan next Sunday. But so far the Hispanic influence on today's Columbus Day extravaganza, organized by the Columbus Citizens Foundation, has been negligible.
''The bottom line is he was from Genoa,'' said Vincent Tese, the foundation's president and the State Economic Development Commissioner, appointed by Mario M. Cuomo, the first Italian-American elected Governor of New York. ''Hispanic-Americans celebrate the event more than the person, whereas we celebrate the person more than the event.''
Political empowerment came slowy for Italian-Americans. Only two have been elected Mayor of New York City - Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1934 and Vincent R. Impellitteri in 1950.
No Italian-American has won citywide since Mario A. Procaccino was elected Comptroller in 1965 (none of Hispanic origin have won citywide at all yet), although Italian-American candidates, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, among them, have fared better in the suburbs.
In 1980 about 14 percent of New York City residents described themselves as of primarily Italian heritage. Nearly 20 percent said they were of Hispanic heritage. Since then the number of new Italian immigrants has been nearly imperceptible, while Spanish-speakers constituted fully a third of all legal immigrants to the city in much of the 1980's.
A float depicts Columbus sailing under the Spanish flag, but the major Hispanic-oriented contribution to today's parade, which features flag throwers from Florence, Italy, and Tommy Lasorda, the Los Angeles Dodgers manager, as grand marshal, may be a contingent of jousting knights from the Medieval Times Restaurant in Lyndhurst, N.J. But the parade is becoming even more inclusive.
''The basis of the parade,'' said Alfred F. Calabro, the chairman of today's march up Fifth Avenue and a member of the Columbus Citizens Foundation, ''has been to perpetuate the honor of Christopher Columbus and to preserve Italian ancestry.
''We started to realize, though, that Columbus belongs to all Americans The foundation is the custodian of the history of the Columbus, but this is no longer an Italian ethnic parade.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
