HEADLINE: Dinkins Joins With Deputies For More Cuts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins and his top deputies and aides huddled at Gracie Mansion yesterday, discussing New York City's deepening fiscal problems and how best to explain them to the public after a troubled week of seemingly conflicting signals from City Hall.
''We think we do have a plan,'' one senior aide said. ''We've got to figure out how we articulate that plan, just what steps do we take, and what window do we have until we have to make definite decisions.''
But even as they sought to regain control of the debate prompted by their actions last week, which ended with Mr. Dinkins saying he was considering the layoff of 15,000 city workers, the Mayor and his aides faced the challenge of making still more difficult decisions to cut spending to close a budget gap for the coming fiscal year that they estimate at $1.4 billion. 
 
Cuts for Building Projects
The Dinkins administration must present such plans as part of its scheduled quarterly report to the State Financial Control Board on Nov. 1, and in its 10-year plan for capital building projects, required to be issued by November under the new City Charter.
The administration, some senior aides said, is expected to detail its plans, perhaps later this week, for cutting outlays for building projects like roads, parks and bridges to reduce mounting debt-service costs. Cuts in some agencies could range up to 25 percent, mayoral aides have said.
Of all the recent bad fiscal news, some experts say trimming the capital budget -which is financed by long-term bonds, was built up painfully and proudly after the city fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's and has been mostly immune to the recent cuts in other city programs - is the most telling sign of the problems that lie ahead. The Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses, recently issued a report calling for the city to cut its capital commitments by 20 percent, or an average of $1 billion a year, by eliminating low-priority projects or stretching out 10-year goals over a 12-year period.
The commission said it had reluctantly concluded that ''the city's current program is not affordable in light of new economic conditions'' of stagnancy and slipping revenues. If building continued on pace, the report said, the cost of debt service on capital bonds, which must be paid out of annual operating revenues, would climb to $5.9 billion in fiscal 1999 from $2.1 billion now.
Officials have said virtually the only agency to be exempted from the cuts in capital spending would be the Correction Department, which under Mr. Dinkins's proposed anti-crime program would have to build about 3,000 jail beds in the next few years.
 
'All Kinds of Problems'
Making his official rounds between meetings with aides yesterday, Mr. Dinkins took note of the challenges facing him.
''As you doubtless know, since you read the papers, we are inundated with all kinds of problems,'' he said at an anniversary celebration at the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, where the pastor is his ally, the Rev. Herbert Daughtry.
The political pressures on the Mayor were intense, from fiscal monitors and other elected officials, as well as editorial boards and the local teamsters union, which took a largely symbolic vote to authorize a strike over the layoff threat.
 
A New Review Panel
Over the weekend, Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation - a state watchdog agency set up during the fiscal crisis to issue bonds on the city's behalf when its own near insolvency barred it from the credit markets - suggested that the city's current problems should be reviewed by a new panel made up of the Governor, the Mayor, union officials and business leaders.
For his part, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said that the state would give the city's actions increased scrutiny, and that the Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, should have a role in handling the problems. Mr. Vallone saw Mr. Cuomo at a Columbus Day ball Saturday evening and insisted then that the Council should play a role, though it was not clear in precisely what forum, a senior Council aide said yesterday.
The Mayor met early yesterday morning with First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and the Mayor's top political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, and again late yesterday afternoon with them and others, including the Mayor's press secretary, Albert Scardino; the Corporation Counsel, Victor A. Kovner, and other deputy mayors.
 
'Overloaded' Circuits
Mr. Scardino said: ''The issue is not whether there's anything different to be done. The issue is why haven't we been able to make ourselves clear. A remarkable series of events in one week has overloaded everybody's circuits.''
''None of this was unanticipated,'' Mr. Scardino said, referring to a week that began with agreement on a 5.5 percent pay raise for teachers and $1.8 billion in proposed new taxes over the next four years to finance a plan to hire thousands of police officers and expand the criminal-justice system, and ended with a partial hiring freeze and the threat of layoffs.
''It was a clear and deliberate attempt to accomplish these various items by this week,'' he said. ''This administration has shown it can make the difficult decisions.''

HEADLINE: University Links Its Future To a New Face in Hartford

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 3

 BODY:
Administrators at the University of Connecticut well remember the euphoria of Husky fever that swept through the campus and much of the state last spring as the men's basketball team clinched its first-ever Big East championship. It was just about the same time that the janitorial staff stopped cleaning most buildings because of state budget cutbacks.
In many minds here those two developments are intimately related. With a new governor taking office in Hartford in January, a state budget bleeding with red ink and an economy slumping throughout the region, the belief that the University of Connecticut's sports success has won it a pool of good will and emotional enthusiasm has become a straw to be clutched at and held onto. 
''There is a pride in the University of Connecticut when I talk to legislators - from both parties, from both houses, and the executive branch - that we used to have to work on before,'' said the university's interim president, Harry J. Hartley. ''And while it may have been basketball that gained us the initial entree, I'm smart enough to ride whatever horse gets me to the destination of selling UConn.''
But for the moment, the daily reality here at the school's main campus in the northeast corner of the state is that much of what the future seems to hold is not that promising. It is the largest public university in the state, but the university still has no permanent president, for example. The last one, John T. Casteen 3d, resigned last March in part, he said, because of doubts he had about the state's long-term commitment to public higher education.
Dr. Hartley, a former vice president for finance, said whether he will even seek a permanent appointment will somewhat depend on whether he becomes convinced that the state will support the school in the tough times to come. Even basketball is in question, since the team's star forward, Nadav Henefeld, returned to his native Israel.
''We're in a waiting mode,'' said Lois Post, the university's acting director of development. ''You don't know who's going to be the president for sure, and that will affect what the university is. And you don't know who's going to be governor, and that might have some effect on who the president is.''
In the meantime, there is the question of money. On Oct. 1, for example, state budget officers in Hartford announced an immediate 5 percent spending cut. Some agencies, like the Department of Income Maintenance, which oversees the welfare system, and the Department of Correction, which handles the prison system, were spared. Higher education was not spared, a fact that many people here took as an omen of things to come.
 
Sparing the Academic Side
The cuts will be concentrated, as previous ones have also been, on the university's physical plant department. The idea, officials said, has been to spare the academic side at all costs, and muddle through on the rest as much as possible. The university's appropriation from the state, $141 million this year, has already been reduced by $6.4 million since the fiscal year began on July 1. The 113-member maintenance staff is down by 54 positions.
Even the fact that higher education spending has not become a major issue in the gubernatorial campaign is seen as ominous. The fear here is that the silence reflects a consensus among the candidates that higher education could be devastated when the new governor moves to resolve a budget gap next year that could be as large as $1 billion in a budget of only $7 billion.
Two of three major candidates for governor, for example, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, the Democrat, and Representative John G. Rowland, the Republican, have already flatly said that the higher education budget request of $469 million for next year - a 14.4 percent spending increase over last year - will almost certainly be unobtainable. The request calls for $159 million for the university.
Avice A. Meehan, a spokeswoman for the third candidate, former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who is running as an independent, said he would not ''second-guess'' the request, because he had not fully examined it.
 
Drawing Out-of-State Students
The university faces other questions. This year's 2,400-member freshman class, for example, includes the highest number of out-of-state students of any class in the university's history, 23.7 percent. Admissions officials say some students are coming in response to even deeper state spending cuts at some other public schools in the Northeast, especially in Massachusetts.
The university wants to keep that advantage, especially since the number of high school graduates in the Northeast is expected to shrink in the 1990's. In a time of increased competition among state universities, avoiding further cutbacks and maintaining a reputation for academic quality will be critical, admissions officials argue. Total enrollment at the university, according to preliminary estimates, was about flat this fall, at 25,500 students, compared to 25,634 last year.
''I paid another $7,000 to come here,'' said Erica Brynes, a 17-year-old pre-business major from Cranston, R.I. Miss Brynes said she looked first at her own state's top public school, the University of Rhode Island, but concluded that the University of Connecticut had suffered less from cutbacks, especially in the business school.
 
Squeeeze From Tuition Rises
And some fear that tuition increases last year, which pushed total costs to $7,172 for in-state student living on campus, and $14,300 for an out-of-state student, is already squeezing out many of the middle-income students on which the university has historically depended. Room-and-board rates for residents, for instance, rose 19.3 percent this year, to $2,028. Tuition alone rose more than 15 percent.
''It's something that the next governor has got to think about,'' said Ann L. Huckenbeck, the director of admissions. ''Connecticut exports over 50 percent of its high school graduates to out-of-state institutions, and the literature confirms that people tend to stay where they get their undergraduate degrees.'' ''It's a brain drain,'' she said. Among the students who are here, attitudes about the governor's race commonly ranged from cynicism to apathy, even though many people acknowleged that financing for the university could be at stake.
''I get the feeling that even if you get someone in there who's really going to pull for more money,'' said Peter Lowe, 27, a graduate student in literature, ''it'll somehow get lost in political transit and there won't be any more money.''

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about budget problems at the University of Connecticut misidentified a graduate student who spoke about higher education as an issue in Connecticut's race for governor. He is Peter Rowe.

HEADLINE: Facing Their Own Recession, Regional Stages Tighten Belts

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
At the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, they've shortened their rehearsal periods, cut down their casts and dropped their play-reading and seminar series.
At the Goodman Theater in Chicago, all tickets left at the box office by 6 P.M. are immediately sold at half price.
At the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, they've entered into a co-production agreement with the Hartford Stage Company to produce A. R. Gurney's ''Snow Ball'' this season because they couldn't afford to do it alone.
In these and other ways, nonprofit regional theaters are seeking to offset serious cutbacks in corporate funding and a decline in subscription sales as the threat of recession is felt across the United States. Although theaters in the Northeast have been hit hardest, the pinch is being felt by almost everyone, says Tom Hall, president of the League of Resident Theaters, known as LORT. The exception is the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, which he says ''has a huge corporate community base of giving no other theater in the country has.'' Mr. Hall, who is also the managing director of the Old Globe in San Diego, says that while his theater has just had its best year in the last 10, ''there is no future of growth ahead of us.'' 
''LORT has existed for the last 25 years and, up until five or six years ago, flourished in fits and starts,'' Mr. Hall says. ''But since then we've seen the membership go from 80 theaters down to 68, with the Actors Theater of St. Paul the most recent casualty in the last six months.''
The irony of the situation, he says, is that ''as Broadway shows a decline in providing employment, artists are looking to LORT to pick up the slack just as the financial universe is shrinking.'' Indeed, meetings of the Dramatists Guild will take place this week to decide how to persuade LORT to agree on a contract for its membership.
 
New Ways of Coping
But if the financial universe is shrinking, it is not quite disappearing. To replace the corporate money lost through mergers and hard times, concentrated drives for individual contributions have proved successful wherever they have been implemented.
''We're putting as much energy and time as we can into getting money from our nearest and dearest - the people who are really using the theater today,'' says David Hawkanson, managing director of the Hartford Stage Company. ''When times are tough, they are the ones who really understand.''
Michael Maso, managing director of the Huntington Theater Company in Boston, agrees. ''Our subscribers are very loyal and responsive to our needs in terms of gifts,'' he says. ''Individual contributions have kept growing despite the recession.''
Co-production, which splits costs between two or more theaters and doubles or triples a paying audience, is becoming much more common. At the La Jolla Playhouse, says its managing director, Alan Levy, co-productions of musicals with the Orange County Arts Center are an effective way to amortize expenses. ''They have a 3,000-seat house, and we can only have limited runs here,'' he says. ''So we develop the work, then use their venue. That partnership allows us at no risk to continue producing our own work without having to generate additional contributed income.''
The theaters are also learning to be less rigid about selling subscriptions, since the younger audiences they are trying to cultivate do not like making plans six months in advance.
''There's been a basic change in the metabolism of theatergoers,'' says Robert J. Orchard, managing director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. ''The older, more established audience was brought up on a subscription system. They liked having specific seats and buying them at the heaviest possible discount well in advance. The younger generation has more difficulty planning. They want a spontaneous approach, though they still want more of an alliance with us than single-ticket sales give them. So we have an alternative subscription where you can pick three out of five shows, which is more accommodating to their life style and mood.''
 
Promoting Single Tickets
The Guthrie's executive director, Ed Martenson, says his theater goes a step further. ''The backbone of our marketing effort is packaging and targeting,'' he says. ''In addition to our regular subscription, if we can identify a group of people who have an affinity for just three of the plays, we will.'' He cited one package, a series of five plays for singles, complete with food and drinks served afterward, that attracted 300 buyers.
Still, there are people who will commit only to a single-ticket buy. And much as it goes against the grain of a nonprofit-theater mentality - and budget - to run a marketing campaign geared toward single-ticket buying, it is happening more and more as theaters struggle to fill their seats.
''We've had a soft subscription campaign this year,'' says Mr. Hall of the Old Globe. ''The ticket-buyers are still there, but they're not planning ahead to spend their cash. That means that we're having to spend more on single-ticket advertising. It's much more cost-effective to sell subscriptions.''
Paula Tomei, general manager of the South Coast Repertory Theater in Costa Mesa, Calif., agreed. ''We encourage single-ticket buying, but we do try to convert the single-ticket buyers of the first one or two shows of the season into subscribers,'' she says. ''With the extra ad dollars it takes to sell single tickets, it's cheaper to renew a subscriber.''
Every effort is made to accommodate single-ticket buyers at the Goodman Theater in Chicago, and then some. The Goodman's producing director, Roche Schulfer, says, ''We've decided that the world is made up of either subscribers or budget-seeking single-ticket buyers. There's nothing in the middle.'' The theater's Tix at Six program, which sells any unsold seats, as well as the notorious subscriber no-shows at 8 P.M., always draws lines. ''At 6 P.M., any unsold tickets go to half-price, no questions asked,'' Mr. Schulfer says. ''It's an idea we stole from Joe Papp and the Public Theater four seasons ago, and we have a very strong following for it. With it, we were able to achieve 100 percent capacity last year.''
The Quicktix program, as it is called at the Public in Manhattan, is still thriving. But the general manager, Bob MacDonald, says the theater has dropped its pass-holder campaign, which allowed anyone who made a contribution to buy tickets at a 30 to 40 percent discount. Although it would appear that the program was too much of a good thing for pass-holders and not one for the theater, Joseph Papp says the program was dropped to make way for a new, younger audience. The theater has begun what Mr. Papp characterized as ''a very expensive direct marketing campaign'' to re-establish the Public as an institutional theater with a subscription season after past individual commercial successes like ''A Chorus Line.''
 
Corporate Focus Shifting
While many nonprofit theaters - La Jolla, Old Globe, Seattle Repertory Theater and Hartford Stage among them - acknowledge a drop in corporate contributions, the Guthrie does not. ''There's no evidence here yet that a recession or the threat of it has affected the picture,'' Mr. Martenson says, ''though there's an awful lot of talk about it.'' He also said that of the roughly $3 million raised by his theater for general operating expenses this year, $1 million came from corporations.
But the Guthrie is a special case. Paul Libin, producing director of Circle in the Square in New York City, points out that not only are there fewer corporate dollars to spend, but that corporate sponsors have also shifted their focus away from the arts to environmental, educational and community programs. ''The shopping list is always changing,'' he says. ''And with all the corporate mergers over the last few years, the support is cut way back anyway. You can seemingly lose the money overnight. They abandon you.''
Though theaters like the Trinity Repertory in Providence, R.I., and the South Coast Repertory cite a rise in corporate support caused by concentrated campaigns by board members, others have had to find new ways to stretch their budgets. Edgar Rosenblum, executive director of the Long Wharf Theater, says, ''We've cut things that don't really hurt us, but they do put the pressure on.'' Though no productions have been canceled, he says, ''We have cut props, sets and costumes, and we have cut three days out of the six-week rehearsal period. We've curtailed the number of people in the plays, and we've dropped our play-reading and seminar series. We've also limited salary increases to 3 percent, so everyone had to take a slight cut. But we didn't lay anyone off.''
The key for any theater's survival in lean times, concludes Mr. Levy of La Jolla, is creativity in the ways it goes about obtaining both its earned and contributed income. ''Any support for the theater that's out there, we try to get, whether its from one local person or a national corporation that may not know us,'' he says. ''We constantly ask for support from everyone. Now is not the time to be shy.''

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Empire's 'Junk' Tactic

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Li Ka-shing has built a multibillion-dollar fortune and a business empire by trusting his instincts rather than the crowd's. But for all his contrarian savvy, his attempt to burst into the United States by purchasing the $3 billion ''junk bond'' portfolio of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association is raising more eyebrows here than cheers.
For the time being, the United States Government has halted the transaction because regulators did not approve of the loan Columbia Savings, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., would be making to Mr. Li's group. But negotiations are continuing, and Mr. Li seems determined to buy the bond package. Through a spokesman, Mr. Li refused to be interviewed.
His determination highlights a sensitive challenge facing Chinese executives in this nervous British colony. As they spirit some, if not most, of their billions of dollars in capital out of Hong Kong before China takes over in 1997, will they also be able to export their money-spinning wizardry to the United States? 
 
Periscope on Corporate America
''The big factor in the deal is that it would give us a periscope into corporate America,'' said Simon Murray, a wiry Briton with a dry wit who is group managing director of Mr. Li's flagship conglomerate, the publicly traded Hutchison Whampoa Ltd.
The United States has a far more competitive market, where the informal networks that tie together and control Hong Kong's economy do not reach.
Mr. Murray emphasized, nonetheless, that Mr. Li could not afford not to look to the United States as a potential home for some of his assets.
''We'd like to have a position in the U.S., but there are different rules in that game,'' Mr. Murray said, acknowledging that wandering outside the cozy confines of Hong Kong was easier said than done. ''It sounds immodest to say that Hong Kong is getting too small for us, but the walls are getting close. We don't have much choice.''
 
Delicacy of the Situation
Making the situation even more delicate is that confidence in Hong Kong may be shattered if it appears that business leaders like Mr. Li are pulling up stakes.
''His options are limited by his profile,'' said John Mulcahy, an analyst at Peregrine Brokerage Ltd., a firm in which Mr. Li has an investment. ''The impact on market sentiment if people thought he was really pulling out would be devastating.''
Undaunted, Mr. Li, who is 62 years old, has placed himself at the vanguard of those determined to gain a foothold in the largest, one of the safest and one of the most open economies in the world. That determination could eventually have a big impact on both Hong Kong and the United States, because of the tens of billions of dollars his companies control.
Mr. Li and various public and private interests he controls are a 50 percent partner in the group that won the bidding for Columbia Savings' junk bonds. With the market for such bonds nearly comatose, describing Mr. Li's move as being against the grain would be an understatement.
 
Potentially Attractive Terms
The deal, nonetheless, had potentially attractive terms. Mr. Li and his partner, Gordon Investment, a Canadian investment concern, would have put down just 10 percent, or $300 million, in cash. The remainder would have come in the form of a 10-year loan from Columbia, which lost $430 million in the first half of the year.
The $3 billion price tag was $70 million over the estimated market value at the time of the bid. At its peak, Columbia's junk bond portfolio had a face value of about $4.5 billion.
''I worry that they're going into something that they don't understand,'' said Marc Faber, an investment adviser here who previously ran the Hong Kong office of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which sold most of the junk bonds to Columbia Savings. ''They are very good, but what do they know about managing a junk bond portfolio?''
''I would prefer they stay in Hong Kong, where they have the expertise,'' said Steven So, an analyst here with Jardine Fleming Securities.
 
Further Drop in Bonds' Value
Joe Bencivenga, head of high-yield research at Salomon Brothers in New York and a former junk bond analyst at Drexel, said the value of the bonds had dropped another $200 million since the bidding. ''They need to have a 5-to-10-year horizon to make this work,'' he commented.
As Mr. Murray emphasized in his office overlooking the Hong Kong harbor, this move would be not an investment play but an essential part of the group's future as it seeks to escape the uncertainty of Hong Kong.
It is also, Mr. Murray added, part of the testing of the next generation of leadership at the company; a key figure in it was Richard Li, Mr. Li's 23-year-old, American-educated son.
''Some people have expressed their doubts about the sons,'' Mr. Mulcahy said, ''but K. S. still has the final say. He's exposing them to the front line.''
 
Loans to 300 Companies
The acquisition would instantly make this canny entrepreneur a big lender to more than 300 large American companies, people familiar with the portfolio's contents said .
The companies, they said, range from RJR Nabisco to McCaw Cellular Communications, Pacific Lumber and Wickes. The deal would give Mr. Li access to potentially large amounts of inside data - as well as the responsibility for helping keep the companies afloat in difficult times.
''It is a good opportunity, but it will require an immense amount of manpower,'' said one Wall Street expert who had studied the portfolio. ''There are going to be numerous workouts, bankruptcies and other negotiations associated with these securities.''
 
Possible Acquisitions Studied
Mr. Murray said Hutchison Whampoa had already studied possible acquisitions like Pan Am, Hilton Hotels and CSX, the transportation concern.
Despite its reputation as a bastion of free markets, Hong Kong's economy is actually a series of semi-monopolies and cartels, analysts contend. Much of Mr. Li's fortune was created from and is invested in such situations.
Mr. Li's background is like that of many Hong Kong entrepreneurs; he is a refugee from China. He left his family's home in southern China in 1940, and 10 years later had opened a factory, riding the crest of the first wave of industrialization in Hong Kong - making plastic flowers. That business provided him the capital to make his move, eight years later, into property investment, where he built his fortune, now estimated at $2 billion to $3 billion.
 
Member of Informal Cartel
By the early 1980's his principal real estate concern, the publicly traded Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd., in which he owns about 40 percent, was an industry leader. It is now a member of what analysts here describe as a sort of informal cartel that orchestrates the supply of apartments to the market every year to insure that supply will not slacken.
When Mr. Li bought control of Hutchison Whampoa - one of the old British trading companies, or hongs - he gained control of one of two leading retailers here and a more-than-60-percent share in the business of loading and unloading containers at what is one of the largest ports in the world. Later, Mr. Li acquired a large stake in a Government-sanctioned monopoly, Hongkong Electric Holdings, a power company.
In recognition of his position as a pre-eminent business figure, Mr. Li holds the title of non-executive deputy chairman of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which dominates finance here.
 
Steps Taken Into Canada
Mr. Li has also taken several big steps into Canada, acquiring 43 percent of Husky Oil Operations Ltd. and buying a 204-acre site in downtown Vancouver, British Columbia, where the 1986 World's Fair was held. He is building, in a project in which his other son, 26-year-old Victor, is heavily involved, a $1.7 billion development at the site that will include more than 7,000 housing units and two million square feet of office space.
Recently, Hutchison has invested heavily in telecommunications. It now dominates the paging and cellular phone businesses here and is a big investor in Asiasat I, a satellite sent into orbit aboard a Chinese rocket earlier this year. Its signal will reach from Karachi, Pakistan, to Tokyo -more than two billion people.
It is an impressive history and array of businesses, but it has still been difficult to get American investment experts to take the company seriously, Mr. Murray complained. One of Mr. Li's problems in moving to the United States, he added, is that Wall Street investment bankers still do not bring him their best deals.
''We're an afterthought for some of these people,'' Mr. Murray said. ''They say, 'There's this guy in Hong Kong named K. S. Li who has got a lot of bread. He'll buy anything.' We have to find a way in that allows us to do the negotiated deals. That's what we hope this deal will do for us.''

HEADLINE: Cigarette Makers Try To Brake a Slide

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE

 BODY:
Here in tobacco country, the notion that Washington is almost certain to raise Federal taxes on cigarettes has some people smiling.
Among them are executives of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, the nation's third-largest cigarette maker and one of the leading sellers of discount brands like Viceroy, Raleigh and Richland. Smokers tend to buy more of these cheaper brands as the overall prices of cigarettes and other consumer items rise.
Brown & Williamson is even betting that discount brands could so stimulate demand that they could help pull the cigarette industry out of its long sales decline.
 
A Tax Rise Likely
The Federal excise tax on cigarettes is now 16 cents a pack. As part of a budget compromise that the House defeated on Friday, Congressional and White House negotiators had agreed to raise the tax by 4 cents next year and another 4 cents in 1993. It is not clear what will emerge from new budget negotiations, but a cigarette-tax increase remains highly likely, industry experts say. 
As the tobacco company most dependent on sales of discount brands, Brown & Williamson, which is based in Louisville, has less to lose and possibly more to gain than its competitors.
The brands can cost as little as $1.10 a pack, compared with $2.35 or more for full-price cigarettes like Marlboros by Philip Morris Inc., in highly taxed states like New York. The industry refers to the lower-price brands as generic cigarettes because they were sold in black-and-white packages with no-name labels when the Liggett Group first popularized them in in the early 1980's.
 
'Branded' Generics
But it did not take long for cigarette makers to realize they could increase sales by marketing ''branded'' generics. Now, about 61.5 percent of generic cigarettes are not generic at all.
About one out of six packs of all cigarettes now sold is a low-price brand. Even before the proposed rise in cigarette taxes, analysts were saying that discounts could account for one in four packs in a few years.
Makers of higher-priced cigarettes often say that consumers get what they pay for in low-cost brands. But the costs for tobacco, paper and other raw materials in all cigarettes are modest compared to the enormous profit. Even after deep discounting, for example, cigarette companies can earn 42 cents in gross profit for a pack, compared with 66 cents a pack for the full-price brands, according to Marc I. Cohen, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
 
A Rise in Market Share
Selling cheap American cigarettes has helped Brown & Williamson's business substantially. Besides Philip Morris and tiny Liggett, it is the only large cigarette company to have increased its market share, according to John C. Maxwell Jr., an analyst with Wheat First Securities. In the 12 months ended June 30, Brown & Williamson's share rose to 11.2 percent from 10.2 percent, a substantial performance in a declining market.
Brown & Williamson's success is built on turning moribund full-price brands like Viceroy and Raleigh into discount lines, and on introducing new discount brands like Richland.
Brown & Williamson is a unit of the London-based B.A.T Industries, one of the world's largest conglomerates, and the world's second-largest tobacco company, after Philip Morris. The cigarette subsidiary posted a 1989 profit of about $587 million, up 25 percent, on a 19 percent rise in revenue to about $5.2 billion. Much of Brown & Williamson's profit and revenue came from the United States.
Cigarette makers and securities analysts say Brown & Williamson's success is no isolated case. The best-selling, indeed the only, new products in the last two years have been discount cigarettes. They have had uninterrupted growth for the last eight years as the price of cigarettes in general has risen steeply.
Even so, some researchers suggest that steep tax increases will further reduce smoking, as people faced with the higher prices either quit or do not start. Industry experts respond that most of those studies were done four or five years ago, when discount cigarettes were not widely available. Today, generic cigarettes account for more than four billion packs a year, or about 16 percent of the market.
 
Targeted Populations
Although only 29.1 percent of adults in 1987 smoked, down from 40.4 percent in 1965, it is far from clear whether smoking is on the road to extinction.
In fact, tobacco companies are looking for the industry to pull out of its sales decline, perhaps as soon as the mid-1990's. The availability of discount cigarettes will help. But more important, further population growth in the groups likely to want discount cigarettes will help even more. These groups include retired people on fixed incomes, the poor and working class in general, and, in particular, poor members of minority groups between 15 and 24 years old, when many people begin smoking.
The general population trend is that there are fewer and fewer young people to start smoking, but the Census Bureau projections say that minority groups will be an exception. The number of blacks age 15 to 24 will rise to 5.5 million in 1995 from 5.4 million in 1990. Similarly, the number of Hispanics in the same age group will rise to 3.8 million from 3.7 million. The trends are expected to continue into the next century.
 
A Boon to the Industry
Some anti-smoking activists reluctantly agree that discount cigarettes will be a boon to the industry. ''It's the wave of the future,'' said Phillip Wilbur, a director of the Advocacy Institute, a public policy and health advocacy group.
Raymond J. Pritchard, chairman and chief executive of Brown & Williamson, said, ''You don't need to be a genius to see growth in generics if the excise tax goes up.''
''One would expect with more people unemployed and with less disposable income,'' Mr. Pritchard continued, ''one would see people shopping for more discount brands than when everyone is flush with money.''
 
Discreet Enticements
Like other companies, Brown & Williamson does not heavily advertise its discount line. Instead it spends much of its marketing budget on cents-off coupons, ''buy one get one free'' promotions, and even on trading stamps to be saved and exchanged for free or discount-priced merchandise.
Last year, close to 40 percent of the 58.5 billion cigarettes Brown & Williamson sold were discount brands. By contrast, discount brands were only 11 percent of Philip Morris's sales and 21 percent of RJR Nabisco's, although these larger companies sold a greater number of discount cigarettes over all.
In August, Brown & Williamson won on appeal a lawsuit filed by Liggett, the smallest of the nation's six cigarette makers and one that is intent on diversifying out of tobacco. Liggett accused Brown & Williamson of engaging in ''predatory pricing'' by undercutting its prices on generic cigarettes, a field that Liggett helped pioneer, especially with its Pyramid cigarettes. The victory reversed a $149 million damage claim against Brown & Williamson, and analysts now project even greater price competition among makers of discount cigarettes.
For Brown & Williamson, branded generics like Richland have helped lift sales 12 percent, to more than six million cigarettes in the first half of this year.
The strategy has also helped its old brands, such as Viceroy, introduced in 1936. Once an also-ran, Viceroy jumped from 24th in sales in 1988 to 16th in 1989 on the basis of a price cut.
Earlier this summer, Brown & Willamson cut prices on a version of its Raleigh brand, first introduced in 1928.

HEADLINE: Sumitomo Chief Quits Over Scandal

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 7

 BODY:
A simmering stock scandal reached the highest levels of the financial industry here today, with the chairman of the giant Sumitomo Bank announcing he would resign to take responsibility after an official of his bank was implicated in a plan to provide illegal loans to a corporate raider.
The chairman of the bank, Ichiro Isoda, shocked many people with the announcement two days after a former Sumitomo branch manager was arrested on charges that he accepted almost $750,000 for arranging $170 million in improper loans for the well-known and politically influential corporate raider, Matsuhiro Kotani. Mr. Kotani was indicted in August for stock manipulation.
The resignation of the 77-year-old banker, one of Japan's most powerful, was regarded as a humiliating and potentially harmful blow to Japan's third-largest bank.
It also added Sumitomo Bank's name to a list of prominent financial institutions that reportedly aided the manipulation scheme. Daiwa Securities and the brokerage unit of Citicorp, Scrimgeour Vickers International, were earlier penalized by the Finance Ministry for helping Mr. Kotani illegally inflate a stock's price in April and then take millions of dollars in profits. 
 
Tacit Understanding
The question is whether Mr. Isoda, like an old samurai following the code of honor, succeeded in halting any further damage to Sumitomo.
Mr. Isoda told reporters at a news conference that Sumitomo Bank's president, Sotoo Tatsumi, had also offered to resign but the chairman had talked him out of it for fear of leaving the bank headless.
By an unspoken understanding, when a Japanese corporation's top executive initiates the ritual of resigning to take responsibility for some misdeed of the organization, it often means the Government will not impose further penalties or sanctions.
Sumitomo could suffer serious damage if the Government were to discover and disclose that more executives sanctioned the reportedly illegal loans or had some other involvement with Mr. Kotani.
In addition to being one of the largest banks in the world and the center of the huge Sumitomo group of industrial companies, the bank owns 12.5 percent of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Wall Street securities firm. It operates a branch system in California and recently acquired Banco del Gottardo of Switzerland.
Sumitomo Bank is known as one of the most aggressive and international of Japan's banks and a pillar of the Japanese business community. It is also the country's most profitable bank.
 
With Bank 55 Years
Mr. Isoda is known as a hard-driving executive who has put making profits as a top priority, which is not all that common here. He joined the bank 55 years ago and served as president for six years until being named chairman in 1983.
The reports on Friday that the Sumitomo branch manager, 45-year-old Akinori Yamashita, who had worked in Yokohama, had helped arrange the huge loans added a key piece to the puzzle of how Mr. Kotani financed his dealings.
Mr. Kotani succeeded in a hostile takeover several years ago of Kokusai Kogyo, an aerial surveying and property company. The Government has said that senior executives of the target company engaged in insider trading. Those involved were arrested earlier on tax evasion charges.
Mr. Kotani was then indicted on charges that he manipulated the price of shares in Fujita Tourist Enterprises, a leading hotel and restaurant group, in part to raise cash to pay for his takeover of Kokusai Kogyo. The arrest of the Sumitomo Bank branch manager might offer a partial explanation of how Mr. Kotani financed those dealings.
On Aug. 31, Daiwa and two smaller Japanese firms were ordered to suspend operations at some branches for two days in connection with the stock manipulation. Scrimgeour Vickers, which has just one branch in Tokyo, was ordered to close for a day.
Even after the prosecutor's announcement on Friday, details of the case against Mr. Yamashita were fuzzy. The basic charge was that he had arranged for a small number of customers of his branch to make two loans, one to a company controled by Mr. Kotani, and another to a second company. The total was about $170 million at current exchange rate. For providing this service, Mr. Yamashita is alleged to have received nearly $750,000.
It is against Japanese banking laws for a bank official to arrange for loans outside of his bank through third parties.
One report added another step to Mr. Yamashita's alleged crime: the article in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a leading economic daily, said Mr. Yamashita had arranged for the bank's customers to borrow money from the bank, and then lend it to Mr. Kotani's group.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Free-Market Lessons Of Chile's 'Chicago Boys'

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
After facing critics and doubters for years, the economists and others who made Chile's free-market revolution are now being sought by many countries to share their experiences and advise on topics like privatization, debt management and fighting poverty.
''We're not preachers; we talk to practical people who are trying to learn from the Chilean experience, who want to know the details of why and how we did things,'' said Pablo Baraona, one of the original group known as the Chicago Boys who joined the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet soon after the 1973 coup that overthrew the Socialist Government of President Salvador Allende.
The popularity of these economists abroad reflects ''the change in the world; we are all looking for the same thing now,'' Mr. Baraona said.
 
Disciples of Free-Market Faith
Hernan Buchi, another of ''Los Chicago'' and a former finance minister who ran for president unsuccessfully in the December elections, observed, ''The main criticism that used to be made of what we did in Chile - that the social cost was too high - has now been proved to be mistaken, because a higher social cost is being paid by countries that followed other policies.'' 
After returning from a seminar in Argentina on how Chile managed to reduce its foreign debt through debt-equity swaps, Mr. Buchi was preparing to go to Bolivia, then to Paris to take part in a conference for East Europeans on overhauling state-owned companies.
The Chicago Boys label came from the fact that Mr. Baraona and several others who drafted and managed the program to turn Chile away from statism studied economics at the University of Chicago and became disciples of Milton Friedman's free-market faith.
Others in the group studied at Columbia University - Mr. Buchi, for example - or at Harvard University or in Chile, but all have been lumped together for the ideas they share.
 
Combating State Dominance
When this group from the country's best and brightest began to enter the military Government in the mid-1970's, it inherited not only the results of three years of the Allende Government, which took giant steps down the path to socialism, but also a long Chilean tradition of state dominance over the economy and inefficient, protected local industry.
Chile was not feeding itself. A large part of the land, once used mainly to provide a comfortable way of life for those who owned it, was the focus of confiscations and other efforts at changes. Only copper was making economic sense in Chile.
Moving with what Mr. Baraona called a spirit of combat, the economists and technocrats sold nationalized companies or returned them to earlier owners, slashed import duties, invited foreign investment, eliminated entitlement programs for the middle class, improved tax collections and pushed local business executives and foreign investors to increase exports by exploiting the country's advantages in areas like fruits, vegetables, fisheries and forestry.
 
Sharing With Other Countries
These advisers now have experiences to share with other countries trying to create market economies, said Cristian Larroulet Vignau, Mr. Buchi's chief aide in the Finance Ministry and now executive director of the Institute of Liberty and Development, a research center.
He said a stream of professionals from the institute, of which Mr. Buchi is president, and others who worked on Chile's economic transformation now travel to Latin America, the Caribbean and Europe, especially Eastern Europe.
One of the most sought-after advisers is Hernan Somerville, Chile's chief foreign debt negotiator from 1983 to 1988, who carried the responsibility for negotiating debt restructuring and reduction with both governments and commercial banks. The agreements included authorization for a debt-for-equity program and debt buyback plan that formed the basis of the so-called Brady plan for reducing third world debt.
''I sit with the finance minister or central bank president, and he tells me their situation,'' he said.
He added: ''Sometimes I have intervened with bank steering committees to sound them out. I guess I have a reputation among the 500 banks that have known me for five years.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Venezuela Improving Oil Quality

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOQUERON, Venezuela

 BODY:
Stacks of pipes near well-drilling rigs here point to a transformation in oil production in Venezuela, the nation with the largest proven oil reserves in the Americas.
By drilling to new depths below the table-flat plains of eastern Venezuela, oil workers are starting to tap a sea of highly prized low-sulfur light and medium crude oil.
''This is the largest oilfield discovery in Venezuela in the last 25 years, another Prudhoe Bay,'' said Norbert G. Sporn, a spokesman for Petroleos de Venezuela, the state oil company.
From the neutral vantage point of a London office, Kim Fuad, an editor for the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, described the fields here as ''a tremendous windfall for Venezuela.'' 
 
Up to 15 Billion Barrels
''These finds are very big - 10 to 15 billion barrels,'' said Mr. Fuad, a Venezuela expert. ''That's more than half of United States proven reserves.''
Indirectly, the fields also represent a boon for the United States, which receives two-thirds of Venezuela's oil exports. United States oil production has been dropping in recent years, and during the 1990's imports are expected to increase by about 50 percent from their current level of 8.5 million barrels a day.
With the threat of war enveloping the Middle East, Government officials here have started touting Venezuela - four days by oil tanker from the United States - as a ''friendly, safe source.''
''Here in the region, we potentially have the oil to meet any crisis,'' Carlos Andres Perez, the nation's President, said in an interview in Caracas recently. ''The United States can trust, always depend on, Venezuela as a safe supplier.''
 
Working Around the Clock
To meet the expected increased demand, geologists and laborers are working around the clock on a crash program to increase production in 15 months to 500,000 barrels a day, from 300,000 barrels today.
During the next 10 years, the production program is expected to change the mix of oil drilled in Venezuela, the Western Hemisphere's largest oil exporter.
Venezuela has historically produced low-value high-sulfur heavy crude from the nation's western region. Today, about 70 percent of Venezuela's oil comes from this region, largely from around Lake Maracaibo.
But with new discoveries around here, 70 percent of Venezuela's proven reserves are now in the east, with light and medium crude oil predominating.
''The future of Venezuela's oil industry is going to be in the east,'' Mr. Sporn predicted, surveying a landscape where oil rigs broke a baking-hot monotony of cattle ranches and cornfields.
 
An Important Difference
By 1995, Venezuela's production is expected to be evenly split between heavy crude and the higher-value light and medium crude oils. For a country that last year relied on oil exports for 76 percent of its income, the difference is important: in recent months, higher-quality oil has sold for as much as $8 a barrel more than lower-quality oil.
A quirk of history is helping the Venezuelans to put the fields into production quickly. Thanks to a legacy of 70 years of oil production here, oil pipelines and tank farms are already in place.
The old wells started to run dry in the late 1960's, leading to two decades of economic stagnation in this state, Monagas, and in the neighboring state of Anzoategui. But in the late 1980's, new technology allowed the Venezuelan companies operating here, Lagaven and Corpoven, to pierce the old well threshold of 5,000 feet and to reach depths of 20,000 feet.
High-resolution seismic surveys, aerogravimetric surveys, steam injection and three-dimensional computer models were among the new technologies that allowed Venezuelans to map out new, deeper fields here in the late 1980's.
Although deep drilling is more expensive, the payoff has been greater. On the average, the deep wells here produce 7,000 barrels a day. By contrast, the average well in Venezuela produces 120 barrels a day.
Today, the main obstacle to rapidly increasing production is a worldwide shortage of drilling rigs.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Budget Solution Is Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Beyond the political theater over the Federal budget lies one stark deadline for the credit markets: the United States Government will be in default on its debt obligations if a budget accord is not reached by Thursday.
To a certain extent, market participants have become anesthetized on Washington's ways; this is, after all, the fourth time in the last decade that the Government has marched to the brink of insolvency.
Analysts expressed confidence that the current crisis would be resolved, despite the deep political differences that divide the parties on the budget issue. The financial price of a stalemate that extends past Thursday morning, when interest payments on Treasury bills are due, seems too great for even politicians to ignore. 
 
Short Shutdown 'Acceptable'
''Shutting down the Government for a short period is acceptable,'' said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. ''A default is not. They have to get something done by Thursday morning.''
''One way or another we will have a budget package, and a cut in the deficit,'' said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
To Mr. Kasriel and other analysts, approval of a package of the dimensions of the $40 billion in spending cuts and tax increases for the current fiscal year that was rejected late last week seemed more likely than the $85 billion to $100 billion in spending cuts that would occur if the Gramm-Rudman budget legislation were enforced.
 
Explosive 'Sequester' Rally
The failed compromise resulted in a rally in the financial markets last week, but analysts said that across-the-board cuts, commonly referred to in Washington as a ''sequester,'' would probably generate an explosive rally. ''Sequester would be better for the bond market, but it would be worse for the economy,'' Mr. Kasriel said. ''It's a bigger package, and it is all on the spending side.''
Congress moved toward a new proposal yesterday for about $40 billion in savings, but traders of government bonds will not return to the market until tomorrow, after the Columbus Day holiday.
Analysts agreed that the Federal Reserve Board, widely seen as ready to lower short-term interest rates to shore up a badly sagging economy, would delay making any move until after a budget package was approved. Moreover, the Fed's response, when it comes, is likely to be tailored to the nature of the fiscal program that emerges. ''If the budget reduction action takes the form of a very severe sequester, that would produce an even greater reaction from the Fed,'' Mr. Crandall said.
 
Reaction to Job Report
On a purely economic basis, the contents of September's employment report released last Friday suggest that the Fed needs to do something soon. Excluding census workers, nonfarm payroll employment fell by 59,000 last month, a number that rounded out a very bleak job-creation picture for the third quarter. In the last three months, payroll employment increased by only 70,000 jobs. During the same period, the number of people working part-time rose by 350,000, with 330,000 in September alone.
''The situation is horrible,'' said Joseph Carson, a Chemical Bank economist. After including the latest employment figures with other reports, he estimated that the economy did not grow at all during the third quarter, and might have even contracted slightly.
''I don't see how anyone could read the employment report as anything other than a recession report,'' said Alan Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company. ''Under normal circumstances, it would call for a Fed easing.''
The Fed would probably be cautious on doing very much, Mr. Sinai and others said, because the inflation outlook remained bleak. Fresh evidence of rapidly rising prices is almost certain to appear on Friday, when producer price figures for September are expected to be released.
 
Larger Price Rises Seen
Given the further sharp increase in oil prices, analysts said they were not optimistic that last month's rise in the Producer Price Index will be improved from the very sharp rise of 1.3 percentage points recorded in August. Indeed, some economists are forecasting that the September number will be even larger.
In addition to the producer price numbers, on Friday traders and analysts will probably take a close look at a September retail sales report that will probably show surprising strength. Experts said retail sales might have jumped by almost 2 percent last month, a figure that would be the largest monthly increase since January. Economists said much of the likely rise was related to higher gasoline prices. But auto sales were surprisingly strong as well.
Those two items probably mask continued consumer caution, however. Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimate that, excluding gasoline and car sales, retail sales rose by three-tenths of a percent in September.
Nevertheless, the inflation and sales numbers are not likely to sit well with market participants. ''Friday's numbers will not be very helpful for the market,'' said Steven Slifer, an economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.

HEADLINE: William Mortensen, 87; Ran Hartford Arts Center

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
William H. Mortensen, a college dropout who became a millionaire philanthropist, a State Senator, the Mayor of Hartford, a candidate for governor and the director of Connecticut's most important center for the performing arts, died on Saturday at his summer home in Old Saybrook. He was 87 years old and lived in Stuart, Fla.
The son of emigres from Denmark, Mr. Mortensen, a popular and gregarious Republican, served only one term as State Senator, from 1941 to 1943, and one term as Mayor of Hartford, from 1943 to 1945. He was forced by heart trouble to withdraw from the 1950 gubernatorial race. 
But he led a bipartisan movement that succeeded in 1947 in establishing a strong city manager form of government in Hartford, investing power in a professional city manager and an elected City Council.
The system, which did away with patronage-ridden commissions that ran city agencies and installed single department heads named by the city manager, is in place today.
 
Development Commission Head
For nearly four decades, Mr. Mortensen helped shape Connecticut's cultural life as managing director of Horace Bushnell Memorial Hall in Hartford, a center for concerts, ballet, theater and other artistic events.
As chairman of the State Development Commission in the 1950's, he helped establish regional planning that promoted economic development, mapped highway routes and improved harbors. He also served on the State Commission for Higher Education.
William Henry Mortensen was born in Hartford on July 15, 1903, and attended public schools in Hartford and Antioch College in Philadelphia. He dropped out and went home to take an insurance job in 1923. A few years later, his life took an unusual turn.
The granddaughter of Horace Bushnell, a Hartford Congregational minister and a friend of Mark Twain, decided to build an auditorium as a memorial to him and asked Mr. Mortensen, a former Hartford High School student of her husband, to go around the country researching such halls.
 
Library Named for Him
He was put in charge of construction, and when the hall was completed in 1929, he was named managing director, a post he held until his retirement in 1968. He received two honorary doctorates: in fine arts from the University of Hartford in 1956 and in law from Trinity College in 1984.
Mr. Mortensen gave $250,000 to the University of Hartford in 1969 for its central reference library, which was named for him.
Mr. Mortensen's first wife, the former Alice Carroll, died in 1983.
He is survived by his second wife, the former Trice Carter; a stepson, Robert Carter of West Hartford; two step-grandchildren, and one step-great-grandchild. The funeral will be at 11 A.M. tomorrow at the First Church of Christ Congregational in West Hartford.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
IMPASSE ON BUDGET IS ENDED; STOPGAP SPENDING MEASURE AVERTS FEDERAL SHUTDOWN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Ending the latest budget showdown, President Bush and Congressional leaders agreed Monday night on stopgap spending legislation that averted a suspension of most Government services this morning.
The agreement came shortly before the Senate adopted the broad outline of a budget identical to the one the House approved a few hours before daybreak Monday.
Mr. Bush and the Democratic leaders of Congress were jockeying to put themselves in the best possible position to control the most important tax-and-spending legislation in years. The effect of last night's votes was to put off until next week the tough decisions on deficit reduction, which taxes to raise and which benefits to lower.
 
Earlier Bill Vetoed
On Saturday, seeking to force Congress to act quickly on the budget framework, President Bush vetoed a temporary spending bill that was similar to the one approved this morning. He said he would sign a stopgap measure if Congress approved a budget measure. The result of Saturday's veto was that some Government facilities like parks and monuments were closed over the three-day Columbus Day weekend. 
Had the Government shutdown continued today, a regular business day, the disruption would have been felt across the country.
The stopgap measure continues Government spending authority through Oct. 19. The Senate approved it by unanimous consent, the House by a vote of 362 to 3. The President said he would sign it. The Senate vote on the budget framework was 66 to 33, with 42 Democrats and 24 Republicans voting for it and 13 Democrats and 20 Republicans voting against it.
 
A Feeling of Frustration
Referring to the fact that most Republicans in the House had fought the budget plan, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, declared that he understood their ''frustration'' but said he wanted to be able to say, ''We're players in this game.''
The budget measure was almost precisely like the one the House had dramatically rejected early Friday, with one main exception. The new one would give the Democratic-controlled House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee broad leeway to recommend which taxes to raise and which benefit programs to cut.
The main effect of giving the Government continued spending authority was a postponement for another 10 days the fundamental decisions on taxes and spending.
 
Relief in the Capital
The latest developments reopened the questions of capital gains taxation and income tax rates that deadlocked budget negotiators for months. Monday, the prospects were that capital gains taxes would be lowered and the tax rate of the wealthiest taxpayers increased.
Last night's partial accord brought some relief to the tension that had swept the capital in recent days over the budget crisis.
''I've been in the Senate 16 years, and I've never seen a time more ominous for the country than now,'' said Senator Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat, at the outset of the Senate debate.
Earlier, in trying to move the Senate toward a vote on the stopgap measure, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, declared: ''We're not just dealing with numbers. We're not just dealing with programs. We're dealing with real human beings, and their families, and their hopes and fears and concerns.''
 
Bush's Advisers Divided
While the Senate talked about the budget and the temporary spending legislation, the President was huddled in the Oval Office with Vice President Dan Quayle and such top aides as John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director.
In a long day of meetings and internal debates, White House advisers were divided over whether Mr. Bush should veto the stopgap measure, officials said.
Some argued that a veto would hold Congress's feet to the fire and lay the ground for vetoes later of Democratic spending and tax measures. But others argued that Democrats and Republican leaders like Senator Dole would be so antagonized by a veto that a satisfactory budget deal would be much more difficult to strike.
According to some accounts and the officials' public comments in the past two days, Mr. Darman, who only a few days ago was one of the loudest critics of Congress, was leading the group arguing in favor of Mr. Bush's signing the stopgap measure, while Mr. Quayle was more sympathetic to those who were arguing for vetoing it. Fight Now Or Later? The ''basic question,'' Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire said after a lunch meeting of Senate Republicans, was whether the issues should be joined now or later. Mr. Rudman said that he favored later but that many of his colleagues wanted the fight now.
Typically, the Senate debate consisted mostly of monologues by individual senators and long periods of silence, while senators clustered in small groups on and off the floor trying to reach a political accommodation.
That was in sharp contrast to the spirited House debate Sunday night and early Monday, when tempers were frayed and sparks flew.
At one point Sunday night, for example, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip who had led the fight against the budget compromise President Bush and Congressional leaders reached Sept. 30, blamed Democrats for the Government shutdown.
''When the Democratic majority fails to override a veto,'' he asserted, ''it has an obligation to respond to that failure by cooperating with the President.''
 
Weariness and Anger
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, his weariness showing in his slumped shoulders but his anger flashing in his eyes, fired back: ''Of all the people in this House, of all the people in the country with little claim to cooperating with the President, it is the gentleman from Georgia.''
The House cheered and jeered at that thrust and parry and many others. It then approved a budget outline about 2 o'clock Monday morning by a vote of 250 to 164, all but 28 Democrats voting for it and all but 32 Republicans voting ''no.''
Then, just before 4 A.M., the House passed the stopgap measure, 305 to 105, to allow the Government's spending authority to continue through Oct. 19.
The budget measure is supposed to cut the deficit, now nearly $300 billion, by $40 billion this year and by a total of $500 billion over five years. It contained only totals for revenues and broad categories of spending like agriculture, education and the military and did not specify specifically how the money would be raised or allotted. This measure does not need to be signed by the President. Smaller Medicare Cuts? Senators and representatives said the newfound flexibility for the committees controlled by Democrats would mean that Medicare benefits would be shaved much less than in the earlier compromise arrangement, and that the various tax breaks for business agreed to by the President and Congressional leaders would not see the light of day.
Other parts of the compromise that would have little effect on the deficit but were politically dicey would also probably be abandoned, the lawmakers said. Such measures include a 2-cent-a-gallon tax on home heating oil and the denial of unemployment benefits the first two weeks someone was out of work.
More important, the tax committees seem likely now to approve a lower tax rate on capital gains and a higher income tax rate for the wealthiest Americans.
 
Two Chairman Give Indications
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, predicted that those provisions would be written into an omnibus tax-and-spending bill that Congress will probably vote on no later than the end of next week.
The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illionis, has given indications he would go in the same direction. However, the chairman provided no clue as to what they thought the new tax rates should be.
The action in the Senate and House underscored important differences between the two chambers.
In the House, Democrats hold a 3-to-2 majority, large enough to steamroller Republicans. But in the Senate, where the Democratic majority is only 55 to 45 and where it takes 60 votes to break a filibuster, Democrats cannot move without Republican cooperation.
 
G.O.P. Strategy Talks
During the day, House Republicans sought to set aside internal divisions to fight the Democratic budget proposal. Several lawmakers said that a closed-door meeting of House Republicans on Sunday was particularly stormy, with members clashing over strategy for countering the Democrats.
Many Republicans conceded that about the only leverage they have would be in mustering the votes to sustain a Presidential veto of the measure.
''We're in a Mexican stand-off where they can pass whatever they want,'' said Representative Chuck Douglas, Republican of Rhode Island. ''But they can't override a veto. And that makes it a very dynamic, fluid situation.''
Representative Ralph Regula, an Ohio Republican, said ''the really fundamental question is whether to support revenue increases or to stonewall - you've got a fundamental issue the House Republicans have to face, and it's hard to determine exactly what the sentiment is.''
A Republican moderate, Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert of New York, said there is ''a clear division'' among House Republicans. ''Some people cling to the unrealistic dream that you can accomplish what you really want to accomplish without spending any money.''
