HEADLINE: Teen-Agers Seek a Path Back From the Edge

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
The wind rushed through the trees of a Harlem park the other day, knocking a few acorns to the ground and startling Nierobie Hardy to his feet. He jerked his head around, as if searching the shadows for a sniper.
''I thought somebody was about to start something,'' the teen-ager said. ''People are crazy out here.'' Nierobie looked down the street where a group of young men mingled on a corner. Perhaps they were selling drugs; perhaps they were just hanging out in a neighborhood where there are few other places for people to gather.
''All my friends,'' he said, ''want to blow up'' - make a lot of money fast. ''They want the Jeep, the fresh girls, the fat chains.'' 
''Do you want the same things?'' he was asked.
''Yeah,'' he said. ''But I want to live, too.''
Despite a difficult present and a checkered past of run-ins with the law and running from school, Nierobie (pronounced nye-RO-bee) is struggling - some days harder than others - to stay out of trouble. At the age of 17, he is emblematic of a generation of young people on the edge. Amid the drugs and unemployment of New York's bleakest neighborhoods - where hope and opportunity have a hard time measuring up to the fast flash of the streets - they are in danger of being lost.
''Without enough positive alternatives, we're going to lose him,'' said Vincent D. Hilliard, Nierobie's counselor at a youth organization in the South Bronx. ''I'm sure he's a good kid. But the streets aren't good. They can change anybody. It's a 50-50 chance that he may be sucked into his environment.''
When Mayor David N. Dinkins unveiled his $1.8 billion proposal last week to remold the city's criminal-justice system, he did not just call for thousands more police officers on the streets. The plan - though its political future is uncertain - would provide more than $479 million for educational and youth programs, to attack the ''root causes'' of crime. Overworked and underpaid counselors like Mr. Hilliard are already trying to do just that life-saving work, though most days they can do little more than the boy with his thumb in the dike.
''We're not tending to our crops,'' he said, referring to the city's young people. ''We're letting weeds grow in. This crop isn't ruined. We need to roll up our sleeves and harvest it.''
Every week, Mr. Hilliard counsels dozens of troubled teen-agers from across the city. There is Nierobie, and there is Faustino Garcia, a gentle 18-year-old who dresses like a tough to survive in his South Bronx neighborhood. Ruben M., who is 16, says that whenever he needs a gun he knows exactly where to get it. Fifteen-year-old Aileen F. is a onetime runaway who hopes to become the first person in her family to graduate from high school.
Bear hugs, hip-hop street talk and plenty of ''I love you's'' are the stock in trade of the 6-foot-3-inch, 250-pound Mr. Hilliard.
''Give me my goodbye hug,'' he says at the end of almost every session.
Even the hardened ones seem to relish the contact. ''When was the last time you were hugged?'' Mr. Hilliard asked an 18-year-old.
''I can't remember,'' the teen-ager said as he disappeared in Mr. Hilliard's arms.
Mr. Hilliard has been a counselor for two years at the Sports Foundation, a nonprofit organization housed on the second floor of a rundown building at 518 Willis Avenue in the South Bronx.
The organization, with an annual budget of $800,000 to $900,000 from state, city and private sources, offers job placement, tutoring, sports activities and drug counseling.
The foundation is located in the middle of a sea of so-called ''prescription mills,'' doctor's offices and pharmacies that will dispense pills with little regard for documentation or medical need. Addicts clutching bottles of cheap wine, pushers and the occasional customer in a business suit gather on the corner across the street.
Last week, Nierobie sat in the window of Mr. Hilliard's office, looking out onto the thriving pill market below, where the prescription drugs were being resold on the street.
''Yo, Vince,'' he said, ''I just saw them make a sale. Why the cops don't be around here? That's where they need to be.'' Mr. Hilliard shrugged.
 
Top of the ClassIn Street Smarts
Mr. Hilliard, who is 38, is the senior prevention counselor at the foundation, working both with children and with adults up to age 24. Many of his clients have been classified by the court system as ''persons in need of supervision'' - PINS - because of their behavior at home or at school or previous run-ins with the police. Nierobie is a PINS. ''There's no one smarter about the streets than Nierobie,'' Mr. Hilliard said. ''If they passed out grades for street knowledge, my man would be a valedictorian.
''You talk to him some days and he can sound like an angel. But you look beyond his eyes and you can tell he's seen people shot, that he's seen people struggling for crumbs, that he's seen a lot of hurt.''
Nierobie dropped out of high school more than a year ago and was kicked out of the Job Corps for fighting. Today, he spends much of his time ''chillin' with the fellas'' in front of a drug store in the shadow of the Ralph J. Rangel Houses along the banks of the Harlem River. Several times a day, every day, boats from Circle Line tours glide past the projects. Nierobie has spent most of his life here, but he has never been on one of the boats.
''That's one thing I really want to do,'' he said as a crowded boat cut through the dark water.
Nierobie lives in a two-bedroom apartment with his mother, grandmother and two younger sisters. His father is dead. His mother, Pearl Anthony, who is 36, said she sent Nierobie to the Sports Foundation because ''he didn't want to go to school.
''He was like slipping into an 'I don't care' attitude,'' she said. ''He was all the way on the edge.''
When he was 16, Nierobie says, he worked for two weeks ''slinging'' -selling crack. He hit the street by 11 A.M. and sold for the rest of the day.
''It was scary,'' he said. ''Sometimes you never know when you're going to get busted.'' He managed to avoid arrest for those two weeks.
Asked if any of his friends had been shot, Nierobie looked surprised at such a silly question.
''Kid I used to play ball with got killed right in front of C-Town,'' he said, pointing toward the local grocery store. ''Another kid, he was 16, got shot, burnt and had his head cut off. He was wild.''
Nierobie spent much of last Monday night at Harlem Hospital visiting a friend who was shot.
''One thing I can't stand is to turn on the news and see that a little baby got killed,'' Nierobie said. ''That messes with me.''
It's Camouflage In the Neighborhood Faustino Garcia walked into Mr. Hilliard's office the other day, wearing a button with the credo of Wall Street and the mean streets emblazoned on its face: ''The color of freedom is green.''
''That's the way I feel,'' Faustino said. ''You can't be free unless you got money. Without some cash in your pocket, you ain't nobody.''
Faustino prefers to be called Tito, his self-christened street name. It sounds tougher than Faustino and in his South Bronx neighborhood ''if you're soft you're lost,'' as a popular rap song by Boogie Down Productions goes.
Tito, a student at Bronx Regional High School, is part of the I Have A Dream program, which offers college scholarships to students if they finish high school. He grew up a few blocks from the Sports Foundation and is as street-smart as they come.
''I fell into stuff a couple of times but I got out of it,'' he said. ''I said to myself, 'This ain't my style.' My father didn't raise me like that.''
Tito has two gold tooth caps, worn for show, that he slips off for job interviews or when he talks with Mr. Hilliard. Sometimes he forgets.
''Smile for me, little brother,'' Mr. Hilliard asked him. Tito smiled.
''No gold. All right,'' Mr. Hilliard said.
Later, Tito and Mr. Hilliard were walking through the throng of addicts on the corner. Tito asked if he could put his caps back on. ''Yeah,'' Mr. Hilliard said. ''You're back in the 'hood.
''Faustino looks devious - gold teeth, wearing his hat crooked - but that's the neighborhood camouflage so he looks tough so he doesn't get beaten up,'' Mr. Hilliard explained. ''He wouldn't bust a grape.''
Last week, Mr. Hilliard's cramped office was filled with teen-agers -Nierobie, Ruben, Aileen and 16-year-old Michele C., her big earrings and bracelets jiggling when she gestured, sounding like a wind chime.
Nierobie and Ruben said they want to become businessmen. Nierobie said he wanted to be his own boss and open a grocery store. But Mr. Hilliard told them that to do well in business they would have to attend school.
''My father had his own business and he dropped out at the sixth grade,'' Nierobie said. ''It's much different than when your father was a kid,'' Mr. Hilliard said. ''The days of 'Lift that bale' and 'Tote that barge' are over. Computers rule the world now.''
The conversation turned to the violence sweeping through the streets. Aileen said the city ignores crime and violence as long as it occurs in poor black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
All four teen-agers said they knew someone who had been shot. ''That's the way it goes,'' Nierobie said.
''That's the problem,'' Aileen snapped. ''You think that way and you'll never get out of the ghetto. That's what's wrong with those dope fiends.''
Aileen, a tall, poised young woman who lives in the South Bronx, said she used to ''be wild, running the street.'' Now, she said, she has settled down and hopes to attend college.
''In my neighborhood, people think that every black and Hispanic who wants to go to college wants to be white,'' she said. ''College is not cool for a lot of kids. I think I'll be the first person in my family to graduate from high school. Right then and there that will be an accomplishment.''
As they talked, a police patrol car cruised slowly down the street. A soft rain was falling on the crowd of addicts. ''Get off the corner,'' a police officer said over a loudspeaker from his car. He sounded like the Wizard of Oz as his voice floated into the office. ''It's raining, for Christ's sake.''
As soon as the patrol car had gone, the addicts returned. Nierobie laughed and said, ''That's the way it goes.''
Wednesday afternoon, Nierobie bounded up the stairs at the Sports Foundation, smiling and excited. He was scheduled to register for a general equivalency degree course at the East Side Settlement House. He was two hours late. Mr. Hilliard rolled his eyes but said nothing. Nierobie smiled again.
Mr. Hilliard walked Nierobie over to the school and introduced him to an instructor, John Bond.
''You must have something going for you since there are so many people interested in you,'' Mr. Bond said to Nierobie. ''They may see something in you that you don't see yet.''
Mr. Bond said the only thing he would ask of Nierobie was to work hard.
''I just want my G.E.D.,'' Nierobie said. ''No games. I'm going to pass them games up.''
On Friday, Nierobie arrived on time for his first day of school.

HEADLINE: New York City's Budget Problems Threaten to Raise Borrowing Cost

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
New York City's economic weakness and budget problems are starting to spill over into the financial markets, which may make it increasingly costly for the city government to issue bonds to raise needed funds.
Responding to the continuing reports about the city's economic troubles, professional investors sold more than $30 million of city bonds last Friday, bond traders said. With few investors eager to buy them, the price of the bonds fell sharply, causing interest rates to rise 15-hundredths of a percentage point.
For New York City, which borrows more money in the bond markets than any other entity except the United States Treasury, a rise of a fraction of a percentage point in interest rates adds many millions of dollars to the cost of raising money for long-term projects such as building schools and repairing bridges. 
More important than the recent increase in rates is the concern that it may be the start of a trend, unless the Dinkins administration can put together a clear-cut plan for curbing municipal costs and raising revenues. Without a credible budget package, the city may have to pay even higher rates on its bonds to attract skittish investors.
''The ball in squarely in the city's court,'' said Harrison J. Goldin, former city comptroller and now a corporate consultant. ''The market knows it is confronting considerable supply of new city bonds and it is waiting for the city to provide some specific and meaningful indication of the steps it is going to take to close the budget deficits.''
New York City sells more than $800 million of bonds every three months. Over the last month, the interest rates on the city's bonds have increased by roughly a quarter of a percentage point more than the rates on bonds issued by other cities. The quarter-point move means that the interest payments on the amount of bonds the city sells in the course of a year would increase by $80 million over 30 years. Bonds are issued for terms from one to 30 years.
The municipal bond markets were closed yesterday for Columbus Day. Officials at bond rating agencies were not available to comment on city bonds.
The sharp reaction in the markets last week seemed to recall the financial turbulence of the city's fiscal crises, like the one in the mid-1970's. But investors insist that the circumstances today are quite different. At present, investors are mainly concerned that the value of their bonds will fall as the city's credit rating declines during the region's economic downturn. They are not yet worried that the city will fail to pay its debts, which happened in 1975.
''The question today is where are the city's elected officials going to cut the budget,'' said William H. Hayden Sr., a managing director at Bear, Stearns & Company, the securities firm. ''The problem is not going to get so serious that there are questions about whether or not there is money available to pay investors.''
Still, the effect of higher interest rates is felt at a time when the city's $28 billion budget seems to be in precarious shape. City officials have already begun plans to reduce spending on long-term projects, and perhaps reduce borrowing in future years.
Some money managers note that more than financial considerations lie behind investors' reluctance to hold New York City bonds.
''It is wealthy people who own New York City bonds, and their fears about the social changes in the city, with a new mayor and more political power to minorities are being reflected in the market,'' said Dale Krieger, an investor in municipal bonds at the Carnegie Hill Company, an investment advisory firm in Princeton, N.J.
Mr. Krieger, who has continued to invest in New York City bonds this year said, ''Those political changes are good for the city, but they make it a tougher environment to borrow.''
 
Effect of Race
But Mr. Hayden of Bear, Stearns, who has served as a financial adviser to many local governments, replied that the racial composition of New York City's leaders was not an important factor for investors.
''Other cities and states have minority leaders,'' he said, ''and if people are concerned about that, and I don't think they are, those concerns will soon dissipate as investors see that the hard facts are being faced and the hard decisions are being made.''
The city's new leaders ''are as capable of making those decisions as any in the country,'' Mr. Hayden added.
The head municipal bond trader at one New York City bank said, ''So far, the city has not even come close to the problems that it faces, whether you are talking about the infrastructure, crime, or the budget deficit.'' He insisted that he not be identified so that his comments would not jeopardize the bank's future business with the city.
 
Steep Drop in Price
On Friday, prices of some city bonds due in 20 years fell more than one and a half points, or $15 for a $1,000 bond, to yield about 8.40 percent, up from 8.25 percent the previous day.
For years, New York City has benefited from the fact that interest on its bonds are exempt from Federal, state and city income taxes.
In 1988, when its credit rating was raised to the single A category, the demand from individuals was strong enough that the city could sell long-term bonds at interest rates lower than similarly rated municipalities.

HEADLINE: THE MIDDLE EAST;
In Baghdad, Few Signs of War Ahead

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The moon was rising over the oldest part of Baghdad when Saad Aziz arrived at the Maqha teahouse for a game of tawle, an Iraqi board game with links to backgammon. The game is a weekly event for Mr. Aziz and his friends, played after the group of men, Arab Christians, attend evening Mass at a church nearby.
Approached at his table on the tiled teahouse terrace, Mr. Aziz, a 33-year-old spice merchant, gestured quickly for space to be made on the straw-mat on the bench beside him. ''Welcome, welcome,'' he said, speaking English and calling for an extra cup of the Maqha's sugary tea. 
Then, to the tap-tap rhythm of dominos hitting the wooden boards at neighboring tables, he set out to discuss the situation in Kuwait, making a plea for the United States to withhold military action until a negotiated settlement can be worked out with President Saddam Hussein.
''I don't think there's going to be a war,'' he said, switching back and forth between English and his native Arabic, translated by a visitor's Iraqi guide.
As his companions nodded, Mr. Aziz added: ''I think that peaceful negotiations will be held, and the reason I think so is that a war would be disastrous, not only for Iraq and the United States, but for the whole world. Remember, both sides in the war would possess very destructive weapons.''
 
Few Signs of War
As the Iraqi merchant spoke of the specter of Baghdad's being bombed, the scene around him suggested how little life has changed for many people here since Mr. Hussein's troops stormed into Kuwait.
Although tens of thousands of soldiers have been rushed as reinforcements to Kuwait, there is little in the Iraqi capital to suggest that Mr. Hussein's Government is preparing for war. There is no curfew, and when soldiers appear at downtown intersections, it is usually only for a few hours, and then they disappear.
Apart from the heavy defenses around Mr. Hussein's palace, there is no obvious sign of intensified military activity, no tanks rolling down the wide boulevards and no trucks filled with troops.
So far as a visitor can tell, daily life here remains normal. Along the broad boulevards of the city center, there is a mix of horn-honking traffic jams, the bustle of shopping and the blare of Arab love songs and Western rock music from garishly lit nightclubs.
Largely unseen are the workings of what is reputedly the Arab world's most ruthless police state, a pervasive network of agents and informers whose reports can lead to sudden disappearances, to long prison terms, even to death.
Mr. Aziz bantered with apparent ease, saying little that seemed likely to arouse the interest of Mr. Hussein's secret police. Only once did the merchant pause, when he was asked if he thought Mr. Hussein would be ousted if war broke out and Iraq lost. Before Mr. Aziz replied, the visitor's guide, a former soldier working part-time at the Information Ministry, interrupted with a flow of Arabic that sounded cautionary.
''If we lose the war, at that point Saddam Hussein is going to find another job,'' the merchant said, choosing his words in Arabic with evident caution. ''But if they lose the war, are not President Bush and Mrs. Thatcher going to lose their jobs, too?''
After moving a white checker, he said: ''We don't wish to fight America anyway. But if we do, Iraqis will be fighting at home, and Americans will not. When our soldiers die, they will be heroes. If Americans go home in coffins, who will remember them?''
Talk of negotiations has been common here for the last week, as though it were obvious that the nations arrayed against Iraq will eventually bargain with Mr. Hussein. But so far, officials who have publicly discussed the matter have stopped short of conceding the only point that seems likely to interest Baghdad's adversaries, an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
Mr. Aziz, too, appeared hesitant on the point, saying that although Mr. Hussein has made a link between Kuwait's annexation and Israel's occupation of lands claimed by Arabs, that did not mean that Iraq would consider giving up Kuwait.
''But if you want my personal opinion, that will not be easy, because Kuwait is part of Iraq,'' he said. ''It's a territory torn from its mother country by the British, and only restored to us two months ago. Whereas the West Bank is Arab land; even America says so.''
Voice rising, he continued: ''For 40 years, America has offered the Palestinians nothing, nothing but sympathy for what they lost. Now, two months after Iraq occupied Kuwait, you have sent an army against us. Where is the justice in that?''
 
A Message for Bush
Mr. Aziz, looking at his watch, said that it was time for him to be going home to his wife and three children, but that he had a message before he left for President Bush, about the futility of hoping that the economic embargo declared by the United Nations would bring Iraq to its knees.
''You tell this to Mr. Bush,'' he said. ''The embargo is how old now, two months? Well, that's eight weeks without food imports, and nobody has died here yet.''
''Iraq is a country rich in agricultural land,'' he said. ''We have all the area of Mesopotamia, between the Tigris and the Euphrates, and we can grow all the grains there we want. So don't expect that we will collapse because of the embargo, and don't think that we are afraid of a war. We ordinary Iraqis want peace, just like people everywhere else. But if you come with your troops, you will never forget the result.''

PUB-DATE: October 9, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1216 words

HEADLINE: For a Political Neophyte, the Preacher's Approach

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The trouble with the United States, said John R. Silber, the resolutely unorthodox Democratic nominee for governor of Massachusetts, is too much prosperity and too much materialism.
Quoting Francis Bacon and Juvenal and comparing Americans to the ancient Israelites, Mr. Silber said that the United States had ''enjoyed prosperity on an unprecedented scale for an unprecedented length of time,'' and that ''only a very small percentage of our population hasn't participated.''
The result, he said, sounding more like a preacher than a politician, was inevitable, because ''luxury destroys the moral fiber and temper and sense of realism and common sense among people and they begin to get a lot of fanciful ideas.''
For Mr. Silber, the 64-year-old president of Boston University who is on leave to make his first bid for public office, the worst of those fanciful ideas are the social and foreign policies advocated by most liberals. In an interview this week he heaped scorn on the way that Massachusetts and the country as a whole have dealt with problems of race, drugs, education and public health. 
 
'Sheer Malice'
He castigated television for exposing children to ''the total sordid range of human experience at very tender ages.'' He attacked journalists, who, he said, ''express their power by destroying things, because it takes a hell of a lot longer to build something.'' In his own campaign, Mr. Silber said, many journalists had demonstrated ''sheer malice'' toward him.
''If we want to stop the drug trade,'' he said, ''we have got to stop the demand, and the only way to stop the demand is first of all to recognize that the big money in the drug trade comes from people who earn their money honestly, and not from hoodlums and not from people who are drug pushers working in the bowels of the underclass. These are highly responsible lawyers, doctors, socialites, socially accepted women, professional women, who use drugs recreationally.''
Then, as always, the attention-getter, he would put them in jail.
''If you put a few yuppie lawyers in jail who make a recreational use of cocaine, if their pictures on the front page of The Globe, if they went to jail for three or four days, that would do a lot to put a stop to all that money flowing in,'' he said.
In a speech the other day, Mr. Silber mounted a bitter attack on what he described as the economic blunders of the Democrat he hopes to succeed, Michael S. Dukakis, and on the Republican candidate, William F. Weld, of whom he said: ''His experience is that of a lawyer and bureaucrat. I cannot think of two less useful qualifications for dealing with the crisis that faces us.''
 
A New Populism
The attention-getter: proposals to limit legislative sessions to six months and to limit legislators to three terms so that ''no one in Massachusetts will be able to plan for a lifelong career in state politics.''
It all comes pouring out in a great rush, thousands of words without pause - full of anger, full of ideas, a kind of egghead populism that captured the imagination of Democratic voters in this economically battered state and gave Mr. Silber a stunning upset victory in the primary on Sept. 18.
Much of the attention focused on what came to be known as ''Silber shockers,'' comments like his statement that he had no intention of going into one particularly crime-ridden black neighborhood to ''talk to a bunch of addicts'' about law and order.
In the interview, Mr. Silber conceded that a lifetime as a teacher may have inculcated in him habits that cause trouble with reporters looking for arresting sound-bites: ''If it's a class at 8 o'clock in the morning or if it's a class at 1 o'clock after lunch, you've got to get them awake and you've got to get their attention.''
But he argued angrily that journalists had ripped his remarks from their context, making it sound, in the case of the remark about addicts, as if he had never campaigned in Boston's black neighborhoods when, in fact, he had on many occasions. He added: ''If you want to have any kind of freedom of expression while you're talking about these subjects, there shouldn't be a requirement that a politician be deadly dull while he's doing that.''
Suggestions that some of his comments constitute a kind of code verging on racial exploitation cause Mr. Silber to explode in indignation. He cited, in great detail, his support for blacks going back to his boyhood in Texas and insisted, ''I've got the best record for race relationships and for doing something to support minority groups of any college president anywhere. Not Derek Bok at Harvard, not Paul Gray at M.I.T. or any of those people ever busted their tails on behalf of the integration of the Boston schools. I did.''
 
Failure of Welfare
The major error in the welfare system, he said, was that ''instead of encouraging the provider to stay with his wife, we rewarded his wife if there were no provider, and with that piece of social engineering, we declared war on poor families, and unfortunately it hit black families a lot harder than white families just because there were more of them at the poverty level.''
He continued: ''Now we've got the typical black male, aged 30, living with his parents, and the typical black female, aged 16, living in her own household, having married Uncle Sam. This was a piece of legislation, designed for a wonderful purpose, that backfired. Unlike real engineers who change their design when something doesn't work, we've just perpetuated this flawed design, year after year. Now I think we have to create rewards for responsibility and not rewards that depend upon persons adopting a passive, dependent role.''
His message involves large amounts of help for poor black children, including day care and incentives to get their mothers off welfare, which suggests that efficiency and not higher taxes will cure the state's fiscal problems. The message is anti-establishment and anti-elitist, but it is more cerebral than most populism. It lacks the anti-business bias of George C. Wallace and earlier Southerners, and it lacks the anti-government fervor of Ronald Reagan, who rode earlier waves of public dissatisfaction with government.
People ask him, Mr. Silber said, ''Why aren't you a Republican?''
''The fact that I don't believe in waste and I don't believe in fraud and I don't believe in unilateral disarmament doesn't make me a Republican,'' he said. ''It makes me a Democrat in the tradition of Franklin Roosevelt or Harry Truman or John F. Kennedy or Scoop Jackson. It doesn't give me much common ground with Dukakis. It doesn't give me much common ground with Jimmy Carter or Eugene McCarthy. But I believe in a pro-active government.''
Whom does he admire on the present-day political scene? He mentioned a mixed bag: Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona, usually described as a centrist, ''a man who had interesting things to say,'' and Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, a liberal, a man with ''a very good mind,'' even if ''a little bit too ideological,'' and Representative John Murtha, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, especially because of his program linking pay increases for teachers to their performance on proficiency examinations.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Countdown to Crisis: Reaching a 1991 Budget Agreement

 BODY:

Jan. 29, 1990 - President Bush sends a $1.2 trillion budget to Capitol Hill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The President says his plan will leave a $64.7 billion deficit.
March 5 - Congressional Budget Office issues its own analysis of the President's budget and predicts that the deficit will be about $131 billion. 
May 6 - Facing concern over a weak economy and high interest rates, President Bush calls the four top Congressional leaders to a private White House meeting. They agree to set ''no preconditions'' an effort to negotiate a bipartisan budget compromise.
May 15 - Congressional leaders and Bush Administration officials begin their ''summit meetings'' on the fiscal 1991 budget and its growing deficit.
June 26 - With the budget talks stalled, President Bush breaks with his ''no-new-taxes'' vow and says any deficit-cutting agreement would require ''tax revenue increases.''
July 16 - In its mid-session review of the budget, the Office of Management and Budget projects that without changes in taxes or spending, the fiscal 1991 deficit will be $168.8 billion - not counting spending for the thrift bailout.
Sept 7 - The budget negotiators meet at Andrews Air Force Base for a new round of talks.
Sept. 30 - President Bush and Congressional negotiators announce in the Rose Garden that they have agreed to a plan that would reducethe Federal deficit by $40 billion next year and by $500 billion over five years. It would raise $134 billion in new taxes over five years including higher taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcohol and make deep cuts in Medicare. Congress approves a stop gap spending bill, good until Oct. 5, to keep the Government going in the absense of a 1991 budget.
Oct. 1 - Fiscal year 1991 begins.
Oct. 2 - Faced with a revolt in his party's Congressional ranks and wariness around the country, President Bush appeals on television for public support. He predicts ''economic chaos if we fail to reduce the deficit.''
Oct. 5 - President Bush and the Democratic leadership suffer a stunning defeat in Congress as the House rejects the budget compromise in an early morning vote. Late in the evening. Congress approves another stopgap spending bill, to keep the government running until October 12.
Oct. 6 - President Bush vetoes the stopgap legislation needed to keep the government running. Later in day, the House fails to override the veto by a vote of 260 to 138, 6 short of the two-thirds needed. The Government starts to close down, but the full impact is not felt. It is a weekend.
Oct. 8 - In the early morning hours, a weary and bitterly divided House passes a Democratic budget plan that would cut Medicare less severely than the plan rejected on Oct. 5. It would also leave room for a deal in which taxes on capital gains would be cut in exchange for raising income tax rates for the wealthy. The compromise contains very few specific and leaves Congressional committees with the power to draw up key components. Late in the day, President Bush and Congressional leaders agree on a bill that would avert a Government shutdown. The Senate approves it and sends it to the House.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
After Budget Trauma, Still More Trauma Lies Ahead

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
For all the trauma that Congress has put itself through in the past four days to produce a budget, the real struggle lies ahead.
Over the next week and a half, nearly two dozen Congressional committees will be deciding how to make the spending cuts or raise the taxes needed to reach the deficit reduction targets in the budget for the 1991 fiscal year. If the past 15 years are any guide, the process promises to be a collision of competing regional, constituent and political interests as powerful chairmen and rank and file members vie to protect their pet projects or programs from the budget ax.
This fractious process is known as ''reconciliation.'' 
 
Finding Cuts, Piece by Piece
Under the process devised in the 1974 budget act, each committee is given a figure designating the amount that must be cut from benefit programs under its jurisdiction. The House and Senate Appropriations committees, which do not deal with entitlement programs, will be directed to hold spending for other types of domestic programs to levels that rise no more than the rate of inflation in each of the next three years.
When the final tallies from all the committees are in, the result is supposed to be a $40 billion reduction in the deficit for the 1991 fiscal year and a $500 billion reduction over five years.
The two panels with the biggest responsibilities are the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, which have jurisdiction over both taxes and much of the Medicare program.
The tax committees have been asked to find about $3 billion in spending cuts and to raise about $13 billion in new revenues for the 1991 fiscal year, and they have been given the choice of spending cuts or tax increases to reduce the deficit by an additional $2 billion.
 
Lobbyists at Work
Their Democratic chairmen, Representative Dan Rostenkowsi of Illinois, and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, were involved in many of the negotiations that produced the original deficit reduction package rejected by the House last week. And it is on their panels where most of the intrigue and horse-trading will occur. Both chairmen, however, were excluded from the final deal struck by top Congressional leaders and the White House, and both have expressed misgivings about the tax breaks for investments in small businesses that were included in that package.
''Every lobbyist in the world is now coming at us and saying, 'If you've got all that wiggle room, take care of me,' '' said one senior member of the Senate Finance Committee.
Many of these measures are likely to be substantially redesigned or jettisoned altogether. If a trade-off linking a cut in the capital gains tax rate and an increase in income tax rates for the wealthy comes to be, these are the two who will broker it.
Mr. Rostenkowsi, who favors a gasoline tax, may have trouble with Mr. Bentsen, who does not. While the two chairmen are expected to soften the blow to the Medicare program, they have a longstanding rivalry about how to do it.
To spare Medicare recipients from the brunt of the cuts in the program, the tax committees will be looking for alternatives, like reducing Government payments to hospitals and health care providers. In that battle, Mr. Rostenkowski, who represents Chicago, has traditionally tried to protect large urban hospitals.
Mr. Bentsen, on the other hand, has tried to look out for smaller rural hospitals, many of which have been forced to close their doors in the past few years because of previous Medicare cuts.
 
Cuts in Farm Programs
The two other panels that will bear a major share of the burden of finding budget cuts are the House and Senate Agriculture committees. Under the plan, the committees will have to find about $1 billion in cuts for the 1991 fiscal year and more than $13 billion over the next five years.
For Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Agriculture Committee, and Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate panel, the task may be slightly less complicated than it will be for other committees, where negotiators will have to reconcile conflicting House and Senate versions of deficit-reduction measures.
By contrast, the two Agriculture chairmen have already spent months working on major legislation overhauling farm programs, and that legislation is now before House and Senate negotiators.
Most of the decisions on spending cuts will thus be made by the agriculture negotiators. That means fewer lawmakers and fewer competing consituencies to mollify.
But that does not mean the cuts will be painless, particularly for committee members like Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, and Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, both of whom face tough re-election battles this year.
A senior aide on the Senate Agriculture Committee estimated that the spending cuts required under the budget will mean a 10 percent reduction in income for the average farmer.
Essentially, the lawmakers face three choices to make the savings: reduce the number of farmers eligible for various subsidy and price support programs, cut the level of existing benefits or eliminate lower priority programs like those that help farmers sell their crops abroad.
Members of both the House and Senate Agriculture panels would like to tie some of the future year reductions to the outcome of current international trade talks.
The United States has been trying to get its trading partners, particularly the European Community, to reduce farm subsidies.
 
Wily Dealers
Farm politics tend to have more to do with region than party affiliation, and the battles ahead will pit cotton and peanut interests against those of wheat and corn.
In some ways, the House committee members have an advantage. They know the details and intricacies of farm programs better than their Senate counterparts, whose duties and outside interests involve them less in farm business.
On the other hand, Senate committee members will have an important and powerful champion in their corner: the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, who is a member of the conference committee.
Two other committees that will play critical roles in the deficit-reduction process are the House and Senate Appropriations panels, headed by two of the most senior and wily lawmakers in Congress, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, and Representative Jamie L. Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi.
In the past 15 years, they have chafed at the incursion by the House and Senate Budget committees on more of their turf. But they remain a sanctum for last-minute deals.
Mr. Whittten, contemplating the spending strictures imposed on him by the lawmakers involved in writing the defeated budget package and their efficient plans to save money, does not relish the task. ''These folks just don't think like I do,'' he said.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The Arab Nightmare

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Almost every day, a particularly important falsehood keeps popping up about the choice facing the United States in the Iraqi crisis.
The choice is between trying to find a diplomatic formula that would persuade Saddam Hussein to get out of Kuwait but would leave him with military power, or seizing the moment to destroy him so that he can never again use his tanks, planes, poison gas and missiles to blackmail the world.
The falsehood: Israel is virtually the only foreign country that believes military action is the best course for the United States to take.
Most often this lie spills out of the brew that is kept aboil by Israel-haters of the American right and left. 
That is nasty enough in itself. But the danger is that it is coming to be assumed as true by many Americans who are not anti-Israel, but simply do not want to enter a war that only Israel supports. The assumption is becoming so pervasive that Zbigniew Brzezinski points to it as one of the risks of military action.
''At some point the public might blame Israel for allegedly having pressed America to go to war against Iraq for the sake of Israeli interests,'' he wrote on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times.
Possibly, but the admirable Mr. Brzezinski could have diminished the risk by adding another sentence about what he and other sophisticated opponents of military action know but often neglect to point out: The current Arab allies of the United States believe that to leave Saddam Hussein's power intact would be a disaster they could not survive.
Arab rulers opposing Saddam Hussein know that if he stays in power he will be victorious in the minds of the Arab world, defeating them and the combined political and economic strength of the West. They will be the losers in their own homeland, frighteningly next door to Saddam Hussein, not thousands of miles away in Washington or Europe.
The Saudi monarchy is likely to be brought down in a year or two by its internal enemies strengthened by agents dispatched by Iraq. If they are not eliminated immediately the Saudis and other Persian Gulf princes will once again try to buy off Saddam Hussein with oil billions.
President Mubarak of Egypt will find it impossible to stay in office for more than a couple of years. Some Egyptians who support him believe it may take the Egyptian fundamentalists that much time to overthrow him, not more.
But State Department specialists, who talked about Saddam Hussein's peaceful intentions before he attacked Kuwait, now put out stories about how to contain him peacefully. Nothing is more dangerous than diplomats trying to justify past mistakes by duplicating them in new policies.
So fantasies are floated. We will create a new order to protect the Middle East.
What Arab government would be stupid enough to sign up with this new, make-believe alliance if Saddam Hussein is left with a poison gas shell in his hand and his gangs of terrorists searching Arab capitals for high-ranking victims?
We will leave troops and stocks of weapons behind to deter the Iraqis, say the diplomats. Really? Name the Arab leaders suicidal enough to keep sliver Western units on their territory after full Western force was withdrawn unused.
''We will put an embargo on arms sales to Saddam Hussein.'' Sure, sure, but how do we deal with the production of the huge arms and chemical factories that the West and the Soviet Union already have built for him?
No Arab despotism is worth American lives. But the only justifiable reason for the American intervention was not for their sake, but for our own - to prevent one bitterly hostile dictator from dominating the Middle East, turning its oil on and off as his hatred of the United States moved him.
Out of Kuwait, but still in power, he will be able to stand astride the Middle East as he never could before the invasion. Arab rulers who oppose him will either be killed or do what he tells them to save their necks. He will control them and their oil by telephone.
Yes, the Israeli Government favors military action, but not joyfully and not just with its mouth. Saddam Hussein is unlikely to go down without trying to strike Israel. The gas masks are not a propaganda stunt.
President Bush will make his own decisions in his own time. But it could help if he told Americans beforehand the full story about which countries support or oppose military action and why. He owes that to himself for the support he will need, one way or the other.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1477 words

HEADLINE: Realty Slump Traps Some as Buyers Nibble Warily

BYLINE: ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
During the giddy 1980's, restaurants from Columbus Avenue to TriBeCa reverberated with customer boasts of shrewd real-estate deals and tales of manic co-op profits. But the binge in housing prices did not bring universal cheer. For many people, high rents and heavy mortgages cast an anxious pall. Economists worried that the escalating cost of housing put New York at a competitive disadvantage.
Now that the cost of housing has plummeted, however, there are few audible sounds of relief.
Parties, dinners and other social events brim with stories of people who have put apartments or houses up for sale and received not a single bid. For those able to sell, the prices generally range from disappointing to crushing. 
Real-estate brokers say the price of New York City houses and apartments has fallen as much as 20 to 30 percent since the peak in 1988. The tumble, after seven years of growth, has dislocated the market, disrupted lives and disconcerted many New Yorkers for whom real estate has long been a barometer of personal well-being.
 
'Not Had a Single Offer'
Ellen Miller-Wachtel, a lawyer who works for a television network, put her Brooklyn Heights brownstone on sale in April. ''We have not had a single offer,'' she said. Her family's plan to move to Westchester has been delayed. ''The bottom line is that I wish it were my choice, as opposed to it being totally outside my control,'' she said. ''I think that's very frustrating to many of us who are used to controlling our life decisions.''
Hardest hit in practical terms are those who bought near the peak in the late 1980's and who must now try to sell, usually at a considerable loss. For those who bought earlier, the loss may be less financial than psychological, though hardly less distressing. Few seem reassured that their homes, purchased before the price run-up, are generally worth many times more than what they paid for them.
Sellers like Ms. Miller-Wachtel, unable to attract a buyer, feel immobilized. Some have taken their homes off the market or have rented them in the hope that the market will turn within a year or two.
While this is disconcerting to families who must delay cherished plans, there is a bright side for the city at large. Some real-estate executives say they suspect, based on the number of sellers, that more middle- and upper-income families are trying to flee the city than at any time in the recent past. But since it is so hard to attract buyers, the slumping market is keeping many of those families in New York.
The market's volatility has created great uncertainty. It is difficult to determine a property's current value or even a reasonable asking price. Ms. Miller-Wachtel said she had dropped hers by $100,000, but that, too, had produced no bids, not even a low offer that might start a serious negotiation. She declined to say how much she was seeking.
 
'Two Different Worlds'
''The problem we've got is that buyers and sellers seem to be living in two different worlds,'' said Carl F. Peek, president of the Prudential-Carl F. Peek Real Estate Company in Brooklyn. ''The sellers seem to think it's 1985 and 1986, and the buyers think it's 1930.''
Many potential buyers lack confidence in the economy, real-estate brokers and economists say. They are so concerned that the housing market will continue to slide that they are afraid to make a commitment, even though today's prices are bargains compared with those of just two years ago.
Sellers are uneasy, too. Brokers say many resist the need to drop asking prices, because they are obsessed with what their homes might have been worth two or three years ago. ''The major reference point still is, 'What would I have gotten?' rather than 'What can I get?' '' said Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan brokerage.
Of course, in a region as large as New York, there are exceptions to every trend. Sales still take place, though the rate has declined sharply, and some sellers obtain prices far beyond their expectations. A couple in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, for example, sold their co-op last spring for $20,000 to $30,000 more than comparable apartments in the building have fetched.
 
For Some, an Opportunity
Some buyers see this as a great time to buy. Rebecca L. Feinstone, a corporate executive, is scheduled to close next week on a one-bedroom co-op in Murray Hill. ''I always wanted to buy in New York,'' said Ms. Feinstone, who has rented an apartment since moving to the city three years ago. ''I thought this was an opportune time to plunge in and do it.''
She said she was confident that the city's economy, and with it the real-estate market, would rebound soon.
Many sellers share that hope, perhaps a little desperately. Unwilling to accept real or perceived losses - or simply discouraged that they have received no offers - they have withdrawn their apartments from the market.
Dr. Steven Blumenthal, a pediatrician, bought a 4 1/2-room apartment two years ago on Riverside Drive at 111th Street. He and his wife decided earlier this year that they wanted to rear their two young children in a smaller city. They put their apartment up for sale in April while Dr. Blumenthal looked for a new job.
He got an offer to join a practice in Portland, Me., but turned it down because no one had bid on his apartment. He lowered the asking price by 7 percent, but still there was no interest.
 
Renting Instead of Selling
When the medical opening was still available a while later, the Blumenthals decided to take their apartment off the market, rent it to friends and move to Maine. They will have to rent a home there because their capital is locked away in the apartment.
The family hopes New York's market will be better in two years, but they are aware that they may have to take a substantial loss when they finally sell. In their co-operative, like many in New York, shareholders can only rent their apartments to outsiders for a limited time, usually a year or two.
Some co-ops do not permit any rentals, which can make owners prisoners in their apartments. Helen Kaptsan, a financial planner for Nynex, had planned to buy a house, after her apartment in Scarsdale, N.Y., and her fiance's apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side were sold.
Her fiance, whom Ms. Kaptsan declined to name, bought his apartment two years ago. He sold it this year at a $40,000 loss, she said, adding, ''At least we sold it.''
 
A Matter of 'Expectations'
Ms. Kaptsan's one-bedroom apartment has been on the market for a year. She initially asked $109,000, and now is down to $89,000. No one has even looked at the apartment in the last two months.
She cannot rent the place either, under the co-op's rules. ''This has put a damper on our plans,'' she said, indicating that she did not feel deprived, in part because she had immigrated to the United States from the Soviet Union when she was 13.
''It's probably a lot different for my fiance, who is American-born,'' she said. ''His sense of frustration is probably a lot higher. Coming from Russia, expectations of having a house were not part of my upbringing.''
Some disappointed sellers say they strive to keep their problems in perspective, particularly in a city where tens of thousands of people are homeless and hundreds of thousands more live doubled-up in cramped quarters.
Still, the inability to sell a house or apartment carries economic and emotional burdens. Ann P. Heilakka, her husband and their two small children moved early this year to a house in Stamford, Conn. They simultaneously put their four-story brownstone in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn, on sale. They are now asking $445,000, a price that she says brokers consider appropriate.
''We have not had a single bid in 10 months,'' said Ms. Heilakka, a portfolio manager.
Some buyers, emboldened by the market shift that has given them far greater leverage, complain that the main reason properties are not selling is that owners have been too slow to adjust to the changed market.
''As a buyer, it is extremely unpleasant to go into a situation where you know someone is asking 30 percent more than something is worth,'' said Harry Rubin, an executive in an entertainment company, who began looking at Upper East Side apartments after his wedding in May.
Mr. Rubin thinks prices will continue to slide. Like many potential buyers, he is determined to pay not a penny more than what he calculates as ''real economic value.''
In June, he said, he looked at an apartment that was listed at $695,000. He bid $400,000, which was immediately rejected. ''Now the seller is indicating that he is willing to accept in the mid-400,000's,'' he said.
Where does that leave Mr. Rubin? ''Getting close,'' he said. ''But now I'm beginning to wonder whether $400,000 is maybe too high.''

HEADLINE: After 3 Years, Gains in 'Decade of the Child' Are Isolated

SERIES: Third article of a series on Mario M. Cuomo's record as New York's Governor.

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 8

 BODY:
When Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented his first Decade of the Child awards last month, it was a celebration of small and poignant victories over the unfathomable plagues of modern childhood.
Among those honored by the Governor was a high school dropout from Long Island who returned to school after kicking a drug habit with the help of a state-financed treatment program. Another citation went to an 18-year-old homeless mother from Chautauqua County who had secured housing with state assistance, enabling her to graduate from high school and find a secretarial job.
But as the ceremony seemed to suggest, the successes of Mr. Cuomo's ambitious Decade of the Child agenda must still be measured in individual accomplishments.
 
Complex Problems Remain
Three years and more than $1.4 billion after he declared the Decade of the Child, the exasperating reality is that the broader condition of New York's youth remains dismal. Because the increasing complexity of children's problems is outstripping the state's capacity to solve them, New York's government is merely treading water. And in the areas most affected by the drug epidemic, it is being tugged below the surface. 
With crack tearing families apart, the number of children in foster care has nearly doubled in two years, as has the number of recorded cases of child abuse and maltreatment. Although the state's welfare grant has been raised four times during the Cuomo years, nearly a quarter of the state's children still live in poverty.
While there has been significant success in attacking infant mortality, the progress has been diminished by growth in the number of babies born with dangerously low birthweights. Meanwhile the adolescent pregnancy rate has climbed steadily in the last six years.
 
Dropout Rate Rising
The high school dropout rate, after declining in the mid-1980's, is rising again, and there is a similar trend in the number of arrests of juveniles for violence and drug-related offenses.
Even the most critical advocates for children's causes do not blame Mr. Cuomo for much of the deterioration. Indeed, as the Governor seeks a third term, most applaud him for having the political courage to unveil lofty goals at a time when it was becoming clear that the state's social-service system was about to be battered by the overlapping waves of a new drug crisis and an economic downturn.
''During a very tough period, the Governor has managed to keep children on the agenda,'' said Barbara B. Blum, president of the Foundation for Child Development. ''Without the Decade of the Child we'd be seeing figures that were much, much worse.''
But other advocates contend that Mr. Cuomo has not dedicated enough of the money available to attacking root problems like poverty and drug abuse.
 
Further Problems Envisioned
With the state's economy sliding and its populace choked with new taxes from all levels of government, they fear that the bloodiest battles in coming years will be over maintaining existing programs rather than adding new ones. And they predict it will be increasingly difficult to expand the pilot programs that the state has used to build political support for its social services experiments.
Fiscal reality has forced Mr. Cuomo to become highly selective in allocating resources. He has targeted health and educational programs with proved records of providing long-term savings through modest investments.
But Mr. Cuomo has been reluctant to support programs that bear the risk of unlimited spending. This year, for instance, he cited budgetary concerns in vetoing a bill aimed at keeping children out of foster care by providing housing subsidies to families without shelter.
Michael S. Dowling, the Governor's deputy secretary for human services, said Mr. Cuomo's moderate approach and his skill at marketing children's programs as economic investments had made it possible to sell the Decade of the Child to the business community during difficult fiscal times.
Some critics complain that there should be little room for compromise on issues affecting children. And they argue that many of the solutions favored by the administration are often more reactive than preventive, that children are being caught by the state's safety net but that little is being done to keep them from falling.
''If we don't invest in these families now, we're going to be investing in their children and their children's children for a long time,'' said Elie S. Ward, a policy analyst with Statewide Youth Advocacy. ''If the state is willing to do a bond act for its environment, isn't it willing to do that for the people who inhabit that environment?''
When Mr. Cuomo declared the Decade of the Child in his 1988 State of the State address, he was smart enough to realize that there were few quick fixes for the complex problems associated with education, child welfare, juvenile delinquency, and children's health. As a result, he set few specific goals.
His political instincts, as usual, were right. The only two benchmarks he set that day - to cut the dropout rate by half and to provide half-day prekindergarten programs for all 4-year-olds within five years - are far from realization.
 
Commitment Seen as 'Watershed'
But simply by declaring that the future of New York's children ''demands a bold and broad commitment,'' Mr. Cuomo provided children's advocates with a rhetorical weapon they have not hesitated to use against him.
''I guess I saw it as at least a hook,'' said Eve Brooks, the director of Statewide Youth Advocacy. ''In retrospect, it really was a watershed because before that children were considered just another age group.''
Ms. Brooks is among those who believe that poverty is the root cause of children's problems and that the state's priority should be on raising welfare reimbursement rates.
New York ranks sixth among all states in the amount of its grant, which is $577 a month for a family of three in New York City. When combined with food stamps and state energy aid, that amounts to 90 percent of the Federal poverty level. But costs are such that housing alone absorbs most of the grant in places like New York City, and the state is being sued by welfare recipients who argue that their shelter allowance is inadequate.
The chief accomplishments of the Decade of the Child have come in the areas of health and nutrition. Financing for the state's nutritional assistance program for women and children has grown from $7.5 million in 1984 to $42.4 million this year.
There have been three expansions of Medicaid coverage for poor children and pregnant mothers totaling more than $100 million, although one of them was mandated by the Federal Government. Money has also been increased for the state's prenatal care program.
This year the Governor pushed through the Legislature a state-subsidized health insurance program for the children of the working poor. Although the plan covers only outpatient procedures for children up to the age of 13, and not hospitalization, as Mr. Cuomo had hoped, the program is one of the few of its kind in the country.
Impressed by the success of Head Start, the Governor has focused his education efforts on the expansion of prekindergarten programs. But two years before the Governor hoped the program would be universal, only 20 percent of the state's 4-year-olds are enrolled.
Most of the criticism aimed at the Governor's children's agenda concerns the state's response to the crack crisis, particularly in the areas of foster care and juvenile justice.
Spending on foster care, which is mandated, has increased by $538 million in three years, but only a negligible fraction of it has been spent on programs to prevent the dissolution of families ravaged by drugs and poverty. State officials concede that not enough money is being devoted to forestalling the problems of child abuse and homelessness before they incubate.
''In the best of all possible worlds we would intervene with the families much earlier,'' said Cesar A. Perales, the Social Services Commissioner.
The same critique is leveled at the juvenile justice system, where youthful offenders are being warehoused rather than rehabilitated, according to judges and social workers. For example, although 56 percent of the youths entering correctional centers of the Division for Youth need drug treatment, the state began providing drug counseling only this year. It is now available in 11 of 52 centers.
In defending his agency's record during the Decade of the Child, Leonard G. Dunston, the director of the Division for Youth, pointed to two pilot programs that provide alternatives to incarceration through intensive supervision at home and in foster care. But out of the more than 2,000 youngsters in the system, the programs accommodate a total of 26.

HEADLINE: Control Board Is Re-emerging As Power Focus

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
As word of New York City's financial distress circulates from the corridors of government to the financial marketplace, an almost forgotten state agency is re-emerging as a major focus of power in the city's future.
The Dinkins administration is facing a major test - will it get on top of a worsening muncipal deficit or risk losing the confidence of the public and markets?
In either case, the State Financial Control Board will set the terms of public debate, vindicate or vilify the administration and, in the worst case, wrest control of city spending from a Mayor and City Council elected by the public.
All this at an agency that found its warnings about deteriorating city tax revenues and fiscal uncertainties about the future largely ignored by the public in recent months.
 
'Times Have Changed'
''We have been actively articulating the view that times have changed, that business as usual has ended,'' said Allen Proctor, the 38-year-old former city budget official who was named executive director of the control board in January by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins. But until now, Mr. Proctor said, ''nobody decided to write about it.'' 
With the Dinkins administration facing a financial crisis, the board is now the center of attention. The administration has yet to show that it will be able to pay for labor settlements after a surprisingly expensive contract with city teachers or to provide promised police officers at a time when tax revenues are falling.
The city has promised to submit a financial plan to the board by early November By JOSH BARBANEL As word of New York City's financial distress circulates from the corridors of government to the financial marketplace, an almost forgotten state agency is re-emerging as a major focus of power in the city's future.
The Dinkins administration is facing a major test - will it get on top of a worsening muncipal deficit or risk losing the confidence of the public and markets?
In either case, the State Financial Control Board will set the terms of public debate, vindicate or vilify the administration and, in the worst case, wrest control of city spending from a Mayor and City Council elected by the public.
All this at an agency that found its warnings about deteriorating city tax revenues and fiscal uncertainties about the future largely ignored by the public in recent months.
 
'Times Have Changed'
''We have been actively articulating the view that times have changed, that business as usual has ended,'' said Allen Proctor, the 38-year-old former city budget official who was named executive director of the board in January by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins. But until now, he said, ''nobody decided to write about it.''
Now with the Dinkins administration facing a financial crisis, the board is now the center of attention. The Dinkins administration has yet to show that it will be able to pay for labor settlements after a surprisingly expensive contract with city teachers or to provide promised police officers at a time when tax revenues are falling.
The city has promised to submit a financial plan to the board by early November that will show that it is in control of its own financial destiny. It has already announced a hiring freeze and a proposal to lay off 15,000 city workers.
The governor, the mayor, the city and state comptrollers and three private members appointed by the governor sit on the board. Their approval of the plan could help restore the public's, as well as the financial markets', confidence in the city administration. Objections could undermine supporters of Mr. Dinkins who believe that he has not been given a fair chance to take his case to the public.
In the meantime, Mr. Proctor has been meeting weekly with the private members - Stanley S. Shuman, Donald D. Kummerfeld, Heather L. Ruth -who have become increasingly concerned about how the city administration has responded to fiscal difficulties.
 
A Legal Brief
Two weeks ago, even before the administration's problems became public, Mr. Proctor requested a legal brief detailing precisely what conditions needed to exist under the 1975 law that created the board before the panel could take over city finances.
At the same time he has been trying to dampen speculation that the current crisis will get out of control. He said the threat of a board takeover of city finances, like the threat of nuclear war, would go a long way to assuring that it would never happen.
''A lot of people, myself included, are issuing public statements of concern precisely to prevent a sense that there might be no end to disorder,'' he said. ''The city has ample opportunity to maintain an orderly budget process.''
He praised the city's statements that it was beginning an $800 million program of service cuts, including possibly 15,000 layoffs. But he said that so far he has seen no details and that the plan outlined so far would not do the job. The city has projected a $1.4 billion deficit, while the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said it could rise as high as $2.6 billion.
But he said it was because the city was required to disclose its financial condition to the board that its problems have become known. ''That is not true of other governments in the United States,'' he said. ''Other governments are not talking about their problems.''
 
'Consistent and Deliberate'
Last night, as members of the Dinkins administration met at Gracie Mansion to discuss the city budget and labor negotiations, Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary, said the adminstration had followed a ''consistent and deliberate'' approach to the city's fiscal circumstances.
''What has been unstable is the New York City economy,'' he said. ''The people of the City of New York elected him to be mayor. They did not elect the Financial Control Board.''
The control board can assume its stronger powers only if one of the following specific conditions are met: if the city runs a $100 million deficit at the end of the fiscal year; if it is unlikely to be able to pay the principal or interest on its debts; if the city and state comptrollers say the city can no longer borrow money, or if the city impairs its credit by violating budgeting and accounting practices required by the state.
Fiscal experts said that even if the city could not get its finances under control, the board would have difficulty acting for many months, unless the city has trouble selling its bonds.
The city plans to sell both revenue-anticipation notes and long-term bonds in the next few months.
 
'Plenty of Leeway'
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said the Mayor and the City Council had ''plenty of leeway'' to cut the budget and reduce taxes, especially since Mr. Dinkins's budget calls for an increase of between 8 and 11 percent in spending.
But he added that the problem was one that was also of perception. ''If the city were to bounce up one hill and down the vale, with the situation of control at City Hall, there is no question that confidence and perceptions could change about the city.
''The problem would have to deteriorate,'' he said. ''The Mayor would have to be unwilling or unable to come to grips with the problem.''
Ms. Holtzman, the City Comptroller, said the city would have to have a ''credible comprehensive plan to balance the budget'' before the city could go to the market.

HEADLINE: Patterns;
By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

 
Some Aren't Crying
Name a fashion business that thrives when times are slow. (Hint: When it makes an entrance, Wagner is playing; as it exits, Mendelssohn.) You got it: the bridal business. Even in hard times, makers of wedding dresses can depend on a steady demand. In 1989, a rocky year for fashion, there were 2,404,000 marriages, the seventh greatest number in United States history, according to Government reports. That adds up to millions of high-ticket sales that don't require a lot of retail romancing. 
Last year, the average wedding dress cost $794, not including veil, which cost about $170, according to a survey by Bride's Magazine. This is market week for New York's wedding suppliers, and the orders have been encouraging, they say.
''The bridal business is pretty much recession proof,'' said Vincent Piccione, the president of Alfred Angelo of New York, the largest bridal manufacturer in the country. ''In tough times, more people get married. Two can live better than one.''
Last year the company made more than 750,000 dresses, including bridesmaid dresses, which are half of all sales, and expects business to increase by 10 percent this year. Although the number of single women in this country has been declining, second marriages are increasing and formal weddings for such marriages are becoming more acceptable, Mr. Piccione said.
At Carolina Herrera, where wedding dresses cost $2,500 to $6,000, business is up about 30 percent. Stylewise, there's a movement away from ornate, beaded, body-hugging looks toward pretty, classical looks with full skirts, fitted bodices and sparing use of lace and beads.
''I don't like these very sexy gowns with decollete and masses of embroidery,'' Ms. Herrera said.
 
To Benefit AIDS
 
With Seventh Avenue gearing up for a huge AIDS benefit next month, European designers are contributing to another effort. Rifat Ozbek and Jean-Paul Gaultier have designed special lines whose profits will be donated to AIDS causes.
It's all part of ''Red Hot and Blue,'' a benefit that will include a record album and video of musicians singing Cole Porter tunes (for example, Sinead O'Connor sings ''You Do Something to Me,'' U2 renders ''Night and Day'' and David Byrne croons ''Don't Fence Me In).
Samples from the two designers were being shown to New York retailers last week by Anneliese Estrada, widow of the designer Angel Estrada. The sweatsuit styles in psychedelic and harlequin prints will be available in February.
 
The Mood Wasn't Woolly
It was a beautiful weekend, unless you happen to be in the coat business. The Columbus Day weekend is considered pivotal to outerwear manufacturers, who look to retailers to reorder, for November and December delivery, based on October sales.
The 80-degree weather, with potential shoppers wearing shorts and strolling outside in the sun, was the last thing they needed. Several of New York's large retailers had advertised their fall-winter coats last week. On Sunday you could send a bowling ball down the aisles and not hit a shopper.
 
What About 'Maybe'?
One can now purchase all kinds of fashions with a message, from Iraqi-made watches with portraits of Saddam Hussein to T-shirts that read, ''Nuke the Simpsons.'' But a pair of Joe Boxer pajamas sold in Bloomingdale's sends out ambiguous signals.
The cotton pj's have the word ''No!'' printed in black letters all over them. When you switch the lights off, they say ''Yes!''
At $42, they are perfect for those times when the lips say no but the eyes say yes, yes, yes.

HEADLINE: Sabyasachi Mukharji, India's Top Justice, 63

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Sabyasachi Mukharji, the Chief Justice of India's Supreme Court, has died in London of heart-related complications, the authorities here said today. He was 63 years old. 
Justice Mukharji, who court officials said died on Sept. 25, had a legal career spanning four decades.
He was a lawyer in London after graduating with honors in economics from Calcutta University in 1946. He was general secretary of the Indian Socialist Group from 1948 to 1949.
On his return from London in 1949, Mr. Mukharji was appointed to the Calcutta High Court.
In 1982 was appointed member of the Government's Finance Commission.
He became a member of the Supreme Court in April 1983 and in the same year was appointed Chief Justice of the Calcutta High Court.
Fifteen days after his appointment as acting Chief Justice of the Calcutta High Court, he was appointed a judge of the Supreme Court of India. Six years later, on Dec. 18, 1989, he was appointed Chief Justice of India.
Mr. Mukharji died on his way back to India after attending a conference of chief appellate judges in Washington last month. His death has further delayed judicial action in the case of the toxic gas leak at Bhopal in 1984.
He is survived by his wife and a daughter.

HEADLINE: Richard Louie, 51, Smithsonian Official <888>

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Richard Louie, an associate director of the Freer Gallery of Art and the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution system, died on Sunday in the Washington Hospital Center after being struck by a car on Saturday in Arlington, Va. He was 51 years old and lived in Arlington. Mr. Louie became assistant director of the Freer in 1978 and participated in the planning and financing of the Sackler in the 1980's. Both museums are noted for their collections of Asian art.
Mr. Louie, who grew up in the Cleveland area, received a bachelor's degree from Princeton University in 1960 and master's degrees in Far East studies and economics from the University of Washington in Seattle.
Before joining the Smithsonian, he was an economist for the Institute for Defense Analyses in Alexandria; the Private Investment Company for Asia in Tokyo, and the United States Postal Service. Mr. Louie had also been president of Asian Development Business Services and vice president of May Lee Industries, both in New York City.
He is survived by his wife, Katherine Preciado; his mother, Gam B. Louie of St. Louis, and two sisters, Sue Fay King of St. Louis and Maie Lin Carrell of Evansville, Ind.
