HEADLINE: Next Bold Step Toward Fusion Proposed

SERIES: BIG SCIENCE: IS IT WORTH THE PRICE? - A PERIODIC LOOK AT THE LARGEST NEW RESEARCH PROJECTS

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

DATELINE: PLAINSBORO, N.J.

 BODY:
ON a grassy site here surrounded by cornfields and dense woods, not far from Princeton University, scientists want to build a machine of vast complexity and cost that they hope will lead to a powerful new source of energy half a century from now.
Their proposal is confronting the Bush Administration with a difficult choice as it tries to develop new sources of energy while cutting an enormous budget deficit.
The machine, the Compact Ignition Tokamak, would be the next stage of development in what is turning into a century-long quest to harness the kind of thermonuclear fire, or fusion energy, that lights the sun and produces the awesome blast of the hydrogen bomb.
Scientists here at the Princeton University Plasma Physics Laboratory say the new machine could be a major step toward ushering in a future age of relatively safe, cheap, clean and nearly inexhaustible energy.
But the device, meant to be switched on in 1998, would cost nearly $1 billion, a huge sum in an era of tight Federal budgets. Moreover, skeptics say the machine, even if successful, offers no guarantee that the field could advance in the 21st century to produce electrical power that would be economically competitive. They say that fusion advocates, long noted for promising more than they deliver, are engaging in another of their periodic bouts of hyperbole meant to promote Federal financing of yet another costly project. 
The new machine would be based on traditional ''hot'' fusion principles rather than the low-temperature or ''cold'' fusion that was proposed with great fanfare last year. The allure of cold fusion was that it seemed to promise enormous energy from simple devices that worked at room temperature, in contrast to hot fusion machines, which must operate at temperatures above those on the sun, and are vastly complicated and expensive. But after a year of intense investigation, most experts have dismissed the notion that cold fusion, if it exists, will ever be a significant energy source.
Controlled fusion, which seeks to fuse hydrogen atoms to generate bursts of usable energy, has long been one of the most risky, daunting, contested and costly aspects of big science ever undertaken by the Federal Government. Billions of dollars have already been spent but, even amid reports of progress, the goal of practical fusion energy always seems to recede into the distance. Today experts estimate that the payoff, if it comes at all, will represent an investment of tens of billions of dollars as well as roughly a century of hard work by generations of scientists. The pursuit got under way in the 1940's and, in optimistic Government scenarios, could culminate in the 2040's with the operation of the first commercial power plant.
Fusion produces energy by fusing, or welding, the atoms of light elements together. In contrast, the nuclear fission reactors now in operation generate energy by breaking apart the atoms of heavy elements like uranium.
In the interior of the sun, where temperatures are 14 million degrees centigrade and gravitational pressures are crushing, nuclear particles are driven so close together that they fuse and release vast energy. In a fusion reactor, the temperature must be even higher, around 100 million degrees centigrade, since the fusion fuel undergoes far less compression than materials at the center of the sun. The main fuel for fusion experiments is a heavy form of hydrogen known as deuterium, which is found in endless quantities in water.
For years, the main path to achieving controlled fusion has been to heat fusion fuel so it breaks into a cloud of electrically charged particles known as a plasma, which can be contained by magnetic fields. No earthly vessel would be up to the task. Any kind of metal, ceramic or glass would melt. So magnetism has been used to build increasingly powerful magnetic ''bottles,'' which today are usually housed in building-size machines that have a doughnut shape.
The job has not been easy. Edward Teller, a founder of the field, once said that confining the plasma with lines of magnetic force was ''like trying to confine jelly with rubber bands.'' The hot plasma would heat water to rotate turbines and generate electricity.
 
A Vast Supply of Energy
Despite the challenge, scientists here say the practical payoffs are so great that forging ahead is worth the risk and expense. In theory, they say, the process could extract far more energy from the top two inches of Lake Erie than exists in all the earth's known oil reserves. And they say the alternatives of relying on coal supplies that pose a threat of global warming, or on nuclear fission reactors that raise safety concerns and generate mountains of high-level radioactive waste, or on oil from politically unstable parts of the world, are likely to grow increasingly disagreeable in the 21st century.
''The fight over oil at $100 a barrel is going to make the fight at $30 look pretty trivial,'' said Dr. Rob J. Goldston, the scientific head of the proposed machine. ''The question is whether there will be a new energy source to keep us at a high level of civilization.''
Skeptics dismiss this type of statement as misguided at best. Dr. Lawrence M. Lidsky, a nuclear engineer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, quit the field six years ago because he felt fusion reactors would be too big, too complex, too expensive and too fragile to be practical. He still feels that way.
''It's hard to make an economically based argument for fusion,'' he said. ''You can't justify it, especially as other sources of energy look better and better, as people find better ways to gasify coal and build fission reactors'' that are safer.
In spite of such sentiments, the Federal Government may be edging toward greater support for fusion research. In late September, a panel of scientists, formed at the behest of Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, urged the department to greatly expand the financing of its fusion effort, citing progress in the field and the size of potential payoffs. Specifically, it backed the building of the new machine, which seeks to contain the energy of nuclear fusion with powerful magnetic fields.
Here at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory, the nation's largest center for fusion research, the current big machine is known as the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (Tokamak being a Russian acronym for doughnut-shaped chamber). Built at a cost of $314 million and switched on in 1982, it recently achieved temperatures of 400 million degrees centigrade, a world record, and triggered fusion reactions that can be interpreted as just shy of break-even, the point where the energy released by a fusion reaction matches that put in to cause the fusion, if only for a moment. In the course of the decade, the machine has been slowly advancing the three key fusion parameters: temperature, density and time of plasma containment.
 
Introducing New Problems
The device, rising some five stories, emits a high-pitched whine during a ''shot.'' The critical action lasts one second before it dies out because of limitations in the plasma-heating mechanism and the need to cut rising temperatures of powerful magnets. In late 1993, the device is expected to reach break-even after its fuel supply gets a dose of tritium, a heavy form of hydrogen that speeds the reaction.
But tritium will introduce new problems. Nearby in a hangar-like hall is a $5 million robotic arm, some 25 feet long, that is meant to inspect and repair the machine's interior once tritium is added. Today people can go inside. But with the addition of tritium, the machine will vastly increase the production of subatomic particles known as neutrons, making its parts radioactive.
In a vacant lot next to this machine, Princeton scientists would like to take the next big step in the fusion venture, the Compact Ignition Tokamak, at a cost of $940 million. This would be the first machine in the world to achieve the true burning of fusion fuel, the point where fusion reactions are so abundant they become self-sustaining. Its ''shots'' would nonetheless be brief, lasting about 10 seconds.
To attain ignition, the new machine would reach the same general temperatures as the current machine but have a plasma that is far denser and less likely to lose heat, a feat achieved mainly by better design of its doughnut-shaped chamber and more powerful magnets. Its energy output would be much greater than the current Princeton machine.
So too, its need for robotic maintenance would be greater, since it would operate far longer with tritium fuel and the resulting fusillade of neutrons, which not only induce radioactivity but make parts brittle and prone to break. Dr. John A. Schmidt, the leader of the project, said its robots would cost about $66 million.
The proposed plan, which the Energy Department has yet to back, would have construction start in 1992, under the budget currently being prepared by the Bush Administration. $6 Billion Proposal Beyond that machine, the attainment of fusion energy would require a series of additional multibillion-dollar machines. One is known as the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor, a joint effort between the United States, the Soviet Union, Europe and Japan to build the world's first fusion reactor early in the 21st century. While the Princeton device would ignite fusion fuel in short bursts, the 10-story international machine, estimated to cost at least $6 billion, would be the first to operate continuously.
Some experts believe that fusion, more than any other ''big science'' project, will become a catalyst for international cooperation, since its research costs will become too great for any single country and the payoff would be so enormous that many countries will want to share in the venture.
Nevertheless, Dr. Kenneth L. Kliewer, dean of science at Purdue University, a self-described fusion skeptic who became an advocate after joining the Federal fusion panel, said the Princeton machine was a critical precursor to the international collaboration.
''We need additional and important data,'' he said. ''The Princeton machine gives the U.S. an opportunity to be a prominent and important partner in the fusion business.'' Several reports have recently said the United States is starting to fall behind the fusion efforts of other countries.
Beyond the international collaboration would be another machine, conceivably built by the United States alone, that would have, in addition to the reactor, a welter of pipes, plumbing and turbines meant to turn fusion heat into electricity. The Federal panel said such a Federal demonstration plant might be completed by 2025. The final step in the process would be the construction of a commercial plant, which the panel said might be accomplished by 2040.
Scientists here at Princeton say fusion is so attractive that the enterprise should proceed with dispatch. Fusion reactors might produce less radioactivity than their fission counterparts by a factor of thousands, they say. And a meltdown, the potential worst catastrophe of a fission reactor, is impossible with fusion.
 
Hurdles to Overcome
But skeptics note that the field is haunted by hurdles that threaten its commercial success. Dr. Lidsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said the neutron barrage would be so great that the materials in a fusion reactor would probably be continuously damaged, hurting its prospects of ever turning a profit. A reactor, he added, would also be vastly more complex than a fission reactor, meaning it would probably break down a lot.
Princeton scientists say these are very real problems that the program seeks to address. Dr. Schmidt, head of the proposed new machine, said fusion researchers' aim was to develop new materials and metals that are far stronger than current ones. And he conceded that a fusion reactor would be ''much more complex,'' saying the program was trying to find ways to simplify the endeavor.
''There's no assurance that fusion power will be economical and competitive,'' Dr. Schmidt said, ''but that's the whole point of the program - to find out'' if that is possible.

HEADLINE: Trying to Reclaim the Rain Forest

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: PARAGOMINAS, Brazil

 BODY:
FROM a 45-foot-high observation tower, the American ecologist surveyed a landscape that is increasingly common in Eastern Amazonia: white Nelore cows dotting fields of African coloniao grass that stretched to a distant horizon of rain forest.
''Once the forest is beaten down for the pasture is it gone forever?'' asked Daniel C. Nepstad, the ecologist. ''That is the conventional wisdom in the United States and Europe.''
Swiveling, gingerly because of the swaying tower, Dr. Nepstad answered his own question by pointing to a pasture that was abandoned 10 years ago. What once was a field was lost under a tangle of vines, woody bushes and saplings 25 feet tall. 
''This is the future,'' said Dr. Nepstad, who recently earned his doctorate from Yale University's School of Forestry and Environmental Studies for research here on regeneration of the Amazon rain forest. ''It will be missing a whole lot of animal and tree species, but it will be a forest.''
Since 1984, an American-financed research team has been investigating human impact on the forest, and researchers feel that their findings will give advance warning of future trends as Brazil's penetration of its vast Amazon wilderness expands and takes new forms in the 1990's.
The researchers have discovered that selective logging of the forest is surprisingly destructive, that conditions for vast devastating fires exist and that regeneration of land used as pasture depends on how heavily it has been used.
 
An Area for Study
Situated three degrees south of the Equator and sprawling over 10,422 square miles, Paragominas was chosen largely because it was considered a ''mature'' Amazon frontier municipality. The first ranches were cleared from the rolling hills and valleys here in 1964, the year a two-lane highway was pushed through.
''It's an old frontier, and you can pick out the patterns,'' said Christopher Uhl, a plant ecologist from Pennsylvania State University who started the project with funds from the National Geographic Society.
One significant and surprisingly destructive pattern in the Amazon's future will be selective logging, Dr. Uhl warned.
Increasing steadily in recent years, wood harvests from the Amazon region now account for about half of Brazil's total, up from 14 percent in 1976. The number of commonly marketed species has jumped from 6 in the 1950's to about 140 today. In Paragominas municipality the number of sawmills has jumped to 300 now from one in 1970.
At the current rate of expansion, much of the Amazon forest could be selectively logged by the middle of the next century, Dr. Uhl calculates.
In a study of two forest tracts here, only 2 percent of the trees were harvested, according to research by Dr. Uhl and a Brazilian plant ecologist, Ima Celia Guimaraes Vieira.
But this selective logging left a destructive trail: 26 percent of trees with trunks greater than four inches in diameter were killed or damaged. Twelve percent lost their crowns in felling, 11 percent were uprooted by bulldozers and 3 percent had their bark scarred.
Cutting 2 percent of the trees also caused the canopy cover to be roughly cut in half, from 80 percent to 43 percent. Such a ''gapped'' forest is vulnerable to further destruction by wind, vines and fire.
Virgin tropical forest rarely burns in the Amazon because of its high humidity. But compared with virgin forest, selectively logged forest in Paragominas is 25 percent drier and 33 percent hotter, and has three times as much combustible material, largely dead branches, vines and saplings.
 
High Risk of Fire
''Six days without rain is enough for the combustible materials to be ready for burning,'' Dr. Uhl and his colleagues wrote in the August issue of Ciencia Hoje, the monthly publication of Brazilian Society for the Progress of Science.
Ranchers and farmers here and in the rest of the Amazon routinely use fire to clear weeds and tree sprouts from pastures near logged forests. Similar conditions created a mammoth fire in Indonesia in 1982 and 1983 that burned 14,300 square miles of tropical rain forest, destroying an estimated $5.5 billion in hardwood.
Studying rainfall patterns with a grant from the World Wildlife Fund, Dr. Uhl and his colleagues concluded, ''The data show that conditions already exist for fires of great size in eastern and southern Amazonia.''
Tropical forest damage during selective logging can be cut in half if loggers plan the trails used to gain access to the trees to minimize damage.
But research here found that loggers have little economic interest in using costly and time-consuming techniques. The loggers do not own the land they forest, and they are under pressure to cut as much wood as quickly as possible. The dry season lasts six months.
Faced with the end of government loans and tax credits, and the steady degradation of pasture, many ranchers are selling logging rights to their forest reserves in order to finance bulldozing, replanting and fertilizing of their pasture land.
Given the emerging fire threat from reckless logging practices, Dr. Uhl said, the Brazilian Institute of Environment and Renewable Natural Resources should start a campaign to promote less wasteful logging techniques and then enforce them.
 
After the Pasture
Turning to another future development, Dr. Nepstad has studied the eastern Amazon's emerging ''post-pasture ecology.''
''Most of the land originally cleared for pasture will not be used for pasture - it was only valuable with government subsidies,'' said Dr. Nepstad, a staff scientist with the Woods Hole Research Center of Massachusetts, which helps finance the research here.
As much as 25 million acres of the Amazon was cleared for pasture in the last two decades. But lacking in soil nutrients, much of the land loses its utility for grazing cattle after four to eight years. In recent years, ranchers and small farmers have abandoned as much as 15 million acres of cleared land.
''At least 50 percent of the land cleared for pasture will be let go,'' Dr. Nepstad predicted as he walked by chest-high underbrush covering an abandoned pasture. ''The perception in the United States and Europe is that deforestation is a terminal event.''
Instead, Dr. Nepstad discovered that forest regeneration depends on the amount of tree roots in pasture soil, the level of old forest seeds in pasture soil, the spreading by birds and bats of seeds from neighboring old forests, and the survival rates for seedlings in the face of drought, cutter ants, and root competition with field species.
''There are a series of overlaid sieves that strain out all but a few species,'' the ecologist said of his work conducted with National Science Foundation grants. ''The cut forest is often gone forever, but clearly something comes up.''
 
Regeneration Possibilities
Research here has confirmed a popular perception: the lighter the land use, the faster the rain forest regeneration. Fields that had only one year's use as pasture regained after eight years of abandonment about one third, or 80 tons, of the original forest vegetation. These plots supported 21 to 25 tree species.
More common to Paragominas is moderate use, grazing for six to eight years and weeding with machetes and by fire. Eight years after abandonment, these study plots had regained about 10 percent of forest vegetation, with 16 to 19 species taking root.
Given current abandonment rates, Dr. Nepstad believes that a major issue in the Amazon in the 1990's will be, ''What do you do with 10 million acres of regrowth forest?''
Answering his own question again, the biologist turned to one experiment, a test field planted with seedlings of 30 varieties of fruit and nut trees. Among the undergrowth of the abandoned pasture were seedlings of several internationally known trees, Brazil nut, mango, mahogany and cashew, and seedlings of local Amazon fruit trees, sapota, genipapo, cupuacu and urucu.
''One man with a machete tends 500 plants a week,'' he said of the seedlings, which on the average would yield a commercial value in four years. ''You can restore agricultural production to these lands at a low cost.''

THE ECONOMY

HEADLINE: Hard Tests Seen for British Despite European Linkup

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Although the British pound jumped and the London stock market soared in response to Britain's formal entry into the European Monetary System, some economists warned yesterday that the euphoria might not be long-lived and that the British economy still faced difficult tests.
The decision to join the system, which was announced on Friday and was effective yesterday, sent the pound climbing. It was up almost 4 cents, or 2 percent, on Friday and more than 2 cents, or 1 percent, yesterday, to $1.9760, in New York trading. [Page D21.] The London stock market's Financial Times-stock exchange index jumped 73.5 points on Friday and another 57.7 yesterday, to 2,201.6, for a two-day rise of 6.3 percent. Other European stock markets, including those in Germany and France, were also buoyed yesterday by the decision. 
But Britain's entry into the monetary system, which ties the value of the pound to other leading European currencies, does not change the nation's fundamental problems, including high inflation and an economy near or in a recession, nor does it make them any easier to resolve.
In addition, the entry into the system does not provide new evidence of the Government's resolve to fight inflation. In fact, an accompanying cut in Britain's interest rates, also announced on Friday, seems to undercut the resolve to curb inflation, which is usually battled with higher rates. In the short term, the rate cut, although overshadowed in Friday's announcement, is a more important policy change than the decision to join the monetary system.
The gravest short-term risk, both for the pound and the stock market, economists said, was that the financial markets would lose confidence in the Government's intention to continue the fight against inflation. This risk exists because the cut in the official interest rate - by one percentage point, to 14 percent - came even though the country's inflation has yet to begin to decline. Britain could have joined the system without any change in interest rates, but the Government said the slowing economy justified the rate reduction.
The cut in rates also adds a new political bias to the Government's economic policy, which could backfire, analysts said.
The Conservative Government of Margaret Thatcher could face a disaster if further cuts in interest rates, which are now expected before a possible election in 1991, result in a sharp decline of the pound that would force the Government to raise interest rates sometime next year to keep the pound within the ranges established for it in the European Monetary System.
There is also the possibility that the cut in interest rates now will mean that once the British economy begins growing at a healthy pace again, inflation will not have fallen sufficiently, and that could force a new round of rising interest rates.
The underlying inflation rate in Britain, which excludes the impact of the poll tax and mortgage interest rates, is around 8 percent, 2.4 percentage points above the average for Europe.
 
Downward Pressure Expected
Several analysts also said yesterday that they felt that the pound would likely begin to come under downward pressure as new data show the British economy slowing further.
''The major impact of the decision Friday in altering expectations is not joining the European rate mechanism but the cutting of interest rates early,'' said John Lipsky, director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers in London. ''Monetary policy is geared to near-term political possibilities that had not been understood before.''
He and many other analysts are now predicting that Prime Minister Thatcher will call the election next year and that interest rates will be cut further to stimulate the sluggish economy and to bring down mortgage interest rates.
 
Political Motivation Denied
John Major, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, denied in a televison interview on Sunday in London that the decisions to join the monetary system and lower interest rates were politically motivated or a reflection of a easing of the Government's stand against inflation. And he said that he would be willing to raise interest rates if inflation continued to rise.
But Mr. Lipsky said that the chancellor's explanation of the policy change was not good enough to offset these concerns. The interest rate cut, he said, still came ''even before inflation has peaked, even before the autumn wage negotiations and even before any convergence of the inflation rate toward the much lower European average.''
Beyond the short-term outlook, the move to join the European Monetary System poses some longer-term pain for the British economy. Warren Oliver, an economist at UBS Phillips & Drew in London, said that Britain was likely to continue for some time with an underlying inflation rate above the rest of Euorpe.
 
Costs Will Remain Higher
But because the pound is now tied to other European currencies, with only a 12 percent range to move in, the higher inflation rate will mean that British companies will become less competitive against their European rivals because their labor and other costs will remain higher.
This process of adjustment and declining competitiveness, which France and other European countries in the monetary system have gone through, is likely to force another round of rising interest rates in Britain to cool inflation.
But Mr. Oliver is not confident that either British companies or British labor unions will respond quickly with the changes needed to reduce costs and make exporters more competitive. So this adjustment process, he said, could be difficult.

HEADLINE: U.S. Urged To End Hanoi Trade Curb

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
As Washington's diplomatic relations with Hanoi begin to thaw, the Administration is under increasing pressure to end the 15-year-old trade embargo that excludes American business from the country that many economists and business executives say could become Asia's next industrial tiger.
Since Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, met in New York on Sept. 29 for the first high-level encounter between officials of the Governments since 1973, speculation has increased that trade normalization may come soon.
 
Groups Pressing for Shift
The pressure is coming from lawmakers and business executives who argue that the sanctions are of diminishing foreign policy importance and are hurting the long-term economic interests of the United States.
The United States Chamber of Commerce notes that other countries are expanding their trade and investment in Vietnam, while American business is kept out. The board of the business organization unanimously passed a resolution in early summer calling for normalization. 
''It's time,'' said William T. Archey, the chamber's international vice president.
While State Department officials are sympathetic, they point to the still-bitter issue of 1,678 American servicemen lost in Vietnam whose status has not yet been resolved.
The Baker-Thach meeting set up a process for further accounting by Hanoi of the American personnel. Mr. Thach is expected in Washington around Oct. 17 and will see Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who is the special Presidential negotiator on the issue of the prisoners of war and those missing in action.
Mr. Thach is also expected to meet with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, several of whose members want to lift the sanctions, which have been in effect since the United States pulled out of Vietnam in 1975. The committee is preparing hearings on the issue early in the next session of Congress.
Supported by economists of the World Bank, many business officials see Vietnam, which has adopted ambitious enterprise-oriented measures, as a market about to take off.
 
New Growth Market
The World Bank has completed studies showing that Vietnam bears an uncannily similar economic profile to South Korea of 1965, which was then just emerging from a long period of economic stagnation after the Korean War. For instance, the gross national product per capita for Vietnam in 1988 was $109, compared with $106 for Korea 25 years ago. Exports as a percentage of national output were 10.3 percent for Vietnam, compared with 9.5 percent in Korea.
Korea today is one of a group of Asian industrial nations that are known as the tigers because of their great economic strength surging out of market-oriented policies. Other tigers include Taiwan, Singapore, Malyasia and Hong Kong.
World Bank and other economists say Vietnam, in efforts to attract foreign capital, has gone even further than new democracies in Eastern Europe in writing liberal investment and banking laws in the last year. Vietnam's new investment law, for example, provides both for joint ventures and for 100 percent foreign ownership of local property.
 
Now Exporting Rice
A former rice-importing nation, Vietnam has now become a rice exporter, thanks to new agricultural policies. About 80 percent of its farm economy is in private hands, according to World Bank economists, and about half of its food market is privately operated.
Steven K. Baker, Citicorp's division head for North Asian Countries, said the economic conditions in Vietnam could offer even greater market potential in the coming decade than China.
But while the sanctions remain in effect, advocates of rapprochement say, the United States risks losing out to Japanese, European and other Asian competition.
Before Vietnam's withdrawal of an estimated 300,000 troops from Cambodia last year - a condition set by the United States for normalization -American allies grudgingly supported the embargo.
 
Requirements Are Met
But today most of these countries say that Vietnam has satisfied fundamental requirements for trade relations. Japan announced last week that it was allowing its banks to operate in Vietnam for the first time since 1975.
The Bush Administration, on the other hand, now says that before normalization, Vietnam must cooperate on a comprehensive peace settlement for Cambodia. Some American businessmen and lawmakers say the imposition of this new condition is equivalent to moving the goal posts.
The President's advisers, however, are divided on how to proceed. Mr. Baker, according to Administration officials, is more eager to repair the economic links with Vietnam than the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. Their deputies, Robert Kimmitt and Karl Jackson, have clashed repeatedly on the issue.
Hotels and business centers in Vietnam, meanwhile, are described as full of non-Americans ready and willing to do business.
 
War Zone to Trade Zone
Thailand has taken the lead in efforts to transform Indochina from a ''war zone into a trade zone,'' as Thai leaders like to put it.
Through the end of last year, Vietnam had approved 106 foreign investment projects with a total registered capital of $1 billion. Hong Kong, French, British, Australian and Thai concerns completed the most agreements.
The biggest losers may have been American oil companies. Off-shore oil drilling and exploration leases for what are considered especially promising tracts in the South China Sea went to such foreign companies as Shell, British Petroleum and Total of France.
To assess the pent-up demand for expanding into the Vietnam market, Citibank recently canvassed 162 companies involved in commerce in Asia. Seventy-five percent expressed an interest in doing business right away, 85 percent over the longer term.
Fifty-seven of the 87 participating American companies indicated an interest in Vietnam business.
 
Loans Being Sought
To support its market-oriented policies and help raise capital, Vietnam, as a member of both the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, is pressing to borrow from both institutions.
For the time being, it cannot, because it is running $140 million of past due debts with the I.M.F. Arrears bar a country from any dealings with the twin organizations, which offer loans to support market-oriented economic policies in third world countries.
Yet later this month, according to international monetary officials, the Vietnam arrears are likely to be paid off, making Vietnam once again eligible for bank-fund assistance.
This would create thorny problems for Washington. Should the Administration try to block the aid, it could antagonize allies the United States has courted in the Persian Gulf crisis.
Should the aid go forward, American business would complain that it was being shut out of a country being aided by American-supported international institutions, further increasing the pressure for a lifting of the sanctions.

HEADLINE: Scattered Military News Lifts Oil by 96/, to $38.95

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
With little diplomatic news from the Persian Gulf, oil prices moved up again on scattered military news in light trading yesterday, a holiday for some.
Crude oil for November delivery closed up by 96 cents, at $38.95 a barrel, in trading at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The close was the third highest since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But several traders said there were few developments, if any, worthy of moving the market. 
 
'Continuing Tidbits'
''It's just continuing tidbits out of the Middle East,'' said Peter C. Beutel of the Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J. ''Helicopters missing, things like that, don't make you feel all that secure.'' Two Marine helicopters with eight men aboard were reported missing yesterday after what the Navy said was a ''routine night training mission.''
News that a British warship fired across the bow of an Iraqi freighter with a cargo of food and stopped it also buoyed prices, as did a report of a jet plane crash that killed two American pilots in Saudi Arabia. In addition, violence between Palestinians and Israelis pushed prices up, some traders said.
''In a market that's trading at these levels,'' said Brian W. Tagler, an energy futures trader at Lehman Brothers, ''a couple of news items like that are enough to support the market and keep prices on the run.''
 
Fears and Momentum
Mr. Beutel said that what moved the market were ''fears that nothing has gotten better in the Middle East,'' along with momentum. ''A market in motion wants to keep in motion, and continue in the same direction it has been going,'' he added.
At Purvin & Gertz, a Houston consulting firm, Ken Miller, an analyst, said: ''The movements in the markets these days are a function of technical and psychological reaction. There really is no fundamental basis for this kind of radical move.''
Gasoline prices rose 1.11 cents, to 93.75 cents a gallon, and heating oil rose 0.26 cent, to 102.96 cents a gallon, in contracts for delivery next month.
Oil for delivery in later months also rose. December oil was up 90 cents, to $37.77.
 
Worries Again a Factor
November oil has moved from a post-invasion peak close of $39.51 on Sept. 27 down to $33.95 at the close on Oct. 2, in reaction to a speech by President Bush at the United Nations that included some conciliatory words. But according to Mr. Tagler, ''that's already over a week old; that's becoming ancient history now.'' He added, ''The worries about the future are being factored back into the price.''
The supply of oil appears to remain balanced with demand, however. The executive director of the International Energy Agency, Helga Steet, told a conference in London yesterday that there were no critical shortages, and that there would be none unless there was an unusually severe winter or an industrial accident.
 
Differences in Estimates
Experts differ about precisely how much the crisis has reduced oil output. The Middle East Economic Survey, a newsletter based in Nicosia, Cyprus, estimates that September production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was 22.49 million barrels a day, compared with 23.5 million in July, meaning that the gap was a million barrels a day, which is a little under 2 percent of world production. The Energy Department has been predicting that the shortfall, which was initially 4.3 million barrels a day, would shrink to under a million barrels a day by November.
But Platts, another newsletter, put September production at 22 million barrels a day. Part of the difference between the two estimates was for Saudi Arabia; the Middle East Economic Survey put the Saudi increase at 2.1 million barrels a day, but Platts said it was less than 1.9 million. They also differed on estimates of output from Venezuela and other OPEC producers.
Experts say consumption is down, too, in response to higher prices. But demand is up, because nervous buyers want to prepare themselves for a siege. Thus, stocks may be rising as the crisis progresses.

HEADLINE: More Women Own Concerns

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The number of United States businesses owned by women climbed by 57 percent between 1982 and 1987, the Census Bureau reported last week.
The bureau said American women owned 4.1 million companies in 1987 - the most recent year for which statistics were available - or 30 percent of all businesses in the nation, up from 2.6 million in 1982. 
The number of new enterprises owned by women grew four times faster than the overall rate of business creations in the United States. From 1982 to 1987 the total number of new businesses rose by 14 percent.
The Census Bureau said women's businesses had total receipts of $278 billion in 1987, 13.9 percent of the total.
Most women were sole proprietors of their concerns. Only 4 percent owned their businesses through partnerships and 6 percent through small corporations. The bureau said its survey did not include larger corporations.
Just over half of the women-owned companies were described as personal or business services, while 19 percent were classified as retail trade and 11 percent as finance, insurance and real estate.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Anticipating Growth, Continental Buys Jets

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Continental Airlines said today that it had ordered 25 new Boeing 757 jets, with an option for 25 more, in anticipation of long-term growth.
The firm order, including engines and spare parts, is valued at about $1.2 billion and will be financed through ''significant participation'' by the Boeing Company and the engine manufacturer, Continental said in a statement.
Continental said it had not yet chosen between Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and Pratt & Whitney for the engines. 
In Seattle, a spokesman for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, Craig Martin, declined to discuss Boeing's financial arrangement with Continental. ''We never comment on such arrangements with our customers,'' Mr. Martin said.
A Continental spokesman, David Messing, said: ''We're looking at the long-term needs of the airline. We know we have higher fuel prices, and some expect a recession, but we want to add capacity for when the economy returns to strength.''
The 757, a twin-engine aircraft that seats up to 190 passengers, will replace older aircraft when delivery begins in May 1993.
Mr. Messing also said the order would help the airline to save money if fuel prices remained high because the 757's were more fuel-efficient than other models.
''This order is a significant component of a well-reasoned fleet plan we have developed for the '90's and beyond,'' said Continental's chairman and chief executive, Hollis L. Harris, who replaced the confrontational Frank Lorenzo as head of the airline earlier this year.
''The 757 is especially well suited for service on our high-density, medium-to-long-distance domestic routes,'' Mr. Harris said. ''We feel this order will make a substantial contribution to our other plans for improving the quality of our service.''
Continental also has an order with Seattle-based Boeing for 100 of its 737's, some of those on option, and with the French consortium Airbus Industrie for 40 long-range A330's, some of those also on option.
With the order announced today, Continental has a total 190 aircraft on order, including 95 on option, to add to its fleet of 338 aircraft.
Continental's stock rose 37.5 cents a share today, to $4.50, on the American Stock Exchange, while Boeing gained 37.5 cents, to $43.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Control Data Unit To Martin Marietta

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Martin Marietta Corporation will purchase the Control Data Corporation's reconnaissance systems business segment for an undisclosed price, the companies said. The Air Force must approve the transaction.

HEADLINE: U.S. View of Soviet Market

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Trading on a Soviet stock exchange could start next year, but foreigners will probably remain on the sidelines until the ruble is convertible, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange said today.
John J. Phelan Jr., the Big Board's top executive, and a delegation of 20 Wall Street executives were invited to Moscow to give a three-day seminar on the nuts and bolts of running a stock market. Dealings in stocks and bonds has been illegal in the Soviet Union since the 1917 revolution.
Mr. Phelan predicted that whatever economic plan was finally adopted, within the next 18 months the Government will have reorganized financial structures, permitted the development of private companies and lifted legal restrictions on private transactions between individuals. He added that a stock exchange could begin as soon as late in 1991.
More than 400 Soviet bankers, economists, academics and Government officials attended the course on securities, American style, seeking explanations for several concepts foreign to the ideology of Communists and to their command economy.
Mr. Phelan said long-term foreign investment in a Soviet stock market probably would require a fully convertible ruble, the right to export profits and the right to receive dividends in a stable currency. The state now controls the price of the ruble against world currencies.

HEADLINE: Sales Strong for Jersey Nordstrom's

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARAMUS, N.J.

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc.'s store here, its first in the New York metropolitan area, appears to be off to a strong start in its first month, industry analysts and company executives say.
Nordstrom executives refused to give details on the store's sales but said it had had the best initial sales volume of any of the company's three East Coast stores.
Managers at competing stores and securities analysts who have long followed Nordstrom said the opening sales, if sustained, would allow the store to reach sales of $100 million in its first year. That is well above average for large new stores. 
When the fashion clothing store opened on Sept. 7 in the Garden State Plaza shopping center, some analysts and retail store consultants wondered how it would fare, given the slump in the New York area's retail economy.
 
Ahead of Rivals
Thomas Rauh, the director of retail consulting for Ernst & Young, said that based on early reports of foot traffic and sales estimates, the Paramus Nordstrom should match the 1989 company-average sales of $475 a square foot. If so, that would put it well ahead of rivals like Macy's, Bloomingdale's and May Company stores. Macy's stores, for example, average $250 a square foot. The new Nordstrom store has 245,000 square feet spread over three levels.
''Even if they underperform their own company average in Garden State Plaza in the first year,'' he said, ''they will outperform the department stores in the area.''
Some analysts say that sales at Nordstrom's East Coast stores will help offset the slumping sales of those on the West Coast, where most Nordstrom stores are situated. But the company is still taking a cautious stance for the rest of the year. Several weeks ago, it said that it planned to reduce its staff natonally by 6 to 12 percent, but would leave the details to its individual store managers.
Jack McMillan, Nordstrom's president, said he was pleased with the early sales but concerned about the shaky economy in the Northeast.
''We're off to a great start and running above our planned sales,'' he said in a telephone interview from Seattle, where the company is based. ''But I think we have a mixed message. The regional economy is tough, but our store is kicking off well. Since we want to expand further, we are concerned whether the economy's turndown will be short- or long-term. So how fast should we go in expanding beyond the other two New Jersey stores we have planned?''
Nordstrom, with 62 stores nationwide, is noted for its high level of customer service. It opened its first East Coast store in April 1988 in the Tyson's Corner shopping center in McLean, Va., and followed it in October 1989 with a store in Pentagon City, Va., both near Washington. The Paramus store is larger than either of those. Other New Jersey stores are planned for Edison and Freehold.
 
Reversing the Usual Pattern
Strong sales in the first few weeks at the new store are no guarantee of long-term success. But Cody Kondo, Nordstrom's corporate vice president and general manager for New Jersey, said the second Saturday after the opening was as strong in sales as the first Saturday. ''That is the reverse of the usual pattern,'' he said.
''The store seems to be doing very, very well,'' said Lawrence Stone, the chairman and chief executive of Stern's department stores, based in Paramus. ''It is always active and apparently very successful.''
So far shoes, men's wear and children's apparel are the leading departments in sales volume at the Paramus store, company officials said. They added that sales of women's wear had not fared as well.
R. H. Macy & Company, which has operated an anchor store in the mall since 1957, says that since Nordstrom's arrival on Sept. 7, business has picked up at Macy's 440,000-square-foot store.
Although Macy's in Paramus had started a $31 million renovation almost a year before Nordstrom's appearance, once Nordstrom announced its entry, ''we decided to accelerate our renovations in two key areas: the men's wear departments and the 'better' women's apparel area,'' said Joel Sneider, Macy's senior vice president and director of stores in the Northeast.
 
Service a Factor
When asked why they thought Nordstrom seemed to be doing well, shoppers often mentioned the novelty of an unfamiliar big new store and Nordstrom's customer service.
''I first learned of Nordstrom's fine customer service when I visited Seattle,'' said Shirley Lieberman of Springfield, N.J. ''They have a well-deserved reputation for being attentive and solicitous to customers.''
Dianne Mauro of Passaic, N.J., said: ''The atmosphere is pleasant. They explain everything to you. Other department stores pack in too much merchandise, so it is hard to move around.''
One loyal Macy's customer voiced an exception. Claire Surgan of Cresskill, N.J., said: ''Nordstrom's prices are much higher than Macy's. Nordstrom has this reputation for service, but Macy's has its own program and you get more attention from the salespeople.''
Mr. Kondo, the Paramus store's general manager, said there was no special manual of customer-service rules that employees had to memorize or any extra-tough training program to prepare them to meet demands by Northeastern customers.
''But we urge our 35 department managers to hire 'nice people' who can respond well to the customer,'' he said.
It does not hurt that salespeople earn commissions, raising some salaries to as high as $100,000 a year.
Even so, some Nordstrom employees in the state of Washington filed labor grievances, charging management had put pressure on them to do many time-consuming tasks for customers for which they were not paid. In August, the company said it had reached a settlement.
Marlene Kraut, one of the Paramus store's 900 employees, said she sometimes went to great lengths for her customers - from booking a manicure to scouring the store for shoes and accessories to match an outfit.
Mr. Stone of Stern's said Nordstrom's marble floors, big atrium and high ceilings set the store apart from others in the area.And Nordstrom's main section echoes with the sound of classical music played on a grand piano.
Macy's, not to be outdone, now has a pianist tinkling light show music in its remodeled women's department on the second floor.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Plan to Turn Engineers Into Teachers

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
IN the 1960's and early 1970's, when employment was relatively stable, many big companies like the Digital Equipment Corporation worked on the theory that they would not have mass dismissals or voluntary early retirements during economic downturns or corporate reshufflings. Now, it is a different story.
Digital Equipment, of Maynard, Mass., in the once-booming high-tech area around Boston, said in its annual report that 3,000 people voluntarily accepted a financial package to resign last year - its first effort to shrink the size of the company. The company took an accounting charge of $455 million to reflect those employee separations and related expenses. The program has continued this year. 
Much more quietly, it began in January to train a small number of engineers to become teachers.
Each engineer selected for the Digital program had at least a bachelor of science degree and five years' employment at Digital as well as a good performance rating. All went through 10 weeks of discussion about the move.
Of 30 offered the program, 26 decided to resign and study for the transition to teaching in school or college the subjects they know best: mathematics, physics, engineering and computer science. Digital expects to have 60 more participants by the spring of 1991. Nationally there has been an extreme shortage of able teachers in these subjects at high school or college levels, and jobs should be available.
Each participant receives an allowance of 40 to 104 weeks of pay, depending on length of service, much like the package offered the 3,000 who resigned. For the engineers in the special program, Digital provides tuition reimbursement up to $13,000 for a year of approved full-time study or two years part time, plus $2,500 to cover costs like books and laboratory fees. It also maintains medical, dental and life insurance coverage for one year.
The initial group of 26 ranges in age from the 20's to the early 60's and has a variety of backgrounds.
Cindy M. Capuano, 29 years old, who graduated from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Worcester, Mass., with a bachelor of science degree in industrial engineering, worked for Digital for seven years in quality control, manufacturing and purchasing. ''I have always been interested in teaching,'' she said in a telephone interview, ''because my father and mother are teachers, and that made the transition easier.''
She now teaches computer science to grades 4 through 12 at Hudson Catholic High School in Hudson, Mass., and an adjacent elementary school. Several afternoons a week she drives to Cambridge, Mass. to take courses at Lesley College, where she is working toward a master's degree in computer education.
Bruce D. Smith of Hancock, N.H., who is 62 and spent 16 years with Digital, calls the program ''just right for the country.'' It is also just right for him. He is working for a master's degree in liberal arts at Keene State College in Keene, N.H.. He already has a bachelor of science degree in electrical engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology and a masters's from Drexel University.
''My thesis will be engineering in contemporary society,'' he said. ''My goal is to influence the educational process rather than to teach. There is a critical shortage of applied engineers who use fundamental principles to create new products and improve quality of old ones.'' He hopes to be an administrator.
Some in the group are working mothers with master's degrees. Several attend Harvard University for education courses needed for teaching certificates.
Many universities like Harvard now offer midcareer opportunities for transition to teaching and other jobs, and so encouraging engineers to make such a move is not new. What is new is the large amount of friendly suggestion and financial support given by Digital.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Off in Foreign Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose slightly in thin trading overseas yesterday, as market participants in the United States took Columbus Day off.
Analysts said the small drop in prices, which amounted to as much as 3/8 point for some securities, was somewhat surprising, because the dollar was battered on foreign currency markets.
At the close of trading in Europe, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 11/32, down 9/32, to yield 8.81 percent, up from 8.78 percent late Friday. 
On the Chicago Board of Trade, which was open for business yesterday, the near Treasury bond futures contract closed at a price of 90 15/32, down 15/32.
Although the House of Representatives approved a vaguely worded budget agreement late Sunday night, and the Senate appeared likely to do the same, it remained uncertain late yesterday whether President Bush would go along with the plan.
The House also approved an increase in the Federal debt ceiling, to $3.19 trillion. The increase would be enough to carry the Government through Oct. 20. The Senate, which was deliberating over the budget last night, was also expected to approve the increase in the debt ceiling.
Should Mr. Bush decide to veto the new budget, the debt ceiling would not be raised and today's auctions of three-month and six-month Treasury bills would be delayed, analysts said.
Despite the budget proposal's vague terms and promises, economists said they did not anticipate an adverse reaction in the credit markets to the plan when traders return in force today.
''I don't think the market will be tremendously put off by it,'' said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers. ''People may be a bit more disturbed by the fact that the accord is a bit flimsier than its predecessor. But you can't cast stones right now because you don't know what is in the package.''
Under the terms of the budget agreement reached by the House, specific spending cuts and tax increases are to be agreed to by various Congressional committees over the next two weeks.
Activity in other debt markets was limited because of the holiday.
Prices of investment-grade and high-yield ''junk bonds'' were unchanged in extremely sparse trading.
And participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said prices of New York City bonds, which were marked down by as much as 2 points on Friday, were basically unchanged yesterday. As on Friday, few city bonds actually changed hands yesterday.

HEADLINE: Bulgarian Strategy Is Made in U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
A group of American experts has taken on the moribund economy of newly democratic Bulgaria and has drawn up a plan for transforming it into a supply-side, free market.
Their work, under the auspices of the United States Chamber of Commerce, was hailed by President Zhelyu Zhelev, who said during a visit here last month that major features of the American plan would be adopted and incorporated into Bulgarian law later this month.
The so-called Action Plan for Bulgaria was drafted by 18 Americans, including some high-powered Reagan Administration officials. It includes such predictably simple recommendations as ''privatization of the means of production and distribution'' and ''basic reform of the monetary, banking and fiscal systems'' to remove impediments created by 45 years of Communist rule. 
 
Guidelines and Deadlines
It is in the details and timetable worked out by the Americans, in cooperation with Bulgarian specialists, that the plan displays its originality as a schedule for transition from what remains largely a Communist economic structure to one recognizable as a Western model.
For example, the plan declares it ''absolutely essential for the functioning of a market system'' that by the end of the year, Bulgaria should adopt a ''privatization program,'' begin basic monetary reform and allow free circulation of foreign currencies, eliminate wage and price controls, take steps to protect the poorest elements of the population from hardships and agree on tax reform. It then provides precise guidelines for carrying out these measures.
''It is the most fascinating thing I have ever done in my life,'' said Richard W. Rahn, vice president of the Chamber of Commerce and its chief economist. It is a sentiment echoed by the other Americans on the project, which was initiated last spring.
''The only way to prevent me from going back to Bulgaria is for the U.S. Government to take away my passport or the Bulgarians to deny me a visa,'' said Charles E. McClure, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who wrote the chapter of the plan on tax policy.
Another enthusiastic participant is Eugene L. Stewart, a Washington lawyer who specializes in commercial legislation. Mr. Stewart, who is 70 years old, spent August taking apart the Commercial Code of Bulgaria, which was promulgated in 1896, and rewriting it to make way for modern international business transactions.
Charles Murray, the conservative social thinker, who is the author of ''Losing Ground,'' contributed a chapter on revision of Bulgaria's social welfare policies.
The chapter on privatization was written by Ronald D. Utt, former associate director of the Office of Management and Budget and now vice president of the National Chamber Foundation, the research arm of the Chamber of Commerce, which has sponsored the Bulgaria project.
Mr. Rahn said in an interview that the impetus for the plan came from Government officials in Sofia who were aware of a lecture he gave last winter in Hungary on transition to market economies. ''They invited me in March,'' he recalled.
He met with economists of the post-Stalinist Government that had taken power in November 1989 and with Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov, himself an economist. ''We need technical assistance,'' Mr. Lukanov and the other Bulgarians told Mr. Rahn.
After visits by an American delegation to Sofia and a Bulgarian delegation to Washington, the American team spent several weeks in August in Bulgaria working with their counterparts on the final draft of the plan, which was put together and printed in late September. The head of the Bulgarian delegation is Ivan Angelov, economic adviser to Mr. Lukanov.
Evidence of the enthusiasm of the members of the American group may be seen in the fact that they have paid their own way to Bulgaria and have donated their time, Mr. Rahn said. As far as he could tell, the Chamber of Commerce's Bulgaria plan is unique in terms of its Western origin and its comprehensiveness.
 
Acceptance Likely
In a news conference at the Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Zhelev said he was confident the Bulgarian Government would accept virtually all the recommendations, even though the Government is in the hands of the Socialist Party, which is the successor of the former ruling Communist Party.
''They will be eager to proceed,'' he said, ''because otherwise the Government will fall.'' Mr. Zhelev heads the main coalition of opposition parties in Bulgaria.
The American team delivered its 600-page draft to Mr. Lukanov in Sofia last week. The Bulgarian reform program is to be taken up in the Grand National Assembly on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Pound Rises Sharply Again; Dollar Ends Broadly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The British pound took center stage again in foreign exchange yesterday, while the dollar weakened against all major currencies amid continued economic jitters.
Market activity continued to focus on the British pound's entry into the Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European Monetary System. The mechanism links European currencies to one another to avoid large swings in exchange rates. The move, which was announced on Friday and sent the pound surging, is expected to help Britain fight inflation and improve that country's economic prospects. 
The pound jumped to $1.9745, from $1.9455 late Friday, in London, and to $1.9760 from $1.9525 in New York.
Trading over all was thin, with many United States banks closed in observance of Columbus Day.
Timothy Barton, an assistant vice president at the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said technical factors, along with concerns about the weakness in the United States economy, helped depress the dollar in trading against other major currencies.
 
Budget Plan Awaited
Most traders in the United Statesd and abroad were also awaiting a new deficit reduction package. The House passed a new budget plan overnight Sunday, offering an alternative to a proposal that was rejected in Congress last week.
A narrower gap between the Government's revenues and spending would probably result in a drop in interest rates, and that is expected to further depress the dollar.
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell to a one-and-a-half-year low against the Japanese yen, closing at 130.05 yen, down from 133.72 on Friday. It traded at 130.70 yen in London, and 130.48 in New York, down from 132.20.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell in New York trading to 1.53225 marks, down from 1.5475.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, were: 1.2800 Swiss francs, down from 1.2940; 5.1300 French francs, down from 5.1850; 1,151.50 Italian lire, down from 1,160.25, and 1.15135 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1524.
In the bullion market, gold prices rose after declining overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $394.90 an ounce, up $1.30 from late Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $395 an ounce, up $1.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $392.45 an ounce, from $394.35 late Friday. In Zurich, gold closed at $391.80 an ounce, down from $394.40. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.26, to $388.69.

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: WARNING IS ISSUED TO NEW YORK CITY ON BOND RATINGS

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In a sign of concern about New York City's fiscal condition, the Standard & Poor's Corporation warned yesterday that the city's credit rating on its bonds might fall and that it must revise its financial plan ''in line with the realities'' of a slipping economy.
Citing questions about how the city would balance its budget in the face of growing revenue shortfalls, rising costs, pressure for labor settlements and proposed police hiring, Standard & Poor's, one of the nation's major credit rating agencies, placed the city's $13 billion in general-obligation bonds on ''credit watch.''
If the city's credit rating fell, it would cost more for it to borrow money to build roads, bridges, parks and the other long-term projects that it is already planning to scale back to save money.
Fiscal experts said the move was not unexpected and reflected the levels at which the city's bonds had recently been trading. But it was the first time that Standard & Poor's had placed the city on a credit watch in the nine-year history of the warning, and in doing so, it prodded the Dinkins administration to act aggressively to close a budget gap for the next fiscal year, now estimated at $1.4 billion or more. 
 
'A Heightened Concern'
The rating agency noted that the city had a ''history of 10 years of satisfactory financial operations'' and that it had successfully closed substantial budget gaps in many of those years. It said that if the rating dropped from its current level, A-, it was expected to fall within the BBB category, where it was in the mid-1980's and which is still considered investment grade.
''It's a heightened concern,'' said Hyman Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, who is one of a handful of experts responsible for revising the ratings. ''We're looking for them over the next two or three months' time to create a plan that's credible and that moves forward based on the new reality of a weakened economy and the counterproductivity of continual tax increases.''
The other major rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, does not have the city's rating under formal review and no immediate change is contemplated, said Jeffrey F. Rizzo, a managing director. But he added, ''We may be coming out with a comment in the next day or so to report on recent developments.''
Market reaction to the Standard & Poor's announcement was fairly muted.
Prices of outstanding New York City bonds fell by about half a point yesterday, municipal bond traders said. But prices of fixed-income securities fell sharply yesterday, and the drop in city bonds was in line with declines recorded by other issues, dealers said.
Last week, Mayor David N. Dinkins said he was considering the layoff of at least 15,000 city workers as well as hundreds of millions of dollars in service cuts to close gaps in the budget for the current and coming fiscal years. He also announced a partial freeze on hiring and a moratorium on most raises.
Asked yesterday about the credit warning, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I don't think it is a reflection on my stewardship.'' He added: ''Certainly, I didn't affect the economy. We've had a downhill run.''
''I'm confident that we're going to be able to satisfy them that we have a plan as to how to meet this gap,'' the Mayor said.
 
Quarterly Revision
The city is to submit its regular quarterly revision of its four-year financial plan to the State Financial Control Board next month.
Earlier this year, the state was placed on a credit watch and its bond rating was eventually lowered to A by Standard & Poor's, in a rebuke to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature for their failure to pass a budget on time. At that time, city officials expressed satisfaction that their credit rating was not under review, thanks in part to the stringent budget controls imposed during the city fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
Yesterday, the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said the credit watch was ''a disappointment'' but said he was ''very confident that we're going to be able to take up their challenge'' and present a revised plan that ''reaffirms our ability to work through these problems.''
 
'Ducks All in a Row'
''We have our ducks all in a row,'' Mr. Michael added. ''We know where the problems are and we're going to knock them off one at a time.''
But it was precisely because the administration did not appear to have all its ducks in a row that it came under mounting pressure last week from fiscal monitors to explain its overall plan for dealing with a budget gap that it had been warning of for weeks.
The city began last week with a tentative agreement on a 5.5 percent pay increase for teachers - financed with previously budgeted money and a mix of other uncertain sources - that a number of outside fiscal monitors criticized as too costly. Then, Mr. Dinkins proposed $1.8 billion in new taxes over the next four years to finance a major anti-crime plan, on top of more than $800 billion in higher taxes passed to balance the current budget.
Most of the new taxes would require approval by the Legislature, which has expressed reluctance to pass them, as would much of the money for the teachers' settlement, which involves recalculating pension fund earnings.
Only after proposing such spending did Mr. Dinkins impose the hiring freeze and suggest that the city might have to lay off thousands of workers.
 
'Clearly Not the Answer'
Mr. Grossman of Standard & Poor's said the issues raised by that sequence of events were among the questions the agency wanted to review with the city.
Privately, some mayoral aides linked the credit warning to a report by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman last week suggesting that the budget gap for the coming year might be nearly twice as large as the administration's estimate.
Yesterday, Ms. Holtzman issued a statement saying the city ''can preserve its credit rating and overcome its budget difficulties by developing a credible, comprehensive budget plan.''
The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, the state's highest ranking Republican, said of the warning, ''It is a not unexpected further manifestation of the problem and underscores the need for the city to live within its means and brace for harder times ahead.''
The Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, said the city intended to proceed with its planned offering of about $800 million to $1 billion of new general-obligation bonds next month and was confident the credit rating would not be lowered.
