HEADLINE: THE BUDGET AGREEMENT;
BUSH HINTS AT RISE IN TOP TAX RATES, THEN BACKS AWAY

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
President Bush said for the first time today that he might agree to an increase in income tax rates for wealthy Americans as part of a budget compromise, but he later abandoned that position under strong pressure from Republican senators.
A few hours after signing a stopgap measure that averted a shutdown of most Government operations, Mr. Bush said in a morning news conference that if Congress agreed to the cut in capital gains taxes he had long sought, he would consider higher income tax rates. [Excerpts are on page A18.] He changed his mind after an afternoon meeting at which 17 senators opposed his proposal, throwing the already confused budget negotiations into near chaos.
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, said the President agreed with the lawmakers' ''uniform position that we will not go up on the rates, no matter what.'' 
 
Democrats 'Thunderstruck'
White House officials confirmed his account tonight. One Presidential aide said Mr. Bush had concluded that a deal along the lines he had specified ''is not worth fighting for.'' The aide said the President had listened to the senators in silence, ''and it's fair to say he aquiesced in their views.''
The effect of the switch from morning to afternoon was to put Mr. Bush in a more partisan position than before, allied with Congressional Republicans against the Democrats. Democratic leaders were ''totally thunderstruck,'' said one senator, and it was not immediately known what they would do in the new political situation. But it appeared highly likely that the President's action had scuttled any chance of alterations in either the income tax or the capital gains rates and had made bipartisan cooperation considerably more difficult.
 
Tax Proposal Was Planned
Mr. Bush, who promised ''no new taxes'' in his 1988 election campaign and stuck to it for his first year and a half in office, retreated on excise and other taxes in negotiations this summer but until this morning had clung, at least in public statements, to his refusal to alter income tax rates.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, had been ready to propose on Wednesday a deal of the kind Mr. Bush outlined, members of his staff said.
In an interview this evening Mr. Bentsen said he was astounded by Mr. Bush's apparent change of heart. ''I think this is unprecedented,'' he said. ''This morning he says said he'll consider the trade and this afternoon we have this statement that there's no way they'll do it. I wonder what his position will be tomorrow morning.''
Mr. Bentsen said the President's reversal severely complicated efforts to complete a deficit-reduction package and to get it through his committee. His panel had planned to begin deliberations Wednesday on specific deficit-reduction proposals, but Mr. Bentsen said tonight he wanted to ''sleep on it'' before determining how to proceed.
''It looks as if they are determined to protect those making over $200,000 from having any increase in their taxes,'' he said.
Senate aides said he had planned to call for a rise in bracket rates for the richest Americans to 33 percent from 28 percent, smoothing out a so-called bubble in the tax system that since 1986 has resulted in richer Americans' paying a lower rate on the top portion of their income than did less affluent Americans.
 
Changes in Other Rates
Senator Bentsen had also planned to recommend lowering the capital gains rate to a maximum of 23 percent from the current 28 percent. And he had planned to raise the alternative minimum tax on all income, regardless of deductions, to 25 percent from today's 21 percent. This measure would also hit the very rich, who have so many deductions and exemptions and exclusions that their normal tax liability falls below those levels.
How all this would redistribute the tax burden among various income groups is not clear, though Senator Bentsen said today that his aim was to make the system more progressive.
Mr. Bentsen had also proposed softening elements of the deficit reduction package that the House rejected last week. These included scaling down a proposed increase in the gasoline tax, eliminating a tax on home heating oil and reducing cuts in Medicare.
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, was reported to have advised Mr. Bentsen to put aside the capital gains and income tax issues and move ahead on the larger question of finding enough new revenue and cuts in spending to meet the requirements of the new budget resolution.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, had planned to make comprehensive proposals of his own Wednesday. But it was not clear whether he would go along with a tradeoff between capital gains and higher income taxes on the wealthy. His committee was meeting late this evening to discuss a tax package.
Even before Mr. Bush's switch today, it was by no means certain that Congress would approve what the President, Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Rostenkowski seemed to be focusing on. With opposition to new taxes strong among voters, with elections looming and with White House tactics misfiring, a painstakingly negotiated budget package failed last week to muster a majority among either Republicans or Democrats in the House.
 
Out of Touch
Some Republicans in the House said today that they still believed the President was out of touch with the sentiment of rank-and-file lawmakers.
After a holiday weekend marked by modest but highly visible reductions in Government operations, Congress early today passed a budget resolution similar to the one defeated earlier, but with deficit-reduction details left to committees like Mr. Bentsen's and Mr. Rostenkowski's. It also approved a resolution to keep Government spending at last year's levels until Oct. 19, a week from Friday.
Mr. Bush signed that resolution at 7 o'clock this morning after intense arguments within his staff about whether he should veto it to keep the heat on Congress. He had vetoed a similar measure last Sunday, which was unaccompanied by a budget package.
The revised budget resolution, incorporating a deficit-reduction plan, cleared the House on Monday, 250 to 164, and the Senate early this morning, 66 to 33.
There is no certainty that the new deadline will be met; a further delay until Oct. 21, a Sunday, is certainly possible, politicians of both parties said, and a postponement until after Election Day, Nov. 6, is conceivable.
The election is a major complicating factor in getting approval for any budget package. Every one of the dozen or so Republican and Democratic Senators facing close elections this fall, from liberal Democrats like Paul Simon of Illinois to conservative Republicans like Jesse Helms of North Carolina, voted against the resolution approved this morning. So did Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, a Democrat who was re-elected last weekend.
 
Bentsen's Proposals
Mr. Bentsen's proposal includes a nine-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, and less onerous cuts in the Medicare program than had been contempltated under a budget compromise rejected by the House last week. His plan would also scrap proposals to limit income tax deductions for those who earn more than $100,000 a year and to impose a new two-cent-a-gallon tax on refined petroleum products.
But Mr. Bentsen retained some of the other tax increases suggested by the Administration officials and top Congressional leaders who negotiated the ill-fated compromise that failed late last week. These include a 10 percent luxury tax on expensive cars, boats, furs and jewelry; increases in excise taxes on cigarettes, beer, wine and spirits and a requirement that state and local government employees pay Social Security taxes.
Hoping to meet objections by Republicans as well as Democrats to deep cuts in the Medicare program, Mr. Bentsen's recommendation would hold increases in monthly premiums and deductibles to a much smaller amount than had been outlined in the agreement reached by White House and Congressional negotiators, and would not require as large an increase in the portion of doctor payments beneficiaries are required to pay out of their own pockets.
 
Massaging the Opposition
At his news conference, the President took an emollient approach toward the Democrats, offering to help them in what he conceded was the difficult task of putting together a package that will achieve $500 billion in deficit reduction over five years while still winning his backing and that of both houses of Congress.
It was a recognition that what the elite group of private negotiators from Congress and the White House failed to accomplish in four months must now be achieved in 10 days, mostly in public.
''The action is in the Congress, but we'll work with them,'' the President said, refraining for the moment from further finger pointing. ''I will do everything in my power to encourage Congress as it struggles to bring forth the most comprehensive and significant deficit-cutting plan ever.''
He defended his two main budget negotiators, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, who antagonized Republicans as well as Democrats on Capitol Hill with what many lawmakers considered outrageously heavy handed tactics.
''When passions get high, there's bound to be a little broken china,'' Mr. Bush said. ''They did an outstanding job.'' But White House officials said that Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman would probably play only secondary roles in the 10 days of bargaining and maneuvering that now lie ahead.
Asked about raising income tax rates for the wealthiest taxpayers, the President replied in language that seemed unequivocal: ''That's on the table. That's been talked about. And if it's proper, if it can be worked in proper balance between the capital gains rate and income tax changes, fine.''
 
Bush Sees No Dents
Mr. Bush was unwilling to accept the contention that his prestige and power have been dented by the budget battle, inisisting that ''the jury's still out.''
Still, his ratings in public opinion surveys have slipped back to where they stood before Iraq invaded Kuwait; his leadership capacities are being questioned after his failure to convince even the usually docile House Republicans to back him on the original budget package, and he has abandoned his no-new-taxes pledge.
''I can understand the frustration,'' Mr. Bush said about the sour mood of the American public. ''I feel it myself at times.''
The President may have suffered little longterm damage so far, as his aides argue, and he will not face re-election for many more months. But he does face major political trouble on three fronts - the Middle East, the budget and the faltering economy - with all three full of uncertainties.
Although he expressed, as usual, a reluctance to analyze his emotions -he said he did not want ''to get stretched out on the couch too far'' - Mr. Bush conceded that he took more satisfaction from coping with international problems like the Persian Gulf crisis than from dealing with difficulties at home.

HEADLINE: AQUINO UNTOPPLED, AT LEAST FOR NOW

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The political scene in the Philippines is a little bit like California's seismic situation: there are regular tremors, and each rumbling provokes new doubts about if and when ''the big one'' will strike.
President Corazon C. Aquino has quelled an army mutiny in the southern island of Mindanao, the seventh uprising in the last four years. But although she claimed victory, the uprising underscores the disaffection and instability that appear to have risen steadily since she came to power in the revolution that ended the rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986.
''Every time there is a coup attempt, eventually people get to asking, why is there a coup attempt in the first place?'' said Felipe B. Miranda, professor of political science at the University of the Philippines. ''This leads to the question: Isn't it the weakness of Government that eventually invites the coup attempt?'' 
 
Poll Shows Decline in Popularity
A survey conducted in late August by Professor Miranda found public opinion evenly divided over President Aquino, with 30 percent satisfied with her performance in office and 30 percent not. The rest declined to answer or did not have an opinion. It was a drop from a popularity of about 70 percent in the beginning of her term.
In many ways, Mrs. Aquino is bearing the brunt of the frustration of a nation struggling to establish democracy after about 15 years of military and dictatorial rule. The repeated uprisings raise further questions not only about the stability of the Government but also about the ability of the nation's democracy to survive until the next elections, which are scheduled for 1992. Mrs. Aquino has said she will not run. Beyond domestic political troubles, the Government faces a floundering economy with debt service and repayments that soak up about 40 percent of the national budget.
More recently, the country has been hobbled by a devastating earthquake, and soaring oil prices and the problems of thousands of Filipino workers who have been displaced in the Middle East have caught the country at one of its more vulnerable moments.
 
Problems Are Aired Now
Some Filipinos say today's problems seem particularly formidable because in the past, many comparable difficulties were covered up and the people were not aware of them.
''Yes, she has problems, but all these problems are coming out because of our democratic system,'' said Lieut. Gen. Eduardo R. Ermita, Undersecretary of National Defense. ''There was no democratic system under Marcos. The problems were there, but the problems weren't coming out.''
Some people say Mrs. Aquino rose to power in 1986 because she had become a powerful symbol by capturing public sympathy after her husband, the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino, was slain returning to the Philippines in 1983.
In contrast with Mr. Marcos, she was a poignant figure of decency. But they add that while people still respect her decency and her suffering, they are grumbling for signs of administrative ability that she never particularly cultivated as the wife of a dissident. [In another threat to the Government, Reuters reported, at least 28 people were killed on Tuesday when Communist guerrillas of the New People's Army battled the army for eight hours on the island of Samar, 280 miles southeast of Manila.] While it is not clear whether the recent military mutiny was intended to overthrow the Government, Mrs. Aquino's ability to crush it as she did six efforts to unseat her may have improved her image for now.
Since a coup attempt last December, the most damaging to her Government, Mrs. Aquino has taken steps to consolidate loyalty and improve management within the military. The Government recently ended an investigation into that uprising, and it appears that Mrs. Aquino is becoming more adept at coup-crisis management. Was It a Coup Attempt? Some say the rebellion in Mindanao was far from a coup attempt, and one professor, Alexander Magno, calls it a ''spectacular local crime.'' Others say the surrender of the leader, Col. Alexander Noble, and the lack of coordination with other rebel leaders suggest that the underground network may not be as strong as some people feared.
Army officials say military rebels have been behind a number of bombings and bank robberies in the recent months, all of which have threatened the Government's stability.
Some political and business leaders say that while Mrs. Aquino may survive these uprisings and signs of instability, they point to real problems that she should address.
''How many times do we have to give this warning before President Aquino listens?'' Senator Ernesto Maceda, the chairman of the Senate Defense Committee, said in a statement. ''The Aquino Government must for once meaningfully and substantially respond to the problems of our people.''
On Friday, Mrs. Aquino announced an economic plan intended to stimulate growth. So far it has not ignited much optimism. Some people suggest the Philippines faces a vicious circle: while economic difficulties compound political instability, each sign of instability also disrupts the confidence of foreign and domestic investors and undermines economic prospects.
Some Filipino business executives also say weak leadership is particularly worrisome here because it invites assaults on the political system.

HEADLINE: Chrysler's Message to Union: Pact Like G.M.'s Is Too Costly

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, plans to tell the United Automobile Workers union on Thursday that the company cannot afford a labor agreement like those negotiated with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.
The union leadership has so far rejected the idea of granting Chrysler, the country's third-largest auto maker, less-expensive contract provisions for its 78,000 blue-collar workers than those at Ford or G.M. But it is not clear how forcefully Chrysler bargainers will press the case or whether the company would risk a strike to reduce its labor costs, which are already the highest in the industry.
Employers often plead poverty during collective bargaining, but Chrysler has an especially difficult task since it has been trying to convince customers, investors and bankers that it is financially sound despite recent weak earnings and sales. The truth, analysts say, is in between. 
 
Missing a Financial Cushion
''Chrysler's balance sheet isn't in bad shape now,'' said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, ''but auto makers are looking at significant cash outflows in the event of a recession. Ford and G.M. have a cushion and are in much better shape to weather that kind of an economy than Chrysler.''
Analysts estimate that Chrysler will post a third-quarter loss of $200 million to $250 million before the month's end. At the same time, the company has been saying it has ''plenty of money'' to weather hard times until an important new mid-size car is introduced in 1992.
Scott Merlis, the automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, estimates that Chrysler's current labor costs of $32 an hour are as much as $2.50 higher than those of the other domestic auto makers. The most important reason is that Chrysler has a higher proportion of retired workers than its competitors, which means higher outlays for pensions.
 
New Mood in the Union
The union gave Mr. Iacocca concessions on salaries and holidays in the early 1980's when Chrysler was close to bankruptcy, but its mood has changed. Stan Marshall, U.A.W. vice president, was quoted today in local newspapers as calling Mr. Iacocca's expected assessment of Chrysler's financial condition ''garbage.''
''It will fall on deaf ears,'' Mr. Marshall was quoted as saying.
Privately union officials acknowledge that Chrysler is in a weakened state. But they are also angry about recent bonuses granted to retain executives and about Mr. Iacocca's own multimillion-dollar compensation package.
Union officials also criticize some acquisitions and other strategic moves that ''aren't consistent with crying poverty,'' said a union official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
''Why is it that the workers always have to make the sacrifices?'' the official said.
The union's customary bargaining stance has been to choose one auto maker as a target, negotiate a contract with it and use that contract as a pattern for those with all auto makers. This strategy is meant to prevent any domestic auto maker from gaining a competitive advantage through tough bargaining on wages and benefits.
 
Little Rancor in Bargaining
In recent years the union has been representing fewer domestic auto workers, as the three American car makers have closed plants and Japanese auto makers have opened plants in this country, some of which are non-union and have lower labor costs.
G.M.'s new contract, which has been ratified, and Ford's contract, which is up for a ratification vote in the next week or so, include provisions that could prove expensive. One provision limits to 36 weeks the amount of time that any worker may be laid off; another mandates a stiff financial penalty for paying overtime instead of hiring new workers. Executives at G.M. and Ford have also agreed to a 3 percent raise in the first year of the three-year contract and 3 percent bonuses in each of the two remaining years.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET AGREEMENT;
Excerpts From the Bush News Conference on the Budget and the Mideast

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Bush's news conference today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Let me just go with an opening statement, and then I'll be glad to respond to questions.
First, on the budget, the committees of Congress now take up the arduous task of implementing the budget resolution that they just passed. We've been pulling and tugging at this framework agreement for nearly five months, and it's been difficult because that whole underlying problem is difficult. And we're trying to reduce the Federal deficit by $500 billion over the next five years - $40 billion of it in the first year. And this would be the largest such cut in history. 
So while it's easy to get caught up in the maneuvers and the countermaneuvers of the legislative process, I want to assure the American people this morning that I will do everything in my power to encourage Congress as it struggles to bring forth the most comprehensive and significant deficit-cutting plan ever.
This morning I outlined several conditions for a budget reconciliation bill. As the committees of Congress begin to fill in the blanks in determining how we raise the revenues and cut the spending, we must be mindful not to let the hard-won goals of the budget resolution dissipate or lose direction.
The budget reconciliation bill, due on Oct. 12, must measure up to the savings Congress has outlined, without smoke and mirrors, with growth-oriented tax incentives, with process reform, with enforceability, with bipartisan support, and with passages of both houses - by both houses of Congress by Oct. 19.
These are the objectives that we fought for since the beginning of the long budget struggle, but they're worthy of our effort. In any undertaking of this size, there is bound to be anguish, and I want to recognize the valiant Federal work force that had to suffer through some uncertainty of this period.
On Saturday morning I said we cannot have business as usual. But the Congress has finally acted and we are back on course and there can be no letup in our attention to detail and our commitment to purpose. We must fulfill the requirements of the budget resolution.
Now, I'd be glad to take some questions.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Confidence on Governing
Q. . . . A week ago you asked Americans to help get a budget passed and they gave you the back of the hand. Then, despite a Government shutdown, Congress still hasn't been able to produce a budget. How can Americans fail to have anything except grave questions about the - your ability and that of Congress to govern?
A. Well, I think there probably are some questions. I don't feel the American people gave the back of the hand to the budget agreement. If you look at the surveys that were carried in the magazines and all of this, they show that, I think, more people wanted the agreement than not. So we've just got to do a better job of getting it through.
But listen, I can understand the frustration. I feel it myself at times. And when you have a Government with one party controlling the Congress, where the action is and where the action will remain now for a while, and then you have a President of a different party, nobody thought it would be easy, and it isn't.
So I think there is some frustration, but I notice that there was strong support for the package. The problem was that you ask in individual categories of the package, 'Oh, no, we don't want this, we don't want that, we don't . . .' - you know, a lot of special interests. But people seem to want the deal.
I think the deal, though not keeping me happy in every way, was a good one and I was proud to join with the Republican and Democratic leaders in supporting that original budget agreement. Now we've got some of the main ingredients of it, broad instruction to these committees that were contained within the original agreement, and let's see if the Congress can get moving and come up with a deal that I can accept. And we'll be working with them. We're not - I'm not up here to assign blame. Yeah, Helen?
 
High Tax Rate for Wealthy
Q. Mr. President, no matter what you say, there was a lot of feeling in the country that the package was not fair. Are you willing to accept a higher tax rate for the wealthy, perhaps in exchange for a capital gains cut, but even so, a higher tax rate?
A. I haven't seen great sentiment for raising people's income tax rates, and I'm not for that. Now, during the budget process - and this was little noted - there was discussion about getting capital gains for straightening out the bubble, which means raising some rates. We were quite open-minded; there was some negotiation.
So I'm not - let me say this, I - that's on the table; that's been talked about. And if it's proper, if it can be worked in proper balance between the capital gains rate and income tax changes, fine. But I don't think it's fruitful here to negotiate the details, or try to.
What we've got to do is get up now with -particularly Ways and Means and Finance -Danny Rostenkowski, Lloyd Bentsen, Bill Archer and Bob Packwood - and discuss with them quietly what we can accept. I want them to know it. But I don't think I can stand here and kind of negotiate or mandate exactly what will happen.
 
Hopes for New Agreement
Q. Mr. President, House Republicans, by the end of last week, were being accused of behaving like Democrats. There seemed to be fairly deep divisions within their ranks. You didn't carry - you and the leaders did not carry a majority of House Republicans on the budget deal. What hope do you now have, and what reason do you have for holding that hope that you can do that the next time on a program that will, in effect, be written by the Democratic Party?
A. Well, I see that - Brit, you only stated -if I could - I don't want to be argumentative, but the Democrats didn't have their troops behind them. They didn't have what they needed to get it through. So it isn't just the Republicans. I think the hope is that people see more clearly now that it isn't easy, and as people go to go with their own alternatives now, they find that they can't get the support. So we may - so I think what we'll end up doing is staying very close to the agreement that I reached with the Republican and Democratic leaders.
The last couple of few days have been like a catharsis. There's been a clearing of the air. People out - here's what I'd do; here's what I'd like to do, and then they find, well, there's no votes to do exactly what they'd like to do. So I think we just have to work the process now and hope that the Congress will come up with a reasonable deal. The action is in the Congress, I keep pointing out, but we'll work with them. Yes?
 
Bitterness Among Republicans
Q. There seemed to be considerable bitter feeling among Republicans towards some members of your team, who felt they had been dealt with in a ham-handed or high-handed way. Has anything been done to patch this up, sir, and have you talked to members about that?
A. Well, I've talked to the leaders, our leaders, Dole and Michel and others, Bill Archer yesterday, over the weekend, Al Simpson and others. But, you know, anytime you have a difficult road like this, there's bound to be griping about it. I have total confidence in our team. I think they did a first-class job, and I don't think we would have ever gotten the agreement out if they hadn't done a first-class job.
So I think that - but also you need a little time to calm things down, cool things off, and let's try to go forward. I think it's my responsibility to say, 'Look, it's not easy; all of us have had to compromise; now let's move the country forward to what really everybody wants, and that is getting these deficits under control.' Yeah?
Q. Mr. President, getting back to the lack of support from Republicans, tomorrow you're going to be campaigning in North Carolina for Senator Jesse Helms, who was one of your opponents on the budget. What is your message to the voters? Vote blindly Republican or vote for legislators who support your policies?
A. If we had more people on fiscal policy like Jesse Helms, and by that I mean control of the Senate, we wouldn't be in this mess. People would have been doing it more the way I want it done. So I can't confine my support to somebody who agrees with me on a deficit deal today or some bill tomorrow. We're talking about the broad approach to saving money. And I think Senator Helms has been very good about trying to contain the growth of Federal spending.
Q. Well if there's no threat of retribution, what is to keep your fellow Republicans on the Hill from defying you with impunity on other issues?
A. Reason.
 
Popularity and Winning Support
Q. Mr. President, going back to Terry's question, you've had unprecedentedly high levels of popularity for a very long period of time. My question is: What do you suppose, sir, that popularity is good for if you can't use it to persuade the American people on an issue you, yourself, described as one that was critical to the country?
A. Well, I'm not - you know - well, I've been the one around here that - you always ask me on these polls, up or down, what do I think? Every Monday there's some new poll by some new combination of a magazine and a television studio. And every week somebody wants me to comment on these, and I've been rather consistent in saying, 'Look, I don't believe in these polls.'
But what it says is we're not doing too bad; like to be doing better. And I think there's pretty strong support. But I guess I learned that I can't do it exactly my way when we get down on something like the deficit. I do think internationally the support is still very, ver a strong.
So when you get into somebody's pocketbook or you get - worrying about a tax or a spending cut that affects someone, I've learned that it's just not going to be done the way I want it, especially if you don't control the Senate or you don't control the House. So I can't worry too much about it. I just have to try to get this process moved forward, and that's what we've done. I've had to compromise, but I think it will come it out all right. Yeah?
 
Price of Supply-Side Economics
Q. If I might - I wonder if you think, though, that you're paying the price now in asking the American people to sacrifice, and having them rebuff it the way it happened -paying the price for all these years in the Reagan-Bush Administration that you sold supply-side economics?
A. No, I don't think so. I think that when you see Democratic votes against the leadership, we're talking about something a little shorter-term here. I think you're looking at something that, when people have analyzed a package, and don't like parts of it, because they're still saying, Hey, we like - we want you to vote for the overall package. So the problem comes from some specific part of the package. That's the way I analyze it. Yeah, John?
 
Domestic Test of Presidency
Q. So you say you've learned that you just can't have things the way you want it on the budget. But earlier this year, you raised the stakes when you said the budget crisis would be the biggest test domestically of your Presidency. So far, have you failed the test, given that fiasco of the --
A. Give me a couple weeks here. I want to see if we can't get this deal through.
Q. Well, do you think --
A. I thought we did pretty well when we got an agreement with the Republican leadership and the House leadership - Democrat and Republican. To me, that's getting something done. Now we couldn't get it through the Congress yet, so we'll try again. So I think the jury's still out on that, John.
Q. Do you suddenly feel politically a bit more vulnerable now? The Democrats smell blood. They're looking to '92 now. George Bush has slipped. What do you think?
A. Well, without referring to the polls, that I don't like to refer to, have them take a look.
 
Problem With No-Tax Pledge
Q. Mr. President, during the campaign, when you took the position that you absolutely, positively would not raise taxes under any circumstance, and then a lot of your fellow Republicans, as you know, were encouraged to follow suit by taking this anti-tax pledge, do you think that that now is part of the reason --
A. Yes.
Q. -- that you're having so much trouble?
A. I think that makes it more difficult for people.
Q. Do you regret that you took that position?
A. No, because what I do is take a look at -at the situation at the time, see the changed economics, and say I've got to - got to, you know, go forward here.
 
Reaction to Incident in Israel
Q. Mr. President, yesterday Israeli forces used live ammunition to put down a demonstration in Israel, killing 19 Palestinians. Today, Saddam Hussein is using that incident in an attempt to rally Arab support against Israel and especially against the United States in the region. Do you think this incident could create a crack in the alliance against Iraq? And what's your reaction to the incident?
A. Well, I don't think it could do that, but look, let me just express my strong feelings about this. First my sorrow at this tragedy. It is particularly saddening, given the sanctity of the holy places and observances there, that violence shattered all of this.
And I want to echo what Jim Baker said earlier, that Israeli security forces need to be better prepared for such situations, need to act with greater restraint, particularly when it comes to the use of deadly force. And at this point what is needed most of all is calm on all sides.
Let me - I don't think I need to say this -but let me just state that we want to see the longstanding policy of maintaining open access to the holy places preserved, tempered only by mutual respect for people of other faiths. And so I am very, very saddened by this needless loss of life, and I would call on all for restraint. The action will shift to the United Nations now.
To your other part of the question, Jim, there's no relationship here. Saddam Hussein is trying to, from the very beginning, justify the illegal invasion of Kuwait by trying to tie it into the Palestine question. And that is not working. The Arab world is united - almost united - - against him.
And I don't think if he tries now to use this unfortunate incident to link the two questions, I don't think that will be successful. And certainly, I will be doing what I can to see that it is not successful.
Having said that, I hope nobody questions our interest in seeing a solution to the Palestine question, to the implementation of the Security Council resolutions. And that's what Jim Baker has been working so hard on for such a long time.
But let's separate out this violence and say, we deplore it, and it must not happen, and regret it - the loss of life for everybody.
Q. Also - a follow, please. Saddam Hussein also indicated today that the Iraqis have a new sort of missile that can reach into Israel and reach the U.S. troops. And he's threatening to use that force.
A. I noticed that and I notice he's getting a little more bellicose. Once in a while you see a conciliatory statement, and then you hear a lot of heightened rhetoric about what he is going to do and what he's not going to do.
Now I'm satisfied that we can defend our interests now. And I am satisfied that - that these threats of his are counterproductive in terms of solving anypeaceful resolution of the question. They don't help a thing, they just polarize.
So, you don't want to overreact to it. I keep reading statements like this, ever since this illegal annexation, illegal aggression took place. . . . We watch it very carefully, and it's pretty hard to detect a pattern.
Now, there's a theme, and that is trying to link the Palestine question into his - kind of giving justification for what he did against Kuwait, and yet the logic falls totally flat. Yes, Frank?
Q. Mr. President, on that subject, you said the action now shifts on this one to the United Nations. Having just been to the United Nations and talked about its increased relevance and role, how far are you prepared to go as far as the United States is concerned in meeting some of the Arab efforts to partially condemn Israel's action and pass a resolution that --
A. Well, I think it all depends what the resolution is, and so that's just starting up there now and we're not sure exactly what direction it all will take. So I'd want to stop short of saying exactly what I could - you know, what the U.S. Government could support or what it couldn't support.
 
Concern on Dismantling Kuwait
Q. If I may, sir, on a related topic, when the Emir of Kuwait was here, you expressed grave concern about the dismantling of Kuwait.
A. Yes, I did.
Q. Your advisers said that that could affect the timetable for permitting sanctions to work. What is your feeling on that now? Is the dismantling --
A. I thought General Scowcroft put it very well after the Emir left here. And I am very much concerned, not just about this physical dismantling, but of the brutality that has now been written on by Amnesty International confirming some of the tales told us by the Emir, of brutality and - - oh, it's just unbelieveable, some of the things at least he reflected. I mean, people on a dialysis machine cut off, the machine sent to Baghdad; people in - babies in incubators heaved out of the incubators and the incubators themselves sent to Baghdad.
Now, I don't know how many of these tales can be authenticated, but I do know that when the Emir was here he was speaking from the heart. And after that came the Amnesty International, who were debriefing many of the people at the border. And it's sickening.
And so I - if your question was how long, I can't give you an answer in days or months, but it is a matter that - it's a new equation in the last three weeks, the systematic dismantling of Kuwait that concerns us enormously. And I think the more people understand it, the more Saddam Hussein will be condemned.
But I have to stop short of telling you what that - where that leads me to, in terms of recommending action by the allied forces there.
Q. It does sound like your patience is wearing thin on the sanctions.
A. It's wearing very thin on that account, yes.
 
Foreign and Domestic Disparity
Q. Mr. President, a couple of minutes ago, you said that public opinion seemed to support your handling of foreign affairs better than domestic affairs. Why do you think that you're so much more comfortable with and better at foreign matters than domestic? To some people, it seems like almost two Presidents.
A. Well, I've read that sophisticated analysis, and I'm troubled, because I don't the - I don't really know the answer to it. Perhaps it has to do with the fact that in one, I think the Vandenburg theory applies. People really basically want to support the President on foreign affairs, and partisanshp does, in a sense, stop at the water's edge. Whereas on domestic policy, here I am with Democratic majorities in the Senate and Democratic majorities in the House, having to try to persuade them to do what I think is best. And it's complicated.
I mean, I think that's part of it, and - well, I don't want to get stretched out on the couch too far in terms of analysis now - but, you know, when you get a problem with the complexities that one - that the Middle East has now, and the Gulf has now, I enjoy trying to keep this - put the coalition together and keep it together and work towards what I think is a proper end, seeing that this aggression doesn't succeed.
Q. It doesn't sound like you have as much fun as it as you do with the other.
A. That's about right, yeah.
 
Erosion of Bush Leadership
Q. Mr. President, you pulled out all the stops on this budget deal, and it just flopped. Are you concerned, sir, that your leadership on other domestic issues now will be eroded since you didn't carry even half your own party in the House? You talk about clean air, you talk about crime. Are you worried that you're just going to - the honeymoon is entirely over?
A. No, because I want to talk to Speaker Foley about this, and Leader Mitchell, because they pulled out all the stops and they didn't get the votes they needed. And so I don't think they feel that they can't conduct their business in the House or in the Senate, and certainly I don't feel that I can't conduct my business here. So I don't think there is erosion. In fact, you saw the House side come together in terms of a veto, - right quick [snapping fingers] - like that. And I think that - that's - you know - there's a certain maturity there, and we go on to the next event. . . . So I don't - no, I don't worry about that.
 
A. Absolutely not.
 
Possibility of Another Veto
Q. As you pointed out, the hard work, a lot of the hard work really remains ahead. Are you determined, as you were before, to keep Congress to the October 19th deadline? Will you veto another C.R. if they haven't finished the job by then?
A. You know, I think the fact that I vetoed that last one resulted in the new budget resolution, and a continuing resolution that we could accept because the budget resolution was - passed both houses. I'm absolutely convinced that if I had not vetoed that C.R., and that had not been sustained, you would have had - everybody'd have gone home, they'd all have marched in the parades for Columbus Day, holding the signs up, and started negotiating today. So once in a while the President, using the veto, can indeed move the process forward. And that's exactly what happened, and I would do it again if I felt that it would constructively lead to getting the problem solved.
Now, they asked me the other day not to veto this continuing resolution - the Democratic leaders did. And I said, Look, I hope you don't think I've been under any false colors with you people, because I've made very clear that I'm going to veto it. And they agreed with that, but they just thought I made the wrong call on it. I don't think so. I think I made the right call, and I think there's one of the times when a President's veto can discipline the process. And so I reserve the option to use whatever constitutional weapons I have to move things forward.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET AGREEMENT;
Moynihan Revives Call to Cut Deductions for Social Security

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan tried today to inject new life into his proposal for a cut in Social Security payroll deductions, but for much of the day the New York Democrat was a solitary figure as he lectured a chamber devoid of fellow senators. Even Mr. Moynihan admitted that his cause seemed less than compelling to his colleagues.
''Is there a reason there are no senators on the floor wishing to speak?'' he said. ''Is it because we don't want to face the fact that a very small segment of the American people saw their incomes double in recent years, while most of Americans saw their incomes fall?'' 
Almost a year after unveiling his first proposal for huge cuts in Social Security deductions, Mr. Moynihan tried again to stir debate on a bill that would save wage earners an estimated $160 billion in the next six years.
But while privately he has broad support from his Senate colleagues, his proposal could not come at a worse time for them. Consumed with trying to put together a budget package, senators seemed today to want to avoid intense debate on legislation that they support in principle, but which would amount to a large-scale tax cut and a huge addition to the deficit.
 
The Basic Problem
''This is an uncomfortable position for a lot of people who want to provide tax relief to average people who deserve it, but don't want to have to raise other taxes to make up the difference,'' said Robert J. Shapiro, vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a research organization whose orientation is considered moderate to liberal.
Mr. Moynihan's proposal did not find its way into the budget agreement, but at times it played a key role in the debate. Democrats, in particular, had on their wish list proposals that would have placed much more of the burden for paying for Social Security on the wealthy.
While Mr. Moynihan wants the Senate to vote on his proposal, it is uncertain what will happen. In an effort to scuttle the bill, some Republicans plan to propose amendments, such as a capital gains tax cut, that would make it politically unacceptable.
Some Democrats feel that since the bill deals with taxes, it would not go beyond the Senate, since the House must initiate all tax bills. Thus, should the Senate should go ahead and approve the measure, it would amount to no more than a symbolic vote.
 
A Debate, at Least
Mr. Moynihan admitted tonight that he was not sure if he had the votes to pass the legislation.''
But whatever the outcome, the New York Senator is credited with drawing attention to the fact that of all Federal taxes, Social Security is perhaps the most regressive, placing a far greater tax burden on the middle- to low-income wage earners, than on the weathly. He created a major policy debate late last year by calling for a large cut in Social Security taxes and creating a pay-as-you-go system.
Last year, he proposed a cut over two years in Social Security taxes and chided policy makers for using the huge surpluses of the Social Security trust fund to pay general debts of the Federal Government and mask the size of the deficit.
While the budget agreement now going through Congress takes the annual surplus of the Social Security trust fund out of the deficit calculation, it is little more than form. The revenues are still used to pay for general obligations of the Treasury, a practice Mr. Moynihan decried today as ''embezzlement.''
''What we are doing is taking money out of wages that have not changed in 30 years to pay bondholders in Europe and Asia,'' he said. Mr. Moynihan produced charts and graphs that showed that when inflation is taken into account, the average weekly income for Americans had not changed over the past 30 years.
 
A Change in Approach
Unlike his original plan, which called for a large two-year cut in the rate of Social Security taxes, his latest proposal calls for phasing in the cuts over six years.
The Senator's proposal would begin cutting the Social Security payroll taxes beginning Jan. 1, and by the end of 1996 it would reduce the tax rate by almost 20 percent.
From a rate in 1990 of 6.2 percent, Social Security deductions would drop to 6.06 percent in 1991, to 5.9 percent in 1992, 5.7 percent in 1993, 5.5 percent in 1994, 5.3 percent in 1995 and 5.1 percent in 1996.

LENGTH: 334 words

HEADLINE: Kenya Undermined, at the Top

 BODY:
Kenya's highhanded President, Daniel arap Moi, appears to have learned little from the collapse of one-party absolutism in Eastern Europe or from the pro-democracy ferment elsewhere in Africa. After threatening to crush opponents ''like rats,'' he arrested two former Cabinet ministers who dared call for a multiparty system.
Though his slogan is ''Peace, Love and Unity,'' his critics die mysteriously or vanish into so-called psychiatric prisons. And now, in banning the Nairobi Law Monthly, he has made it a crime to advocate respect for the law. 
''They will all be picked up and kept aside to cool down,'' Mr. Moi says of his critics. ''If they want chaos, Moi is not a coward.'' The President's way with dissenters threatens the stability he seeks to preserve. Washington has warned him, perhaps too gently, that U.S. aid and favor are at risk if he ignores the connection between economic progress and respect for political and human rights.
When Mr. Moi assumed power in 1978, Kenya was deservedly praised for its stability, its outspoken press and independent judiciary. Since then he has imposed single-party rule, abolished secret voting and given himself the right to dismiss judges and order prolonged detention without trial. Press criticism has been stifled in a campaign that climaxed with the banning of the Law Monthly and the detention of its editor, Gitobu Imanyara, on charges of sedition.
Mr. Moi's pretext has been the need to keep order and curb tribal rivalries. It is true that Kenya has been spared the bloody turbulence and harsher tyranny of Ethiopia, Uganda and the Sudan. But by defining dissent as treason, and by eroding belief in the law, Mr. Moi imperils the tolerance that has made Kenya different. This is the tactful message of the U.S. Ambassador and conservative well-wisher, Smith Hempstone. If Mr. Moi persists in his course, the deluge is all too likely to follow. This is a danger that should concern Congress when it next considers U.S. aid to Kenya.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

LENGTH: 300 words

HEADLINE: No Taxes Needed in Savings and Loan Bailout;
Lending and Spending

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Inflation Isn't Our Biggest Problem'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 25), Roger C. Altman of the Blackstone Group argues that the Federal deficit must be reduced if a serious recession is to be avoided. ''Never before,'' he declares, ''have we headed into a recession with a budget deficit as high as 5 percent of gross national product.'' The assertion is incorrect.
The Federal budget deficit in 1944 was 27.3 percent of G.N.P.; in 1945, it was 21.9 percent of G.N.P. According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, the United States entered a recession in February 1945, reaching bottom in October. That the deficits were incurred during a war is unimportant in economic terms.
If Mr. Altman is looking for analogies, he might recall that the national debt was greatly reduced in the 1920's (from $24 billion to $16 billion). Yet this close attention to Government spending and economic principles did not head off the Great Depression.
Mr. Altman is correct on one major point, but he overlooks its implications. Corporate debt is indeed dangerously high, with companies using as much as 50 percent of current earnings to meet interest payments.
These problems are traceable to huge borrowing for unproductive mergers and buyouts that enrich manipulators, while hurting everyone else, and to the deregulation of interest rates on savings deposits, which has driven up the costs of borrowing (including Government borrowing), not to mention the costs of the savings and loan bailout.
Corporations are obviously borrowing and spending too much, while the Government is spending much too little.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Los Angeles, Sept. 26, 1990
 The writer retired as a professor of the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public and International Affairs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: No Taxes Needed in Savings and Loan Bailout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Who Should Pay for the S.& L. Bailout?'' by Joseph P. Kennedy 2d (Op-Ed, Sept. 21) offers a popular nostrum: a surtax on the rich; not one cent from the poor. This scheme is, unfortunately, flawed, reflecting a widespread misunderstanding of the economics of the savings and loan fiasco. Policy prescriptions such as Mr. Kennedy's, stemming from this misunderstanding, threaten serious damage to the economy. 
The issue is not that of achieving a more equitable tax system, making the rich pay their fare share. Some of the recommendations Mr. Kennedy makes, such as closing the capital gains tax loophole on death, do make good sense.
The basic point, though, is that no one should pay higher taxes now to finance the savings and loan bailout. Government generally should raise taxes to finance increased expenditures. If we are to spend $25 billion more a year in connection with military operations in and around the Persian Gulf, taxes may have to be raised for that. If the Government finds itself paying out more over the long run in benefit payments of one kind or another or in interest on its debt, it may be appropriate to raise taxes for that. But there is no reason to raise taxes to keep depositors from losing their money in savings and loan institutions and thus to maintain the money supply. And that is exactly what is involved in the bailout. Imagine that we just learned $100 billion of currency was being destroyed in a fire; would we tax the American people $100 billion to secure funds to reimburse the losers? Of course not! We would simply print new money to replace the old.
Would printing new money be inflationary? Again, of course not! We would not be adding to the money supply, but rather keeping the money supply constant, that is, preventing it from going down by as much currency as had been destroyed.
All this is not to say that there may not have been real losses as a result of bad loans, high living and outright fraud in the savings and loans. These losses were the houses, office buildings or consumption that might have been undertaken if the savings and loan financing had been directed elsewhere. By the way, it is, unfortunately, not quite clear that if bad investments had not been made in Houston, there would have been more good investments in New York and Chicago. We might just have had less total investment. But raising taxes now will do nothing to remedy all that. It will only slow the economy.
And particularly at this point, with most analysts seeing us already teetering on the brink of recession, any significant increase in our total tax bill - or other tightening of fiscal policy - would very likely push us over that brink.
If Mr. Kennedy can find a way to tax the rich more and the poor, or any of the rest of us, less without injuring the economy, fine! But raising the level of taxes to prevent savings and loan deposits from being wiped out is the wrong way to go.
 
ROBERT EISNER
Evanston, Ill., Sept. 20, 1990
 The writer is the William R. Kenan Professor of Economics at Northwestern University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Paris Subway, Like New York's, Had to Turn Itself Around

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In regard to ''Underground Ideas'' (editorial, Sept. 19), about an American who likes the Paris Metro and wonders why it can't be duplicated in the New York City subway system, I would like to offer some observations of a Frenchman in New York with experience in mass transit.
Fifteen years ago, the Paris Metro suffered from the same problem of declining ridership that is plaguing New York City, and crime was a main issue. The Paris Mass Transit Authority started a campaign to reverse the decline, including complete renovation of stations, improvement in lighting, and a comprehensive closed-television and alarm system to monitor all areas in the subway, augmented by police patrols. The result was a measurable increase in the safety of subway platforms.
The Paris Metro also pioneered automatic fare collection with those little yellow tickets that have become a symbol of such fare systems. Convenient ticket-vending machines that are placed throughout the subway system allow passengers to buy tickets for single rides, daily, weekly or monthly service - often at a deep discount against the cost of multiple single rides. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's Trans-Hudson, or PATH, system is in the process of installing similar vending machines.
This aspect of convenience and economy has impressed regular Paris Metro riders and tourists alike, and I believe it would work in the New York subways as well.
In recent years, New York City has made great progress in improving its subway trains. The challenge for this world capital now is to improve security and convenience at the subway stations so that even its most sophisticated foreign visitors will be impressed.
 
ERIC BERNARDINI
New York, Sept. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: Dinkins Was Told of Risk in Teacher Pact

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
The 5.5 percent raise that Mayor David N. Dinkins gave New York City's teachers came over the fierce objections of top city budget officials, who warned it might have serious consequences for the city's fiscal health, interviews with officials who took part in the negotiations reveal.
The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, argued that the pay increase should be held to 4 percent, just below the cost-of-living spiral and a figure that Mr. Michael thought would not hobble the city in its negotiations with other municipal unions. He was backed by Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who was sanitation commissioner in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch.
But Eric J. Schmertz, the city's Commissioner of Labor Relations and a former dean of the Hofstra University Law School, argued that the money for a 5.5 percent increase was available in state and pension sources outside the city's budget. With Mr. Dinkins's approval, he opened the city's accounts to the teachers' union and the Board of Education to show that the city was not hiding any funds that might be used for pay increases. 
Some negotiators for the city and the Board of Education think that strategy backfired. The union identified extra funds and strengthened its case for a higher increase. Ultimately Mr. Schmertz prevailed with Mr. Dinkins, and the Mayor made the 5.5 percent offer on Sept. 30. Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary, acknowledged that there was a ''vigorous debate'' on the raise. He said Mr. Dinkins had sided with Mr. Schmertz's figure because he felt it would recognize the teachers contributions while allowing the city to ''maintain its fiscal balance.''
 
Split in City Ranks Apparent
The division in the city's negotiating ranks was so open that it became evident to negotiators for the other side. Technically the other side was the United Federation of Teachers, but in this case it sometimes included the Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, and his aides. Mr. Fernandez supported higher salaries to stop a drain of teachers to the suburbs.
Accounts of the negotiations, gathered from interviews with officials of the city, the board and the teachers' union, suggest that the union may have exploited the discord to achieve a figure that some fiscal monitors have challenged as an untimely extravagance.
''The city boxed itself in by being totally honest on how you would finance it,'' said one negotiator. ''The city didn't have a strategy, and they allowed events to overtake them.''
The negotiator, who supported the 5.5 percent increase, said he was nevertheless surprised by the successful outcome and astonished that Mr. Schmertz did not fight more tenaciously for a lower figure.
Officials of the teachers' union, however, praised Mr. Schmertz's ability to bring the sides together.
The 64-year-old Commissioner, a former arbitrator whose decisions in city disputes often angered Mayor Koch, said only that Mr. Michael ''argued his position, and I argued mine.''
 
Pact Defended as 'Prudent'
He said he had taken the position that ''a total package of 5.5 percent was a fair and reasonable and prudent settlement for the teachers, particularly because only 1.5 percent of the package came from the city budget.''
''This is the cheapest contract ever negotiated by the city for any group of employees,'' he said.
Mr. Michael, a former executive director of the New York State Financial Control Board, said he did not want to reveal any of the city's ''internal discussions.'' But he acknowledged that there was ''a lot of debate.''
''I think we worked together, and we came up with a settlement that we all signed off on,'' he said.
The city had always budgeted a wage increase of 1.5 percent for all its unions, or about $62 million for its teachers. It also knew that it could find 2.5 percent more - or $104 million - by recalculating the earnings of the teachers' pension fund to diminish the city's contributions. Any changes in the pension assumptions must be approved by the State Legislature, however.
 
Board Figures Disputed
The 4 percent was all Mr. Michael felt was available. The Board of Education felt there was more. It had earmarked state aid to offset inflation for the coming year, and of that aid, its officials believed $70 million could be used for increasing teacher salaries.
But city officials interviewed said that Mr. Michael, Deputy Mayor Steisel and others felt that the extra money was illusory. If past experience held true, the city officials felt, the city would be asked to cover board overruns in expenditures before the year was out.
''The board has traditionally gone out on many limbs, and then they asked the city to write the check,'' said one city official who took part in the negotiations. ''Why should this year be any different?''
''The Board of Education talked out of both sides of its mouth,'' he said. ''They screamed about layoffs, and then they squirreled this state money away.''
 
Wrong Signal Feared
The officials were also concerned about the signal a larger increase would send to other unions, as well as to the potential buyers of city bonds and others who base their decisions on the city's fiscal prudence.
''We could have stayed with 4 percent,'' the city official said. ''That would have been a signal of real austerity, yet it would have been a commitment that the teachers needed to receive some funds.''
Mr. Schmertz, who was particularly worried about the impact of a strike, did not agree.
''The budget department does not make labor policy about precedents for other labor contracts,'' he said.
While the teachers' union has a history of not working without a contract, Mr. Michael and Mr. Steisel believed that the city should have held to 4 percent.
Sandra Feldman, the president of the teachers' union and one of the earliest and strongest supporters of the Dinkins mayoral campaign, wanted 8 percent, negotiators said, and she did not trust Mr. Michael's figures. She felt there was more flexibility in the city budget than officials were admitting - in such traditional caches as the allocations for lawsuit settlements, for example.
 
Pitch for 6 to 6.5 Percent
Her aides felt they could identify enough money to increase teacher salaries by an additional 1 percent. That would have meant a total increase of 6 to 6.5 percent.
''We believe strongly - and we looked at the budget and the numbers, and we care about the city - that the money to pay for the settlement is there,'' Ms. Feldman said in an interview.
Mr. Michael rejected her figures, according to some officials who took part in the negotiations. But, they said, she got a sympathetic ear from Mr. Schmertz.
Mr. Schmertz denies that he ever moved beyond 5.5 percent.
As the deadline neared and as the negotiations moved to Gracie Mansion, Mr. Schmertz argued that the money was available in the three-part package he had outlined. Mr. Michael protested, in the words of one negotiator, that ''everything available for the teachers was bad precedent for everybody else.''
 
In-Fighting 'Assumed'
''They never argued in front of us,'' said one negotiator. ''But we knew they were fighting because they spent all those hours with each other. What were they talking about? We assumed they were split.''
Late on Sept. 30, Mr. Dinkins sided with Mr. Schmertz, pleased that the increase would not stretch the city's budgeted share beyond the original amount of 1.5 percent set aside for all unions. He made his 5.5 percent offer to the teachers, and Ms. Feldman, feeling she had got less than she wished but enough to please her membership, accepted.
Mr. Schmertz said the decision to offer 5.5 percent was the Mayor's. ''It's not unusual for advisers to have a disagreement, but the basic decision that was made in that situation was made by the one who should be making it -namely, the Mayor,'' he said.
''I believe our approach should be different from what it was in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch,'' he said. ''The Koch administration's approach was one of disrespect for unions. We wanted an approach of cooperativeness and problem-solving together. The teacher contract was consistent with that philosophy.''

Mr. Schmertz prevailed and a 5.5 percent raise was offered. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times; Neal Boenzi/The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: U.S. Sports Prominent on Japanese Shopping Lists

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI

 BODY:
From baseball to auto racing to golf, the games Americans play and watch have become the focus of a recent wave of Japanese buying interest in the United States. The buying activity appears to be part of an effort by the Japanese to expand their financial interest here to include their passion for American sports and leisure.
In recent months, Japanese investors, or their American subsidiaries, have acquired the Pebble Beach Golf Club; the 1989 horse of the year and Kentucky Derby winner, Sunday Silence, and one of the best-run minor league baseball franchises, the Birmingham Barons.
The most dramatic Japanese attempt was probably an aborted deal to buy the Dallas Cowboys, an icon of pro football in this country. The most symbolic attempt might be the interest they recently showed in acquiring part ownership of the New York Yankees. 
 
Having Fun With Money
''This is just the beginning,'' said a Japanese-born economist, Yoshi Tsurumi, professor of international business at Baruch College of the City University. ''Having an ownership gives a company not only an inside view of how a team works, but what's happening in America.''
This trend is symbolic, Japanese executives and observers say, of the rush to have fun with the money the Japanese have worked so diligently to earn.
''We believe in further growth of leisure and sports,'' said Shiro Yasuno, president of Suntory International Corporation, owners of the Birmingham Barons and the New York-based arm of Japan's largest privately held company. ''The Japanese have become rich. Everyone says Japanese work too hard and should take vacations.''
Yuji Minami, the vice president of Dentsu Incorporated, the New York arm of the world's largest advertising agency, added: ''Until the end of the 1970's, Japanese watched only Japanese play against other Japanese or against foreigners. But now they enjoy watching good games: National Football League teams, National Basketball Association.''
 
Concerned About Image
This year, an N.F.L. game of the week is being shown in Japan, and two N.B.A. teams, Phoenix and Utah, will open their seasons in Tokyo with two games Nov. 2-3. American baseball has been popular in Japan for three-quarters of a century, and Japanese leagues have grown since the end of World War II.
But the Japanese are greatly concerned about how their acquisitions will affect their image. Japanese buyers and American sellers are wary of offending an American public that has become sensitive to a burgeoning number of Japanese investors, who now trail only the British as foreigners with a financial investment in the United States.
That is why, a former official of the Dallas Cowboys disclosed, Japanese do not own the team. Jim Francis, a banker and partner of Bum Bright, the club's former owner, said that two years ago the Japanese conglomerate the Seibu Saison Group, whose American holdings include Inter-Continental Hotels, had studied the Cowboys and American football.
 
Fear of Public Backlash
''We had a lot of interest from Seibu,'' Francis said. ''First they sent a lawyer from Honolulu. Then two people came from Japan. They had a verbal offer on the table.''
That was late in 1988, when Bright's financial empire, which included a savings and loan institution, was toppling. But even though he needed cash, the deal was aborted. The Cowboys had become known as ''America's Team,'' and despite their poor performance in recent seasons they remain a powerful symbol of American sports and are as Texas as the Alamo and the 10-gallon hat.
''The Japanese were very worried about a public backlash, and very frankly so was I,'' Francis said.
Eventually, the club was sold last year to Jerry Jones, an American oilman. But it remains obvious to Francis why the Japanese had expressed interest in the Dallas team and not another football franchise.
''They wanted a crown-jewel N.F.L. franchise,'' he said. ''What ran through my mind was what the N.F.L. would say about it, what the country would say about it.''
 
Diversified Investments
Although Japanese investment is most visible in their purchases of traditional American sports entities like Pebble Beach, their involvement also includes land investment, the payment of rights fees and the purchasing of copyrights. Their involvement includes:
* Holding an $80 million stake in Gulfstream and Calder parks outside of Miami. The owner contends the Japanese are not his partners, but a rival insists the deal gives the Japanese control of the race track.
* Purchasing an event on the Virginia Slims tennis tour - the Dallas tournament - and transplanting it to Tokyo.
* Purchasing the right to the ''Indy'' name from the Indianapolis Speedway with plans to run a ''Japan Indy'' at a new track outside Tokyo. The track can accommodate 200,000 spectators.
The Japanese are also taking a stronger interest in areas of international competition they have previously shunned. They are planning their first challenge in the America's Cup yachting competition, to be sailed in 1993. Not just one boat, but two, are being built by competing syndicates, each boat costing about $20 million.
 
'Business Is Business'
In the recent turmoil involving the Yankees and their embattled owner, George Steinbrenner, two limited partners have attempted to unload their 9.6 percent share of the club. The broker says he is looking to Japanese investors. If they buy in, they would own a share of America's most valuable, and visible, sports franchise, worth a minimum of $250 million. Some owners put the value at more than $400 million. To Arthur B. Hancock 3d, this is not a happy trend. He was the principal owner of Sunday Silence, who fetched more than $8 million and is going to the island of Hokkaido for breeding. Hancock's roots are deep in the blue grass of Kentucky, and he contends that Government regulations have stifled initiative in this country.
''It breaks my heart to have to sell the horse,'' said Hancock, whose partners included the trainer Charlie Whittingham. ''But Charlie said we'd be fools not to take the offer. I've got six children. Business is business.''
 
Learning Baseball
Earlier this year, Art Clarkson, who bought the Birmingham Barons for $150,000 in 1980, sold them to Suntory for a reported $3.6 million.
''I was comfortable selling to them,'' Clarkson said. ''I knew they'd be responsible to the community.''
The new president of the club is Marty Kuehnert, who spent most of the past 20 years living in Japan as a broadcaster, writer and restaurateur before joining Suntory. He described the company's interest as ''a tremendous involvement in sports'' and said it had sent two men from Japan to learn stadium management.
Yasuno, the Suntory executive, said the main purpose of buying the Barons was ''to learn the baseball business, and this is where it started.''
''We don't have any plans now for further teams, but if there's a chance to buy a team in Japan, we will look into it,'' Yasuno said. ''We have no intention to buy a Major League Baseball team. Maybe Triple-A.''
 
Crowded Courses in Japan
Suntory remains sensitive about its involvement in the American pastime. When Kuehnert was asked by The New York Times to allow a photographer to take pictures of the two Japanese working with the team, he declined unless he could be guaranteed a ''positive'' article. The Times refused. Tom Oliver, the president of Pebble Beach Company, said that he had not encountered widespread anti-Japanese sentiment since the sale of the golf club. The 5,300-acre resort on the Monterey Peninsula was reportedly sold for $800 million.
''Some people had xenophobic sentiments - 'How can you sell to Japanese?' - but of course there's no answer to them,'' he said.
Affluent Japanese already travel to Hawaii and California to play golf rather than play on their own crowded courses, where a round of golf routinely costs $200 and club memberships go for as much as $1 million. Would Japanese ownership of Pebble Beach increase the flow of golfers to California?
''It's too early to tell,'' Oliver said, ''but they like it for its tradition and what it's done for the game.''
 
Importing Sports
Japanese are also bringing American-style sports to their own country. Auto racing, for example, has become a passion. So Japanese interests have bought the ''Indy'' name to create a track there, and are considering creating a duplicate of the Indianapolis track's 2.5-mile course.
Another American event came to Japan recently: a tournament on the Virginia Slims tennis tour. Each stop on the tour is independently owned, so Dallas interests were able to sell their event to Dentsu of Japan.
''Tennis has become a status symbol in Japan since Prince Akihito met Princess Michiko at a tennis match in 1960,'' Minami said.
America's games have been a longtime attraction for the Japanese. ''The young people are interested in United States sports,'' Yasuno said. Minami, the Dentsu executive, recalled: ''After World War II, Japan was ruled by the U.S.A., and we always tried to catch up.'' And what's next? ''We went recently to the head office of the World Wrestling Federation in Connecticut,'' Minami said. ''Sooner or later, we'll get interested in that.''
