HEADLINE: Frozen Pizzas To Feed a Nation Of Homebodies

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
BELT-tightening and pizza-eating go hand in hand. Not that pizza is diet food - although it can be - but it is budget food. For the manufacturers of frozen pizzas, hard times can mean increased sales.
''With a downturn in the economy, this is a great time for frozen pizza,'' said Eugene Welka, president of the National Frozen Pizza Institute, a trade group. Mr. Welka is also president of McCain Ellio's, a major brand sold in the East.
For two years the frozen-pizza industry has accounted for more than $1 billion in sales, growing at a rate of about 7 percent a year. But it is dwarfed by the $25 billion restaurant and delivered-pizza market, which has been posting increases of 10 to 12 percent a year, in part because of expanding chains like Pizza Hut and Domino's. 
''Adults preferred home-delivered pizza to frozen and this part of the industry is driving consumption,'' Mr. Welka added. ''But we'll be seeing changes. In this economic climate, mealtime consumption of frozen pizza is bound to go up because of the price benefit. No other food delivers this much taste and nutritional value for the money.''
The average price of frozen pizza is $2.71 a pound; home-delivered pizza is at least triple that amount.
No matter how you slice it, pizza has become a favorite American food. On the average, Americans now eat a pizza every six weeks, as against one every eight weeks five years ago, according to Pizza Today, a publication of the National Association of Pizza Operators, a restaurant trade group.
The city with the highest per capita consumption is Milwaukee, Mr. Welka said. But in terms of total sales of frozen pizzas, Chicago is No. 1, with about $69 million annually, with New York a close second at $57 million. Regionally, frozen pizza sales are highest in the Southeast.
Pizza, which many references say was first served in America in 1905, at Lombardi's on Spring Street in New York, has been available in supermarket freezers for more than 25 years. Now the freezers are bulging with a proliferation of styles: pizza with something for everyone, for families with children in particular, but also for dieters and people with sophisticated tastes. In a sampling of 20 brands of frozen pizzas, this writer rated half of them satisfactory or better in texture and flavor.
The average supermarket carries at least a dozen different kinds of frozen pizza. The most popular, nationally, are made with a thin crust (67 percent) and topped with a ''deluxe'' combination, sausages and peppers (33 percent). Pepperoni is the next most popular topping (24 percent), followed by cheese (20 percent) and sausage (17 percent), according to SAMI, a market research company based in Chicago.
But in the East, plain cheese is the favorite topping, accounting for more than 60 percent of the sales. Easterners are more likely to add their own toppings, the manufacturers say. The rest of the country insists on sausage.
Children have a great deal to do with the growth in sales. In a Gallup survey conducted by telephone among 258 parents with children under 13 in December 1989, 82 percent named pizza as their children's favorite food. Chicken nuggets were a distant second with 51 percent.
A study conducted in the summer of 1989 by the American Frozen Food Institute in Washington reported that 62 percent of American children are preparing at least one meal a week for themselves. The researchers, conducting interviews by mail with 800 working women with children under 13, reported that more than half the children said they consider pizza their favorite frozen food to prepare.
''Of all the products Stouffer's makes, pizza is at the top of the list among favorites for children,'' said Roz O'Hearn, public-affairs manager for Stouffer's, one of the leading brands of frozen pizza.
Child-sized pizzas in single servings, like those of McCain Ellio's and Tony's, can be popped into toaster ovens or microwave ovens and are convenient for snacks and often dinner, especially for households with working parents whose children may have to fend for themselves after school. ''My children eat a lot of frozen pizza; it's something they can get to easily and prepare by themselves without a problem,'' said Claudia McAdam of Littleton, Colo., in response to the American Frozen Food Institute survey. She is a writer who has boys age 7 and 10.
Ms. O'Hearn of Stouffer's said parents often keep single-serving Lean Cuisine pizzas in the freezer as a convenience for baby sitters. Selina Guber, president of Children's Market Research in New York, said, ''Pizza becomes almost a mainstay in the diet as kids get older.''
One advantage of pizza is that it is nutritious. A serving of the average frozen pizza is 15 percent protein (about 15 grams), 58 percent carbohydrates and 27 percent fat, and contains a number of vitamins and minerals including calcium, according to the pizza institute. It has about 320 calories. Pizza has become one of the most widely served foods in school lunch programs, said Mr. Welka of the National Frozen Pizza Institute.
But these days, frozen pizza is not being marketed only for children. In recent years some restaurants have entered the frozen-pizza business, going after sophisticated adult palates.
Wolfgang Puck, the chef and owner of Spago in Los Angeles, introduced Spago-style frozen pizza in 1986 with such flavors as four cheeses, spicy chicken and sausage and herb. These pizzas are sold in supermarkets for as much as three times the price of other frozen pizzas but are of a quality that makes them suitable for guests, not just for a quick supper. Hotels and restaurants also offer them. The Pizzeria Uno stores sell restaurant-quality frozen pizzas for home consumption, comparable with the fresh pizzas served in the chain's 74 stores around the country.
The leading brand in supermarkets, Tombstone, which began in 1962 in a bar called the Tombstone Tap in Medford, Wis., was acquired by Kraft General Foods in 1986. Its pizzas are now available in the West and are gradually being extended into national distribution.
Among the varieties of Tombstone pizza is the new Tombstone Light, a line of relatively low-fat pizzas with about 250 calories in eight to nine ounces, compared with 310 calories in a Weight Watchers pizza weighing 5.75 ounces. The Tombstone Light pizzas are made with leaner meats and lower-fat mozzarella than the regular cheese used by the company.
''We expect to see increased interest in this type of product,'' said Cathy Pernu, communications coordinator of Tombstone pizza.
The diet pizzas are primarily aimed at the adult market, said Mr. Welka of the frozen-pizza institute. ''Concerns about fat on the part of aging baby boomers will create the next wave of growth for frozen pizza designed to appeal to that market,'' he said.
The industry is also turning to new flavors, more combinations and other ways of extending the lines. Pizzas intended primarily for microwave ovens now account for nearly a quarter of the market. ''We do not expect the microwave segment to increase,'' Mr. Welka said. ''It has slipped about half a percent over a year ago.''
In The Living Section's sampling of frozen pizzas, only plain cheese pizzas were compared. Most companies use real cheese, but it is sometimes brick, cheddar or generic semi-soft cheese, not always mozzarella. A few use imitation cheeses in which vegetable oil is substituted for animal fat. Most pizzas made with real cheese trumpet the fact on the label.
The pizzas tasted included some lower-calorie, French-bread and deep-dish varieties in addition to the traditional round, thin-crust cheese-and-tomato styles. The best were the brands that delivered a uniformly crisp crust, a well-seasoned tomato base and an ample amount of flavorful, pleasantly elastic cheese.
A few of the other brands came close to these standards, but suffered from excessive blandness or odd flavors. Others consisted of crust like sodden cardboard covered with an unsightly mass of bland tomato and relatively little cheese.
The worst were the microwave pizzas. Because microwave ovens heat food without allowing them to crisp and brown, pizzas intended for heating in microwave ovens come with silver cardboard pads and sleeves, not much help in achieving the crispness usually associated with pizza.
''It just does not deliver the taste and crispness,'' Mr. Welka said. ''Those are the things people demand in pizza and most adults will not sacrifice them for sheer convenience.''
 
Something From the Oven
Thirteen widely available brands of frozen cheese pizza were tasted by Florence Fabricant, who baked them in a conventional oven following manufacturers' directions. In some instances the pizzas took slightly longer to cook than the time specified. The pizzas were removed from the oven when the crusts looked reasonably brown and the cheese was melted. They were allowed to cool about five minutes before tasting. Pizzas are listed alphabetically within each ranking.

The Proof's in The Microwave
FROZEN pizzas intended for microwave ovens now make up about a quarter of the frozen pizza market, but they leave a lot to be desired in terms of flavor and texture.
I tasted seven brands of frozen cheese pizzas recommended for baking in a microwave oven. They were Celeste Pizza for One, McCain Ellio's Microwave Extra Cheese Pizza, Pillsbury Microwave French Bread Cheese Pizza, Red Baron Deep Dish Singles, Stouffer's Lean Cuisine Cheese French Bread Pizza, Tony's Microwave and Weight Watchers Cheese Pizza.
These brands all come with special paper sleeves, bases and crisping disks, equipment intended to produce the crisp, brown curst that is difficult to achieve in a microwave oven. They were baked according to manufacturers' directions.
Only Tony's Microwave Cheese Pizza was satisfactory. It had a decent flavor and a reasonabley crisp crust.
The other pizzas were fair. The McCain Ellio's, with a slightly crisp crust, was the only one that was not utterly soggy. The cheese topping on the Stouffer's Lean Cuisine French Bread Pizza was better cooked in a microwave oven than in a conventional oven.

HEADLINE: Crafting Jewelry for the Tourist Trade

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: LIMURU, Kenya

 BODY:
ON one wall of Vicky Chignall's jewelry workshop, nestled in the green hills of the farming country northwest of Nairobi, hang ropes of red beads, some of them centuries old. Along another wall are rows of boxes, each containing ornamental metal leaves, cowrie shells, blue Venetian beads, turquoise cylinder beads used in the slave trade and antique Ethiopian silver beads.
Exotic adaptations of African styles have become fashionable in the West even as many Africans attach themselves to the symbols of Westernization - blue jeans, running shoes and gold jewelry - and lose the taste for their traditional jewelry.
Mrs. Chignall and other Western designers like Angela Fisher and Alan Donovan use African materials, inspirations and craft artists to make beaded jewelry that appeals to tourists in Nairobi. ''Africa Adorned'' by Ms. Fisher, a book on African jewelry published by Harry N. Abrams in 1984, helped popularize what had been a connoisseur's specialty. 
Each of the three designers came to Africa with no intention of staying. Mrs. Chignall, formerly an interior designer in London, first arrived on a cross-continent trip in 1972. Mr. Donovan went to Nigeria as a program officer for the United States Agency for International Development in 1969 and soon found that the bureaucratic life did not suit him. Long fascinated by African art and culture, he established the African Heritage Store in Nairobi in 1972.
Ms. Fisher, an Australian, came to Africa in the early 1970's as a tourist. She has been exploring the continent with a camera and an eye for jewelry and African decoration ever since.
Much of the fascination with African jewelry comes from the stories and meanings associated with the beads and objects used. In African society, jewelry is not only an elaborate form of adornment but can signify important milestones like puberty, circumcision and marriage.
The best of the Western-designed jewelry in the African style incorporates old African beads of stone, horn, ostrich shells and cowrie shells as well as antique European glass and amber beads. European beads first trickled into Africa in the fourth century and poured into the northern and western coasts of the continent from the 1500's and were traded for ivory, gold and slaves.
Mrs. Chignall delights in explaining the different elements that make up her ''witch doctor'' necklace. The first bead next to the clasp is a turquoise tubular glass one brought from Europe centuries ago and commonly used in the West African slave trade. ''A West African ruler is reputed to have exchanged five people for one bead,'' Mrs. Chignall said. The necklace is a dramatic mixture of shapes and colors with beads of horn, wood, silver, coconut shell and volcanic stone beads, illustrating the creator's definition of a bead as anything that can be threaded. A newly made metal medallion symbolizing a crocodile hangs in the center.
Another creation uses strands of fine red Venetian trading beads with white interiors, known as heart beads, that are twisted into a choker around the neck. Similar beads were customarily worn as bodices, loosely draped over the front and back of young Dinka women in southern Sudan. The bodices were a sign that a woman was eligible for marriage.
The beads, according to Ms. Fisher in ''Africa Adorned,'' were provided by the woman's family and arranged in patterns to indicate the family's prosperity. Cowrie shells were often added as a centerpiece to the bodice, and were believed to promote fertility.
Old beads are becoming harder to find, many of them already scooped up by Western jewelry makers and tourists. Some are difficult to get because of war: much of the southern Sudan has been virtually impenetrable to outsiders for the last seven years because of conflict. What is left in African hands is often kept as a bank balance to be sold during times of drought.
And as the outside world, particularly Western museums and wealthy collectors, begins to recognize old African gold, amber and coral jewelry for its craftmanship, prices have soared. A single Egyptian scarab can cost up to $25; the witch-doctor necklace is $1,000.
Both Mrs. Chignall and Ms. Fisher scour favorite markets in the Ivory Coast, in northwest Africa and Ethiopia in search of old pieces. And they rely on traders who buy jewelry in remote parts of Africa and bring it to the cities to sell.
As the authentic pieces become scarce, the designers have to innovate. Mr. Donovan, who has been designing jewelry since 1974, recalls trying to copy the aluminum-leaf pendants worn by the Pokot and Turkana tribes in northern Kenya. (If worn through the nose, the leaf pendant announces a daughter's engagement.) The leaves are traditionally made from melted-down cooking pots, so Mr. Donovan bought similar aluminum pots for his craftsmen in Nairobi.
''The new cooking pots did not melt down in the same way,'' he said. ''The consistency was wrong.'' The Banana Republic stores, which had ordered leaf jewelry from him, insisted on the original look. ''So I had to go around the country exchanging new aluminum pots for old ones to melt down,'' Mr. Donovan said.
The designers employ African craft artists to make the jewelry, which can take days. Mrs. Chignall estimated that it takes a week for her most senior worker, Charles Muchunga, to complete one witch-doctor necklace.
Among Mrs. Chignall's 16 workers from the Masai and other tribes, there is some bemusement that Westerners are fascinated with jewelry that Africans no longer wear. One man wore a thin gold necklace of Western design. Several Masai men wore a single-beaded bracelet, but they say young people do not wear the traditional African styles. As Mr. Muchunga inspected a half-finished necklace in the workshop, he said the design would be foreign to most Kenyans.
''This is not for many Africans,'' he said. ''It is heavy and has many surprising things on it, like a crocodile. If we were buying a necklace that we wanted to wear, we would buy a light one that looks like gold and is imported.''
Another craftsman in the workshop, Patrick Njumguna, said that since he and his parents had converted to Christianity they had stopped wearing jewelry. ''Christianity says it is sinful to decorate yourself,'' he said. ''My grandmother was the last one to wear the jewelry and then she threw it away.''
When the Masai of Kenya wear jewelry now, they tend to wear less metal, preferring pieces made of tiny glass beads from Czechoslovakia. But marriage necklaces are still fashioned from leather that must be made from the back of a cow and slept on for a year to make it supple before being cut into a circular collar. The leather is sewn with hundreds of multicolored beads. From the collar, strings of beads hang to the knee, the number of strings signaling the wealth of the girl.
New Masai marriage necklaces are made in Mrs. Chignall's workshop, but are usually bought by Westerners as wall hangings, not as the latest fad in body decoration.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Masai men assembling necklaces from beads, stones and artifacts in Vicky Chignall's workshop in Limuru, Kenya. (Jane Perlez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Motorola Net Disappoints; Stock Slides

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Motorola Inc., one of the world's largest producers of communications equipment and semiconductors, announced a smaller than expected increase in third-quarter profits yesterday, and the company's stock fell sharply.
The company said it earned $102 million, or 78 cents a share, on sales of $2.7 billion in the third quarter. The profits were up 14.6 percent from $89 million, or 69 cents a share, a year ago, while sales rose 12 percent from $2.41 billion. Motorola said sales rose but operating profits fell in its cellular telephone equipment and two-way radio businesses because of heavy research and development spending. 
 
Shares Down by $7
Shares in Motorola dropped $7 in extremely heavy New York Stock Exchange trading to close at $52.75.
Analysts said they had been led by the company to expect higher earnings per share. ''Here's what is annoying: About a month ago they guided the numbers down from over a buck to 90 to 95 cents,'' said Andrew J. Kessler, an electronics analyst at Morgan Stanley. ''Then today they came out with 78 cents.''
Motorola's third-quarter cellular equipment sales jumped 39 percent from a year earlier, but operating profits fell because research and development spending in the division more than doubled, to 10 percent of revenues from 6 percent, said Richard L. Whittington, an electronics analyst at Kidder, Peabody. ''I would say it'll go up to 12 to 13 percent next year, further crimping margins,'' he said.
Increased competition from LM Ericsson, a Swedish telecommunications company, is depriving Motorola of some contracts to build cellular systems in the United States and overseas, and forcing Motorola to invest more in improving its technology, Mr. Whittington said.
McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., a longtime Ericsson customer, announced a week ago that it would buy digital telephone switches from Ericsson as part of a $250 million overhaul of several of its cellular systems. McCaw said it would move the existing analog switches from Motorola and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to other markets.
Digital switches use the 1's and 0's of computer language to transfer calls, while analog switches use a wave pattern that mimics the human voice. The Ericsson purchase does not include digital radio transmission equipment, which promises to increase the capacity of cellular telephone systems by three to 20 times.
George Grimsrud, a spokesman for Motorola, said the company was investing much more in communications but declined to comment on how much. The spending is for the development of small, low-power wireless telephones for outdoor and indoor use, and for the improvement of digital cellular equipment, he said. Motorola is also building a new cellular equipment factory in Scotland.
Motorola was forced to invest heavily in the early 1980's in its cellular equipment business, often at the expense of earnings, and now is being forced to do so again for a ''second round'' of cellular technology, Mr. Grimsrud said.
The increase in third-quarter profits this year was also limited because income taxes totaled $40 million, compared with $15 million last year, when Motorola took a one-time adjustment that reduced its tax burden.
The sharp drop in Motorola's stock yesterday partly reflected investors' continued and growing concerns about a possible recession, which could badly hurt sales of the company's cellular telephones and computer chips, Mr. Whittington said. After trading as high as $88.375 earlier this year, the stock now could drop below $50 a share if the economy continues to deteriorate, he said.
Motorola said its sales of semiconductors rose 14 percent from a year ago and operating profits for the division were higher. The company's sales of non-cellular communications equipment, mostly two-way radios, increased 7 percent and operating profits were lower.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Adam Smith, Meet Northrop Frye

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
MOST economists earn their bread by discovering more and more about less and less.
Not Donald N. McCloskey, University of Iowa professor, analyst of Victorian England's economic climacteric, sometime literary critic -and tireless scourge of humbug wherever he spots it.
His latest book, ''If You're So Smart: The Narrative of Economic Expertise,'' published this month by the University of Chicago Press, is surely the first by an economist to marshal the ideas of Harold Bloom, Daniel Defoe, Euripides, Northrop Frye, Steven Jay Gould, Eric Hoffer, C. S. Lewis, Plato, Damon Runyon, George Santayana, Wallace Stevens and Virginia Woolf in pursuit of his prey.
What is on Mr. McCloskey's mind this time around? Perhaps it would be best to let the author explain:
On economists and the decline of the work ethic: ''Once upon a time there was a kingdom with a people who did not like to study, preferring to sniff cocaine and watch videos on MTV; then the king hired an expert social engineer who had done much studying; and then as a result the people became prosperous, without of course having to do anything so painful as studying.'' 
On deconstruction in history: ''The philosophical difficulty was first articulated in the fifth century B.C. by Parenides and his student Zeno: that if everything is perfectly continuous, change is impossible. Everything, so to speak, is packed too tightly to move. . . . [But] if human nature doesn't 'really' change, then history will be a string of weary announcements that the more things change the more they stay the same. If the economy is 'really' in equilibrium all the time, then nothing remains to be done.'' On economic decline: If Victorians did better selling insurance than steel, as they did, then insurance is reckoned a nullity. Similarly the new 'McJobs' in American service industries, such as nursing and education, are reckoned as not being real jobs, like mining coal or spinning cotton.''
On simplifying abstractions: ''Economists spend a lot of time worrying whether their metaphors - they call them 'models,' a phrase that makes tiresome trips to the library unnecessary -meet rigorous standards of logic. They worry less whether their stories - they call them 'stylized facts' - meet rigorous standards of fact.''
On analogies between economics and literature: ''Good empirical work in economics is like realist fiction. Unlike fantasy, it claims to follow all the rules of the world. But of course it, too, is fictional. The applied economist can be viewed as a realistic novelist or playwright, a Thomas Hardy or a Henrik Ibsen.''
On why economists disagree so vehemently on what seem to be matters of fact or logic: [Economists] are like the imperious British visitor to Florence who believes that Italians really do understand English and can be made to admit it if one speaks slowly and loudly.''
On the dangers of using sports analogies in measuring economic performance: ''We do not need to be No. 1 in order to be happy and prosperous; we do not need to crush the Japanese to keep our self-respect. . . . Is it God's plan that the United States of America should ever after be Top Nation?''
On why economists prefer to sell their advice than use it themselves: ''No one with experience of life believes Publishers Clearing House when it writes, 'Ms. Z. Smithh, you have just won $250,000.' ''
On the risk in equating industrial power with military power: ''The Union sacrificed more men than the entire United States did in any other war to put down a rebellion by a less populous section that it outproduced in 1860 by 30 to 1 in firearms, 24 to 1 in locomotives and 13 to 1 in pig iron.''
On why prudent social scientists keep their metaphoric feet on the ground: ''The Nazis drew much of their power from a modernist science grown magical. The buildings and displays of Auschwitz put one in mind not of tarot cards and crystal balls but of modernist laboratories and industrial processes gone mad in an attempt to lay down the future. Likewise, when the modern historical sciences yield to the temptation of myth - the myth of national destiny, for example, or the myth of social engineering - they become silly and magical and dangerous.''
Is there a theme lurking? ''By seeing their stories and metaphors together,'' says Mr. McCloskey, ''the economists and their audiences can resist the many charms of snake oil and see that economists are wise, but not so smart.''
Well, maybe. But one need not linger on the question of whether the whole here is more or less than the sum of the parts. Mr. McCloskey is more interesting on an uninspired day than most of his peers can manage at their very best.

HEADLINE: Brazil Hopes For Lasting Debt Accord

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
Seeking to leave behind a decade of capital flight and debt-induced economic stagnation, Brazil's new Government opens talks today in New York over the nation's $60 billion commercial debt, the third world's largest.
After a series of broken accords with creditor banks in the 1980's, Brazil's negotiators now want a radical, lasting debt-reduction pact that would allow the nation to meet payments and provide for growth.
''Capacity to pay'' is to be the slogan of the Brazilian side in what are expected to be marathon talks with its bank lenders, Jorio Dauster, the principal Brazilian negotiator, said in an interview here on Friday.
''From 1983 until today, Brazil had a net transfer overseas of $60 billion in interest and principal payments,'' Mr. Dauster said at the Economy Ministry. ''During that time, our debt increased from $70 billion to $115 billion.'' Mr. Dauster, who holds the rank of ambassador in Brazil's foreign service, is currently on loan to the central bank and working to reduce the country's foreign debt. 
On the other side of the table, foreign creditor banks, especially American banks, are eager to get Brazil to meet its obligations. $10 Billion in Arrears In a default that has cut deeply into the profits of American banks, Brazil stopped making interest payments on its medium- and long-term private bank debt in July 1989. Brazil's arrears have since grown to $10 billion - $8 billion to foreign private banks and $2 billion to foreign government lending agencies.
Through a combination of payments and reschedulings, the foreign government debt is to be cleared up by next February. But the remaining $8 billion is expected to be a critical issue at the talks starting in New York on this afternoon.
''Token payments are out,'' Mr. Dauster said, referring to the commercial debt arrears. Mr. Dauster said Brazil would not make any debt payments until a comprehensive plan had been worked out with its creditors.
In response to pressure from finance ministers of Western creditor nations, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned Brazil last month that progress toward settling the arrears would be essential for winning the fund's approval of a $2 billion loan to Brazil. To increase pressure on the nation to make up those payments, creditor banks have scaled back short-term trade lines to Brazil.
American bankers fear, however, that a hard line by Brazil on paying the arrears will prompt a United States Government credit review committee to further downgrade Brazil's debt, forcing banks to increase provisions against losses on Brazil's loans.
But Mr. Dauster said that ''that's not a problem for us - that's a problem for bank regulators in the U.S.''
Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello, has said he wants a debt deal completed by the end of the year. But many bankers believe the talks could easily drag on for a year as both sides wrangle over a list of debt-reduction options.
Mr. Dauster has a reputation as a skilled and tough negotiator. He honed his negotiating skills in the 1980's when he served as Brazil's representative in London for talks of the International Coffee Organization involving export quotas and pricing.
In one pre-negotiating gambit, Mr. Dauster announced Friday that he had added six European banks to the negotiating committee, bringing the total number of members to 22.
''He is trying to dilute the American and Japanese influence on the committee,'' a senior bank official familiar with the talks said in a telephone interview from New York.
Under the new arrangement, France, which holds about 5 percent of Brazil's foreign debt, has four banks on the committee. Japan, with 20 percent of the debt, has two banks. The United States, with about one-third of the debt, has seven banks including Chase Manhattan, Chemical, Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover and BankAmerica.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Bankers Trust Picks Unit Chief

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
C. Edward Midgley, a veteran of Wall Street and the corporate board room, has joined the Bankers Trust Company as head of its corporate finance group.
At Bankers Trust, which reorganized in the 1980's to become more of a financial adviser and deal-maker and less of a traditional lender, Mr. Midgley will concentrate on developing the relationships with corporate executives needed to generate more business. He is joining the New York-based banking company after two and a half years as vice chairman of the Amoskeag Company, a Boston-based holding company he had advised during a 25-year career at Kidder, Peabody & Company. 
''Bankers Trust did a fine job developing an expertise in investment banking products during the 1980's,'' Mr. Midgley said. ''Now we are pushing to develop stronger relationships with corporate clients, to become less transaction-oriented and more advice-oriented.'' Bank executives hope that stronger relationships with corporate executives will lead to banks taking a more prominent role in arranging mergers and reorganizations, instead of just participating as lenders in deals put together by Wall Street firms.
Mr. Midgley inherits a group of about 25 executives, and expects to hire 10 to 15 more investment bankers from Wall Street firms. With firms and some banks cutting back corporate finance staffs, he said there was a good opportunity for Bankers Trust when activity revived.
Mr. Midgley described himself as ''an egghead'' when it comes to using the complex financial instruments such as interest rate and currency swaps and options that have spread through Wall Street in recent years. ''A lot of chief executive officers are still not comfortable with the idea of swaps,'' he said, and need financial advisers to show how the new techniques can protect against risks such as fluctuating interest rates, currencies and commodity prices.
As vice chairman of Amoskeag and its affiliate Fieldcrest Mills, where he will continue as a member of the board, he saw firsthand the benefits of protecting against the risk of fluctuating cotton prices.
Mr. Midgley lives in Irvington, N.Y. and is a competitive bridge player with his wife, and bridge partner, Laura. At the North American championships in July, he said they fared poorly. ''We are not in the same league with with some of those option traders,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Borrowing Growth Dips

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Americans cut the growth of their installment credit in half in August, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said consumers took out a seasonally adjusted $2.1 billion more than they repaid, or 3.4 percent at an annual rate over July and slightly more than the average $1.78 billion a month in the first seven months of 1990. 
But the growth of consumer credit slowed dramatically from a net increase of $4.73 billion, or 7.8 percent at an annual rate, during July, the Federal Reserve said. Consumer credit averaged $4.42 billion a month during 1988 and 1989.
Consumer confidence plummeted after Iraqi tanks moved into Kuwait on Aug. 2, according to various surveys. The Conference Board, a business research group in New York, said confidence in the United States economy in August dropped to its lowest level since 1983, when the nation was emerging from its last recession.
''The slower growth in August reflected a larger decline in auto loans outstanding and a smaller expansion of revolving credit than in July,'' the report said.
Automobile loans continued their slide, down 7.3 percent, or $1.74 billion. The sluggish automobile sector declined 1.6 percent, or $377 million, in July and 7.3 percent, or $1.76 billion, in June.
Revolving, or credit-card, debt rose $1.78 billion, up 10.1 percent from the previous month. But that was less than half of the 21.7 percent, or $3.78 billion, gain in July.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose 10.6 percent, or $1.84 billion, after a 7.4 percent, or $1.27 billion, increase the previous month.
Borrowing for mobile homes advanced 10.9 percent, or $208 million, after a 3.3 percent, or $63 million, gain in July.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Plunge

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities plummeted and interest rates rose sharply yesterday, as market participants saw rising oil prices, a weaker dollar and a continuation of the Federal budget negotiations as strong reasons to sell securities.
''I was sort of at a loss to explain why people were buying so strongly on Friday, so I can't say that I'm surprised the market is getting killed right now,'' one trader of government bonds said. ''And even though we have given back half of the gains that were made in the last week or so, I wouldn't be a buyer here either, particularly of bonds. With the dollar and oil acting the way they are, that is not a good trade.'' 
Traders and analysts said that auctions of seven-year Treasury notes and 30-year bonds issued by the Resolution Funding Corporation coming today and Thursday served as another impulse to unload positions.
 
Difficult Auction Foreseen
''With the dollar weak and confidence in Washington at a low ebb, it will be very difficult to auction seven-year and 30-year debt,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., research concern. ''It will take more rate concessions to get these securities sold.''
Late yesterday, the seven-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.68 percent.
As Mr. McCarthy suggested, reaction in the financial community to the latest twist in the Federal budget negotiations was decidedly negative. The only positive, dealers said, was that the agreements allow the Government to meet its debt obligations for the next two weeks, thereby avoiding default. However, market participants said they were not optimistic that the Oct. 19 deadline for producing a budget would be met.
''As far as I'm concerned, Congress has moved us back to square one on the budget,'' another bond trader said.
 
The Election Factor
''Now we have a dozen different Congressional committees that are going to be participating in the budget process, and there is an election in about a month. I would be very surprised if anything gets done before the election. What they will probably go for is another agreement that pushes out a decision until the middle of November.''
The Treasury, which would have had to postpone auctions of all securities had the budget agreement not been reached and the Federal debt ceiling not been raised, was able to hold its regular auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.19 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.18 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, bids on the new six-month bills produced an average yield of 7.21 perccent, unchanged from a week ago.
 
Secondary Rates Near 9%
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, yesterday's selloff pushed long-term interest rates back up close to 9 percent.
In late trading, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 97 27/32, down more than 1 1/2 points, or more than $15 for each $1,000 face amount of securities. That pushed the yield to 8.95 percent, up from 8.81 percent in overseas trading on Monday, when United States credit markets were closed.
Treasury note prices were also pummeled.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 21/ 32, down more than a point, to yield 8.80 percent.
And traders of two-year notes, who said the budget agreement reached late Monday would likely delay any move by the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates, pushed down the price of the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes by 6/32, to an offered price of 100 13/32, to yield 7.89 percent.
 
New York Issues Slump
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said the sharp selloff in Treasury issues as well as an announcement from the Standard & Poor's Corporation that it might lower its A- rating on outstanding New York City securities helped to push prices of the city's issues down by about 1/2 point.
The announcement by the ratings agency came as no surprise. Less than a month ago, Standard & Poor's issued a gloomy assessment of the city's economic and fiscal condition that coincided with New York's most recent public debt offering.
Municipal bond traders said that the sharp downturn in Treasury issues helped to push down prices of most actively quoted municipal issues by 1/2 point to 3/4 point.
 
Baltimore Gas Bonds
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company offered $200 million of five-year first mortgage bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 1/8 percent bonds, which mature Oct. 15, 1995, were priced at $99.77 to yield 9.183 percent, 75 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower In Worldwide Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly lower on world markets yesterday, but selloffs in other currencies prevented its decline from deepening.
The dollar fell sharply in Asian dealings, hitting new lows against the German mark and 18-month lows against the yen before consolidating and recovering slightly when trading shifted to Europe and the United States, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the consulting firm IDEA.
Traders cashed in on the weekend run-up in the pound and the yen, and their profit taking prevented the dollar from relinquishing further ground. 
Dealers expressed disappointment about lawmakers' extended haggling over a deficit-reduction package and complained about a seeming lack of commitment to resolve the budget problem. President Bush signed a temporary spending bill that keeps the Government operating until Oct. 19 while Congress tries to come up with a budget accord.
Any accord raises the possibility that the Federal Reserve would ease interest rates. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors, thereby increasing their need to hold the dollar.
The outlook for the dollar remains bearish ''given the problems with the budget as well as the economics we've seen with a recession scenario building here,'' Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen to close at 129.95 yen. Later in London, it was quoted higher at 130.30 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 130.25 yen, down from 130.48 yen on Monday.
In London, the pound was quoted at $1.9705, compared with $1.9745 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.9730 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.9760.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5238 German marks, down from 1.5323; 1.2735 Swiss francs, down from 1.2800; 5.1015 French francs, down from 5.1300; 1,142.25 Italian lire, down from 1,151.50, and 1.1506 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1514.

HEADLINE: Publishers Are Urged to Shift Focus

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Oct. 9

 BODY:
Something seems to be missing at the American Magazine Conference here. What is missing, oddly enough, is a sense that this conference is about magazines.
To be sure, there are workshops, endless discussions about event marketing, multimedia selling, reducing rate bases and other subjects of concern to the 600 magazine publishing executives gathered here. But it is as if the editorial product were of little consequence. 
There have even been some curious moments of role reversal when the media directors and the advertisers reminded the publishers of the importance of editorial content.
 
'Crystal Clear Identity'
''It seems to me that many publishers don't seem to realize that the relationship with the reader that they sell to the advertiser is provided by the editorial,'' said Richard M. Smith, editor in chief of Newsweek.
At a session today entitled ''What's Wrong, What's Right With Magazine Advertising,'' the four advertising executives on the panel were asked how well they thought publishers represented the editorial philosophy of their magazines. The idea got a big laugh from the audience, which was mainly publishers.
The panelists made it clear that publishers talked to them about magazines ''as if they were talking about program trading'' instead of giving a sense of the individual magazines and its readers.
''I think we sometimes have a greater respect for your readers and your editorial than you do,'' said Paul Keye, chairman of Keye/Donna/ Pearlstein, an advertising agency.
At a panel entitled ''Multimedia Selling: What Do Advertisers Want?'' the discussion turned to whether single-publication companies could still succeed when there was so much emphasis on multi-publication companies and cross-media advertising.
David K. Braun, vice president of media services for Kraft General Foods, said a single magazine with a ''crystal clear identity'' was especially attractive to advertisers because it enabled them to define more precisely who the readers were.
 
Bond With Readers
Dale W. Lang, chairman of Lang Communications, said publishers should never treat magazines as commodities but should emphasize the bond between a magazine and its readers.
He cited Sassy, a Lang magazine for teen-age girls. In a recent issue, a question on the spine of the magazine asked: ''Should Jane put a ring in her nose?''
Readers not only spotted the question but also knew immediately that Jane was Jane Pratt, editor of the magazine. Mail poured in urging Ms. Pratt to put a ring in her nose. She now wears one, and Mr. Lang can present advertisers with just the kind of reader-magazine bond they love.
On Monday evening, the American Society of Magazine Editors, which is sponsoring the conference with the Magazine Publishers of America, discussed what they called the relationship between church and state - between publishers and editors. Many said that as editors, they had not done a good job apprising publishers of the problems of magazine editing in a sluggish economy.
''I would hope that we could discuss the particular issues that tough times raise, particularly for smaller magazines,'' said Maynard Parker, editor of Newsweek.

HEADLINE: The Myth of Classnessness

BYLINE: By Benjamin DeMott; Benjamin DeMott, professor of humanities at Amherst College, is author of ''The Imperial Middle: Why Americans Can't Think Straight About Class.''

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
This country is in shackles, its thought, character and public policy locked in distortion and lies. The deceit stands at the root of Federal and state budgetary chaos and corrodes every aspect of national life. It causes the chief executive to expatiate on the defense of ''our life style'' - our life style - as though the way of life of the privileged were universal. And that obliviousness is but a minor symptom of a vast, country-wide self- deception.
Several hallowed concepts - independence, individualism, choice -are woven into the web of illusion and self-deception. But presiding over the whole is the icon of classlessness. 
George Bush asserts that class is ''for European democracies or something else - it isn't for the United States of America. We are not going to be divided by class.'' The forces behind this icon of classlessness range from the media to the national experience of public education.
The myth of classlessness has a history, of course. Caught up in that history, the Framers of the Constitution refused to impose land and property qualifications for Federal office; and 8 out of 10 Americans, in the Depression, claimed to be middle class. In our time, the myth not only lives deep in people's our nerves, but exerts an ever more destructive influence on public policy.
The myth is in tens of thousands of hours of sitcoms watched by tens of millions, young and old. On ''The Cosby Show,'' black Princeton grads win admission to the law and medical schools of their choice - then chuck it all, preferring to start at the bottom as busboys and waitresses.
On ''Designing Women,'' elegant, expensively coiffed Southern businesswomen talk for a second or two with striking curtain factory employees and at once become partisans of the strike: ''We are all labor!'' the ladies cry. In the Harvard alumni magazine, a recent graduate genially avers that ''we're all working class.''
And the myth directly affects the distribution of privileges, bounties and hazards in every sector of life.
Every year, a Federal housing donation of close to $40 billion is awarded to millions earning more than $50,000 annually. The donation takes the form of tax abatements, such as the mortgage interest and property tax exemptions, and the capital gains deferral on housing sales.
The handout to these $50,000-plus neediest comes at a time when the fair market price of rental housing in all 50 states exceeds the means of families in which two wage-earners work full time for the minimum wage, and when New York City alone has 170,000 families on the waiting list for public housing. Only the faith that America is a classless society prevents this charity to the propertied from being recognized for what it is: an indefensible class ripoff.
And the myth of classlessness figures in corporate decisions that strip the workforce of its dignity and skills by killing off one industry after another, from steel to semiconductors. The assumption is that workers aren't shaped by their skills; when quality jobs disappear, workers can just do - and be - something else.
Classlessness functions as the ultimate unspoken excuse for a range of inequities stretching from regressive Social Security taxes to pauperization requirements for care for the disabled, from Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's rejection of guidelines mandating prison terms for white collar criminals to the denial of proper medical care to heart disease patients lacking private insurance and wholly dependent on Medicare.
The Vietnam ''draft,'' the upper income ''bubble,'' tracking in the public schools, ''vocational'' education - all these episodes of state-administered injustice reflect the influence of the myth of classlessness.
And always that influence is masked, obscured, downplayed. Work-related accidents and illnesses kill 70,000 a year - but those people are nearly invisible. ''Most occupational risks are blue collar,'' says Peter Sandman, director of the Environmental Communication Research Program at Rutgers, ''If most risks were professional level they'd get more [media] coverage.''
Gov. James Florio dared to present a fresh, pertinent vision of New Jersey - a vision of a state prepared to acknowledge the realities of our class system and committed to broadening educational opportunity and narrowing the gulf separating rich and poor. The protest against his program is strongest in the richest suburbs, but it has significant working class backing. How could it be otherwise, given the huge resources that have been poured into the campaign to persuade us that we're all one, that each has access to all, that serious inequities simply don't exist?
An immense weight of subsidized opinion has gathered on the side of social untruth, and the means available to those who try to contend against the untruth are fragile. Social wrong is accepted because substantive, as opposed to sitcom, knowledge about class has been habitually suppressed, and the key mode of suppression remains the promotion of the idea of classlessness.
We shall not shake the monster in our midst until we take serious account of the idea of difference - differences between, for one more example, youngsters for whom opportunity means college and youngsters for whom opportunity can only mean the Army. The task is nothing less than that of laying bare the links between the perpetuation of the myth of social sameness and the perpetuation of social wrong. We have all too little time in which to get on with it.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
BUSH SHIFTS STAND ON TAX RISE AGAIN; CONGRESS BAFFLED

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The White House shifted course again today on tax policy, baffling the Congressional tax committees and leaving Congressional leaders confused about which way to turn.
By the end of the day, the White House was saying that President Bush had no public position on whether taxes on the wealthy should be raised in return for a lower capital gains rate - an arrangement he had embraced and then rejected only the day before -and that he was willing to leave the matter to Congress to decide.
With legions of lobbyists clogging the hallways, lawmakers met in closed sessions throughout the Capitol seeking to make sense of the President's position and to try to write the most important deficit-reduction legislation in history. Ten days into the new fiscal year, the Government remained without a detailed budget plan.
 
An Issue Frozen
The latest developments left frozen the issue that has divided the President and Congress all year: whether capital gains taxes should be lowered in exchange for a higher income tax rate on the wealthiest taxpayers. At this point, the issue of capital gains is likely to end up as a free-for-all debate on the House and Senate floors. 
The House Ways and Means Committee ducked that issue today, approving a bill that left the capital gains issue unaddressed. The plan would raise the gasoline tax and Medicare premiums, but in a way that seemed more palatable to the rank and file than the deficit-reduction deal that the House rejected last week.
 
Similar to Bentsen Bill
The committee's bill was similar to one Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Finance Committee, suggested Tuesday but withdrew today because of the confusion over President Bush's position.
As uncertainty over Mr. Bush's shifting position on higher taxes slowed efforts to work out a new budget agreement, the President took to the campaign trail for events in behalf of Republican candidates in Raleigh, N.C., St. Petersburg, Fla., and Atlanta. [Page D22.] The President has the authority to veto any tax-and-spending measures Congress might pass, and it would take a two-thirds vote of both houses of Congress to override the veto.
Judging by White House statements today, Mr. Bush's latest position represents a full-circle progression from where he stood about 2 A.M. Tuesday, when Congress approved the broad outlines of a five-year Federal budget.
Later Tuesday morning, Mr. Bush said at a news conference that if Congress agreed to the reduction in capital gains taxes he has long sought, he would consider higher income tax rates on the wealthy. It was the first time he had been other than inflexibly opposed to higher rates.
 
Tuesday Meeting Pivotal
Then, on Tuesday afternoon, the President met with Republican senators. Afterward, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon announced that Mr. Bush had agreed with the senators that tax rates should not be increased at any price.
Asked about that, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said Tuesday, ''It's fair to say he acquiesced in their views.''
Tuesday night, John H. Sununu, the President's chief of staff, told about 40 lobbyists for corporations and trade associations at the White House that a combination of lower capital gains taxes and higher income taxes on the wealthy would be opposed by the President, said one of the lobbyists, Alan Kranowitz of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors.
This morning, however, Mr. Bush met with Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the influential chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and afterward Mr. Fitzwater said: ''Publicly, we're not taking a position on any specific items.''
The meetins between White House and Congress continued today as Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, met with Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill.
 
How Republicans Differ
The situation was complicated by a split between Republicans in the Senate and House. Senate Republicans do not want to cut the capital gains rate if the price is a higher top income tax rate. House Republicans would accept a higher top rate in return for a lower capital gains rate.
The confusion today was such that Senator Bentsen canceled the meeting at which his Finance Committee was to begin voting on a tax plan he offered Tuesday that would have raised the top income tax rate to 33 percent from 28 percent and lowered the capital gains rate to 23 percent from 28 percent. The plan also would have raised the minimum tax paid by the very wealthy to 25 percent from the current 21 percent.
''Frankly, I was ready to proceed this morning,'' Senator Bentsen said. ''But once they changed their position on this, we had to redo our package.''
 
Democrats Chart Course
The Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said after talking with Mr. Bentsen, ''In view of the apparent reversal of position by the President, we will now have to reconsider what the appropriate course of action will be.''
Mr. Bentsen, who chatted briefly with reporters after the Democrats on his panel ended their closed-door meeting this evening, said he planned to call a meeting of the full committee on Thursday. ''We've made good headway. I'm pleased with it, we've got good options to present to them tomorrow,'' he said.
Asked whether the choices that would be presented for its consideration would include a cut in the capital gains tax rate, Mr. Bentsen replied, ''That will be one of the options.''
For his part, Mr. Rostenkowski pushed through his committee today a bill that was almost identical to the one Mr. Bentsen offered Tuesday, with one main exception: it did not mention capital gains, income tax rates or the minimum income tax.
Both the Bentsen and the Rostenkowski bills would raise the gasoline tax; increase taxes on alcoholic beverages, tobacco and luxury items; raise the premium and the deductible for Medicare insurance, and over all cut the deficit by $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years.
 
Trying to Limit Amendments
Mr. Rostenkowski's intention is to bring this core bill to the House floor next week under a rule that would allow two amendments, one to be devised by Democrats and the other by Republicans.
The Democratic amendment would almost certainly raise the tax rate on wealthiest Americans at least to 33 percent. Whether it would give a break to taxes on capital gains is unclear.
The Republican amendment would surely contain a lower capital gains tax. Whether it would also raise the top income tax rate is not certain.
Since Democrats control the House by a 3-to-2 margin, their amendment will probably be adopted and become part of the bill that will be sent to the Senate.
The issue between Republicans and Democrats turns on this: Democrats believe the top tax rate needs to be higher so that the wealthy would bear more of the burden of deficit reduction and the poor and middle class less. Republicans maintain that a low top rate and a lower capital gains tax, while directly most beneficial to the wealthy, would help all Americans by improving the state of the economy.
 
Crystal Ball Is Foggy
Even the most sophisticated students of Congress are unwilling to predict how all this will work out. If, as seems probable, Congress approves a tax-and-spending bill Mr. Bush does not like, there are two possibilities.
He could sign the bill and then blame the Democrats in the remaining days before the Nov. 6 election for raising taxes and approving a budget with insufficient incentives for economic growth. He could also use that argument to deflect blame to Democrats in the event of an economic recession.
Or, he could veto the measure and force Congress to reconvene after the election in a lame-duck session to tackle deficit reduction once again.
Some Democrats, including the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, believe the partisan nature of the budget battle will help Democrats in the election, enabling them to claim to be the party supporting fairness in the tax system.
But others, including Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, fear the fight plays into the Republicans' hands by letting them portray themselves as the party of prosperity and the Democrats as the party of higher taxes.
 
'Obnoxious' Elements Omitted
The measure approved by the House Ways and Means Committee this afternoon followed the same framework as the agreement announced by President Bush and Congressional leaders Sept. 30 and rejected last week by the House of Representatives.
But the Rostenkowski bill stripped from the agreement elements that the chairman said were ''totally obnoxious to members on the floor of the House of Representatives.''
Among the elements were a two-week waiting period before a person could receive unemployment benefits, nearly $20 billion worth of tax breaks for small businesses and a 2-cent-a-gallon tax on home heating oil.
The bill would raise monthly premiums and the annual deductible for insurances covering doctors' bills under Medicare by a much smaller amount than the President and Congressional leaders had set.
Monthly Medicare premiums, which have not increased since 1982, would rise to $32.40 next year from $28.60 now and would go to $46.50 by 1995. The annual deductible would rise to $100 next year from $75 now, and to $125 from 1992 on.
Under the Rostenkowski bill, gasoline taxes would rise to 20 cents a gallon, an increase of 11 cents, by next July.
A 10 percent luxury tax would be placed on cars costing more than $30,000, boats and airplanes costing more than $100,000 and jewelry and furs costing more than $5,000.
Workers would have to pay a hospital insurance tax on their first $73,000 of income, up from $52,000 today.
Three percent of the deductions of taxpayers with gross incomes of over $100,000 would be disallowed.
Altogether, the plan would raise taxes by $144 billion over five years, about $15 billion more than the plan Mr. Bush and the Congressional leaders adopted.

LENGTH: 1428 words

HEADLINE: Life Insurers Jolted By Sharp Downturn In Real Estate Value

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
With real estate values going downhill and banks nationwide struggling to avoid being buried in the slide, anxieties are focusing on another group of lenders: life insurance companies.
Last week, the Travelers Corporation acknowledged large losses on its real estate investments and chopped its dividend. The news prompted worried investors to sell Travelers shares as well as those of other life insurers with sizable holdings of real estate and ''junk bonds,'' sending their stock prices sharply lower.
Some analysts warn that troubled assets have grown so large at dozens of insurance companies that they could face the prospect of bankruptcy -especially if the economy weakens further. But most experts believe that a wave of bankruptcies putting large numbers of policyholders at risk remains unlikely. Even a lesser crisis of confidence in the life insurance industry, however, could tighten the credit noose on many business borrowers, deepening and lengthening the now-likely recession. 
''It would be disaster to lose a major source of capital,'' concludes Eden Sarfaty, the head of the National Organization of Health and Life Insurance Guarantee Associations.
Until the last decade, life insurance was the most predictable of financial industries. Much premium income was invested in bonds, mortgages and real estate, all of which were susceptible to fluctuations in value. But the death benefits and minimum investment returns promised to policyholders were based on such conservative assumptions that honestly managed insurance companies ran little risk of being unable to pay their obligations.
But since the early 1980's, said Terry Lennon, a senior official in New York State's Department of Insurance, ''life insurers have been forced to change because other financial institutions changed.'' Banks and savings and loans were freed to pay any interest rate they chose, and the competition for deposits grew hotter.
Companies guaranteed higher returns to policyholders, cutting margins for investment error. Yet in seeking to maintain profits, they sank more money in riskier assets, notably bonds from less-than-blue-chip borrowers. IDS Financial Services in Minneapolis estimates that ''junk bond'' holdings now represent 6.4 percent of life insurers' assets - roughly equal to the industry's net worth.
As important, life insurers spread their nets wider in search of cash. Fixed annuities, effectively tax-deferred certificates of deposit, were marketed to investors. And guaranteed investment contracts - promises to pay fixed returns over periods as long as 10 years - were sold by the billions to pension funds.
 
Vulnerability Studied
Much of this new business was profitable. But it increased the probability that insurers would end up owing a lot of money at high interest rates, even as the income on their investments was falling. The savings and loan industry was trapped in just such a predicament in the early 1980's. Without the sense of security conferred by Federal insurance, many would have lost the confidence of depositors and been unable to attract new cash.
IDS concludes that life insurers are now highly vulnerable to economy-wide shocks that raise interest rates, or force corporate borrowers into bankruptcy or undermine the value of commercial real estate. As a test, they estimated the likely losses of each of the 100 largest companies in the event of a moderate or a severe economic downturn.
Assuming a ''moderate'' downturn, 18 would be at risk of insolvency, leaving state guarantee funds to pay policyholders about $3.1 billion. Under the ''severe'' projection, 34 companies might fail, with a total loss as high as $11.5 billion.
In a memo written at the request of John D. Dingell, chairman of a House committee that oversees financial industries, the American Council of Life Insurers disputes the assumptions behind the IDS analysis. Many of the junk bonds owned by insurers, the memo argues, are junk in name only; the corporations that borrowed the money are unlikely to default. And while the industry does indeed hold a lot of mortgages backed by sagging commercial real estate, much of its asset base is worth far more than book value.
 
Wholesale Bankruptcies Doubted
''We're not saying everything is rosy,'' said Henri Bersoux, a spokesman for the association. ''But it looks like it would require an unbelievably bad downturn'' to lead to wholesale bankruptcies.
Mr. Lennon largely concurs: ''You can't look at life insurers' assets without looking at their liabilities, too.'' In most cases, he points out, companies have years or decades to pay claims. It is true that insurers' ultimate ability to pay depends on the recovery of real estate values. But a permanent slide in real estate, he argues, ''is almost an Armageddon scenario.''
If some big life insurance companies were to fall, would consumers' savings fall with them? Most policyholders are protected by state guarantees: state insurance commissions would levy taxes on solvent insurance companies to make good the losses. But Mr. Sarfaty of the insurance guarantee group notes that there are significant holes in the safety net.
Some 45 states have guarantee funds. Two, California and Alaska, will have guarantee systems by January. But three other states - New Jersey, Colorado and Louisiana -and the District of Columbia have no guarantee funds. Residents of these states would have to depend on the guarantee funds in the failed insurers' home states. And in 27 of these states, the funds are not obliged to compensate nonresidents.
 
Insolvencies in the 80's
From January 1985 through September 1989, 62 life insurance companies were declared insolvent by state regulators, according to the American Council of Life Insurance. Compensation for policyholders depends on state regulations. ''The rules vary widely in terms of who is covered and to what extent,'' said Joseph M. Belth, a professor of insurance at the University of Indiana.
Guarantees in most states are limited to $300,000 in death benefits and $100,000 in cash value. And the prospects for pensioners whose security is based on guaranteed insurance contracts is even more problematic. Most state laws, Mr. Sarfaty points out, do not address the question of whether the pooled assets of individual pensioners are covered.
Ordinary ''defined benefit'' pensions, the kind in which a specific monthly check is guaranteed by the pension fund, are also protected by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Federal agency. But those with insurance company-backed assets locked up in other sorts of retirement plans, notably ''401(k) salary reduction plans,'' would be left to make the case to state regulators.
Even the most pessimistic numbers suggest, however, that most policyholders would eventually get their money back. State funds typically have the right to assess up to 2 percent of insurers' revenues. In a pinch, IDS estimates, the states could raise about $4 billion annually - enough to cover the most severe projected losses in about three years.
But other damage related to a solvency crisis in the life insurance industry could not be so easily undone. A loss of confidence in the industry could lead to a flurry of policy redemptions, the insurance industry equivalent of a run on banks.
It is not as easy to withdraw money from an insurance policy or an annuity as it is to withdraw deposits from a bank; substantial penalties would give policyholders good reason to think twice. But Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, argues that ''if you are really worried about solvency, you'd take the money out.''
Fiduciaries responsible for managing the guaranteed insurance contracts held by pension plans are more sophisticated investors, and presumably less likely to panic. But there are only modest rewards to pension managers who take a chance and win, while the penalty for guessing wrong with other peoples' money is often a flood of lawsuits.
The consequences of even a minor run on the liabilities of the life insurers could be devastating to the economy. The industry channels billions annually into corporate bonds and real estate. Without policy income, the flow would stop - or reverse.
The money previously going into insurance policies, Mr. Litan acknowledges, would not disappear unless total savings fell by the same amount. And eventually, one presumes, those corporations and builders would find alternate sources of capital.
But ''eventually'' could be a long time, Mr. Litan said.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 11, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1247 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Troubles Are Tied To Aides' Conflicting Advice

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
When Mayor David N. Dinkins announced last week that he might have to lay off at least 15,000 city workers, his chief political aide and longtime adviser, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, learned that such a specific warning was in a news release only after it was issued.
If Mr. Lynch was in the dark, the municipal union leaders he helped marshal as campaign workers for Mr. Dinkins last year were incensed that they had not been notified in advance of the layoff warning, which was recommended to Mr. Dinkins by his Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, and First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel.
Those lapses, which occurred as the administration rushed to announce its plan, illustrate Mr. Dinkins's difficulties as he confronts New York City's deepening fiscal problems, beseiged with conflicting advice from outside critics and his own aides.
 
'Considerable Dissension'
Just days earlier, Mr. Dinkins had rejected the advice of Mr. Michael and Mr. Steisel when he agreed to grant teachers a 5.5 percent pay increase favored by Mr. Lynch and the city's Labor Relations Commissioner, Eric J. Schmertz.
''I think there's considerable dissension within the administration,'' said one senior city official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''Not over the facts of the fiscal situation, but they're disagreeing over how you react to it.'' 
''I think he's pretty good at taking advice,'' the official said of the Mayor. ''The guy listens, he probes. I don't think this was his problem.'' The official added that ''I think he was very ill served'' on the sudden layoff recommendation.
Generally, the Mayor's aides say, Mr. Dinkins sticks stubbornly to his own convictions, as he did when he refused to be rushed into hiring new police officers despite public clamor. But as he confronts an increasingly intense array of questions at once, aides say it is not clear who ultimately has the power to move the Mayor.
''Everybody has his ear,'' another senior aide said yesterday. ''He listens to everybody and then makes up his own mind.''
A mix of subtleties is at work. Mr. Dinkins is innately cautious and instinctively skeptical about dire budget warnings, though he has vowed repeatedly to keep his fiscal house in order. When he was the Manhattan Borough President, he, like his colleagues on the city's Board of Estimate, often complained that the Koch administration's budget office was hiding money from other officials.
 
Political Intimacy
There is also the interplay between the forcefulness and managerial experience of Mr. Steisel - a former City Sanitation Commissioner - and Mr. Lynch's political, though not personal, intimacy with the Mayor, coupled with Mr. Michael's detached approach to his job.
Mr. Lynch and Mr. Steisel, who did not know each other well but have developed a cordial relationship since Mr. Dinkins took office, both sought to play down any dissent yesterday.
Several mayoral aides and outside fiscal monitors said they saw Mr. Michael's harsh warning on layoffs as a move to buttress his credibility in light of the Mayor's rejection of his advice on the teachers' pact and to make tangible the quieter warnings he had been sounding for months.
Yesterday, after several published reports on the dispute over the labor settlement, Mr. Michael's office, which typically deals directly with reporters' questions, referred them to the Mayor's press office. Mr. Michael later returned a reporter's phone call. The Mayor's press secretary, Albert Scardino, said the new procedure was ''simply an effort to coordinate the flow of information at a time of very sensitive discussions.''
Unlike his predecessor as Budget Director, Paul Dickstein, who was a kind of surly genius of the Koch administration, crafting budget cuts and strategy with disarming bluntness, Mr. Michael has taken what he describes as a ''warmer, gentler'' approach. Mr. Steisel, himself an old budget hand, oversees much of the strategy.
 
Budget Gap Predictions
On the same day of the layoff warning, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman was preparing to predict a possible $2.6 billion gap in the city budget for the fiscal year that starts next July -nearly twice Mr. Michael's estimate. She also called for a ''budget summit'' of city, union and business leaders to discuss how to handle the gap.
The specter of Ms. Holtzman's warning, several mayoral aides said, prompted them to move quickly to put out their own announcement of a hiring freeze and possible layoffs. As facsimiles of news-release drafts were sent between City Hall and Gracie Mansion, aides said, not everyone meeting at the mansion knew just what was included until after the release was issued from City Hall.
A day later, some senior officials were still puzzling over how and why the precise number 15,000 had made it into the announcement, one senior adviser acknowledged last night.
Instead of reassuring jittery fiscal monitors about the city's resolve, the layoff warning - coming as it did on the heels of the teachers' settlement and hundreds of millions of dollars in proposed new taxes to finance Mr. Dinkins's anti-crime plan - left an appearance of disarray and inconsistency.
Some senior city officials and outside fiscal experts said the budget aides received no new factual information last week to justify making such a dramatic warning then, as opposed to almost anytime over the last few weeks.
 
Based on Tax Receipts
Mr. Michael had said that he made the recommendation based on tax receipts for the quarter ended Sept. 30, which fell below expectations at an annual rate of $150 million.
But two days before his announcement, the City Finance Commissioner, Carol O'Cleireacain, said tax receipts were actually about on target. Mr. Michael later acknowledged that actual receipts were not so bad but that he had taken the opportunity to revise his economic forecasts for the future to take into account expected declines in the national economy.
In subtle ways, Mr. Dinkins has sought to distance himself from the layoff recommendation, issuing a news release noting that Mr. Michael had made the proposal, but declining to endorse or reject it without further study.
 
A 'Credit Watch'
On Tuesday, when the Standard & Poor's Corporation put the city's general-obligation bonds on a ''credit watch'' and threatened to lower its credit rating, Mr. Dinkins, at a news conference, repeatedly deferred comment on the move to his Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero. The Mayor came to the microphone to discuss it himself only in response to persistent questions.
Besides his own staff, Mr. Dinkins meets occasionally with a ''Council of Economic Advisers,'' which includes such leading business figures as David Rockefeller, the retired banker; Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier, and Lewis Rudin, the real-estate developer, but only one economist, Ms. O' Cleireacain.
The Mayor's aides concede that he rejected the consensus of this group that it would not be wise for him to seek special taxes to finance the hiring of police officers and that he should instead blend such an initiative into the rest of the budget. The aides said the Mayor did so because he believed taxes reserved for the police hiring would be more palatable.
But the taxes he proposed drew immediate criticism from state legislative leaders whose support would be necessary to pass them and whose assent the Mayor had not sought in advance.
