HEADLINE: Socialists Ponder a Changed World

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
Buoyed by the collapse of one of its oldest foes, the Communist movement, but uncertain about its own role in the post-cold-war world, the Socialist International gathered in New York this week to set a course for the future.
It was one of the first public meetings of the International since Communist Governments fell in Eastern Europe in the last 12 months, and it was its first meeting in this country in more than a century.
Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor who has been president of the Socialist International since 1976, chaired the two-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Mr. Brandt suggested that Socialism is a victim of semantics. ''Let's face it,'' he said, ''Socialism has been discredited by the mess created in the so-called 'socialist countries.' '' 
 
An Upbeat Mood
Even so, the mood at the two-day conference was upbeat. As Mr. Brandt noted, 28 nations in the world have Social Democratic governments or governments in which Social Democrats share power.
''Our traditional role has not changed,'' said Pierre Mauroy, former Prime Minister of France and First Secretary of the French Socialist Party. ''As the countries of Eastern Europe move towards a market economy, Social Democracy will continue to serve as a strong counter-balance to the excesses of laissez-faire.
''We are traditionally the third way, in between the totalitarian state and the unregulated free market,'' Mr. Mauroy said.
Before the meeting began, some Socialists expressed the concern that the collapse of state-run economies in Eastern Europe would discredit all Social Democrats.
''Although Europeans do make a distinction between Communism and Social Democracy, the collapse of the first and only socialist experiment in history will have long lasting repercussions on the Socialist movement as whole,'' said Hans Janitschek, a former general secretary of the Socialist International. ''It may, in fact, kill it altogether.''
 
Free of an Albatross
''On the contrary,'' said Cornel West, a member of the Democratic Socialists of America and a professor of religion at Princeton University.
''We no longer have this albatross on our backs,'' he said, referring to Communism. ''Our values can now be played out. We can begin to translate them into programs of action.''
The Socialist International traces its ancestry to the International Workingmen's Association, founded in 1864 in London by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels. Deep divisions between Socialists and anarchists led to its dissolution 12 years later in Philadelphia. As Socialist parties gained strength in various European countries, they revived their organization as the Second International, founded in 1889 in Paris. It collapsed during World War I. In 1919, the Socialist International was again revived, while the Communists split away and founded the Third International, later known as the Comintern.
 
Old Concerns and New
The public sessions at the Waldorf, attended by some 300 delegates and observers from 100 countries, were taken up with discussions on traditional socialist concerns, such as bridging the gaps between rich and poor nations and disarmament.
But the conversations in the corridor dealt almost exclusively with the future of socialism in the wake of Communist collapse.
''Eastern Europe is not going to become part of the Western European Community,'' said Bogdan Denitch, leader of the Democratic Socialists of America. ''That's just an illusion. And the Socialist International is perfectly situated to mediate between the new groups forming in the East and West.''
''The failure of Communism is in some sense for us a victory,'' said Jean-Pierre Cot, a French Socialist and a leading Socialist in the European Parliament. ''We said for 70 years that there could be no socialism without democracy. Now we have to prove that what failed is Communism - not Social Democracy.''

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Soviets Seek Meeting of U.N. Military Panel

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The Soviet Union is seeking a meeting of the military chiefs of staff of the five World War II victors with permanent Security Council seats to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, a senior Soviet diplomat says.
The official, Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir F. Petrovsky, said in an interview that Moscow wants to convene the United Nations Military Staff Committee at the chief of staff level for the first time in its history to review the gulf situation ''on the basis of existing Security Council resolutions.''
Mr. Petrovsky thus indicated that the purpose of such a high-level meeting would not be to plan any new military action against Iraq, adding that the United Nations Security Council should tighten existing economic sanctions further before it considers using force to end the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. 
Instead, he said the chiefs of staff should review the military situation in the gulf, discuss options and consider the efforts many Western countries are making to enforce the Security Council's economic sanctions against Iraq by sending warships to search vessels suspected of breaking the trade embargo.
But he also made clear that his proposal is part of Moscow's longstanding campaign to revive this near moribund body, the duty of which is to advise the Security Council on military matters including the command and deployment of armed forces sent to enforce its orders.
''The machinery is there,'' he said. ''We have a chance for a breakthrough, to make the machinery work.''
For most of the 45-year history of the United Nations, cold-war tensions kept the Military Staff Committee paralyzed with the United States and the Soviet Union unable to agree on any joint role for their military forces within the United Nations context.
But since the gulf crisis began the Soviet Union has been pressing for its revival.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Campaign Fizzles, but Not Quietly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10

 BODY:
At the outset, the race for Pennsylvania governor had promised to be an interesting, perhaps nasty, conflict between a tenacious incumbent and a fiery challenger whose views on abortion and taxes clashed not only with each other's but also with the traditions of their respective parties.
The two have exchanged barbed remarks, but the conflict has had a stunning lack of depth and drawn relatively little attention. Even the intensity of the abortion debate has faded, perhaps because almost a year has passed since the state adopted, and courts began reviewing, the nation's most restrictive law on late-term abortions.
Whatever tension there was in the campaign seemed to fizzle this week, when an independent poll, confirming earlier assessments, showed the Democratic incumbent, Gov. Robert P. Casey, ahead by a 3-to-1 margin, with a substantial amount of that support coming from Republican voters.
And on Tuesday night, in the campaign's first and probably only televised debate, Barbara Hafer, the Republican challenger who is state Auditor General, occasionally put the Governor on the defensive. But she won no decisive victory in what was widely seen as her best opportunity. 
 
Benefits From Television
''She needed to strike a body blow, and she didn't,'' Sandra Featherman, director of the Center for Public Policy at Temple University, said today.
But Dr. Michael L. Young, associate professor of politics and public affairs at Pennsylvania State University at Harrisburg, said Mrs. Hafer's cash-poor campaign benefited enormously from the 60 minutes of free air time. ''I think she will get some bump-up in the polls from the debate, but not as much as she would have if her performance had been more impressive or if the Governor's had been less impressive,'' he said.
The race, which started soon after the public debate over abortion peaked late last year, offered voters an off-beat choice between an anti-abortion Democrat, who frequently sounds former President Ronald Reagan's no-tax and all-is-well-and-getting-better themes, and a Republican who advocates a woman's right to abortion and sees social problems everywhere.
A good fight seemed in the offing. In one corner, the 58-year-old Governor, who has been seasoned by eight years' service as state Auditor General and three failed campaigns, dating back to 1966, for the governor's office. In 1986, he was elected Governor by a narrow margin. Some political analysts attribute his victory to a 30-second advertising spot that devastated his opponent, William W. Scranton 3d, then 39, son of the former Governor.
 
Skewered by a Sitar
The advertisement featured 15-year-old photographs of Mr. Scranton wearing a beard and shoulder-length hair and gazing intently at a popular guru from the 1960's. A narrator, speaking over sitar music, said, ''His only real job was lieutenant governor, and they gave him that because of his father's name.''
In the Republican corner, there is 46-year-old Mrs. Hafer, a robust, tough-talking woman who says she used to carry ''a little automatic handgun'' in her early career as a public health nurse and director of a center for victims of violent crime in the Pittsburgh area. She served as a county commissioner for five years there before being elected Auditor General in 1987.
Republican Party leaders drafted Mrs. Hafer to run for governor after other experienced Republicans in the state declined to take on Governor Casey, whose approval ratings have never dipped below 65 percent.
Mrs. Hafer got her campaign rolling in February by calling Governor Casey a ''redneck Irishman from Scranton'' and, after a series of prison riots, suggesting that he was afraid of dismissing the prison commissioner because he was black. She backed off a little -saying, for example, that she was part Irish herself. But the offhand remarks have haunted her campaign and become the foundation for criticism from the Casey campaign, political analysts and Republicans who oppose her stand on abortion.
 
Running on His Record
Governor Casey has quietly campaigned on his four-year record and is relying heavily on a $4 million advertising campaign. The television advertisements cite the Governor's programs for clean water, toxic waste, drug education and the state's selection by a small business magazine as the fourth-best managed in the nation.
Governor Casey opened the debate on Tuesday with a summary of his administration's accomplishments, including his claim to being Pennsylvania's first governor in 43 years not to raise taxes. The League of Women Voters sponsored the debate, and 324,000 households tuned in to it, more than for any other program in the time period, according to Arbitron, the ratings agency.
Mrs. Hafer's opening remarks were biting yet delivered in a tentative style, with a pause and an ''ah'' between every few words, as though she was not really committed to delivering the message. She repeatedly charged the Governor with dishonesty, saying he had a ''secret deal'' to bail out Philadelphia from its fiscal crisis, was running up a $1 billion state deficit and was planning to raise taxes to record heights next year.
Mrs. Hafer may have been most effective in speaking about abortion. ''This man would condemn women in Pennsylvania to going to the back alley and having an illegal abortion,'' she said, barking out the words. ''I was a public health nurse; I have held women in my arms that have died from botched abortions.''
 
Not Backing Down
Governor Casey denied all of her charges. But he did not back down from his strong anti-abortion position. He was asked whether he would sign a law, presuming it had the blessing of the United States Supreme Court, that banned all abortions and provided criminal penalties for doctors and hospitals that violated the law. ''If the legislature passed such a law and it had an exception for the health of the mother, I will sign it,'' he said.
Both politicians dodged a question about whether they would help Philadelphia ease its problems by granting the city authority to raise its own taxes. Philadelphia, which faces a $208 million deficit and is scheduled to run out of money on Dec. 1, presents a troublesome problem. Helping the city is not popular beyond the city's limits, but the largely Democratic city has a quarter of the state's Democratic votes.
Governor Casey restated his skepticism about the city's managment, saying the state would not help the city until the city provided ''hard numbers, audited figures we can rely on.'' He also said local officials would have to reach a consensus on how to solve the problems.
Many Republicans, especially conservatives, have refused to support Mrs. Hafer. She has been able to raise only $1.1 million this year, as against the $5.5 million Governor Casey has raised.
 
Poll Confirms Big Lead
All along, the Casey campaign has maintained that its surveys put the Governor 40 percentage points ahead of Mrs. Hafer, but it was not until Tuesday that an independent poll confirmed the wide lead, giving the Governor a 47-point margin.
The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette conducted the survey last weekend. It was based on a representative sample of 719 Pennsylvanians who said they were registered to vote; the survey had a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Voters also ranked the abortion issue below prison overcrowding, taxes. education and the economy, which was ranked the most important issue. Governor Casey outpolled Mrs. Hafer by huge margins among voters of both parties and in all demographic groups, except Jews, who favored Mrs. Hafer by a 2-to-1 margin.
Political analysts say that Jewish response could be explained by their support for her abortion views, but that the response is subject to a high margin of error since Jews represent only about 2.5 percent of the state's population and, thus, only about 18 of the survey's respondents.
''Hafer has run a weak campaign,'' said Dr. G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville University in Lancaster. ''But, to be honest, she is running a race that probably could not have been won by anybody else.''
Dr. Madonna said taxes, the state economy or scandal have been the big issues in every campaign since 1954. ''What does Hafer have to exploit?'' he asked. ''A scandal-free administration? A soft economy? A budget that doesn't yet call for new taxes?''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania greeting his Republican challenger, Barbara Hafer, the state Auditor General, on Tuesday night in Philadelphia before their first televised debate of the campaign. (Associated Press)

PUB-DATE: October 11, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 506 words

HEADLINE: A Tax Cut That Deserves to Die

 BODY:
President Bush's obsessive campaign to cut the capital gains tax may finally have been buried by his fellow Republicans.
He remains somewhere between flip and flop. First, he signaled Congress he would swallow a deficit reduction package that linked a higher income tax rate for the rich to a cut in the tax on capital gains. The concession sent the Democratic chairmen of the House and Senate tax-writing committees off to work out a detailed proposal. 
Then, only hours later and after heavy lobbying by House and Senate Republicans, Mr. Bush reversed himself by agreeing to no such deal. Yesterday he denied coming to any conclusion. Whatever the reason for the President's flipflops, the deal has been at least temporarily derailed. That's welcome because it would have wrecked the tax code and harmed the economy. It deserved to be buried, once and for all.
The idea looks equitable. Capital gains are overwhelmingly earned by families with annual incomes above $150,000. By raising the top income tax rate and cutting the tax on capital gains, the rich pay for their own tax shelter. But the appearance is deceiving. At tax rates close to the levels Congress has in mind, the wealthy would come out way ahead.
Fairness is not the only problem. The Bush Administration has persistently exaggerated the potential benefits of cutting the capital gains rate below 20 percent, contending that economic output would rise by $12 billion a year for the first five years. Frankly, a $12 billion boost to a $6 trillion economy doesn't amount to very much. But even $12 billion is a wildly inflated estimate.
Alan Auerbach, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania, provided Congress with compelling evidence that the Administration plan would cause output to rise by at most a billion a year and might well cause output to fall. A tax cut could spur the economy only if it led to increased rates of capital investment. And that would happen only if the tax cut caused savings to rise.
Yet the tax cut would not affect foreign investors or pension funds and other tax-exempt savers. So the entire burst of savings would have to come from domestic taxpayers who, according to Dr. Auerbach's estimate, would have to boost their savings by a preposterous 25 percent.
The Administration's case is weaker still. The tax cut would eventually widen the Federal deficit. That means saving would fall, dragging down investment and productivity.
The White House and its supporters have argued that a lower capital gains tax would free investors to sell old investments and reinvest. Maybe, but merely shuffling old assets creates nothing. In short, it is hard to take the Administration's claims seriously. If growth were really the goal, Mr. Bush would have restricted his proposed cut to new investment. By including old assets, he rewards his political supporters, not the economy.
The President scuttled the deal at least for now because of a benighted campaign pledge not to raise income taxes. Wrong reason. Right outcome.

HEADLINE: Gas-Electric Hybrid Cars Can Be Built Now;
For Health's Sake Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Natural Gas in Cars - and Step On It'' by Patrick McGeer and Enoch Durbin (Op Ed, Oct. 2) suggests using domestic natural gas to end our dependency on imported oil. The American Lung Association of Brooklyn supports switching fleets to natural gas for different reasons - those affecting human health. 
Lung diseases, ranked as the third most common cause of death, are still major destroyers of the human body. Convincing research demonstrates a connection between air pollution and upper-respiratory infections, including the common cold (the repeated assault of air contaminants on the body appear to weaken its defenses against germs).
A growing volume of research also points to a strong link between air pollution and the development of emphysema and lung cancer. During periods of elevated ozone concentrations, even healthy adults and children have exhibited impaired lung function after mild exercise.
We are pleased that New York City, following the example of Brooklyn Union Gas, is introducing natural-gas buses to replace the diesel buses that fill the air with some of the worst pollutants, including known carcinogens. New York has a network of streets and highways daily traversed by more than 5,000 diesel vehicles, spewing hazardous smoke into the lungs of defenseless victims. Certainly, a cleaner fuel can do more to protect the lung health of our residents than any rearrangement of traffic or construction of toll barriers to bridges, tunnels or the inner city.
Human health should be added to energy independence, the balance of payments, and the high cost of oil with inflation as a reason for a rapid switch from diesel and gasoline to clean, domestic natural gas for buses and automobiles.
 
CAROLE SNYDER
Executive Director, American
Lung Assn. of Brooklyn
 Brooklyn, Oct. 2, 1990

HEADLINE: China's Prime Minister Losing His Hold?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Further on Chen Jinhua, who replaced China's Prime Minister Li Peng as Minister of the State Commission for Restructuring the Economy (news article, Sept. 8): Mr. Chen has been president of the China National Petrochemical Corporation since 1983. In 1977 he was vice chairman of the Shanghai Revolutionary Committee, and from May 1979 to March 1983 deputy secretary of Shanghai's city government. In 1984 he was elected vice mayor to Jiang Zemin, now party general secretary.
Mr. Chen's replacement of Mr. Li symbolizes the increasing power of Mr. Jiang, whom Deng Xiaoping favors over the Prime Minister. Mr. Li probably owes his advancement to being the adopted son of Zhou Enlai. Since reviving the Chinese economy is now of prime importance, the replacement could indicate that Mr. Li's days as Prime Minister are numbered.
 
>SIMON P. J. >CHEN
 Cleveland Heights, Ohio, Sept. 21, 1990
The writer is Asian studies librarian at Cleveland State University.

HEADLINE: Face Up to the Fairness Issue

BYLINE: By Jim Leach; Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, is a member of the House Banking Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The American people voted in 1988 for a reduction in the rate of growth of government and taxes. They did not vote to mortgage their future to the whims of undisciplined politicians. They did not vote for ostrich politics and depression-inducing economics.
At the root of the constitutional crisis that is gripping Congress is a new ''duck test'' on fairness. While conservatives object to anything that quacks like a tax, liberals sense the outrage of the public and demand sacrifices from the wealthy in any package that cuts benefits for the poor. 
In a Congress of little leadership and less followership, the left and right are mugging the middle, raising the question whether the center can hold, whether government can govern.
Amid the questions of fairness that arose over the details of the budget package, largely overlooked were the unfair consequences that would result if Congress failed to enact a deficit reduction package.
Would it be fair, for instance, to the young of America to add $300 billion to the national debt?
Would it be fair to the elderly who would have to pay more for food and medicine because of a refusal of Congress to curb inflation?
Would it be fair to taxpayers who would have to pay more for nothing, that is, interest on the national debt?
In the savings and loan debacle, Congress learned that refusal to deal with insolvency problems early cost far more later. The same with budget deficits. The fairest budget of all would appear to be a balanced one.
Twelve-figure deficits simply have no place on the economic agenda of either a true liberal or a true conservative. Just as it is counterfeit liberalism to devalue the currency with living-for-the-moment spending, it is counterfeit conservatism to object to deficit reduction of the nature contemplated in the bipartisan package.
Ironically, by refusing to engage constructively in the budget negotiations and objecting bellicosely to the initial agreement, conservatives opted out of the governing coalition and ceded their seats at the bargaining table to their adversaries. Their ideological rejection of the initial package may have been good short-term politics, but it guaranteed the passage of a more liberal alternative, jeopardizing the Reagan revolution.
By refusing to contemplate a change in the tax code to put high-income citizens in the same tax bracket as middle-class taxpayers (breaking the so-called ''bubble''), even in exchange for capital gains reform, Congressional Republicans ignore at their peril the frustrated demands for fairer burden sharing by low- and middle-income Americans on whom they depend for support. Naively, White House operatives left the President vulnerable to the fairness challenge by standing stubbornly by the views of legislators who would not stand by the President.
Given conservative obduracy and the resulting political gridlock, the President has little choice but to seek a governing coalition with the Democrats in Congress, one in which centrist Republicans can be utilized to avoid a stampede to the left. A center-Democrat coalition has the potential to save Republicans from themselves on fairness issues, even though it could lead to a deficit package with fewer new tax deductions and slightly greater spending authorizations.
The internal priorities of a five-year, $500 billion deficit reduction package are less important than its framework. The country cannot stand the panic that would follow a significant rundown in the stock market, run-away from Treasury bills and runup of interest rates.
Deficits of the current gargantuan magnitude are sinkholes in the road to economic recovery. They jeopardize the President's program and the Presidency itself.
Credible deficit reduction can only be achieved if the politics of fear give way to the recognition that what is micro-politically jeopardizing for individual politicians is macro-economically sound for the country; if liberals develop a functioning spleen to go with their heart; if conservatives reflect a greater judgment and sense of equity to temper their convictions.
Me-generation citizens cannot afford me-generation politicians.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
At the Circus

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
Not since the tall ships has there been national esprit as great as that inspired by the budget negotiations. In bank lines, drugstores, supermarkets and parking lots Americans have gathered in a spirit of grand unanimity to discuss the possibility that the people who run the Government are completely out to lunch.
Some of this public sentiment is due to the technological advances afforded by cable television, which enable us to watch actual deliberations on the House and Senate floor and to see that the average debate in Congress bears a remarkable resemblance to a kindergarten classroom when the teacher has been called away.
The people have realized the dirty little secret of those of us in journalism: that by distilling public officials to one sound bite, one quote, we made them look like ringmasters when so many of them were actually clowns. 
Some have found this entire spectacle entertaining, and some have found it disgusting, and some have found it entertaining and disgusting at the same time, not unlike watching the Red Sox choke yet again in the playoffs. The lines between children's television and the Federal Government are blurred. Are John Sununu, Newt Gingrich and Marlin Fitzwater real people, or are they cartoon characters? If they are real, why do they have those names? And if people get the government they deserve, are we all Mickey Mouse?
Many of us might never have noticed the budget negotiations until we picked up our paychecks, looked at the revised amount, and said, ''Well, there go the car payments.'' But closing the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and the Grand Canyon sent a signal that we had better listen up. And when we did we realized it was the end of an era. For 10 years we have been living with the big lie, the lie that we know so well because we have told it ourselves. The check is in the mail. Finally the bill has come due. ''You can fool all the people all the time if the advertising is right and the budget is big enough,'' the movie producer Joseph E. Levine once said. There is no evidence that he was speaking of Ronald Reagan, but if the quote fits, share it.
The people have had their own convictions about all of this, which is more than you can say for Congress. The people like the idea of taxing those with more money at a higher rate. (The President went for the idea for about a half-hour the other day, but then Republicans came to call and he backed off. There are more waffles in Washington this week than there are at the House of Pancakes.) The New York Times took a poll, and a whopping 87 percent of those surveyed said that people making over $100,000 should pay more in taxes. Shall we all guess how much money those respondents make? The defense budget also seems vulnerable. It has heretofore stood for our belief in ourselves as a macho, hairy-chested kind of country. But since we discovered that the Soviet Union is a third-world nation that cannot even manage to beat its plowshares into plowshares, and since we have learned that the Defense Department has been known to spend $27.50 on such items as paper clips, hairy-chestedness has ebbed somewhat as a national priority.
These two things won't be enough to put a dent in the deficit, and we've always known it. Some of us will grouse about entitlement programs, until we realize that entitlements include things we like, like Social Security. Some of us will grouse about welfare; like a company mounting a recall, the Government of the 1980's spent a lot of time teaching us to trash its wares. All decade long, there was a free-association test. Welfare . . . cheat. Trickle . . . down. Free . . . market. Tax . . . cuts.
Everybody flunked. We just didn't know it until now, when we are no longer under the voodoo-economics spell of an avuncular, folksy, not terribly bright guy who only said the nation's finances were in a helluva mess when he thought the microphone was turned off.
As so often happens, the bill comes due at the worst possible time: when our homes are devalued, when filling our gas tanks and grabbing a burger is an either/or proposition, when beef is a luxury item. Deep in our hearts we knew that the cuts would someday be deep and the cost high. But we figured the guys in Washington had a plan. Until we saw them on television and couldn't tell them from Yogi Bear and Boo Boo. Until we tried to take our kids to the Smithsonian one Saturday and discovered that the only dinosaurs you could see in town were the ones at the Capitol.
At least it's brought us together.

HEADLINE: PRO HOCKEY;
Expansion Too Pricey for Some

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
When Milwaukee withdrew its application for a National Hockey League expansion franchise this week, nine groups in eight cities were left vying for the six remaining openings.
Lloyd Pettit, who headed the Milwaukee bid, said it was ''not economically plausible'' to begin a business with a $50 million entry fee and a roster of castoffs from other teams.
''We just recognized that it was an impossible thing,'' he said, adding that a realistic entry fee would be closer to the $31.5 million purchase price of the Minnesota North Stars, who were sold last spring.
At least one other applicant, a group that hopes to put a team in the Suncoast Dome in St. Petersburg, Fla., said it could make a profit, even with a $50 million entry fee. 
''We looked at the guidelines of the N.H.L. and we used them in our negotiations with the Suncoast Dome,'' said Jim Rutherford, director of hockey operations for the St. Petersburg group. ''We came out with a lease that is favorable and we can make the numbers work at $50 million.
''We're in a market, an on-tap market, which we feel can be very successful. Not only is it heavily populated and a good TV market, you really don't have a lot to compete for for the entertainment dollar. TV is very important to make the numbers work. We're looking at a local and state TV package.''
The league's board of governors is expected to award at least two franchises at its December meeting. The league last winter announced plans to expand from 21 to 28 teams in the 1990's. The first franchise, in San Jose, Calif., went to George and Gordon Gund, who had threatened to move the Minnesota North Stars there last winter.
Instead of moving, they sold the Minnesota team and will draft 30 young players from the North Stars organization after this season. (The new Minnesota owner, Norman Green, has called the arrangement ''a screwy deal'' and said he would fight it.) Rutherford said there were ''20,000 ideal hockey seats'' in the Suncoast Dome, which was built for baseball.
 
Concerns About Drug Policy
Bob Goodenow, the new deputy executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, began his fall tour of league teams this week to hear opinions from his members.
Goodenow, in Detroit on Tuesday and in Chicago yesterday, said he ''will be traveling five days a week for the next three or four weeks.''
He may hear a rising chorus of opinions concerning the league's drug policy. Influential players like Doug Wilson of Chicago have voiced concern about the current policy, which allows John Ziegler, the league president, to evaluate all cases and hand down all punishment. Ziegler recently suspended Grant Fuhr, the Edmonton goalie, for one year after Fuhr admitted using cocaine in the past.
''They see what can happen to players under different circumstances,'' Goodenow said. ''They are all wondering and trying themselves to logically rationalize the whole thing. You get different opinions.''
The issue might be a major one in negotiations for a new contract. The present agreement ends after this season. Goodenow is the current deputy and future successor to Alan Eagleson, who is serving his last season as executive director. But Goodenow stressed that he, not Eagleson, would lead the next negotiations.
''I am negotiating the contract,'' he said. ''Alan is not. That's what they hired me to do.''
 
New Idea in Minnesota
In Minnesota, where fewer than 6,000 customers attended each of the first two home games, some interesting ticket and crowd-control policies have been instituted by the North Stars' Green. For instance: If you wish to sit near the ice and between the blue lines, you can buy a season ticket, with each game's seat costing $28.50.
But if you wish to attend a single game and sit in those same sections, each seat will cost $50 per game.
Green has said he expects to turn North Stars tickets into prestigious commodities in a year or two. He has said he wants the best seats filled with people in suits and ties.
He has discontinued many giveaways and discounts on tickets because, he said, they often fell into the hands of ''drunks'' who would sit near paying customers and offend them.
On the scoreboard above center ice, an electronic message board warns the Met Center fans: ''DON'T USE ABUSIVE LANGUAGE.'' (What if Green had bought the Rangers and tried these things at Madison Square Garden?) Other messages ask fans not to come and go from their seats unless play has stopped.
Such civility is common in the buildings of Canadian cities, which make up one-third of the 21-team league. Green, for the past 10 years, owned 18 percent of the Calgary Flames.
 
LaFontaine Update
Don Meehan, agent for Pat LaFontaine of the Islanders, said yesterday that he had ''heard nothing'' from Bill Torrey, the team's general manager, on a proposed contract re-negotiation. LaFontaine, who is making $425,000 this season, wants a new pact at a considerably higher salary.
''I would expect they know and understand and appreciate what he means to the team,'' Meehan said. ''If they understand and appreciate his value and presence on the team, they know where we stand. It's up to them.''
LaFontaine left the team for the final two exhibition games, but returned, he said, out of a sense of obligation and loyalty. Meehan said LaFontaine didn't want to withhold his services during the season because he didn't want to harm the team or his reputation. That would seem to leave him with little leverage. His salary is less than half the going rate for players of his caliber.
Asked if he finds the Islanders' stance frustrating, Meehan said: ''Yes, very much so. And so does Pat.''
Torrey said last weekend that he expected to speak with Meehan about LaFontaine early this week. Torrey couldn't be reached for comment yesterday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 2; Home Desk

LENGTH: 1474 words

HEADLINE: It's a Boy! It's a Girl! It's Time To Shop

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
CONSIDER the newborn infant. So small. So wrinkled. Above all, so helpless.
But not for long. Not with a nearly $2.5 billion industry of home furnishings and other products ready to serve and soothe Baby around the clock, whether asleep or awake, feeding or fussing.
For example: the modern baby can ride in a stroller bright enough to be spotted in a gale at sea, travel in a cushioned carrier that looks like a gigantic running shoe, wear diapers that resemble zebra skins, drink from bottles tinted to match any outfit and sleep on sheets that are a forest of grinning animals. Also, Baby can race through the house in a walker that is a turtle on wheels, gaze at a crib mobile that is a ripe banana tree, lounge on the beach in a cabana of mosquito netting, suck on a pacifier that looks like Dumbo and eat with a bib that reminds elders that ''Spit Happens.'' 
These possibilities and more were on display here last week at the annual Juvenile Products Show. The merchandise, which filled five floors of the vast Apparel Mart, the length of several city blocks, was testimony to the consumption that attends childbirth in much of America today. It suggested that a doctor who informs a patient that a pregnancy report is positive may as well add, ''Congratulations, it's time to go shopping.''
The show's sponsor, the Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association, was optimistic about business, even though much of the rest of American industry is going through a difficult period. The juvenile-products industry, which reported a 16 percent increase in sales last year, is ''driven by the new baby boom in the United States,'' said Doug Dolansky, president of the association. There were 4 million births last year, the most in 25 years. Mr. Dolansky said the rate was expected to remain steady for most of the decade.
Also cheering the industry is the fact that 40 percent of new babies are born today to first-time parents, prime customers for the awesome array of infant paraphernalia. Mr. Dolansky predicted that ''a high percentage of total industry sales will continue to be lavished on these first-birth children.''
But not everyone here was convinced that the industry is immune to the spreading downturn in the economy. Some manufacturers said they thought buyers were more cautious than usual and were doing more looking than ordering.
The juvenile-products industry consists of home furnishings, accessories and personal care items for children up to the age of 4, but it is estimated that sales of infant products account for at least 70 percent of its business. It is an industry that thrives on planned obsolescence and the innocence of its customers: parents-to-be who happily spend $500 for an Italian stroller or $200 for a Japanese high chair have no idea that by the time Baby reaches the ageof 2, she will probably refuse to sit in them.
For the 3,000 American and foreign buyers who converged on this city of tall glass buildings and arctic air-conditioning, the news of the industry was twofold: color and diapers. This could be the year when Baby sees red. Red was everywhere, from strollers, cribs and bedding to feeding accessories and pacifiers. Neon shades of orange, green and pink also made a strong showing, especially for strollers.
As for diapers, the growing popularity of cloth was much in evidence. Of the 287 manufacturers who showed their wares, 14 produced cloth diapers or decorative covers for them. Until quite recently, the popularity of the disposable diaper, introduced nearly 30 years ago, made the cloth diaper nearly obsolete. But as environmentalists have spread the message that disposables will clog landfills for generations to come, cloth has staged a comeback.
The new cloth diaper bears no resemblance to the flat piece of fabric that bundled earlier bottoms. Today's diaper, 100 percent cotton, has elastic around the legs and Velcro closures - and no more pins.
Moreover, a whole new industry has sprung up to cover cloth diapers, to give Baby what manufacturers call a ''fashion forward'' look. Nylon diaper covers come in a rainbow of solid colors, and there are prints, too: clowns, cows jumping over the moon, zebra stripes, leopard spots, flowers, pinstripes, trains, neon polka dots.
This emphasis on color and pattern has spread throughout the industry, even to strollers and car seats. Strollers, once a basic blue or gray, are now anything but. Today, Baby can ride in a carriage of stripes, polka dots or African prints, as well as just about any solid color.
Hundreds of different strollers were on display. Manufacturers said styles had proliferated to meet the needs of the typical two-stroller family: a sturdy model to push Baby down city streets and a lightweight style for travel. And for parents of twins or triplets, there is an array of stretch strollers.
Ira Hymen, the owner of two Bellini stores in Chicago and Glenview, Ill., said the new red strollers would appeal to his customers, who typically spend at least $3,000 to equip and outfit an infant. ''They want things that are bright and showy,'' he said.
David Schweig, owner of Sunnyland Furniture in Dallas, said his customers, too, wanted ''lots of bright colors.'' But he predicted that strollers covered with polka dots or stripes will also be popular.
Car seats, too, have broken out of basic dullness and are being manufactured in a variety of colors. Renolux introduced a model covered with fabric resembling an abstract Jackson Pollock painting. And Century unveiled a cream-colored leather car seat ''for the parent who has everything.'' Cleaning instructions were not attached.
As for cribs, which remain predominantly white, the Italian influence has taken hold throughout the industry. Plain, boxy cribs are disappearing. The new shape has soaring arches spanning each end. These Euro-cribs, which can sell for as much as $700, do not come with warning labels: when Baby starts teething, the glossy finish will be dotted with bite marks. For children who have outgrown the crib, there are high-octane fantasy beds. One is a black sports car with working head and tail lights. It will sell for $499. Another bed, which will sell for at least $1,200, looks like a red 18-wheel tractor-trailer. It makes a loud groaning sound when the engine is turned on, and it has a horn that screams ''Beep! Beep!'' ''This is going to drive parents crazy,'' a buyer remarked. Loren Anderson, products manager of Playnix Inc., the manufacturer, did not blink. ''Don't all kids' toys drive parents crazy?'' he replied.
A new category of furniture was the transitional bed for toddlers. It looks like a twin bed but is the size of a crib. Manufacturers hope to attract parents who live in tight quarters.
Other than beds, there was little furniture innovation on display. One exception was a wooden play table and chairs developed by the Viennese architect E. Warlamis. The furniture, in red, green and yellow, is covered with numerous pegs and grooves. Children can create a universe of their imagination by inserting an accompanying set of wooden toys that look like trees, castles and birds.
The exhibitors were a mix of large, nationally known manufacturers and mom-and-pop operations. While the former unveiled products that were developed through laboratory research and information gleaned from focus groups, the latter introduced products that came out of their own needs and experiences as parents. Their test markets were their own children.
Jamie Leach, for example, is a registered nurse who saw a need for a better baby bottle. Her new Genesis collection consists of bottles that are imprinted with useful information for parents, like instructions for performing cardio-pulmonary resuscitation and the month-by-month developmental stages of a normal baby.
Susan Matthews, a former advertising executive, displayed her new Boppy Pillow Pal, a firm round play pillow for infants. Inspiration struck when her own infant was in a day-care center.
Jacob Feinzilberg, formerly a producer of television movies, wanted to work in ''a kinder and gentler industry.''
So he invented the portable Inflate-a-Potty, which can be used in the car. The picture of the crying child on the box is his daughter, who says in big letters, ''I need to go NOW.''
Joe Swan, a buyer from Luton, England, stared and shook his head. ''I can't believe it,'' he said. Parents are not the only customers in the industry's line of vision. That is what Steve Fox, vice president of the Baby Shop in Severna Park, Md., was thinking when he examined a blue floor mat shaped like a bear. Its box described it as an ''educational play mat.'' Mr. Fox was not convinced, but he liked it anyway.
''It has absolutely no value whatever,'' he said. ''But it looks cute. It's something that grandma would buy.''

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 2; Home Desk

LENGTH: 913 words

HEADLINE: Surviving a Short Stay: White Decor Helps

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
SOME people have trouble moving from one place to another. Others can pick up, reorganize and move all their belongings to a new location with very little effort.
Definitely of the second persuasion are Peri Wolfman and the photographer Charles Gold, who are partners in Wolfman-Gold and Good Company, the home furnishings store in SoHo. The all-white esthetic that Ms. Wolfman is well-known for in design circles has, time and again, made the move easier. 
''I've moved a lot in my life,'' she said, ''but I never redecorate. White has always come through for me. It provides me with a really quiet environment - something I need in New York because it's such a pressured place.''
With a few broad strokes - stripped pine, exotic bunches of dried flowers and lots of white, of course - Ms. Wolfman seems able to create an established feeling of home in the time it might take others to take a long walk around the block.
''I don't waste time over decorating,'' Ms. Wolfman said. ''And I don't suffer about it. For me, it's boom, boom, and it's done.''
A few months ago, Mr. Gold and Ms. Wolfman sold the large Gramercy Park apartment they had had for 10 years. ''Because of the vagaries of the real-estate market, we decided to make a temporary move, thinking that we might eventually move out of the city altogether,'' Ms. Wolfman said.
They decided to become renters. ''I see the move as a sabbatical,'' she said. She had to find a space that would be large enough to accommodate ''very, very big furniture,'' as well as the comings and goings of the couple's four children, who are in their 20's.
Ms. Wolfman looked at 35 apartments, taking one with 18-foot-high ceilings and a mezzanine, near the store. The 2,500-square-foot apartment has two bedrooms and a small den. The view is not dramatic, but offers what Ms. Wolfman calls ''an interesting cityscape.'' There is good light, and of course the walls were in her one and only shade: white.
An enviable assortment of copper pots, which had no place in the small kitchen, were the only items to go into storage. To Ms. Wolfman's relief, her new home could accommodate her armoires, including a seven-foot-high French fruitwood armoire.
''An antique, but not a Louis,'' she said. ''That one and some of the others have moved from Westchester to San Francisco and then to New York.
''I could have put some of them away in storage,'' she continued, ''but I really wanted to bring it all together in one place. These things represent a lifetime of homemaking.''
Large mirrors are also important to her. An English over-mantel pine mirror from the 1880's hangs over one of the sofas and reflects the windows. A pair of long mirrors lean informally against the wall. ''I had those made because I didn't want to buy anything expensive, and I felt I needed them for some of the blank space,'' she said.
Before moving, Ms. Wolfman and Mr. Gold did get rid of anything they ''didn't like a teeny-weeny bit,'' she said, including ''the clutter of 10 years: magazines and clothes and about 100 pairs of shoes that I kept in wicker baskets.''
The apartment seemed made for them. The bathrooms were outfitted with old-fashioned white sinks and white tile. The small kitchen was also all white. ''I didn't think everything would fit in here,'' Ms. Wolfman said, ''but once in place, we realized that we had to buy more furniture.''
To her, that meant finding benches, one of her ad hoc solutions for bookcases and side and hall tables. Ms. Wolfman creates still-lifes on them: a leaning mirror, a birdhouse, a basket, a family photograph.
She stacks dozens of books on long low benches and places one bench atop the other.
''We don't have bookcases and didn't want to build anything in,'' she said. ''With benches, all you have to so is find the right size and color.''
To furnish the small den, she bought two large old-fashioned armchairs and ottomans upholstered in dark-green cotton. ''Quite dogproof,'' Ms. Wolfman said, an important feature because of the couple's Tibetan terriers, Daisy and Rose. ''I guess that makes this apartment a lot less white than the previous one.''
The two chairs face a space for the television set and stereo equipment. A small chest, two benches and a trunk were added; a painted door was propped against the wall, a sort of free-standing artwork, and the room was complete.
Over the years, Ms. Wolfman has learned a few lessons about living in an essentially all-white space. ''I moved here from California with white canvas chairs,'' she said. ''A few small spots, and they were done.'' That was when she started throwing more durable fabric, like movers' blankets, over her furniture.
The terriers put the white decor to the test. ''I decided early on to simply cover the sofas with Marseilles bedspreads,'' Ms. Wolfman said. ''It may sound stupid to have the dogs all over the white covers, but we just wash them all once a week.''
Ms. Wolfman did deviate from her usual all-cotton preference by using polyester for the flowing draperies on the 15-foot-high windows. ''Spending $500 for the fabric was our biggest expense,'' Ms. Wolfman said.
One of the big differences in their new apartment is the kitchen, which is much smaller and did not come with what had been Mr. Gold's favorite piece of equipment, a restaurant range. ''He stopped cooking,'' Ms. Wolfman said. ''He lost 25 pounds and I lost 11, and we eat out a lot.
''Some things turn out all for the better.''

HEADLINE: A Jazz Fixture of No Fixed Style

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
If American culture has promised anything, it is diversity, and Muhal Richard Abrams has always taken advantage of America's palate.
Mr. Abrams, who is performing his music with the American Jazz Orchestra tonight at Cooper Union, is one of the most resourceful composers working in America. A typical orchestral concert of his moves easily from dense and luxurious Ellingtonian harmonies to spikey Bartokian flourishes to deep Chicago blues. At its best, his music is a thrilling vision of democratic possibility. It's exciting and it's slippery, unwilling to settle down into the familiar. 
''American musicians are lucky,'' Mr. Abrams said in a recent interview. ''We can tap into so much raw music material. If I write something in what is called the European classical tradition, I'm comfortable doing it as long as I personalize it, just like when I write something in the jazz tradition. All of these different musical styles make up the world of music, and I feel free to deal with the world of music. Music is about bringing great colors and great moments and great music to an audience. It is about erasing all the labels and divisions people pick up on.''
 
Staying Out of Pigeonholes
Mr. Abrams has a right to complain about labels. At the age of 60, he has avoided being labeled as the most important inheritor of the big band tradition and he has also avoided taking his place in the contemporary concert system in America. There is no place for somebody who walks carefully between the two worlds; jazz fans, especially in an orthodox age, are suspect of his eclecticism, and his jazz tendencies don't let him fit into the European mold.
But Mr. Abrams has the credentials. As a young graduate of the Chicago Musical College in the late 1940's, he was one of the city's top be-bop pianists, playing with Miles Davis, Sonny Rollins, Max Roach and others. He arranged for several big bands, then in 1962 founded the Experimental Band; three years later he formed the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a cooperative that influenced the vanguard of jazz for a decade through musicians and groups, including the Art Ensemble of Chicago, Lester Bowie, Anthony Braxton, Chico Freeman and George Lewis. And all the while he was studying the European tradition.
''His music covers an incredible spectrum, and he's come up with startling original music,'' said the saxophonist Marty Ehrlich, who will be playing in the American Jazz Orchestra and has performed and recorded with Mr. Abrams for most of the decade. ''And he has really great craft in so many musical languages. I don't know anybody who has that combination in the way he does. I think there have been times where he doesn't fall into any one camp. He's a master of so many traditional languages. Which has been a problem in the way he's been received. Because he always works from inside the language instead of just using a surface, he can't appeal to the Downtown post-modern college style, and because his range is so broad, he alienates traditional jazz fans. And that has probably confused people.''
 
A Broad Range in Age
Mr. Abrams's music will be played by the American Jazz Orchestra, a repertory group that has helped legitimatize jazz as repertory music over the last five years. The band has a broad range in both age and culture, moving from Mr. Ehrlich, who is equally at home in contemporary music and various jazz and jazz-related music, to Benny Powell, the great trombonist known primarily for his association with the Count Basie Orchestra.
''I love playing with this band,'' said Mr. Abrams. ''There's so much depth to it. When you get somebody like Danny Banks on baritone saxophone, he's worked with so many big bands that there's a real level of profundity to his playing. And since I'm such a disciplinarian, I feel that what I'm doing, for the younger musicians, is providing them with a foundation that for economic reasons, they don't get anymore.''
Mr. Abrams will be performing two different sets of music, ''The Hearinga Suite,'' a brilliant piece of music recently released on the Italian Black Saint label, and a set of pieces that he wrote for a performance keyed to his acceptance of the Danish Jazzpaar prize. On ''The Hearinga Suite,'' the big band tears through march cadences only to segue into hard-swinging, swirling big band writing that clears the way to incisive solos. Slow, pensive sections come up against straight-ahead swinging, and the music resonates with possiblities. It is accessible music that belies the tired avant-garde label Mr. Abrams has toiled under for the last 25 years.
''People are still using the term avant-garde, which is frightening,'' said Mr. Abrams. ''What can be avant-garde today, with so much different artistic activity going on around us? I think the term has alienated an audience unfairly. I'm an American musician playing music that comes naturally as an American. I don't need any labels.
''America has still a great potential for being a great country, especially through the arts. Look at the influence the arts from here, music in particular, has had on the world - just the appeal of it shows its power. America set the world dancing a different dance, singing a different tune. It has produced art which is inclusive, and if anybody tries to deny me my rights, I don't even bother with them.''

HEADLINE: Oil Down $1.71 After Big Swings

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices fell yesterday after bouncing up and down on war worries and then on rumors that Saddam Hussein had been assassinated.
In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a barrel of crude for delivery next month closed at $38.69, down $1.71 from Tuesday's record high of $40.40. In the course of a wild day, prices reached $41.15 and then fell back to $38.
The gyrations were felt in the stock market, but for a change stocks moved in the same direction as oil prices, with the Dow off 37.62, at 2,407.92, after fluctuating wildly. [Page D10.] Refined products fell even more sharply than crude oil; heating oil closed at $1.0105, down 5.10 cents, the equivalent of $2.14 a barrel. Unleaded gasoline fell to 93.60 cents a gallon, or 4.66 cents, the equivalent of $1.96 a barrel. 
''The markets were kind of manic-depressive,'' said James Fielder, a trader at E.D.& F. Man International. ''As long as the situation in the Persian Gulf is not resolved, it's going to stay volatile like this, and you might as well get used to it.''
Mr. Fielder described a market torn between two magnets: a war price of $60 a barrel and a supply-and-demand price of $20 a barrel, with occasional panicky lunges toward one or the other.
At Cargill Investor Services, Howard P. Rennell, a trader, said that heating oil had led the plunge in crude. ''The market was getting overbought before the Palestinian situation hit the news,'' he said, referring to the riot in Jerusalem on Monday in which at least 19 Palestinians were killed. ''People have gone into the heating oil market with the expectation of December's being as bitter cold as it was last year, and a war, combining the two worst-case scenarios.'' In addition, he pointed out, inventories are high.
After the market closed, the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade association, released its weekly survey, showing that inventories are still strong, although slightly lower in some categories.
 
A View From Canada
Most experts see volatility ahead. At the Canadian Energy Research Institute, in Calgary, Alberta, Dr. Gerry Angevine, the chairman, said: ''If the price falls to $30, all Saddam Hussein has to do is make a statement and the price will go up. And I would think that from where he sits, he wants to see the price stay high. He'd like to see his enemies pay as high a price as possible.''
''On any one day, we could continue to see swings of 10 percent or more,'' Dr. Angevine said. The range today, $3.15, was about 8 percent, larger than average but not the largest in the 11 weeks since Iraq invaded Kuwait, a period in which the price of oil has more than doubled.
Since then, resentment against the oil industry and the futures market has grown. In Washington yesterday, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman complained in a speech on the Senate floor of ''a feeding frenzy in oil futures.''
Senator Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said ''speculators on the futures market often trade up prices on the basis of hysteria, not rational projections of future economic factors.''
''Rumors fly at the speed of sound, and prices rise or fall in quick consequence,'' Mr. Lieberman said. ''It makes little difference whether those rumors are true or false.''
Others argue, however, that the futures market is doing its job of determining a price, one that is now heavily influenced by uncertainty.
John H. Lichtblau, the head of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, said, ''the great bulk of these transactions are for the purpose of hedging, not speculation.'' For example, he said, a company that pumps oil from the ground might buy a contract to sell oil next month at $40, to protect itself against the risk that a resolution to the crisis would cut world oil prices and make the company's output worth less.
''It's really risk insurance,'' Mr. Lichtblau said. And if rumors drive prices up, they also drive prices down, he said, adding that for every winner on the market there is a loser.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
700 Jobs To Be Cut By Saks

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Saks Fifth Avenue, which has been owned by a Middle East financial company since last spring, announced a five-year strategic program yesterday that calls for a cut of 700 jobs, capital investments of $250 million and plans for an additional chain of small fashion specialty shops.
Melvin Jacobs, Saks's chairman and chief executive, said at a news conference that about 700 jobs, representing about 6 percent of the company's 12,000 employees, would be eliminated to ''create operating efficiencies to achieve our five-year goals.'' About half of the ''redundant and marginal administrative positions'' will come from Saks's corporate office and the rest from the 47 stores, he said.
Philip B. Miller, one of Saks's two new vice chairmen, said attrition in the central office had already cut 200 to 300 jobs. He denied that the unspecified savings from the cutbacks would be used to finance some or all of the store renovation expenditures. ''That's a separate allocation and has nothing to do with the redundancy program,'' Mr. Miller said. 
 
Economy Moves
The staff cutback apparently represents yet another in a series of economy moves that have spread throughout New York retailing. Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's pruned their staffs in 1988 and 1989 after their acquisition by the Campeau Corporation. Two weeks ago, another leading fashion retailer, Seattle-based Nordstrom Inc., which has three stores in the East, reported 6 to 12 percent staff reductions.
Despite industry reports indicating sales declines at area stores catering to the affluent, Saks said sales at comparable stores - those open at least a year - were ''nicely ahead.''
Mr. Jacobs said 100 top employees would be allowed to acquire an 8 percent equity stake in the company for about $48 million. This amount will be offered to them by Investcorp International, the Middle East holding company that bought Saks earlier this year from B.A.T. Industries of London for $1.5 billion, including $600 million in equity.
Speaking at the new Saks Tower on Fifth Avenue and 49th Street, which includes the Fifth Avenue flagship store, Mr. Jacobs said, ''Our plans call for substantial capital investment in our stores, a stronger focus on the selling floor, intensified merchandising, an increase in our Folio catalogue business and equity participation and other incentives for our people.''
Saks will invest about $250 million over five years to renovate stores and improve information data systems, Mr. Jacobs said. Under the B.A.T. ownership, he said Saks had made ''significant expenditures'' in the last five years to erect the Tower, expand the flagship store and open new stores in Chicago, Denver and Portland, Ore.
Referring to the employee cutback, Mr. Jacobs said, ''It will be invisible to the customers but will allow us to enhance our service.'' As part of the strategy of concentrating more effort on the selling floor, he said, Saks was reclassifying a number of positions, eliminating job redundancies and planning to install greater incentives for salespeople and higher bonuses for mid-rank executives.
 
New Team at the Top
The news conference was also used to introduce Saks's new top management team made up of Mr. Jacobs and the chain's president, Burton Tansky, who have both been associated with Saks for a number of years, and the two new vice chairmen, Mr. Miller and Arthur Martinez. All four members of senior management have purchased ''significant equity stakes in the company,'' Mr. Jacobs said. He declined to give details.
Saks's executives declined to comment on reports that the company's first-half profits had been disappointing, registering only $26.3 million after taxes against an expected $32 million. But Mr. Miller did say, ''We expect a satisfactory profit year in 1990, higher than the year before.''
 
'Running Nicely Ahead in Sales'
Mr. Martinez said Saks's comparable stores were ''running nicely ahead in sales and our three new stores are having an outstanding response.'' Later, Mr. Miller said, ''We are showing a high-single-digit gain in sales in October so far, and our profits are on line with our expectations.''
The executives said that they expected Saks's Folio catalogue operation to double its present sales, from $55 million to $110 million. Expansion efforts are being pushed toward opening a separate chain of small fashion stores, emphasizing a specific merchandise category such as shoes or men's wear. Referring to the small stores, Mr. Jacobs said that ''their number would have to be considerable to add much growth to Saks.''
He and his associates said that they were interested in opening new Saks stores internationally, especially in Japan and Europe.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Portman Mortgage Holders To Control Atlanta Project

BYLINE: By JERRY SCHWARTZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 10

 BODY:
John C. Portman Jr., the Atlanta architect and developer, said today that he would surrender to mortgage holders a controlling interest in the Peachtree Center office complex here, the keystone of his worldwide real estate holdings.
The move puts the mortgage holders, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and Nippon Life Insurance, in control of six downtown office towers. Mr. Portman will keep a minority interest. It comes after weeks of talks in which Mr. Portman tried to obtain more favorable terms for more than $2 billion in debt.
He has been meeting since August with a committee of 22 creditors, led by Citicorp. He has tried to get breathing room after cash-flow problems caused his privately owned development companies to miss loan payments and led to lawsuits from two creditors - Chemical Bank and Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank -that ran out of patience. 
Mr. Portman, 65 years old, is best known for designing and constructing a series of trend-setting hotels whose lobbies featured large atriums. They include the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan and the Hyatt Regency in Atlanta. He also owns multi-use commercial projects in San Francisco and Shanghai.
Citicorp is Mr. Portman's largest unsecured creditor, having lent him $378 million to build his newest Atlanta venture, a 60-story office tower to be known as One Peachtree Center.
With a fairly strong service-based economy, Atlanta has not been hit as badly by the real estate slump and commercial office glut as the Northeast and states like Texas. But developers here say the office market has gradually been softening.
Given that situation, several commercial real estate experts have questioned the wisdom of Mr. Portman's continuing aggressive development here and elsewhere.
Last year, when other big developers sharply cut back their activity, Mr. Portman nearly doubled the size of his Atlanta Apparel Mart and at the same time opened a technology mart, which now stands only one-third leased. One Peachtree Center, scheduled to open in 1992, is not included in the deal with Equitable and Nippon.
Repeated requests to interview Mr. Portman in the last several weeks have been rebuffed by his office.
 
Suits Filed by Banks
Mr. Portman's problems became public when he was sued Aug. 31 by Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank. The West German bank contended Mr. Portman had failed to repay a $3 million, 90-day loan.
Chemical Bank sued Mr. Portman in September when he failed to make a $5 million payment due Sept. 1 on a revolving line of credit. Mr. Portman also failed to make a payment scheduled Sept. 1 on his Equitable mortgage.
Under the terms of a 1988 mortgage with Equitable and Nippon, the two life insurance companies would have gained a 50 percent interest in the Peachtree Center complex at the end of the 10-year mortgage.
The deal concluded this week will give the two companies substantially more than 50 percent ownership of the complex, although the exact terms were not immediately available. In turn, Mr. Portman may receive several million dollars more from the two companies, people familiar with the talks said.
 
Other Holdings Seen as Safe
While the deal covers only the Peachtree Center complex, a spokesman for Mr. Portman said the additional cash should make it easier for the developer to conclude new loans with his other creditors.
Company officials would not say how the Peachtree Center deal might affect Mr. Portman's operating income. But one person close to the negotiations said the deal would not imperil Mr. Portman's other holdings.
The One Peachtree Center project was hurt last month when the First Atlanta Corporation, heavily courted by the Portman Companies, chose to lease 20 floors of space at a competing office building under construction four blocks away.
Sam Williams, an executive with the Portman Companies, acknowledged that the adverse publicity the company has received in recent days has hurt the company's efforts to lease space in the new center.
 
Additional Sales Ruled Out
Mr. Williams said the Portman Companies was not considering selling any additional holdings. ''There are no distress sales, no fire sales,'' he said. ''The properties are much too good. They are not weak enough for that to be considered.''
Mr. Portman's Shanghai complex of a hotel, stores, offices and apartments was set back last year when the Chinese Government cracked down on dissident students in Beijing. Earlier this year, a consortium of 19 banks agreed to allow Mr. Portman and his partners in the Shanghai development to defer payments on $145 million in loans for an additional three years, to January 1993.
Mr. Portman sold one of his hotels in San Francisco this spring for $103 million after last fall's earthquake severely cut tourism to the city.
Some economists say Mr. Portman could benefit from the announcement last month that Atlanta would be the site of the 1996 summer Olympic Games. The city's slumping construction industry will be buoyed by nearly $500 million in contracts for construction of new sports centers.

HEADLINE: House Fails to Overturn Bush Veto of Import Bill

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The House failed today to overturn President Bush's veto of a bill cutting imports of textiles, apparel and shoes.
The vote was 275 in favor of the override and 152 against, or 10 short of the two-thirds necessary to block the veto.
The failure to overturn the veto had been expected, signaled by the House's inability to get enough votes for an override when it passed the legislation last month. The vote nevertheless gave Mr. Bush a legislative victory at a time when his leadership has been undermined by confusion over budget policy. 
 
The Parties Split
The voting today showed Democrats as well as Republicans divided. Voting with the President were 103 Republicans and 49 Democrats, while 206 Democrats voted against the President, along with 69 Republicans.
''We have absolutely no chance to get into foreign markets if we unilaterally close our own markets,'' said the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski. The Illinois Democrat is a strong opponent of textile protection.
But Jamie L. Whitten, a Mississippi Democrat who heads the House Appropriations Committee, argued in support of the override motion. ''We're headed for a real recession in this country,'' he said, ''because we're letting everyone around the world have our domestic market.''
 
Whip Sides Against Bush
The Republican whip, Newt Gingrich, the No. 2 House Republican who led a successful fight last week against a budget agreement backed by the President, again opposed Mr. Bush, voting with the Georgia delegation to overturn the veto.
The action winds up the textile industry's third attempt in the last five years to get Congress to mandate trade restrictions.
Mr. Bush said the newest effort, cutting growth of textile and apparel imports to 1 percent a year and freezing footwear imports at 1989 levels, would not only increase clothing costs for consumers but also abrogate international agreements, destroying the Uruguay Round of global trade talks for freeing more trade.
 
'A Very Bad Bill'
''Of course, we're pleased that the veto has been sustained,'' said Torie Clarke, an aide to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills. ''It was a very bad bill, very protectionist and very damaging to U.S. efforts to achieve successful conclusion of the round.''
Joseph P. O'Neill, the president of the National Retail Federation, a trade organization based here, observed that ''American consumers today got the only good economic news they will hear this week.''
Despite Administration opposition, the House and the Senate had passed the measure in the last few months with large majorities. But the House vote came up short even then of the two-thirds needed to override any veto, which Mr. Bush had promised at the time.
The broad support reflected the geographical diversity of textile, apparel and shoe manufacturers and a vigorous lobbying campaign by the industry asserting that American jobs are being lost to low-wage foreign suppliers.
Sam M. Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means trade subcommittee, said during today's debate that the cost of textile protection was comparable to the losses from the savings and loan crisis.
According to the President's Council of Economic Advisers, the bill would cost consumers $30 billion over five years, with the burden falling most heavily on low- and middle-income Americans, since apparel and shoes make up such a high fraction of their household budget.
William R. Cline of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, estimates that textile trade restrictions already cost American consumers $20.3 billion a year, or $238 annually for every American household.
While the legislation might increase the number of textile jobs, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Michael J. Boskin, said in a letter to lawmakers last month that consumers would end up paying $70,000 for each job created.
Administration officials have also cited the textile and apparel industries' improving profitability, noting that domestic shipments rose nearly 7 percent in 1989 and exports were up 27 percent.
With the two earlier defeats of similar legislation, many trade officials and private analysts saw the new initiative as basically aimed at maneuvering for better leverage in the Uruguay Round, the final session of four-year trade talks that will be held in December in Brussels.
Textiles are one of the keys to a successful round. To get developing countries to commit to better protection of patents, copyrights and other intellectual property and to open markets for services, like insurance and tourism, the United States and other industrial countries have offered to gradually remove protection for textiles and apparel.

HEADLINE: A More Pessimistic View of Bank Deposit Insurance Fund

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
New projections by the Bush Administration show the fund insuring bank deposits shrinking to less than half its current size within three years, a senior House Banking Committee member said today.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's Bank Insurance Fund will lose $6.1 billion through the fiscal year 1993 even if the fees banks paid for deposit insurance rise, said Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois, citing projections by the Office of Management and Budget.
The new estimates are far more pessimistic than the budget office's previous projections. In June, the office had estimated that the F.D.I.C. would show a profit of $600 million over the period, Mr. Annunzio said. 
''The taxpayer is in serious jeopardy of being asked to bail out the banks,'' he said in disclosing what he characterized as ''little-noticed calculations'' by the budget office.
The new projections are in the budget agreement reached by White House negotiators and Congressional leaders on Sept. 30, he said.
 
'Pessimistic' Outlook
Roger Watson, the F.D.I.C.'s research director, said the figures as described by Mr. Annunzio ''certainly are pessimistic.''
''They are possible, but not likely,'' he said.
They show the insurance fund shrinking to $5.3 billion by Sept. 30, 1993, or to only 22 cents for every $100 in deposits. That is less than a fifth the $1.25 minimum considered safe and less than half the 60-cent level in the fund at the end of June.
''These O.M.B. projections are doubly alarming when you realize that they are based on economic assumptions that do not include a recession,'' said Mr. Annunzio, the chairman of the House Banking Financial Institutions Subcommittee.
The fund protecting $2 trillion in deposits stood at $11.4 billion at the end of June. By Sept. 30, 1991, it will have shrunk by $3.7 billion, according to the projections, Mr. Annunzio said. It will lose $2.3 billion in the fiscal year 1992 and $100 million in the fiscal year 1993.
 
Higher Premimums Included
The latest forecast of big losses is being made despite an assumption that insurance premiums paid by banks will continue to rise. The fee is already set to increase from 12 cents per $100 of deposits this year to 19.5 cents next year. The budget office assumed it would rise to 23 cents in 1992 and 1993.
The F.D.I.C. has not made projections for its fund beyond the end of the calendar year. The bank fund lost $1.8 billion in the first six months of the year and will lose $1 billion more by Dec. 31, the agency has said.
L. William Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., said this summer that the bank insurance fund was ''under stress'' but has said that it will be adequate to handle foreseeable bank failures, which are expected to total around 200 in 1990 for the fourth consecutive year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Layoffs by Hasbro

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Hasbro Inc., the nation's largest toy maker, said it had laid off 90 workers. Hasbro said it had made the cuts because of the ailing economy and its need to remain competitive. The company, which employs 8,000 worldwide, said administrative costs had grown at a greater rate than sales. The layoffs affected workers in marketing, research and development, sales and administration. Hasbro's shares fell 37.5 cents today, to $12.25, on the American Stock Exchange.
