HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Commodities Trader Starts His Own Firm

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Gene D. Donney, former president and chief executive of Elders Futures Inc., a commodity futures trading company, has set up his own commodities research and portfolio management firm and claims a unique status for it.
Mr. Donney, 37 years old, says his company, Pegasus Econometric Group, is the first in the industry to provide market research and analysis while not relying on brokerage commissions for revenue. ''We are doing something completely new,'' he said. ''Unbundling advice away from actual trading. We're out in front of the field.'' 
The firm is not executing trades, he said, ''because the economics are just not there; the commission rate is so low.'' That leaves Pegasus to focus ''on the success of the clients' trading strategies, not on the frequency of their transactions,'' Mr. Donney said.
Among those joining Mr. Donney are Peter C. Beutel, 35, an oil industry analyst who will head Pegasus's energy division, and Mr. Donney's brother, Randolph L. Donney, 30, who will head commodity research.
Gene Donney went to work in the commodities trading industry in 1976 after graduation from Fordham University and after deciding against pursuing a career playing the violin. ''Music was my primary interest from age 4 to 17,'' he said, and it took him to the Juilliard School, where he studied for a time.
Mr. Donney worked at Merrill Lynch and then Dean Witter and in 1985 went out on his own for two years as a money manager and consultant. One of his big clients was Elders IXL of Australia, which wanted to get into the futures business.
Mr. Donney helped the company buy a futures firm, Rudolf Wolff. ''We overhauled it, and it became very successful in the industry,'' he said.
But then Elders, a beer company that expanded rapidly in the 1980's, fell on hard times and was forced to divest itself of its financial businesses. Elders Futures Inc. was sold in May to Merrill Lynch.
Mr. Donney's brother and Mr. Beutel were at Elders and after its sale to Merrill Lynch worked at Merrill before joining Pegasus.
Along with commodity market research, Pegasus, based in Hoboken, N.J., offers fixed-income fund management and consulting for professional and institutional clients, Mr. Donney said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Decline Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved sharply lower and interest rates rose again yesterday, pushed by continuing concerns about the Middle East and the Federal budget as well as a disappointing auction of seven-year Treasury notes.
With the rise in interest rates over the last two sessions, traders had expected demand for the record $8.5 billion worth of new securities to be strong. That was not the case, though, and the notes were sold at an average yield of 8.76 percent, up from 8.57 percent at the last seven-year note sale on July 11. It is the highest yield on a seven-year note since the auction of April 12, 1989. 
''The auction was very sloppy,'' said Peter Bass, a managing director at S.G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''People thought rates were high enough for it to have had a better outcome than it did.''
The notes traded poorly after results of the auction were announced, and were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.79 percent.
The note sale provided the first opportunity to gauge how Washington's inability to come up with a budget package is being received by foreign investors.
 
American Fixed-Income Markets
Foreigners have been leaving American fixed-income markets in droves for much of the year, attracted by higher yields and more stable currencies elsewhere. Based on what happened at the auction yesterday, the continuing budget problem has provided another reason to stay away.
''There were absolutely no bids from Japan, which is ridiculous,'' Mr. Bass said. ''Normally you would see some bidding for a seven-year, but not this time.''
Mr. Bass said foreign investors were looking at the unfolding drama in Washington ''with disbelief.''
''People in Europe are becoming very pessimistic about our ability to manage our affairs,'' he said, ''and think that yields, irrespective of very weak economic activity, will rise.''
William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc., said demand from Japanese investors was ''nonexistent, continuing a trend we have seen.''
''We are hearing and seeing sensible people selling U.S. securities and buying foreign securities,'' he said.
Still, for domestic investors Mr. Brachfeld said the Treasury market was a ''screaming buy,'' primarily because of the weak American economy. ''But for foreigners with the option of buying anywhere, it is a sale,'' he said.
A decline in oil prices, which moved well below $40 a barrel yesterday, did not help to improve the market's gloomy mood. Nor did comments by Robert Glauber, the Treasury Department's Under Secretary for Finance.
Speaking to a business group in Washington, Mr. Glauber said that while rising oil prices might increase the possibility of a short-term economic contraction, a ''meaningful'' recession was not on the horizon.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, long-term issues bore the brunt of yesterday's selloff.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at 96 7/8, down nearly a point, or almost $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 9.05 percent. Late Tuesday, following a price drop of more than 1 1/2 points, the benchmark issue yielded 8.95 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 31/ 32 late yesterday, down 5/8 point, to yield 8.90 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, down 5/32, to yield 7.98 percent.
 
Short-Term Bill Rates
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.18 percent, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.20 percent.
In other developments, the Public Securities Association, an industry group, said yesterday that it expects to start the first phase of live dissemination of Government securities price information in mid-February.
The first phase will include information on all Treasury bills, notes and bonds, the P.S.A. said. The information will be disseminated on a 24-hour, global basis.
The P.S.A.'s action follows recommendations by various Government agencies and departments, incuding the General Accounting Office and the Securities and Exchange Commission, for wider availability of price information in the government securities market. Currently, only one government securities firm, Cantor Fitzgerald, provides the public with pricing information on computer screens.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by a competitive offering of $500 million worth of general obligation bonds by the State of California.
A bid from a group led by the Bank of America won the issue, which consists of serial and term bonds.
The serial bonds were preliminarily priced with yields from 5.91 percent on securities maturing in 1991, to 6.20 percent on bonds that mature in 1995 and 7.05 percent on securities that mature in 2005.
A term bond that matures in 2008 was offered on a preliminiary basis at a price to yield 7.10 percent. Term bonds maturing in 2009 and 2010 were not reoffered.
Investment bankers familiar with the deal said that demand for the issue was extremely strong. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most issues came under selling pressure again yesterday, and that prices fell by about 1/2 point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, according to participants.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Grain and Soybean Prices Off After Weather Forecast

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Corn futures were influenced by slack demand from overseas. They received some support from reports that the Soviets would eventually make a purchase.
Slack sales by farmers also lifted to corn prices.
Over all, the market was under pressure from forecasts that the rains of the last few days would be ending, allowing farmers to get on with the harvest, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago.
 
Crop Production Report Today
Trading was cautious in anticipation of today's release of the United States Agriculture Department's October crop production report.
Wheat was 1 cent to 3 1/2 cents lower, with delivery in December at $2.76 1/4 a bushel; corn was 1/2 cent to 1 1/2 cents higher, with December at $2.35 1/2 a bushel; oats were 1/2 to 1 cent higher, with December at $1.23 a bushel, and soybeans were 4 1/2 to 9 1/2 cents lower, with November at $6.25 a bushel.
Livestock and pork futures were lower in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Pork prices were under pressure from a drop in cash prices.
Slack demand for beef products pushed livestock futures lower. Analysts said the market was also under pressure from concerns that the United States economic outlook is weak.
Live cattle were 0.37 to 0.88 cent lower, with October at 79.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.25 to 0.85 cent lower, with October at 87.70 cents a pound; hogs were 0.15 to 0.50 cent lower, with October at 56.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.10 cents lower to 0.20 cent higher, with February at 63.40 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Survey Gives Magazines Edge vs. TV

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Magazine publishers winding up the three-day American Magazine Conference here got some good news today. Preliminary results of a reader survey show that in 8 of 10 households, at least one person buys and reads magazines.
The survey, which will be presented in final form at a meeting of the Audit Bureau of Circulations in November, also indicates that magazines outscore television and newspapers by at least 2 to 1 as the most effective source of overall knowledge. 
Those surveyed also indicated they preferred magazine advertising over television advertising as a more ''appealing, informative, believable and helpful'' buying guide, the survey said.
The survey's reference point was the 12,000 consumer magazines in this country.
 
Study of 978 Households
Personal interviews were conducted in 978 households in May by Audits and Surveys, an independent research company. The survey was financed by Publishers Clearing House. It was the sixth such survey of reader involvement since 1979 and the first comprehensive one since the original survey in 1976.
While it included no surprises, the survey provided publishers with some proof that magazines continue to be as important in these economically tough times as they have been insisting. Magazine publishers have been battling a downturn in advertising that has also been felt by newspaper publishers.
Statistics for the 173 consumer magazines tracked by the Publishers Information Bureau, for instance, show a 3.15 percent decline in advertising pages through August, compared with the same period last year. And an even larger decline, of 6.5 percent, was noted by the current Media Industry Newsletter for the 19 weekly magazines it has been tracking.
 
'No Basic Underlying Problem'
Donald D. Kummerfeld, president of the Magazine Publishers of America, one of the sponsors of the conference, was nevertheless cheered by the survey. ''It indicates no weakening at a time when people are questioning whether there is something basically wrong with the magazine industry,'' he said. ''This is heartening evidence that this recession is not aimed at the magazine industry and that there is no basic underlying problem from the consumer point of view.''
Among other preliminary results, the survey showed that the preference for magazines as a source of information was greatest in the upper socio-economic group, the group that most interests advertisers. Eight of 10 people surveyed said they felt there was too much advertising on television, compared with five of 10 who thought magazines had too much advertising. And those surveyed said they were more likely to pay attention to advertising in magazines than to advertising on television.
The respondents also said they were more apt to order a product by phone or mail after seeing a magazine advertisement than after seeing a television commercial.
 
Question on Car Ads
When it comes to advertising cars, the people surveyed indicated, magazines are twice as effective as television and considerably more effective than radio and newspapers. This finding was particularly true among people aged 25 to 54 who were better educated and either had professional or managerial jobs or were owners of their businesses.
In addition, 39 percent of respondents said they thought that magazines were the most effective medium for finding out about money matters, compared with 14 percent who thought television more effective and 47 percent who favored newspapers.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Senate Panel Approves a Major Cut in AIDS Relief for Cities

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
In a tangle that pitted one needy group against another, the Senate Appropriations Committee today approved less than 20 percent of the money authorized for disaster relief to the cities hardest hit by the AIDS epidemic.
''We have arrived at a point that we were afraid we were going to arrive at, where people in need are fighting one another for too few resources,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.
Anguished statements were heard from senators seeking more money for AIDS and from those seeking to avoid cuts in other health programs, from cancer and cystic fibrosis to Head Start in the schools.
In May, the Senate voted 95 to 4 to approve $2.9 billion over five years for cities hard hit by AIDS and for states to distribute to community groups and home-care programs that help AIDS patients. The House authorized somewhat more money in a parallel bill. 
 
Final Amount Yet to Be Set
Both chambers authorized $875 million in the first year of the program. But the Senate committee today voted to appropriate only $159 million. Of that, $110 million is for continuing programs in the states, and $49 million is new money in relief to the cities. The House is expected to appropriate money for the bill next week, and Senate aides expect the Senate to approve the lower amounts in a floor vote soon. A conference between the two houses is to determine the final amounts sometime before Oct. 19, when Congress is set to adjourn.
The vote today by the Senate panel is crucial because it set budget restraints on the AIDS measure. The bill may gain money in conference but is expected to remain far below the amounts authorized by the two houses earlier this year.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, objected to the situation, saying that defense programs have increased $756 billion over the past decade while domestic programs increased only $14 billion. ''It's like the runt pig,'' he said. ''It's hard for him to get up and stay alive when he's deprived of his fair share.''
 
Robbing Peter
The crucial vote came after Senator Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, offered an amendment to gather the money for AIDS disaster relief by cutting nine-tenths of 1 percent from all the health programs that were set to get increases above inflation for 1991.
''We have a disaster in this country, which the Senate has voted 95 to 4 as being a disaster,'' he said. ''The public health systems in the country are breaking down.'' He compared the money needed to the emergency money given to San Francisco for the earthquake there or the Carolinas for Hurricane Hugo.
Senator Ted Stevens, Democrat of Alaska, said it would be unfair to cut across the board and that supporters of the AIDS measure should instead find specific programs to cut to raise the money for AIDS.
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, agreed. ''There has been an enormous increase in other AIDS funding this year,'' he said. ''Now we are talking about taking money away from cancer, heart disease, childhood immunization, diabetes, arthritis. In fact, this will also take money away from AIDS, from research programs at the National Institutes of Health.'' He said that although he voted for the AIDS bill, he could not cut money from other programs for it.
 
Many Programs, Little Money
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, spoke in support of the Adams amendment. ''This is not research,'' he said. ''This is treatment money. These people are going to die, and we want to treat them with some dignity as they leave the earth.''
But Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said too many programs were authorized by the Senate for which no money can be found. ''It's like calling the spirits from the briny depths,'' he said. ''You can call them and I can call them, but will they come?''
The amendment was finally defeated on a voice vote.
Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, then offered the package that was approved, appropriating $159 million for 1991 and $441 million for the 1992 fiscal year. The $441 million becomes part of next year's base budget and requires no further action to be spent.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he was disappointed with the turn of the bill, which is named after Ryan White, the hemophiliac who died of AIDS in April when he was 18 years old.
''I recognize there are serious budget restraints,'' the Senator said, ''but this inadequate level of funding is a deep disappointment. The real tragedy is for those people with AIDS in desperate need of treatment and care who do not have time to wait.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
In a Worried Economy, Impasse Adds to Unease

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The budget stalemate, coinciding with the Persian Gulf confrontation, is worsening the economic slump and increasing the chances of another jolt to the financial markets, various analysts say.
Wall Street and business executives have long had low expectations for Government fiscal policy - the political difficulties of, say, scaling back increases in Social Security are immense - but the defeat last week of a budget plan is seen as a particularly discouraging sign.
''We are sick and tired of Washington,'' commented Rimmer deVries, chief economist for J. P. Morgan & Company. ''It's the same spectacle of inaction.'' 
 
Dealing With a Giant
In strict economic terms, the Government's inability to put in place a spending-and-taxing blueprint for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 is of small consequence. A few score billion dollars of tax increases and spending cuts should not cause a significant change in the course of a $5.4 trillion-a-year economy. And regarding future years, there is strong skepticism that any budget targets will actually be met.
Psychologically, however, the stalemate has had a marked impact, even though most analysts consider the Persian Gulf crisis, which has sent the price of oil soaring above $40 a barrel, to be even more important for the immediate future.
''If Washington continues to play games with the budget, we're likely to see a very serious risk in the financial markets of another October crash,'' said Jay N. Woodworth, a senior economist at the Bankers Trust Company and a former Treasury Department official. He added that ''budgetary drift'' was one factor contributing to the 1987 market debacle.
Congress's rejection of the agreement reached at the budget summit meeting and announced in the Rose Garden 10 days ago also makes it highly unlikely that there will be immediate economic stimulus through the Federal Reserve. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has said for some time that he will cut interest rates once a credible long-term plan to reduce the budget deficit is adopted.
 
More Delays Expected
With the immobilization of the Federal Reserve, which in recent years has by default come to dominate economic policy making, a budget deal is being viewed as more crucial and more elusive by the markets, by business executives and by many consumers. Many now believe, in fact, that no agreement can occur until after the elections in early November.
To the extent the budgetary impasse undermines confidence and aggravates recession, the budget deficit will grow even further, analysts note. Recession implies both lower tax revenue and higher spending for unemployment compensation and other benefits.
Yet it remains unclear how much short-term benefit even a solid-looking budget plan would provide. For one thing, Mr. Greenspan has indicated that even though a credible agreement is a precondition for easing monetary policy, passage of such a plan will not make action automatic.
The budget stalemate represents ''another element of uncertainty that is hitting the economy,'' said Howard Keen, chief economist for Conrail. He said the situation called for paying even more attention to a variety of ''downside risks,'' which analysts say include an increasingly shaky financial structure, heavy debt loads and plunging consumer confidence.
 
Big Role for Oil Prices
The jump in oil prices, while possibly short-lived, is gradually becoming embedded in many costs - though not yet in labor - and putting upward pressure on inflation. A skidding dollar, another source of inflation, may also cause the Federal Reserve to hesitate in its easing or be grudging in the amount of relief it grants.
Mr. Greenspan almost certainly will not instantly drive rates down even if he sees a deal that meets his test of a credible and enforceable deficit reduction. Rather, the Federal Reserve would wait for the bond market to drive down long-term rates, which Mr. Greenspan has observed are the ones that really count for economic reinvigoration. Only after the market acts would the central bank then bless the process by cutting short-term rates.
Long-term rates, which climbed back above the 9 percent level today, are governed mainly by market expectations for inflation. Short-term rates, over which the Fed has considerable control, are relatively immune to inflation pressures and are set by the supply and demand for temporary credit.
Even with a lower structure of interest rates, however, there is no certainty that borrowers would feel confident enough about the economic outlook to seek the loans and do the spending that would eventually help revive the economy.
On one point, though, economists and market professionals - though not the politicians - are in broad agreement: If Mr. Greenspan tries to cut rates before a budget agreement is enacted, the result would be a highly counterproductive rise in interest rates.
''That would be taken,'' declared Mr. Woodworth of Bankers Trust, ''as one gigantic negative signal - a caving-in by the Federal Reserve'' to the forces of inflation.

HEADLINE: Chemical Bank Cuts Its Dividend As Bad Real Estate Loans Sour

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Chemical Banking Corporation announced a sharp cut in its stock dividend yesterday and a loss for the third quarter, joining a growing list of large banking companies whose problems with real estate loans have led to reduced payments to shareholders.
By cutting its dividend payments, Chemical will save $44 million a year, conserving those funds as additional capital. Greater amounts of capital provide more of a cushion for banks to absorb losses, and many analysts expect the industry's losses to grow as the economy weakens further and more borrowers default on their loans.
Chemical, the holding company for the nation's sixth-largest bank, announced a loss of $43.7 million in the third quarter, primarily because it set aside $250 million in a reserve for loan losses. Most of the increase in its troubled loans came from commercial real estate projects like office buildings in the Northeast. 
''Nobody in banking knows the extent of the risk of falling real estate prices,'' said Judah Kraushaar, a banking analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
 
Strategies for a Downturn
Analysts expect several other banking companies to cut their dividend payments in the months ahead. In addition, many banks will deal with the harsh operating climate by curbing their lending activities and pulling out of less profitable businesses.
Large banking companies whose dividends are vulnerable to cuts include Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover, Bank of New York and First Chicago, analysts said. The move to cut dividends has been most common on the East Coast, where weakness in the real estate market has spread southward from New England.
Moreover, signs of weakness in California real estate have led to concerns about banks in that state, many of which have been big lenders to developers.
Companies that have recently cut dividends - an action that in past years was rare among banks - include Chase Manhattan; Midlantic and First Fidelity in New Jersey and Southeast Banking in Miami. In New England, dividends have been cut or eliminated at Bank of Boston, Shawmut and Bank of New England.
The dividend cuts have come as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has repeatedly declared that he wants to strengthen the banking system by requiring large banks to accumulate more capital. Increasing the capital cushion in the banking system should also limit the losses of the banking industry's government-run insurance fund.
''It's a clear shift in Fed policy,'' said Walter V. Shipley, the chairman of Chemical. ''The Fed did not tell us to cut our dividend but it's clear to me that the more capital we have got, the more relaxed the Fed will be about what we can do.''
The Federal Reserve has not said when or how much it will raise capital requirements for banks. The current capital standards are to be replaced by the end of 1992 with a system that calls for capital equal to 8 percent of assets, adjusted for the risk in the assets. Some analysts have predicted that the Fed may want banks to have capital equal to 10 percent of their assets, adjusted for risk.
Chemical is already in compliance with an 8 percent standard, but Mr. Shipley said that adding to capital would give the company greater flexibility to expand its most profitable businesses. He said that cutting the dividend was the fastest, most efficient way to raise capital at a time when prices of bank stocks are extremely low and interest rates on bank bonds are extremely high.
Chemical's stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $14.75, down 25 cents on the day, and far below the $31.25 at which it issued 16.1 million new shares a year ago. Long-term bonds of Chemical have been trading recently with interest rates of 14 percent; by comparison, Treasury bonds are yielding slightly more than 9 percent.
The quarterly dividend for the company's biggest class of common stock was cut to 25 cents, from 68 cents. For series B stock issued in the late 1980's in exchange for shares of Texas Commerce Bancshares, the dividend was cut to 7 cents, from 19 cents.
A sharp rise in Chemical's reserves for loan losses was needed because the level of domestic loans on which interest is not being paid or that are considered troubled increased to $1.7 billion, up $222 million in the past three months. Chemical forecast that in the current quarter it would add $100 million to $125 million to its loss reserves, and that its holdings of troubled loans would rise, but to a level not much different from what it was at the end of last year.
In last year's third quarter, Chemical posted a loss of $824.6 million, reflecting large additions to its loss reserves for loans to third world countries and problems with its Texas Commerce unit.
Mr. Shipley said Chemical is not planning a new program to reduce its payroll. The company is in the last stages of a previously announced plan to cut 1,300 workers. Since 1987, it has reduced its work force by 3,800 employees, to 27,200.
 
Profit at Bank of New York
Bank of New York also reported its quarterly results yesterday. Real estate loans and loans to highly indebted corporations were a problem, though not enough to prevent a third- quarter profit. The company earned $70.6 million, or 90 cents a share, in the quarter. In the comparable period last year, Bank of New York lost $271.3 million as it set aside reserves to cover a large portion of its loans to developing countries.
In this year's third quarter, the bank set aside an additional $113 million for loan losses. Its holdings of loans that were not paying interest or facing serious trouble rose $139 million, to $1.475 billion. Loans to highly indebted companies, a sector in which Bank of New York is very active, declined to $4.47 billion, from $4.7 billion.
Although Bank of New York does not yet satisfy the 8 percent capital standard that becomes effective at the end of 1992, it has not tried to solve the problem by reducing its dividend. Earlier this week it announced that the quarterly stock dividend would be unchanged at 53 cents. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Bank of New York shares lost 62.5 cents to close at $17.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
New Budget Ideas Offered as Tug-of-War Goes On

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The budget impasse grew even more complex today as Congressional Democrats and Republicans pushed rival plans, and conflicting statements at the White House added to the air of confusion.
Democrats in the House of Representatives tonight unveiled a plan that would sharply increase taxes on wealthy Americans. That plan threatened to disrupt a new round of negotiations involving the White House and both parties in the Senate that had seemed to be making headway toward a budget agreement.
The Democratic majority on the House Ways and Means Committee approved a proposal calling for a 33 percent tax rate on income above a certain level, affecting the richest segment of the population, and a 10 percent surtax on individuals with taxable annual incomes exceeding $1 million. Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the committee's Democratic chairman, described the plan as an effort to ''restore fairness to our tax system,'' but Mr. Bush said he ''cannot accept'' it. 
 
'We Have Made Progress'
Earlier, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, had predicted that both houses of Congress would pass and President Bush would sign an agreement before the stopgap spending measure expires a week from Friday. He said the odds were 100 to 1 against its including either a capital gains cut or an increase in income tax rates for the rich.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, met with Mr. Dole, Finance Committee leaders and Richard G. Darman, the budget director. ''We believe we have made progress,'' Mr. Mitchell said afterward. The President himself had also expressed optimism about an early budget settlement. But it was not clear how rapid progress could be made with the House Democrats pulling one way and Mr. Bush and his allies pulling the other. With Capitol Hill racing to seize the initiative after two days of faltering White House leadership, the situation was in turmoil.
 
Where to Find Money
To cut the deficit by $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years, some lawmakers predict a mix of tax increases and spending cuts, similar to the one in the original budget agreement that was rejected by the House of Representatives on Oct. 5. This could include an increase in gasoline taxes, as well as taxes on alcoholic beverages, tobacco and luxury items, combined with cuts in some domestic programs.
The new measure would probably raise Medicare premiums, but in a way that seems more palatable to lawmakers than in the deficit-reduction deal rejected last week. New cuts may strike at farm programs and other domestic measures.
Mr. Rostenkowski's plan, which may ultimately include a very limited cut in the capital gains tax, would almost certainly be opposed by Senate Democrats, who have a narrower majority and tend to be somewhat more moderate, when the bills passed by the two Houses go to conference for resolution. But if he can mobilize the large Democratic majority in the House behind his proposals, that momentum could well force the Senate to agree to some sort of tax increase upon wealthy people.
 
Political Hobson's Choice
Democratic strategists said Mr. Bush would then be faced just before the Nov. 6 elections with either signing a bill that imposed higher taxes than he wants or vetoing it and facing partisan attack as the patron of the privileged.
After another muddled day at the White House, during which President Bush's position seemed even less clear for a time than in two previous days of complete confusion, aides to the President said he hoped that the final settlement would closely resemble the one that was worked out by bipartisan negotiators over the last four and a half months, only to be rejected last week by the House of Representatives.
Mr. Bush's position, as explained by the President himself and a number of aides, seemed to have boiled down to this:
In principle, the trade would be fine, but the Democrats will not give us a capital gains rate as low as we want, and we won't give the Democrats an income tax rate as high as they want, so we had better leave those topics alone and push ahead on the rest of the deal.
Speaking in an interview during a break in intensive compromise talks, Mr. Dole suggested that Mr. Bush would get something close to what he wanted, with ''the edges smoothed off'' the original package. The smoothing, he said, would include reduced cuts in Medicare, a smaller increase in the gasoline tax and the elimination of a tax on heating oil.
 
Dole Predicts Agreement
Mr. Dole conceded that the politics of the situation ''aren't at all good for us, short range.'' But he said that if a deal was concluded - ''and we're very close to it, unless I'm blind'' - the issue would fade quickly. Then, Mr. Dole said, ''the President will get some credit, and the Congress will get some credit - mostly the President, I suppose, that's the way it always is around here.''
Like other Republicans, the Kansan said it was politically imperative that their party not seem to favor the rich.
In the House, Representative Steve Gunderson, a Republican, said he was ''sick and tired of going home to rural Wisconsin and protecting the Republican Party'' against charges that it belongs to the rich.
 
How the Day Began
The day began with Mr. Bush, who had seemed to waver between opposing and conditionally endorsing higher tax rates during the last 48 hours, meeting with House Republican leaders. Unlike their Senate counterparts, who want no changes at all in the income tax, the House Republican leaders supported a plan put forward by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, a senior Republican member of the House Ways and Means Committee.
That plan would increase from 28 percent to 31 percent the overall income tax rates for the wealthiest Americans, provided that the tax on capital gains - profits from the sales of stocks, real estate and other assets - fell to 15 percent from 28.
Standing in the White House driveway, Mr. Archer said the President had bought his idea. ''He said, without equivocation, this is what we wanted to do,'' Mr. Archer said.
But first Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, and then Mr. Bush himself threw cold water on the idea. While acknowledging that he liked Mr. Archer's approach, the President made it clear that he could not accept Democratic proposals that would step up the tax rate for the richest taxpayers to 33 percent, rather than 31, and grant a smaller capital gains cut than Mr. Bush wants.
''My view is that it's not going to happen, and we ought to move forward on another approach,'' he told a group of Republican lawmakers in the afternoon. ''I think it's just a waste of time because it's not going to get through both houses of Congress.''
 
'The Clock's Running Out'
''There just isn't a deal there,'' said Mr. Darman in a similar vein. ''The clock's running out. We ought to put those issues aside.''
On Wednesday, the Ways and Means Committee approved a bare-bones bill that is unacceptable to both Republicans and Democrats - a shell meant to be crushed. Republicans dislike it because it has no ''growth incentives,'' such as a capital gains cut, and the Democrats don't like it because it contains regressive tax increases and other measures that would hurt the middle class.
Mr. Rostenkowski plans to bring it to the floor under a rule that will allow only two amendments - one sponsored by the Republicans and the other by the Democrats. The Democrats on Ways and Means approved part of theirs tonight.
Among other things, the Rostenkowski proposal would do the following:
* Create a 33 percent tax bracket for individuals with taxable income over $113,460 and couples with taxable income over $193,190. They now pay 28 percent. The richest 1 million to 1.5 million people would be affected.
* Impose a 10 percent surtax on people with incomes over $1 million, making their effective rate 36.3 percent.
* Raise the alternative minimum tax rate, which applies to individuals with so many deductions, exemptions and exclusions that they would otherwise avoid taxes, to 25 percent from 21 percent.
* Delay for one year the indexing of tax brackets for inflation.
* Increase the wage base for the Medicare tax to $100,000 from $51,300.
* Raise the gasoline tax by 3 cents a gallon. (The budget ''summit agreement'' called for a 12-cent increase.)
* Impose a luxury tax on expensive cars, private planes, boats, jewelry and furs.
* Raise taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.
* Increase the earned income tax credit available to the working poor.
* Keep the monthly Medicare premium (insurance against doctors' bills) at $29.90 in 1991, same as the current law, and raise it at a pace slower than the expected rate of inflation over the following four years; raise the deductible to $100 a year from $75, more generous than the summit agreement.
 
The Poor Would Benefit
Altogether, this would lower the taxes of the poorest 20 percent of taxpayers. Others would get a slight tax increase, in the 1.5 to 2.7 percent range. The wealthiest 1 percent of the population (after-tax income above about $400,000) would see their taxes increased by 6.8 percent.
Mr. Bush's aides said that the three points on which he was not prepared to budge were: that the overall budget goal of $500 billion in deficit reduction within five years must be achieved; that the balance between spending cuts and tax increases, contained in the original budget summit agreement must not be altered, and that defense spending must not be further curtailed.
''If someone wants to cut agriculture more and Medicare less, O.K.,'' one Presidential adviser said.
The same adviser commented that, after his long Washington experience, the President feels ''that things sometimes go down once or twice to defeat, but that they come back, eventually, and can be adopted more or less the same, and he'd like to see the summit plan adopted more or less the same.''

HEADLINE: Church Leaders Voice Doubts on U.S. Gulf Policy

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders are beginning to raise moral questions about American policy in the Persian Gulf, edging away from the general support they voiced for it two months ago and opening up a gap with their Jewish counterparts.
Virtually all American religious groups have condemned President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait and continue to support the economic embargo aimed at forcing him to withdraw Iraqi forces. But in recent weeks many church leaders have warned against further military actions, against including food and medical supplies in the embargo, against a long-term American military presence in the gulf and against a way of life at home that leaves the nation so dependent on Middle Eastern oil.
They have also argued that a resolution of the gulf crisis demands steps toward settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, linkage that the Administration and Jewish leaders disavow. 
If this attitude runs counter to the historic tendency of churches to bless the weapons and the war aims of their governments, it fits with a strong pacifist strand in American Christianity that flourished after World War I, died down with the war against Hitler and the Cold War, and has been reinvigorated in the years since Vietnam.
Church leaders' questioning of America's gulf policy still falls short of outright opposition, and no one knows how widely these concerns are shared by average clergy members. But the movement is not limited to the traditional peace churches like the Quakers or to antiwar groups.
Last month the generally liberal National Council of Churches, which brings together 32 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches, spelled out many of these strictures on United States policy in a long resolution.
The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles, Roger M. Mahony, who is chairman of the Catholic bishops' international policy committee, told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that Iraqi civilians should not be deprived of ''essentials,'' especially food and medicine, by the economic sanctions. The United Nations embargo allows Iraq to acquire as much food, medicine and medical spare parts as it needs, so long as it meets United Nations conditions.
Several influential Catholic moralists sharply condemned the statement by Gen. Michael J. Dugan that led to his dismissal as Air Force Chief of Staff: that ''the cutting edge'' of American military plans would be heavy bombing of ''downtown Baghdad.''
 
The Quiet Evangelicals
Perhaps more suprising, leaders of conservative evangelical churches, often a source of vocal support for American military intervention, have instead been subdued, either echoing some of the same cautions or simply appealing for prayer.
At a news conference here today, some Protestant and Catholic church leaders went further. Calling the gulf policy precipitate and dangerous, they urged withdrawal of American troops in favor of a multinational force and proposed a mobilization of public opinion to oppose any heightening of the conflict. ''The alleged national consensus of support for U.S. policy must be disrupted,'' said Jim Wallis, editor of the radical evangelical magazine Sojourners, which was the conference's sponsor.
Other participants were Edmond L. Browning, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church; Thomas Gumbleton, Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Detroit, who heads Pax Christi, a Catholic peace group; Bishop Dale White of the United Methodist Church in New York; Patricia Rumer, general director of Church Women United, an interdenominational group; the Rev. James Forbes, senior pastor of the Riverside Church in Manhattan, and Joan Campbell, director of the American office of the World Council of Churches.
They criticized American policy, saying it relied on military power rather than diplomacy. Several contrasted the willingness to spend money on the Persian Gulf buildup with the limits on health and housing programs discussed in the current budget negotiations.
Between this stance and that of other church leaders is a complicated overlay of agreement and disagreement. The Rev. J. Bryan Hehir, for example, an adviser to the Catholic bishops on international affairs, calls the deployment of the forces in Saudi Arabia ''justified politically and morally.''
Writing in the coming issue of Commonweal, a liberal biweekly edited by Catholic lay people, Father Hehir says that by deterring further Iraqi aggression, the rapid deployment forestalled war and provided time for diplomacy and economic sanctions to work.
But the priest, who also teaches ethics and international affairs at Georgetown University, argues strongly against a military effort to liberate Kuwait, saying it would risk destruction out of proportion to any legitimate gains. ''War undertaken to vindicate state boundaries in the Middle East,'' he writes, ''could end by erasing most of the borders which today define the region.''
 
Threat of a 'Sawdust Hitler'
Though they disagree on the military deployment in Saudi Arabia, Bishop Gumbleton and Father Hehir forcefully condemn the idea of air attacks on Iraqi cities. Both say Catholic moral teaching would require believers to refuse orders to engage in carpet bombing or other direct attacks on civilians.
A wide range of Orthodox, Conservative and Reform Jewish rabbis and lay leaders have voiced strong support for the Administration's actions in the gulf. They, too, say they prefer a multinational force. But they support military action if necessary to counter what Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler called the ''real, immediate and ongoing'' threat posed by a ''sawdust Hitler.'' Rabbi Schindler is president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the association of Reform synagogues.
Unlike many Christian leaders, Jewish spokesmen argue that Iraq's threat to its neighbors demonstrates that the conflict between Palestinians and Israelis conflict is not the main threat to peace in the region.
Staff members at the National Association of Evangelicals, the largest association of evangelical Protestant churches, say their leaders have been conspicuously quiet about the Gulf crisis. Brian O'Connell, who directs the association's educational program on international issues, said this silence might reflect tacit support for the Government's military policy, but might also reflect evangelical leaders' awareness that their members are divided.
 
A Call for Prayers
In August, the Rev. Billy Graham, the most respected of evangelical preachers, called the situation in the gulf ''potentially one of the most dangerous threats to world peace and stability since World War II'' and called for prayers. In late September, he called the crisis ''far more sinister and far more difficult'' than the conflicts in Korea and Vietnam.
Christianity Today, the leading evangelical weekly, will publish its first comment on the crisis on Oct. 22. The editorial issues no policy prescriptions but warns strongly against anti-Arab feelings: ''When international disputes escalate to this extent, the church has a special responsibility to douse the flames of hatred.''

HEADLINE: Ozone Hole Reopens Over Antarctica

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
A gaping hole in earth's protective ozone layer has again opened over Antarctica, and scientists reported yesterday that the depletion of ozone there seemed to be nearly as severe as it was in the worst previous years, 1987 and 1989.
This is the first time a severe Antarctic ozone hole has developed in two successive years, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
Scientists worry about such holes because they imply increasing health hazards throughout the world. Ordinarily, a layer of ozone in the stratosphere prevents a dangerous form of ultraviolet radiation from the sun from reaching the earth. 
But in recent years, synthetic chemicals called chlorofluorocarbons released into the air by various human activities have reached the stratosphere, where they break apart and destroy ozone. As a result, increasing amounts of dangerous radiation reach the ground, prompting fears of an epidemic of skin cancer and cataracts, and damage to crops, notably soybeans.
 
Extent Is Unknown
The exact geographic extent and overall depletion of ozone in this year's hole have not yet been determined, but Dr. David J. Hofmann, an aeronomist at the University of Wisconsin, said that balloon-borne instruments have found no ozone at all in a layer of atmosphere between 9.3 and 10.8 miles above the Antarctic continent. But above this level some ozone appears to remain, he said.
Aeronomists are not yet sure whether this trace of high-altitude ozone extends over the whole continent, but if it does, this year's ozone depletion may be somewhat less severe than that of 1987, the worst year on record.
Dr. Mark Schoeberl of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center said the minimum value of the ozone shield over Antarctica this year fell to 123 Dobson units on Oct. 4. Dobson units are a measure of the ability of the atmosphere to absorb certain wavelengths of light, especially in the ultraviolet range. When the ozone layer was intact, normal readings above Antarctica reached 500 Dobson units. In 1987 and 1989 they fell to about 115.
''An Antarctic ozone hole in 1990 comes as a surprise to some scientists,'' Dr. Schoeberl said.
 
Monitored Since 1979
Seasonal Antarctic ozone depletion has been monitored since 1979 using NASA's Total Ozone Mapping Spectrometer, an instrument carried by the Nimbus-7 satellite. Its measurements are supplemented by ground-based instruments that measure the intensity of ultraviolet radiation reaching the ground, and by high-altitude balloons launched from Antarctica by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Each time the ozone hole has occurred since its first appearance in 1987, it has appeared in late August -early spring in the Southern Hemisphere - and dispersed in early October. Many scientists believed that the holes occur in odd-numbered years but are apt to be less severe or nonexistent in even-numbered years.
An exception was Dr. James K. Angel of Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Air Resources Laboratory in Silver Spring, Md., who published a paper predicting that this year's hole would be severe. Dr. Hofmann said yesterday that this year's hole appears to confirm Dr. Angel's prediction and the theory underlying it.
Dr. Angel said in a telephone interview that while most investigators based their predictions about the Antarctic ozone hole on calculations derived from wind patterns in the stratosphere, his own calculations were based more on temperature patterns in the stratosphere. In June through August, the temperature of the stratosphere was higher than normal, and so were temperatures at the surface. This coincidence, Dr. Angel said, led to his unorthodox prediction of an ozone hole this year, published last month in the journal Geophysical Research Papers.
 
World Accord on a Halt
Seasonal ozone depletion over Antarctica - and a less severe depletion in the high Arctic - concern scientists because they imply a thinning of the ozone layer throughout the world. Worried leaders of most of the world's governments have agreed that chlorofluorocarbon production and use must be halted, but even if the phasing-out of these chemicals proceeds on schedule, the ozone layer will remain severely depleted well into the next century.
On June 29, senior government leaders from more than 90 nations agreed in London to hasten the halt in global production and use of chlorofluorocarbons. Joining the agreement were China and India, which had previously declined to curb the chemicals. Their change followed agreement by the United States and other Western nations to contribute to an international fund intended to relieve the economic burden imposed on the third world by a ban.
Chlorofluorocarbons have many important applications, especially as refrigerant gases in refrigerators and air conditioners, and as foaming agents in insulating plastic materials.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 12 about the ozone "hole" over Antarctica misstated an affiliation of Dr. David J. Hofmann. He is a faculty member, on leave, at the University of Wyoming, not the University of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: North Korea Releases 2 Japanese; 'Humanitarian' Gesture Is Praised

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 11

 BODY:
North Korea today released two Japanese sailors seized as spies seven years ago, prompting Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other Japanese politicians to praise the totalitarian Government in Pyongyang for its ''humanitarian consideration.''
The freeing of the two sailors, though widely expected, was seen as a significant gesture of conciliation that helped clear the way for talks between Japan and North Korea aimed at eventually restoring diplomatic relations after 45 years of hostility.
The release was foreshadowed last month during discussions in Pyongyang between President Kim Il Sung of North Korea and a delegation of political leaders that apparently marked a shift in North Korea's generally antagonistic attitude toward Japan.
The two sailors, Isamu Beniko and Yoshio Kuriura, the skipper and chief engineer of a Japanese freighter, were seized on espionage charges in 1983, apparently in retaliation against the defection of a North Korean soldier who had stowed away aboard a Japanese vessel stopping in North Korea. 
 
Limits on Sailors' Remarks
The two Japanese sailors were later sentenced to 15 years of hard labor, and their release has been a persistent demand by Tokyo as a prerequisite to improving relations with Pyongyang.
The sailors returned home amid intense public attention, accompanied by Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, and Takako Doi, chairwoman of the Japan Socialist Party. At Haneda Airport, they had an emotional reunion with their families before going for medical checkups.
Japanese news reports said the final release was made possible when Miss Doi and Mr. Ozawa, normally political opponents, agreed to work out a joint statement expressing thanks to North Korea's governing Korean Workers Party for their release.
The news accounts also said that North Korea had sought Japanese assurances that the two sailors would refrain from criticism of their treatment to avoid disrupting coming negotiations, but that Mr. Ozawa rejected such proposals.
 
U.S. Role in Koreas
Despite the release of the sailors, diplomats say a difficult road lies ahead for efforts to improve relations between North Korea and Japan. A senior Japanese official said Tokyo wanted to make sure that its efforts did not undercut the recent efforts by South Korea to reduce its own tensions with its northern neighbor.
North and South Korea had a breakthrough in their traditionally hostile relations last month, with the first meeting of their Prime Ministers. The second round of talks is scheduled for next week in Pyongyang.
Neither side has altered its longstanding position, and North Korea continues to demand the expulsion of American troops and a ban on American nuclear weapons in the region as a prerequisite for improved relations.
A close reading of the joint statement from North Korea and Japan last month indicated to some Japanese diplomats that North Korea also wants Tokyo to endorse its call for removing the American presence, including nuclear weapons, from the region.
 
Overtures to Adversaries
Japanese officials say that if such demands prove to be the position of Pyongyang in actual negotiations, they cannot be accepted. But Japan has signaled its willingness to apologize to North Korea for its past colonization of the Korean peninsula and to come up with a large package of financial assistance.
There have been reports in the press that in the second round of talks the South Korean Government of President Roh Tae Woo may make its own conciliatory gesture, like releasing anti-Government leftist dissidents in South Korea.
North Korea has begun in recent months to reach out to its former adversaries as its two most important patrons, the Soviet Union and China, have begun to improve ties with South Korea. This month, South Korea and the Soviet Union announced that they would establish diplomatic relations.
North Korea is generally believed to be reaching out for help for its sagging economy, which has sputtered along at about a 3 percent growth rate a year, compared with 9 percent a year for South Korea.

HEADLINE: Quebec Indians Ponder True Cost of Electricity

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREAT WHALE, Quebec, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Chief Robbie Dick has seen the future and he wants no part of it. Neither do most of the 500 Cree Indians he represents in this remote northern Quebec village on the eastern shore of Hudson Bay.
To the Cree Indians in Great Whale, the future may mean an end to the hunting, trapping and fishing that have defined their way of life for 5,000 years. Traditions are already eroding, particularly among the young, as contacts with white society grow. The Crees put the blame on one of Canada's most powerful companies: Hydro-Quebec.
The giant utility, owned by the province, wants to expand its hydroelectric operations in northern Quebec dramatically by building dams on the Great Whale River, a focus of Cree life. Hydro-Quebec contemplates flooding several hundred square miles and altering the flow of 300 miles of wild river, actions conservationists say would cut out the ecological heart of a rocky region the size of Massachusetts, Vermont and New Hampshire. 
''It's very hard to explain to white people what we mean by 'Land is part of our life,' '' Chief Dick said. ''We're like rocks and trees. We know we're running out of time.''
But there is more at stake than preserving the traditions of several hundred Indians. Electricity rates in New York and New England are also involved.
 
Rise in Rates Hinted
New York State and New England utilities are eager for Hydro-Quebec to expand so they can be assured the Canadian utility will have enough surplus power to sell them. The Northeastern utilities, which have had contracts with Hydro-Quebec since the 1970's, say buying the Canadian electricity is cheaper than building new power plants. If such purchases are not made, electric rates in the Northeast could rise, they assert.
What the Cree and the 400 members of the other indigenous population here, the Eskimos, fear most is the loss of the land on which their culture is built. Many were born in the bush and continue to spend months at a time there, hunting and fishing the same expanse of lakes, black spruce and caribou moss that their ancestors inhabited.
Aided by environmentalists, the Crees are fighting Hydro-Quebec's expansion plans in Federal and provincial courts and through a public relations campaign.
Hydro-Quebec, which had hoped to complete work in 1998, also faces government environmental reviews that could delay construction for several years. In the meantime, the company wants to start building a 100-mile-long road north to Great Whale next year, but that also faces an environmental review.
Great Whale would be constructed north of Hydro-Quebec's La Grande complex, already one of the world's largest hydroelectric projects. Another hydroelectric project, called Nottaway-Broadback-Rupert, is planned south of La Grande. The combined expansion would add 41 percent to the utility's generating capacity. Expansion is necessary, the utility says, because Quebec's energy demand is growing quickly.
 
'It's All Under Water'
The La Grande River, which powers the huge complex's turbines, empties into James Bay, the fingertip jutting from Hudson Bay that has become identified with Hydro-Quebec's Northern Quebec push. Since construction of La Grande got under way more than 15 years ago, Cree and Inuit leaders say, the native communities and environment have changed for the worse.
''The Cree life was more at ease before the coming of the white man,'' John Petagumskum, a 70-year-old Great Whale resident, said through a translator.
Reservoir creation eliminated or disrupted many traditional hunting and trapping grounds, the Crees say. In Chisasibi, near La Grande, many Crees can't go back to where their ancestors used to hunt. ''It's all under water,'' said Matthew Coon Come, Grand Chief of the Grand Council of the Crees, who number 10,000 in Quebec.
Mercury released from rotting vegetation in the new reservoirs has contaminated fish, a Cree staple. More than anything, though, the native culture has been buffeted. In less than a generation, people have gone from living in shacks with no electricity to fully furnished homes.
Hydro-Quebec officials acknowledge some environmental damage - they have no immediate solution to the mercury problem - and elimination of some traditional hunting grounds. But they say the concerns have been overstated and that native people have been helped by the James Bay project. Roads have made the territory more accessible for hunting, they say, and health services and education have also improved.
 
Land Rights for $263 Million
Change came fast after Hydro-Quebec began building a 375-mile road north into Cree country in the early 1970's to permit construction of the La Grande complex.
The Crees wanted no part of development and fought it in the courts to no avail. In 1975, as part of a resolution of land disputes spanning decades, they signed an agreement under which they gave up claims to all but 5,400 of 410,000 million square miles. The natives have hunting privileges on the land they gave up, but development is permitted, Hydro-Quebec says. The Crees, in pending law suits, dispute that.
In return for giving up land claims, Canada, Quebec and Hydro-Quebec contributed $263 million to the Crees and the Eskimos who call themselves Inuit. Self-administration also was part of the package.
Besides the electricity sales to the United States, the battle between the native peoples and Hydro-Quebec has broader implications for Quebec and Canada.
In the past, few in this French-speaking province have stood up to Hydro-Quebec, a proud symbol of French economic strength in a nation dominated until recently by English companies. Now, Quebecers are taking a closer look at the company and the influential role it plays in the province's economy.
In the middle of the debate are Great Whale's Cree community, the northernmost of Quebec's nine Cree bands, and the Eskimo community, the southernmost of 14 groups.
 
Two Local Radio Stations
No roads lead to Great Whale, about 650 miles from Montreal. Visitors must come by air or boat. Fifteen years ago, this sandy speck on the windy shores of Hudson Bay was little more than a collection of shacks. Today, however, in the aftermath of the 1975 agreement, Great Whale has about 150 new one- and two-story homes and more on the way. From a nerby hill, it looks like a rambling trailer park, a place not yet comfortable with permanence. In fact, 40 percent of the population still ventures into the bush for prolonged stays.
There are many other concessions to 1990's living. Two local radio stations broadcast in Cree and Inuktituk, the Eskimo language. Satellite dishes deliver television signals to homes. All-terrain vehicles are ubiquitous. There are Cree and Eskimo businesses, including two airlines.
Two well-supplied general stores sell such things as Pringles potato chips and television sets. Residents can rent movies on video cassette or buy tapes of best-selling pop-music albums in the United States, including M. C. Hammer's ''Please Hammer Don't Hurt'em.''
Robbie Niquanicappo, a 31-year-old Cree leader in Great Whale, expressed the Indians' ambivalence about the new world.
''We adapted - why walk when you can ride a Ski-Doo?'' he said, referring to a snowmobile. ''Why paddle when you can fly?''
 
Cocaine Busts Cited
In the years since Hydro-Quebec's presence became felt, alcohol abuse has become a problem, particularly among younger people, Mr. Niquanicappo said. And, he added, ''There have been cocaine busts here.''
About 65 percent of the Crees are 25 years old or younger. And they are much less inclined to spend their lives in the bush, even though there are not enough jobs for them in the village. The population is growing quickly because medicl care has improved and the infant mortality rate declined.
Television was criticized by several people as a bad influence on young people. ''T.V. has been one of the most damaging things to the community'' since it arrived 10 years ago,'' Mr. Niquanicappo said. ''It warps the values.''
He recalled his four-year-old son's comments after watching a news program. ''Mom, police have sticks, they go like this,'' Mr. Niquanicappo said, simulating a beating. ''That's pretty sad to see in a four-year-old.'' But he added, ''My son likes his Ninja Turtles.''

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Britain Sees Gulf Blockade Deadline

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today that the American-led forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf would have to decide ''in a matter of weeks'' whether economic sanctions should give way to war to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull his troops out of Kuwait.
''I am suggesting that the military option exists,'' Mr. Hurd told the British Broadcasting Corporation. Speaking of Mr. Hussein, he said, ''I think there is just a chance, I wouldn't put it a great deal higher than that, that once he is clear in his own mind, certain that if he doesn't go in peace he will be forced out, that he will go.''
Asked when the policy of sanctions would be reconsidered, he said, ''In a matter of weeks.'' He said the allies would have to ''take stock whether these pressures are going to do the job or whether the military option will have to be prepared.'' 
Mr. Hurd's remarks were broadcast on BBC television hours after 321 evacuees from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait arrived here, describing continued clashes between the Kuwaiti resistance and Iraqi troops and a deteriorating situation for the local population and the several hundred Americans and other Westerners they left behind.
 
Kuwaiti Resistance Reported
The pace of the Iraqi dismantling of Kuwait's economy would be a factor in any calculation of whether to use force to oust Iraq, which invaded on Aug. 2.
The refugees, who included 271 who are Americans or related to Americans as well as 50 other evacuees from Britain, Canada, and various other countries, arrived at Gatwick Airport here on an American-chartered Iraqi Airlines flight from Basra and Baghdad just after 6 A.M. today. It was the first such flight in nearly three weeks.
''We have seen so many Iraqi Army trucks and jeeps destroyed on the streets,'' said Mohammad Issa, a language teacher from Bridgeport, Conn. who arrived this morning with his wife, father and brother. ''We know who is doing it. It is the Kuwaiti resistance. It is a group of Kuwaitis combined with some other nationalities.''
Mr. Issa said that living conditions in Kuwait were ''miserable, with people having to stand in line for bread, for gas, for everything.''
 
Iraqis 'Taking Everything'
''Food is very difficult to get,'' another man who did not give his name said before boarding a bus at the airport. ''It takes a day just to get a piece of bread and a piece of chicken.''
Alison al-Haider, a 27-year-old Briton whose Kuwaiti husband, Adnan, is still there, told the Press Association: ''I have heard a lot of rumors about killings of Kuwaitis. It is terrible to have to leave my husband over there.'' She arrived this morning with her children Sarah, 2, and Omar, 4.
Natasha Asfari, a Canadian, told the Press Association that ''the Iraqis are taking everything.'' She continued: ''People are having to go by bus to Basra to buy food. The Iraqis have destroyed shopping centers, but there is still food if you search for it.''
The evacuees looked tired from their journey, and an American Embassy spokeswoman, Charla Hatton, said the Americans had decided not to go on to the United States today, as originally planned, but to rest overnight before the final leg of their journey.
 
Briton to Meet Hussein
Michelle Darr, of Portland, Ore., said it had taken all day Wednesday for the group to reach Basra by bus. They had had to go there from Kuwait after Iraqi authorities closed the airport in Kuwait City earlier this week, after American authorities had made arrangements for the evacuation flight.
Mrs. Darr, who arrived with her husband and 8-month-old daughter, said the Iraqis had taken some passengers off the bus in Kuwait but had let them rejoin the group later, as far as she knew.
American officials said that from 650 to 700 Americans remained in Iraq and Kuwait. The British Foreign Office said earlier this week that Iraq was holding about 280 British men as hostages, with about 700 others remaining voluntarily in Kuwait and 400 in Iraq.
A former Conservative Prime Minister, Edward Heath, broke ranks with the Thatcher Government today and announced that he would travel to Baghdad over the weekend to talk with President Hussein about the British hostages.
 
Unsuccessful Appeals to Hussein
Mr. Heath, who in recent weeks has said the West should couple its demands for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with an offer of negotiations over Iraq's territorial claims there, said that he would be going on a humanitarian mission after appeals from the families of sick and dying British hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.
One British hostage, William Atack of Scotland, died in Kuwait of natural causes last month. Another is said to be suffering from terminal cancer but has not yet been allowed to leave.
Jenny Stenton, who recently appealed to President Hussein to let her husband come home with her, arrived this morning without him but with their 1-month-old son, Craig, and infant daughter, Kelly. Christine Pedley, who had also appealed on behalf of her husband, was likewise unsuccessful and arrived this morning with her 12-day-old daughter.

HEADLINE: Drive Mounted for Environment Vote

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Amid signs that a far-reaching environmental measure on the California ballot is faltering, three national leaders of the environmental movement declared today that the state faced an environmental crisis. They announced the start of a door-to-door drive for the measure.
They charged that eight oil and chemical companies that have contributed nearly $3 million to an advertising campaign to kill the voter-initiated measure were among the worst polluters in California and the nation. The measure would impose the strictest environmental controls in the country, banning many common pesticides and requiring drastic reductions in carbon dioxide emissions, among many other things. 
While none of the environmental leaders would concede the measure, which they call Big Green, was in trouble, many in the movement fear a loss would seriously slow the national political momentum for ecological causes. The vote is shaping up as a major test of whether the public's general desire for a cleaner environment is matched by willingness to pay for it.
 
Opponents Tell of Job Loss
Industry groups have mounted a withering advertising drive against it, charging that the measure tries to do too much and will raise water and power rates and cost jobs in manufacturing and agriculture. While there have been no recent statewide polls on the measure, political experts believe its once huge margin of support has eroded substantially in recent weeks.
''Much is at stake in this fight, both for California and the entire nation,'' John Adams of New York, president of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said at a news conference at the Sierra Club's headquarters in San Francisco. ''Big Green is perhaps our best chance to translate the shift in public consciousness about the environment into political change.''
He was joined by Jay Hair, president of the 5.8-million-member National Wildlife Federation, from Washington, and Michael L. Fisher, executive director of the Sierra Club, which has 200,000 members in California. Absent from the conference, and a similar one in Los Angeles, was Assemblyman Tom Hayden of Santa Monica, chairman of the steering committee running the campaign. Opponents have tagged the measure ''the Hayden initiative'' in the hope that voters will tend to oppose it if it is linked to the former anti-Vietnam War leader. #750,000 Members Alterted Expecting to be greatly outspent, the environmental leadership said it was mounting a statewide effort to get out the ''green'' vote with the help 750,000 members of environmental groups. The Sierra Club said it would call on its 11 chapters to man telephone banks, hand out leaflets at shopping centers, movie lines and street fairs and participate in local debates.
At the same time, the natural resources council released a report stating that the fast-growing state faced alarming environmental degradation. ''California's environment and quality of life are in serious peril from the combined and continuous pollution of our air, drinking water, food supply, rivers, lakes and coastline,'' said the report, compiled by council staff members. It asserted that 227 million pounds of chemical pollutants are released annually in California.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Adams said that a direct voter measure was the only way to tackle these problems because ''special interests'' had thwarted efforts to pass laws in Congress and the State Legislature.
The environmental leaders said major contributors to the campaign to defeat Proposition 128, as it appears on the ballot, are makers of pesiticides and other toxic chemicals. They said the Monsanto Company, which has contributed $405,000, is the sole manufacturer of the pesticide alachlor. They said alachlor was ''a probable human carcinogen'' that had contaminated ground and surface water in the Midwest. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which has given $365,000, released 1,084,000 pounds of toxic chemicals in California in 1988, they said.
The other six companies the environmentalists said had paid for the advertising were the Chevron Corporation, Dow Elanco Inc, Rhone-Poulenc S.A., Ciba-Geigy International AG, ICI Americas and ARCO and its sister company, the ARCO ChemicalCompany.
Don Schrack, the spokesman for the chemical-industry backed group called ''No on 128,'' said the backers of the referendum had made a strategic decision to avoid discussing its lack of merit.
The measure, which runs nearly 30,000 words, would substantially rewrite California environmental law, cobbling together an array of loosely connected laws. Among other things, it would phase out pesticides - just how many is at issue - that cause cancer or birth defects, strictly limit discharges of pollutants into coastal waters and phase out chemicals believed to deplete the earth's protective ozone layer. It would create an elected ''environmental advocate'' with special legal powers and require a state plan to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent by the year 2000 and 40 percent by 2010, adjusted for population growth as necessary.
 
Study Cites High Costs
Critics maintain the law is grounded in no reliable science and asks voters to impose huge costs on local governments and businesses. The critics also contend the measure would even undermine American competitiveness in international trade by establishing different food standards for the huge California market.
According to a study by DRI/McGraw-Hill a Boston-based economic consulting concern, complying with the carbon dioxide provision would raise gasoline and diesel fuel taxes by 50 cents a gallon, require an investment of up to $50 billion to build high-speed trains between major cities, increase the use of nuclear power and slow California economic growth to about 65 percent of the national average from 150 percent.
''Clearly these numbers generate a great deal of concern,'' said Victor F. Weisser, president of the California Council for Environmental and Economic Balance, a coalition of industry and labor groups that commissioned the study. The council has not taken a formal position on the proposition.
Backers of the referendum say claims of huge costs are overblown.dEli Lilly(Dow Elanco)
