HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: Washington Talk;
Modifying Medicare: No Dice Once Again

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Of all the fiscal powders that turned the recent budget summit to budget bomb, perhaps none proved more explosive than the plan to cut Medicare. In the resulting detritus lie lessons of budgetary politics.
President Bush and the Congressional negotiators lit the fuse when they proposed what many saw as modest increases in the amount that recipients of Medicare pay for their benefits. They sought to raise monthly premiums to $34, from $28, and to increase yearly deductibles to $150, from $75, over five years. 
''Devastating,'' said Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Senate Finance subcommittee overseeing the program.
''Chicanery,'' said Ronald Pollack of the Families USA Foundation, one of about 100 advocacy groups that banded together to help defeat the plan.
Enough of Congress agreed to send the Medicare proposals, and the rest of the summit meeting's work, into early retirement.
The more modest Medicare alterations now under discussion are almost certain to demand less from the elderly and more from the work force whose payroll taxes help support the program.
Were Yogi Berra in town, he might call the situation deja vu all over again: another demonstration of the power of entitlements for the elderly, and lobbyists for the elderly. But there are other questions. Are entitlements for the elderly affordable, as they are now run? And are they fair?
Taken together, Social Security ($264 billion) and Medicare ($114 billion) account for 28 percent of the entire $1.35 trillion Federal budget projected for 1991. Or after subtracting military spending and interest, the programs would cost more than 4 of every 10 Federal dollars.
That kind of spending cramps other social spending, leaving less to build housing, fight infant mortality, provide better schools, battle drug abuse and otherwise invest in the future.
It also raises important questions about equity between the generations. Both Social Security and Medicare offer the elderly benefits that far exceed their earlier contributions as workers, even after inflation is accounted for.
More important, in the eyes of some of the programs' critics, neither program distinguishes between those elderly who truly need the benefits and those who do not.
Many Washington analysts say the failure to make the distinction between, say, the $350-a-month pensioners in Miami Beach and the more fortunate retiree in Palm Beach is the main flaw in the programs, and the key to fixing them. But part of the problem with the summit proposal was that it, too, treated virtually all the elderly alike.
There were other options. By contrast, for instance, the budget negotiators might have assigned Medicare an actuarial value and asked recipients to pay taxes on it. Thus, only those with enough income to pay taxes would be affected. The Congressional Budget Office estimated earlier this year that $17 billion over five years could be raised this way. The budget office estimates that modest increases in the portion of Social Security subject to taxation could raise $20 billion in the same period.
But such proposals never came to the table, and it takes only a short memory to guess why. In 1988, Congress passed a bill that offered the elderly increased protection from the catastrophic costs of long-term hospitalization. It financed the expanded benefits by a surtax on the elderly, capped at $800 a year for those with incomes of more than $35,000. Led by Washington advocacy groups, the elderly raised an outcry so strong that a year later Congress repealed its own legislation by large margins.
Whenever there are efforts to modify the entitlement programs to make them less generous to the affluent, critics quickly charge that they are being gutted through ''means testing'' - being downgraded to welfare programs, some say. But it is unclear how much longer Congress can continue to provide benefits without regard for need.
Some projections show one Medicare trust fund approaching bankruptcy by the end of the decade. So today's skirmishes may be harbingers of things to come.
''We can no longer afford to treat the wealthy dowager living with an inheritance the same as we treat the little old lady on a fixed income in a cold-water flat,'' said Jack Meyer, president of New Directions for Policy, a Washington consulting organization. ''But Congress is still clinging to that outmoded idea.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1205 words

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
In a Survey, Americans Wish a Pox On Both Congress and the President

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Four weeks before the midterm elections, the American public is in a discontented mood, with 60 percent saying they disapprove of the way Congress is doing its job and more than two-thirds saying it is time to replace most members of Congress, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll has found But people still look more kindly on their own members of Congress than on Congress in general, and the forces protecting incumbent House members are formidable, from superior war chests to the perquisites of office. Moreover, there is little for the White House to gloat about in all the bashing of Congress.
Despite the public's irritation with Congress, 55 percent said they still trusted it to do a better job in cutting the Federal deficit than President Bush, while just 24 percent said Mr. Bush would do a better job.
Congress's approval rating was 27 percent, down sharply from January's level of 42 percent. While there was clear and pervasive concern about the economy, Congress's stock was equally low among those who thought the United States was in a recession and those who disagreed. 
 
Congress and Special Interests
The portrait of Congress that emerged from many people was of a body driven by special interests and by the lawmakers' own concerns, rather than those of the people who sent them there.
Many people seemed to be saying a pox on both branches of government. In follow-up interviews after the poll was completed, Lance D. Deroucher, a 32-year-old Republican from Utica, N.Y., asserted that Congress and the President were ''acting like a bunch of kids, bickering back and forth.''
There are many crosscurrents in the public's attitude toward their Congress members, according to this telephone survey of 960 adults on Oct. 8-10, while the White House was repeatedly shifting its position on the tax measures it would accept and negotiations with Congress were in turmoil. The poll also examined in-depth attitudes toward the President; the results of that part of the survey will be made public within a few days.
People still draw a distinction between Congress as a whole and their own individual member of Congress: Forty-four percent say their own representative deserves re-election, while 40 percent say they would prefer somebody new, even in their own district.
This swings overwhelmingly when people are asked to consider Congress as a whole: 20 percent say most lawmakers deserve re-election, while 67 percent say it is time ''to give new people a chance.'' The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Influence of the Wealthy
''It's more a matter of punishment than that the new people would necessarily be better,'' said Vinny M. Boland, 31 years old, who owns a sign-making company in Miramar, Fla., and described himself as an independent voter from a Democratic family. ''The wealthy and the special interests will still sway whoever is in ofice and get their point across. But if elected officials know they're vulnerable, maybe they won't give as much.''
Still, the re-election rate for House incumbents in the last two elections was 98 percent. And Common Cause, the Washington group lobbying for new campaign finance laws, recently asserted that most incumbents were protected by ''a wall of political money that makes them nearly invincible.''
Of 405 House incumbents seeking re-election this fall, Common Cause classified nearly three-fourths of them as ''financially unopposed'' - either with no challenger at all from a major party, or with a challenger who had raised less than $25,000 as the fall campaign began, hardly enough to mount a vigorous effort.
However it is translated at the polls, there is a sour mood in the land. Voters were asked if they thought government ''is pretty much run by a few big interests looking out for themselves,'' or run ''for the benefit of all the people?''
That question has been asked periodically by the Times/CBS News Poll and by the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan, and the current level of cynicism matches the previous high-water mark set in 1980, at the end of the Carter Administration: 71 percent said this week that Government was controlled by big interests, compared with 21 percent who saw a government run for the people.
Similarly, 58 percent said most members of Congress were more interested in serving themselves than in serving the people they represent. And 71 percent said they thought most lawmakers were more interested in serving special interest groups than serving the people.
''To get into office, you have to have a lot of backing,'' said Marcella Fowkes, 58, of Pittsburgh. ''I think that they owe a lot of favors to the big oil companies, and the other ones backing them.''
Another reflection of this mood was the strong support for a 12-year limit on service in Congress: 56 percent backed it, compared with 37 percent who said members should be able to serve as long as they are able to get re-elected.
 
'Out of Touch'
''Congressmen should not be in office for 30 years,'' said Gary Ostermueller, 32, a Republican who is a sales manager from Metuchen, N.J. ''The longer they're in Washington, the more they get out of touch with the people back home.''
Still, there were glimmers of trust. Fifty-one percent, for example, said they thought Congress made ''the right decisions most of the time,'' while 22 percent said they thought lawmakers made the wrong decisions.
Mildred Tudor, 72, a retiree in Newton Center, Mass., said: ''I think that they want to get to the right thing, but other things get in their way, especially in an election year. They could come up with a solution to the budget but they don't want to hurt their image.''
After weeks of feuding over the budget between Congress and the White House, 64 percent said they blamed both branches of Government for the fiscal impasse, while 24 percent said they blamed Congress and 6 percent blamed Mr. Bush.
But of those blaming Congress, most said it was the fault of both the Republicans and the Democrats on Capitol Hill.
On the tenor of this year's campaigns, 23 percent said they thought they were more negative that past campaigns, 11 percent more positive and 61 percent about the same.
 
Assessing Congress: Mixed Reviews

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Pentagon Finds an Odd Ally in Iraq for Budget-Cutting Talks

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Because of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the Defense Department has emerged so far from the chaotic budget process with more modest cuts in military spending than seemed likely in early summer.
''A lot of members find it difficult to make significant cuts as long as the gulf crisis is going on,'' said William W. Kaufmann, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
House liberals have voiced dismay that the Defense Department has escaped the brunt of larger cuts. ''Everyone over here is stunned that this came out so well for the Pentagon,'' said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado. 
Even so, decisions on how to apportion this year's money have provoked a bare-knuckles fight between Senate and House negotiators who are working out a conference agreement. The debate has been particularly fierce over money for the radar-evading Stealth, or B-2, bomber and the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program, as well as over the magnitude of troop cuts.
 
No Guarantees After '91
Pentagon spending for the fiscal year 1991, which began Oct. 1, as established in the revised budget resolution approved on Monday, would be virtually unchanged from the original ill-fated budget compromise of the week before.
And the spending level seems likely to withstand efforts by some Congress members to make deeper cuts this year.
But the resolution's projected spending for 1992 and 1993 are anything but guaranteed.
''We'll be free to revisit these matters and reduce defense spending,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who as chairman of the Senate Budget Committee is one of many lawmakers who remind people that the budget resolution sets ceilings on spending, not floors.
The newly forged agreement would allow spending of $288.3 billion in 1991, a reduction of $18.6 billion from what the Bush Administration proposed and a cut of 8 percent from the 1990 budget, as calculated in constant 1990 dollars and adjusted for inflation.
 
Outlook Last Spring
In the earlier budget compromise between the White House and Congressional leaders, which fell to defeat in the House, Democrats agreed to cut military spending by 3 percent in 1992 to 3.6 percent in 1993 in 1992 and 1993, again in constant dollars.
They made slight additional trims over the next three years in the revised plan. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had proposed 2 percent annual reductions in the Administration's budget request.
While that may sound like a setback for the Administration, the cuts could could have been much deeper. By last spring, when the Soviet threat in Europe was quickly receding and efforts to slash Pentagon spending were gaining momentum, it had become increasingly clear that the Administration's numbers were unrealistic.
The only question left was whose budget levels would be embraced by the Democratic-controlled Congress: those of the Senate Armed Services Committee and its chairman, Sam Nunn of Georgia, or the much deeper cuts proposed by the House Armed Services Committee and its chairman, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin.
 
Changed Overnight
The Senate bill called for a $289 billion military budget for 1991, while the House plan was for $283 billion.
The size and type of cuts proposed by the House prompted Mr. Cheney to recommend that President Bush veto the legislation if it was approved by Congress. In the usual course of political horse-trading, the House and Senate would have compromised and emerged with a military budget somewhere in the middle.
But on Aug. 2 that all changed. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait suddenly curbed the appetite of many lawmakers for deeper cuts.
Even before the White House and Congressional meetings on the overall Government budget, Congressional officials said the invasion had moved the military spending debate closer to the Senate's levels.
Under pressure from the Administration and having a desire to spare cuts in domestic spending, the Congressional budget negotiators agreed on a formula that bore a striking resemblance to the Senate figures.
Even when that package collapsed, Democrats and Republicans balked at deeper Pentagon spending cuts, instead making only slight trims.
 
Domestic Programs Lose Out
Not surprisingly, even before the Iraqi invasion, the Administration had been quietly supporting the Senate budget levels as its best hope. ''Sam Nunn became the G.O.P. standard-bearer,'' said John Isaacs, legislative director of the Council for a Livable World, a lobbying group on arms control and other military issues.
The military spending bill does not include the cost of the American military operation in the Persian Gulf. The operation is now estimated to cost about $15 billion by next September unless there is an outbreak of hostilities, which would send that figure soaring. About half the cost is expected to be met by foreign contributions.
A casualty, not only of the higher military spending levels, but also of costs attached to the Persian Gulf operation, has been any hope of channeling Pentagon savings into domestic programs.
The ''peace dividend,'' resulting from military spending cuts, ranged from the Bush Administration's estimate of about $85 billion over five years to $185 billion under the Senate plan to $240 billion under the House version.
''The message is, 'Honey, I shrunk the peace dividend,' '' said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a research organization here.
''There is a peace dividend here, but for the next three to five years, it's going to be rolled entirely into deficit reduction.''
Aides to Mr. Aspin sought to play down any notion that the budget agreement was a serious setback to their position.
 
'Not Thrilled to Death'
''Obviously, we're not thrilled to death,'' said one House staff member, who said the committee's attitude all along had been to shape a military spending bill, given whatever level the budget negotiators adopted. ''Now the challenge is to spend the money correctly once the top line is established.''
For House conferees, that is likely to mean favoring less drastic personnel cuts over expensive strategic systems. The House, for instance, approved cutting the military by 129,500 troops next year, compared with 100,000 for the Senate.
Mr. Cheney, the Defense Secretary, has urged lawmakers to limit personnel cuts next year to 80,000.
The House also eliminated financing for any additional Stealth bombers after the 15 that are already paid for. The Senate has approved the Administration's request for $4.6 billion and two new B-2's in 1991.

HEADLINE: The Empty Pulpit

 BODY:
The budget charade that has dominated Washington for weeks has diminished almost all of its participants. That includes the majority of both parties in the House who, without offering any serious alternative, rejected a budget compromise engineered by their leaders. But the roll of dishonor is headed by George Bush, who failed to present a convincing and consistent case for a deal he had worked hard to achieve.
One might have expected more from a man who has so successfully orchestrated a collective global response to Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf. But when faced with a crisis at home, he chose not to use those skills. His failure has nothing to do with the ''vision thing'' he finds so uncomfortable. It has everything to do with his reluctance to exercise power - and use the pulpit he was hired to fill. 
True, Mr. Bush made one good speech. Honoring his promise to the Congressional leadership to present a united front, he appeared on television last week and called the budget deficit ''a cancer gnawing away at our nation's health.'' Uncontrolled deficits ''mortgage the future of our children,'' he said - a plain and simple acknowledgment that recurrent deficits threaten future living standards by siphoning money from private investment. And he urged the public to ask their representatives to ''fight for the future of your kids by supporting this budget agreement.''
That was not an easy speech for George Bush. It required an implicit concession that the economic policies of Ronald Reagan, to whom he had given eight years of undivided loyalty, had brought the country to the brink. While the budget compromise was hardly draconian, it required him to admit, once again, that the theme of his Presidential campaign -no new taxes - had been nothing but blue skies. And it asked him to spend a small amount of his treasured popularity.
But when the House repudiated him, his well of conviction ran dry. Indeed, within days his own budget director, Richard Darman, made the astonishing statement that Mr. Bush hadn't really said what everyone had heard him say. ''He wasn't actually asking the public to support this,'' Mr. Darman said, suggesting that maybe the President didn't think so much of his own idea.
Mr. Bush's subsequent behavior has been equally confusing. Instead of returning to his central theme that huge deficits demand urgent attention, he has trapped himself in a bizarre and baffling dispute. The debate is whether to include in any new package something that was not even in the original - higher income taxes on the wealthy combined with lower capital gains taxes.
Mr. Bush embraced that proposal Tuesday morning and, after conservatives screamed, rejected it that afternoon. On Wednesday he said he had no public position on the matter and that it was up to Congress to decide. Then, yesterday, he (a) proposed a ''hypothetical'' package containing a capital gains cut and a modest increase in income taxes on the rich and (b) said he would prefer a budget agreement that had neither element in it.
That's how many, four contradictory statements in three days? Five? ''The meter is running,'' he said yesterday. ''But look, I can't dictate to Congress.'' But he can certainly give Congress a far clearer idea of what's on his mind.
What a depressing week. Official Washington has converted a fine opportunity to make a bold statement about fiscal sanity into a dismal statement about the quality of America's elected leadership. The deficit is a cancer. The public needs to be rallied to support an effective remedy. What does the President do about that? He dithers.

HEADLINE: Keep Our Powder Dry

BYLINE: By McGeorge Bundy; McGeorge Bundy was special assistant for national security affairs for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson.

 BODY:
As they move into the third month of their shared response to Saddam Hussein's aggression, the governments of the U.S., most Middle Eastern countries and most members of the U.N. Security Council deserve applause. Together they have established a winning position. Unless they become divided in ways that none can desire, the Iraqi aggression, sooner or later, will fail.
Oddly, the principal threat to this prospect is that one or more members of this extraordinary coalition may not appreciate the strength of their present position and so may lose patience. Because the Americans are the linchpin of the coalition, it is America's patience that matters most, and it is precisely among Americans that there are voices calling for moving from blockade to ''decisive'' combat. These voices are wrong in three ways. 
First, if the U.S. takes the lead in escalation, it will put heavy strains on the unity and steadiness of the coalition it has done so much to bring together and will gravely threaten the blockade constructed under our leadership.
Second, there is no need for escalation because the blockade itself, over time, is a winner. There can be no durable success for Saddam Hussein while the blockade remains in force, and his strength, military and political, is bound to decline month by month as it continues.
Already he is weaker than he was, and his behavior shows he knows it: his threats get thinner and his search for a political escape more frantic. Because it is necessarily slow, the blockade can easily be underestimated. Iraq is unusually vulnerable to blockade. Large-scale imports and exports are vital; they are readily blocked; the necessary participants in this process are few, and all are deeply interested in success.
We can't be sure a cornered Saddam Hussein will never strike out, but it is reasonable to expect that the allies will be able to turn any such act into a clear defeat for him.
A third error is the assumption that because it was wrong in Vietnam it is wrong now to use force in a limited and graduated way. This assumption is entirely understandable to me, because I know at first hand what we tried to do in Vietnam and how it ended in disaster. It was a disaster, not because we did too little, but because we tried to do too much. We tried to do with our own forces what in the end could be done only by the Vietnamese. Tragically, there was a persistent and eventually fatal imbalance of effectiveness between the Vietnamese Communists and their opponents.
It makes no sense to let an honorable but deeply mistaken view of the American tragedy in Vietnam be misapplied in the wholly different situation of Iraq and Kuwait.
This time, as a result of quick and excellent work by our own leaders, we and our friends are doing enough to prevail - a position we never reached in Vietnam - and we need not do more unless Saddam Hussein makes war. A blockade has daily costs, but even a year of blockade will be cheaper for both sides by every measure of cost than even a week of war.
It is true that blockade will not by itself do more than bring independence back to Kuwait. It cannot settle the political future of that country or insure a stable peace between Iraq and its neighbors.
As President Bush made clear at the U.N., there will be much to work out after the Iraqis leave Kuwait. In particular, there are other dangers in the Iraq of Saddam Hussein, notably a deep preoccupation with the acquisition of weapons of mass destruction. But these are not matters to be settled by warfare - at least not by warfare of American choice.
We shall do better on these larger problems if we keep to what President Bush has described: a course that does only what we must to restore the independence of Kuwait. Once that goal is attained, there will be a new political and military balance of power in the region that will help in larger matters - as an open war begun by the Americans will not.

HEADLINE: Facing Yonkers Housing Foes, Banks Balk

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: YONKERS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Five years after a Federal judge ordered Yonkers to desegregate by building low-income housing in white neighborhoods, public opposition remains so potent that banks, apparently fearing picketing or boycotts, are balking at financing the construction.
Chemical Bank of New York has withdrawn from talks with the developer chosen by the city, who now faces a deadline of Friday to arrange other financing. If the developer fails to do so, the city may have to seek new bids; even if the developer succeeds, the start of construction will be delayed until at least next spring.
It appeared tonight that the developer would work out its difficulties, and that the city's housing authority was prepared to forward the developer's financing plan to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, where the final decision will be made. 
Even though Chemical's decision appears to have stemmed not from threats, but from concern that protests might develop, news of its withdrawal quickly led housing opponents to promise that they would boycott any other bank that stepped in. Meanwhile, supporters of the plan began picketing Chemical over its decision to withdraw.
''Chemical gave the developer a handshake on a deal to build housing in Yonkers, and then backed off under the threat of boycotts,'' the Rev. Darryl George, the pastor of the Messiah Baptist Church, said on Wednesday at a demonstration of about 40 people outside the bank's branch in downtown Getty Square. ''We're going to shut this branch down.''
The developer, DeLuxe Development of New York, had been negotiating with Chemical for a loan of $16 million to build 142 apartments for low-income families on five sites scattered in predominantly white neighborhoods.
Just what prompted Chemical's decision to break off talks in mid-August remains in sharp dispute. A bank spokesman, Kenneth Herz, said that the decision was based on ''prudent banking practices.''
But a court-appointed monitor in the desegregation case, Oscar Newman, said in a letter to all parties in the dispute that the developer's president was told by Chemical that it ''had a branch in Yonkers and was afraid it would get out that Chemical had made the loan and the branch would be picketed.''
Mr. Herz denied that Chemical had said that to the developer.
Then late last month the financing problem became public when a lawyer representing the city wrote to Mr. Newman, saying there was ''a story circulating'' that ''an unnamed person, allegedly a city employee, had interfered with the financing'' by threatening ''to remove $300 million in funds from Chemical Bank.''
 
City Conducts Investigation
An investigation by the City Manager, Neil J. DeLuca, found no employee who had spoken to Chemical Bank, or even anyone, he said, who ''knew that Chemical was dealing with DeLuxe.'' He also said the city had no more than ''$3 million to $4 million in a payroll account'' with Chemical.
Ultimately 200 apartments are to be built under the order of the judge in the case, Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan. The original schedule called for construction to begin last spring.
Mr. Newman said that DeLuxe's negotiations with other banks to replace Chemical have become ''increasingly protracted and complex.'' DeLuxe's president, Donald Meske, is negotiating with First Eastern Bank in Pennsylvania, which has financed other projects for his company, but there, too, the possibility of protests in the city is causing trouble.
DeLuxe and First Eastern sought a guarantee from H.U.D., which will eventually pay for the housing, that it would compensate them for any losses due to lawsuits or other factors beyond their control.
But an assistant secretary at H.U.D., Joseph G. Schiff, rejected the request and set Friday's deadline, replying that ''DeLuxe well knew, or should have known, of the dimensions of the 'local controversy' when it submitted its proposal to develop the housing.''
Mr. Meske has declined several requests to discuss the negotiations.
 
Series of Maneuvers
Mr. Newman estimated that ''even if H.U.D., DeLuxe and First Eastern reach agreement, we've lost a building season and will probably not start construction until next spring.''
The threat of pickets and boycotts is the latest in a series of controversies that have dominated Yonkers since 1985, when Judge Sand found the city guilty of intentionally segregating schools and housing.
The next year Judge Sand issued remedy orders calling for a school desegregation plan that introduced busing and magnet schools to the city of 190,000, and the construction of 200 units of subsidized housing on several sites in middle-income neighborhoods. He proposed that an additional 800 units of affordable housing be built by private developers who would receive incentives to participate.
The school plan was accepted with little opposition, but the housing remedy has been bitterly resisted by neighborhood groups that formed the Save Yonkers Federation and by a majority on the City Council. Though there have been many legal challenges, with one reaching the United States Supreme Court, Judge Sand's remedies remain intact.
The desegregation case has become a preoccupation for Yonkers, said Mr. DeLuca, the City Manager, clouding its economic future and delaying or overshadowing other advances.
A Yonkers 2000 commission acknowledged in a report issued today that the city's image is a ''tragedy'' and that it is the most serious problem Yonkers is facing.
Ignoring the long and bitter struggle over the desegregated housing, the authors of the three-year study blamed ''the sensationalism of out-of-area media'' for the negative public perception of Yonkers. To change the image, it recommended ''development of a positive business image, centralization of development agencies, subsidization of new and rehabilitated affordable housing as well as an improved public relations effort, video presentations, an ''historical trail'' for visitors and ''welcome wagons'' to greet new residents.
As for the campaign against the court-ordered housing, Jack O'Toole, head of the Save Yonkers Federation, said, ''We're going to keep up the pressure, telling our people to withdraw funds from any financial institution that provides funding to the builders of the low-income housing or the developers of the long-term housing.''
That vow added fuel to the counter- demonstration on Wednesday outside Chemical Bank's branch in downtown Getty Square.
Chemical Bank said that it had no plans to change its decision and that it has an excellent record of financing subsidized housing in the New York region. The bank also said that Federal regulators gave it their highest rating earlier this year for investments in communities where they operate.

HEADLINE: Quiet for 4 Years, Board Is Child of Crisis

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The State Financial Control Board, which has been all but dormant and forgotten in the budgetary quietude of recent years, was created in 1975 to impose fiscal austerity on New York City - then at the brink of bankruptcy - and see it through its worst financial crisis in history.
Awash in $3.3 billion of debt, the city had been shut out of credit markets, and default appeared certain on Sept. 9, 1975, when Gov. Hugh L. Carey signed into law a plan establishing the board to restructure the city's fiscal management, slash its expenses and infuse it with $2.3 billion in cash.
The seven-member panel, originally called the Emergency Financial Control Board, was empowered to monitor the city's finances and approve its budgets and financial plans, in effect taking over the authority of the mayor and other elected officials for the duration of the crisis. 
The board made many painful, controversial decisions that Mayor Abraham D. Beame and other officials were unwilling or unable to make. It ordered hundreds of millions of dollars in budget cuts and layoffs for thousands of city workers, imposed a wage freeze on all municipal workers and rejected labor contracts already negotiated with teachers and transit workers.
 
Change in Name
The panel was so aggressive in its belt-tightening that many public officials feared the state had virtually taken over the city, and many labor leaders expressed concern that collective bargaining with the city was dead.
But three years later, as the crisis eased, the word ''emergency'' was dropped from the board's title. And on June 30, 1986, under terms of the law that created it, the board invoked a ''sunset'' provision that altered its duties from direct oversight to exclusively advisory.
To do so, the board had to affirm that the city had balanced its budget for three consecutive years, had regained access to the credit markets and had retired its federally guaranteed loans. The board by law will exist until the year 2008 but must vote annually to remain in its ''sunset'' mode.
The control board may resume its stronger powers only if one of the following conditions are met: if the city runs a $100 million deficit at the end of a fiscal year, if it is unlikely to be able to pay the principal or interest on its debts, if the city and state comptrollers say the city can no longer borrow money or if the city impairs its credit by violating state-required budget and accounting practices.
 
Members of the Board
The seven members of the board are Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and three private members appointed by the Governor. The private members are:
* Stanley S. Shuman, executive vice president of Allen & Company, the investment banking concern, who has been on the board since 1977.
* Donald D. Kummerfeld, president of the Magazine Publishers Association, former City Budget Director, former First Deputy Mayor and former executive director of the Financial Control Board.
* Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association, representing the municipal bond underwriting community, who is the former executive director of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's to issue bonds to raise money for the city.
Since January, the executive director of the board has been Allen Proctor, a 38-year-old former deputy director of the city's Office of Management and Budget. He and a staff of 25 are responsible for tracking city finances and advising the board on its duties.

LENGTH: 738 words

HEADLINE: Cuomo Warns the State Is 'In for a Period of Pain'

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
As New York City's financial outlook grows bleaker, officials in Albany, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, are warning that the state is also facing a dark financial future and that layoffs and tuition increases are likely.
Governor Cuomo is expected to revise the economic forecast for the state to reflect a recession in the second half of the fiscal year, which started April 1. The original forecast had called for an upturn in the state's economy in the second half.
The warnings from Albany appear to be aimed in part at New York City officials, telling them, in effect, to expect little help from the state as they search for solutions to the city's increasingly desperate fiscal problems. In the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, it was the state that created the borrowing mechanisms to bail out the city. 
 
Prepare for 'Pain'
At a meeting earlier this week, Governor Cuomo told his top staff members that the state's capacity to raise new tax revenues was limited and that they should expect an austere budget next year.
He made similar comments yesterday in an interview at The New York Times, saying: ''I believe we're in for a period of pain, and I think we have to be prepared for that.''
The Governor said that cuts in aid to local governments would have to be made and that state employees, whose contracts expire in March, should expect only meager salary increases.
The comments amounted to an unusual pre-election confession, defying the conventional wisdom that holds that bad news should wait until after November. Mr. Cuomo, who is running for a third term, holds an overwhelming lead over his opponents, according to most polls.
 
Drop in Revenues Expected
The Governor's remarks also seemed aimed at quieting critics who have accused him of failing to address some of the state's most obvious problems during the current campaign.
''The truth is we're going to have a difficult time with finances at the state level,'' Mr. Cuomo said yesterday. ''Everybody knows that.'' At the end of this month the Governor is due to release an update of the state's finances that is expected to show tax collections falling hundreds of millions of dollars short of expectations. The expected change in the economic forecast, to reflect a recession at the end of the year, is likely to force the Governor to reduce his tax revenue estimates significantly.
''The numbers are going to be way down,'' one Cuomo administration official said.
Already the figures for the first five months of the fiscal year show that state income-tax collections are $200 million lower than expected. They are down $600 million, compared with collections in the same period last year, a time when the state was already experiencing severe fiscal problems.
 
Layoffs a Possibility
It was unclear yesterday what steps Mr. Cuomo would propose to close the budget gap in the current fiscal year. But looking toward next year's budget, the Governor said that the state's workforce of more than 200,000 employees would have to be reduced.
''I'm not going to rule out layoffs,'' he said. But he refused to be more specific, saying, ''I'm not going to start floating layoff numbers and getting into trouble that way.''
Last week, when Mayor David N. Dinkins suggested that up to 15,000 New York City employees might have to be laid off to close the city's budget gap, Mr. Dinkins found himself at the center of a storm of criticism.
Historically Mr. Cuomo has been a staunch foe of raising tuition at the state's public universities, going so far last year as to veto an increase. But yesterday he said the state, which has had record tax increases in each of the last two years, had exhausted other sources of revenue and might have to impose a tuition increase next year.
In suggesting that aid to local governments would have to be cut next year, Mr. Cuomo sent a strong signal to New York City not to look to Albany for help. Noting that the largest segment of the state budget was made up of aid to localities, Mr. Cuomo said, ''We have to find a way to reduce that.'' New York City, he said, ''is included.''
Complicating both the city and the state's financial outlook are the labor contracts that both governments must negotiate against tight budgets. The city is currently engaged in negotiations with scores of municipal unions whose contracts have expired; the state faces comparable negotiations.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

Mondrian
If you believe the gossip, Mondrian, the corporate-lookingFrench restaurant in midtown, is more poised for calamity than a tightrope walker. Even when Mondrian opened in 1988 (the summer following the stock-market crash), the betting was it would be short-lived. Industry observers reasoned that New York City needed another luxury dining spot about as much as it needed more potholes.
Mondrian received another blow when its founder and chef, Dennis Foy, threw in the towel in late 1989, selling the struggling restaurant to his partners. The current chef, Thomas Colicchio, has an impressive pedigree: Rakel, where he was sous chef, and before that, Gotham Bar and Grill and the Quilted Giraffe. The economy has not improved, but Mondrian certainly has, and I wouldn't be too fast to make any bets about its demise.
Mondrian is named for the Dutch artist Piet Mondrian, who worked in this neighborhood in the 1940's. The 100-seat main dining room (a 40-seat private room is downstairs) was designed by Philip George, who also created Le Bernardin on West 51st Street, among others. Mondrian is a roomy yet intimate spot with its recessed ceiling, warm wood paneling holding Miro's drawings, soothing lighting and sound-absorbing rugs. 
Winning appetizers on the versatile fall menu include a ragout of sweet little clams, squid-ink pasta, kale, leeks and tomato in a wonderful shellfish broth. Sauteed sweetbreads were enhanced with mildly bitter sauteed salsify and a contrasting sweet puree of onions and deep-fried leeks. Less elaborate but equally alluring were the pristine terrine of leeks with a truffle vinaigrette (very little truffle flavor could be detected, however), flanked by briny oysters out of the shell, and an artichoke, green bean and lobster salad drizzled with basil oil.
Lovely cured salmon came with a corn-and-red-pepper relish, glistening with red-pepper oil, and corn pancakes that were undercooked and still runny in the center. Corn chowder was superb, full of sweet corn flavor, bolstered with bacon and holding oysters encased in webs of deep-fried potatoes.
Mondrian has a well-rounded French and American wine list at moderate prices. Servers at Mondrian are first class in every respect, able to explain anything on the long and intricate menu.
Mr. Colicchio's list of entrees carries some stellar seafood compositions. Braised red snapper came in a pellucid lemony vinaigrette along with deep-fried spinach. At lunch one day I had a terrific tartlet of blackened tuna, black olives, ripe tomatoes, garlic chips and sweet onions. Roasted salmon was simple and appealing, with sliced beets, a sweet rhubarb puree and rivulets of red-wine sauce. The menu described it as having horseradish, but none was in evidence. A friend who had never tried skate marveled at its delicate texture and flavor, served over white beans and garnished with laces of deep-fried leeks. And in a colorful takeoff on Le Cirque's roasted sea bass in a potato crust, Mr. Colicchio camouflages the well-seasoned fillet in slices of zucchini, eggplant, squash and tomato, then sets it over a red-wine fume along with white beans.
Several at my table found the confit of duck a touch too salty, although the texture was right on the mark and the porridgelike polenta with it was a fine foil. Venison chop had a stout gamy flavor and tender texture, served with black mushrooms, lingonberries, delicious pumpkin ravioli and barley. Grilled rib of beef looked great on the plate but had little flavor. A better choice was roasted baby chicken served off the bone with mustard greens and crusty risotto cakes.
The pastry chef, Susie Dayton, turns out a versatile roster of sweets. Warm blueberry tart with vanilla ice cream is a treat, as is the napoleon of figs with a tower of hazelnut parfait on the side. Her tongue-in-cheek chocolate ice cream sandwich - chocolate ice cream, chocolate cake and chocolate sauce - is fun, even though it's 97.5 on the chocoholic meter. One dessert that is promoted heavily and must be ordered in advance is a ganache cake whose warm core of chocolate gushes out like lava when you dig in.
If Mondrian indeed is expiring as scuttlebutt periodically has it, the city's fine dining scene will be poorer for it. Should such a sad day arrive, I certainly wouldn't want to miss the food at the wake.
 
Tatany
Tatany is a feverish Japanese restaurant and sushi bar that runs on overdrive from noon until 10 P.M., with just a short lull between services: a good sign for demanding fish eaters. One gets the impression that nothing sits around in this dining room for more than 30 minutes, including some of the customers. Three recent visits confirmed that for pristine seafood in a simple and pleasant environment, Tatany is still hard to beat.
At lunch and dinner, a legion of seafood aficionados invades these animated, moderate-size dining rooms done in characteristic light wood walls adorned with Japanese artwork. Tatany recently moved three doors down from its previous location into larger quarters.
Some of the better starters on the regular menu include succulent little pork-filled dumplings called shumai and fried eggplant disks called nasu shigiyaki served with rice and sweet miso paste. The negimaki (slices of beef wrapped around broiled scallions) was disappointing because the meat was a bit dry. An outstanding appetizer, though, is called hamachi-kama, or broiled collar of Japanese yellowtail with teriyaki sauce. The collar of the fish is the section between the head and the body, and the meat there is particularly sweet and moist. This one was broiled to perfection and glazed with a little teriyaki sauce. One aspect of Tatany that I noticed after an absence of more than a year is that the service staff seems more rushed and impersonal. On two of three visits, our waiter seemed to have many things weighing on his mind, none of which included serving us. The pace of the kitchen is brisk, though.
Sushi or sashimi can be ordered as an appetizer or main course. Everything I tried was superior: tuna, toro (fatty tuna belly), giant clam, shrimp, flounder, uni (sea urchin) and mackerel, to name a few. The maki, or rolls wrapped in dried seaweed, were freshly made and colorful.
A host of cooked dishes is available. Tempura is cleanly executed, whether it is made with assorted vegetables or seafood. Broiled squiggles of pork in a bright ginger sauce was delicious, as was the swordfish teriyaki. Swordfish also shines in chirashi, which is an assortment of fish and shellfish over warm rice with shredded Japanese yam. Nearly a dozen soba (buckwheat noodles) and udon (wheat noodles) are offered, each in a broth with different ingredients. The sliced beef version, with ungainly thick scallions, mushrooms, onions and hard carrots, was nearly flavorless. The curry broth with noodles was slightly better but one-dimensional. Fruit and various ice creams (some too icy) round out the meal.
Tatany is not about creature comforts and polished waiters. It is about fresh fish. And for that, it rarely disappoints.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Apple Risks Profits on New Line

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
Apple Computer Inc. will introduce three of the most important new computers in its history Monday. Industry analysts expect these lower-priced Macintosh computers to revive the company's flagging revenue growth and increase its market share in the personal computer business.
So why is Wall Street so worried? Apple's stock is selling for little more than half its high of the last 12 months, which was just above $50. Yesterday, the stock, traded over the counter, closed at $27.75 a share, up $1.25. Much of the fall has come in the last three months, but the market's overall decline and the negative outlook for the economy are only partly to blame. 
The answer is that the machines represent a major shift in strategy for Apple and therefore a risk. After emphasizing high-priced computers that produce high profit margins, Apple is shifting toward lower profit margins and, it is hoped, higher volumes.
The risk is that Apple's increase in volume will not quite make up for the lower margins, causing profits to drop. A day after Apple's chief executive, John Sculley, enunciated the low-margin strategy last week, Apple's stock fell 9 percent.
 
Pressure on Unit Sales
''You really need to sell a lot of units just to keep flat,'' said Daniel C. Benton, a personal-computer industry analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company. He is not recommending the stock despite its seemingly low price, and while he expects Apple to begin doing very well starting in June, he sees more upheaval until then. ''We are not yet through all the pain in terms of earnings,'' he said.
Almost everyone agrees Apple had little choice but to lower prices. The Macintosh's advantage over I.B.M.-compatible personal computers in ease of use has been eroding. Apple has been losing the dominant position it once had in selling computers to schools because competitors like the International Business Machines Corporation and the Tandy Corporation offer lower-priced machines. And with its shrinking market share, Apple was beginning to lose the support of software companies, which want to develop new programs for computers with large sales.
The new machines are given generally good reviews by the industry and analysts. They are the black-and-white Macintosh Classic, expected to be offered at a list price of $1,000; the color Macintosh LC, which will sell for $2,500 to $,3000, and the Macintosh IIsi, which will start at about $3,800.
Still, there is concern that Apple will not be able to transform its somewhat loose and lavish California corporate life style into a cost-conscious, disciplined culture. The company has never been known for tough cost controls, except during an occasional crisis.
Apple's gross margin, the amount by which sales exceed manufacturing costs, is about 53 percent. By contrast, the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Houston-based vendor of I.B.M.-compatibles, has gross margins of 40 to 42 percent. Smaller clones, like AST Research and Dell Computer that tend to compete more on price, have gross margins of 35 percent.
By contrast, however, Apple has spent 20 to 25 percent of its revenues on marketing and distribution, about twice as much as Compaq, Mr. Benton said.
Michele Preston, an analyst with Cowen & Company, said she was optimistic that Apple would succeed with its strategy and recommended the stock. She expects Apple's domestic personal-computer market share to grow from 9 percent now to about 12 or 13 percent in the next 18 months.
Ms. Preston said she expected Apple's gross margins over all to drop only to about 50 percent, in part because the low-priced Macintoshes will in large measure replace the Apple II, which was also a low-margin product. Moreover, she said, the new management team under the chief operating officer, Michael H. Spindler, appears capable of instilling the needed spending discipline into the company.
The difference in earnings estimates is wide, reflecting the great uncertainty. Ms. Preston estimated that Apple's earnings in the 1991 fiscal year, which began this month, would rise to $4.65 a share from an expected level of $3.65 for the year that just ended. Revenues should climb 15 percent, to $6.3 billion from $5.5 billion, she said.
Mr. Benton of Goldman, Sachs sees revenues growing in the 1991 fiscal year to $6.2 billion, nearly the same as Ms. Preston's estimate. But his estimate for profits, which he reduced again this week, is for only $4 a share.
Apple also has other clouds hanging over it. The Macintosh, first introduced in 1984, is aging. High-powered work stations, like those made by Sun Microsystems, are beginning to compete with personal computers. And the Macintosh is not compatible with other systems at a time when customers are increasingly demanding machines that adhere to industry-wide software standards.
''My opinion is that Apple is going to have to take some fairly drastic action here to restore confidence in the Macintosh standard and rebuild momentum in Macintosh sales,'' said Mark D. Stahlman, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons. ''These products are not going to do it.''
Apple seems to be moving to take on these longer-term challenges. It is considering, however reluctantly, licensing its Macintosh software to other companies to make Macintosh-compatible products. That will probably start with laptop and notebook Macintoshes made by Sony or Toshiba, or both.
It also plans to add more powerful computers next year and is working on a family of non-Macintosh computers that should start appearing in about two years.

HEADLINE: Dow Slides 42.82 Points, To 2,365.10

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks fell again yesterday, partly in reaction to a 63 percent dividend reduction by Chemical Banking, the nation's sixth-largest banking company. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day down 42.82, at 2,365.10, a 17-month low.
Allowing for a small gain on Monday, the Dow has fallen 145 points, or close to 6 percent, this week. And since mid-July, when it came within a hairbreadth of reaching 3,000, it has sunk 21.2 percent, leaving no doubt on Wall Street that the bears are in control. 
As traders have waited in vain for hard news from somewhere - particularly from the Middle East or Washington - the Dow has tumbled nearly 159 points, or 6.5 percent, in just three days. Prices of Treasury issues also weakened yesterday in the credit markets.
 
Trading Volume Increases
On the New York Stock Exchange, trading volume picked up markedly, to a robust 180.1 million shares, from 167.9 million on Wednesday.
But 1,290 stocks fell in price and 375 reached new lows, including NCR, a widely watched high-tech stock. It slid to 48 3/4 before ending at 50 3/4, down 2 3/8, after Salomon Brothers and Smith Barney lowered their earnings estimates.
The slide in NCR touched off another decline in I.B.M., which was down 2 1/2, to 101, after a 6-point drop in the previous two days.
With two-thirds of the Big Board's stocks losing ground, only 301 moved higher and just 3 reached new highs.
The 1.8 percent drop in the Dow spread through the broad Standard & Poor's average of 500 stocks and to a great extent into the small stocks covered in the Nasdaq composite index, where stock prices slid 2.3 percent.
On an uncharacteristically depressing note, Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, wrote in his current market report, dated Oct. 8, ''We do not think, however, that the bear market has run its course and would treat any recovery in the next couple of months as a temporary respite in a major downtrend.''
Richard T. McCabe, Merrill Lynch's senior market analyst, added yesterday that this outlook '' would still hold true unless the market has an immediate, further substantial decline, a move that would produce a major oversold condition.'' Typically in an oversold market, investors rush in to buy, lifting stock prices.
On a hopeful note, Joan Lappin, president of Gramercy Capital Management, a small Manhattan advisory firm with $70 million under management, remarked: ''This is not fun, but I haven't given up all hope yet. Everybody now thinks we're going off the cliff. But if there's a resolution of the budget - including a solid effort to close the deficit gap - we could be in for a solid bounce.''
The move by Chemical yesterday, coming only three weeks after Chase Manhattan Bank cut its dividend amid worsening real estate problems filtering throughout the economy, came as no great shock. Shortly after noon, with the Dow already down close to 30 points, the ticker carried the news that the New York Stock Exchange had halted trading in Chemical's stock ''pending news.''
Without knowing what the news might be, traders surmised that it was probably a dividend reduction. Within the next few minutes, the Dow slid another 10 points as investors, traders and speculators fled the market.
By 12:30, Chemical said it would lose $43.7 million in the third quarter, add $250 million to its loan-loss reserves and cut dividends next year to 25 cents a share from 68 cents.
By nearly 2 P.M. the Dow had plunged 50 points, prompting the Big Board to move in and bar program selling on a downtick so that selling would not feed on itself. At 3:30, the Dow was still off 50 points.
 
Program Selling Lowers Dow
From 12:02, before the Chemical Bank halt in trading, to 12:28, long after the halt, program selling lowered the Dow by 24 points, said Birinyi Associates, which tracks the effects of program trading. Ten waves of computerized selling had lowered the Dow by 82 points by the close.
Asked why even supposedly invulnerable I.B.M. succumbed to the big selloff, Morgan Stanley's computer expert, Carol E. Muratore, said, ''It's a liquid stock and the market's going down.''
Early in the day, however, Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures, for Shearson Lehman Brothers, remarked: ''This is going to be a nasty one. The selling's beginning to feed on itself.''
Daniel C. Benton, computer expert at Goldman, Sachs, remarked, ''A number of analysts have downgraded it'' and ''it's a very nervous market.'' He noted that I.B.M. would report earnings on Monday.
''We've heard it all before,'' said Mr. Grennan of Shearson. ''Oil's up, bonds are down and the dollar's weak. The market wants to see some results, and until it does it'll chip away at the confidence level.''
The Chemical move ''doesn't come as a tremendous surprise, but it certainly doesn't add to confidence of investors to buy stock,'' he said, adding, ''They don't see any results from anywhere, either good or bad.''
Chemical's stock closed at $13.75, down $1.75.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Terrible Time For a Deadlock

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH's flip-flop on whether or how to raise taxes to reduce the widening budget deficit - leaving the problem for Congress to work out as he hits the campaign trail - is a stunning blow to public confidence in the nation's leadership. It could scarcely have come at a worse time, with the economy sliding toward recession, the markets in turmoil, the dollar falling to new lows, speculators driving oil prices up, down and up, and the United States carrying the heaviest military burdens in the Persian Gulf.
Congress has only a few days to solve the problem before its extension of spending and temporary lifting of the debt ceiling runs out. But pessimism has risen that a genuine reconciliation of conflicts between Democrats and Republicans, and among the Republicans themselves, can be reached in the next week. 
President Bush, who had at first dropped his campaign pledge of ''read my lips, no new taxes'' in accepting the first compromise agreement between the White House and Congressional leaders, is now campaigning for the re-election of opponents like Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who declared his continuing and undying opposition ''to any - read my lips - any tax increase.'' And Mr. Bush, jogging in St. Petersburg, Fla., told reporters, ''Read my hips.''
If the contending politicians in Congress (and the White House, assuming it is still involved) cannot reach a budget agreement by Oct. 19, either the deadline will have to be extended again, perhaps until after the Nov. 6 Congressional elections, or a deal will have to be made that falls far short of cutting $40 billion in 1991 and $500 billion over the next five years. Those are the goals to which the President, on last report, said he remained committed and would not achieve by ''smoke and mirrors.''
But Mr. Bush has lost control over the Republicans in Congress, many of whom, as the saying goes, are now in business for themselves, with ample income from lobbyists and political action committees. The Democratic leadership has the same problem. And the budget stalemate reflects deep differences between the constituencies and ideologies of the parties; it also reflects clashes between economists and their witting or unwitting political disciples.
The supply-siders, still influential with the Republican right, hold that growth would be sapped by any increase in taxes. They are abetted, in strange-bedfellow fashion, by some liberal Keynesian economists, focusing on the short run, who maintain that in existing circumstances growth would be hurt and unemployment increased by trying to get rid of the deficit, either by tax increases or spending cuts. Belief has not died on the Republican right and the Democratic left that the nation can ''grow its way out of the deficit'' - even after eight years and a tripling of the national debt.
Nevertheless, public anxiety about the deficit persists. But for most people it remains an abstraction, while the means of getting rid of it are anything but abstract. Focusing on their own direct interests, many resist the tax increases that would chop into their take-home pay and oppose the cuts in spending or benefits that would cost them income or jobs. So, in the absence of strong political leadership, the budget impasse persists.
In the securities, capital and foreign exchange markets, anxiety is worsening about America's fiscal deficits. What might end the impasse? A financial crisis might bring Congress and the White House to their collective senses. But with the nation's financial structure severely strained, nobody wants to risk a ''crisis solution.''
Thus the odds have worsened against Congress's reducing the deficit by $40 billion in 1991 and $500 billion over five years. The shortfall might have to be concealed after all by ''smoke and mirrors,'' by underestimating spending and pushing some expenditures ''off budget,'' and by overestimating revenue projections.
What will the economic consequences be? Over time, the likely outcome would be continuing sluggishness and possible decline in the American economy, with insufficient savings to support real investment in plants, equipment and research and development of new technology, and with heavy reliance on the inflow of foreign capital. But, with ebbing confidence in American leadership and economic stability, foreign investment would ebb or even go into reverse.
Hope remains that a majority in Congress, worried about the danger to the securities markets, may still be able to salvage a credible budget agreement, which would brace confidence at home and abroad, pave the way for lower interest rates and help curb recessionary forces. But a continued stalemate will aggravate fears of financial trouble and a deeper recession. Hold on to your hats.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Changes at the Top Of Aubrey G. Lanston

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Government securities brokerage house, announced yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, John B. Ford, plans to retire at the end of the year and that he will be succeeded by Richard M. Kelly.
Mr. Ford, 58 years old, who has spent 34 years in the bond business, will continue as a director and counselor, the Wall Street firm said. Mr. Kelly, 47, is currently president. He will be succeeded as president by James A. Rice, 42, senior vice president. 
''It's a wonderfully exciting place, but a tough job, too,'' Mr. Ford said. ''I will be happy to be retired from the trenches, so to speak, and let Mr. Kelly assume the responsibility.''
Lanston is a primary dealer in Federal securities, so designated by the Federal Reserve Bank. It underwrites the Treasury debt at auction, assists the Federal Reserve in carrying out its monetary policy and maintains liquid secondary markets, Mr. Kelly said. Transactions are reported daily to the Fed.
''The business has been more difficult in the last several years,'' Mr. Kelly said, citing narrowed trading profit margins as the problem. As a result, the number of primary dealers has been reduced to 42 from 46 in the last few years, he said.
''That's a trend that may continue,'' Mr. Kelly said. ''The industry could operate just as efficiently with fewer dealers.''
Lanston, founded in 1949, has been owned since 1986 by the Industrial Bank of Japan. ''We have a very high regard for our owners,'' Mr. Ford said. ''They have allowed Lanston to retain its independence and autonomy. In this management change, you'll notice there aren't any Japanese. There hasn't been any cultural problem either.''
Mr. Ford got into the bond business after graduating from Princeton, spent six years with the Bankers Trust Company and joined Lanston in 1962.
Mr. Kelly, a graduate of the University of Florida, joined the Bank of America upon graduation and stayed there for five years before moving to Lanston in 1972. For two years, starting in 1978, he was Deputy Assistant Secretary for debt management at the Treasury Department.
Mr. Rice, the new president, joined Lanston in 1981 as vice president from the Trust Company of Georgia.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rhone-Poulenc to Cut 3,500 Jobs in Brazil

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The giant French chemical and pharmaceutical company Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said today that it would slash 3,500 jobs from its Brazilian work force because Government austerity measures there were crimping business activity.
Voluntary layoffs are being conducted at Sao Paulo-based Rhodia S.A., which makes chemicals, fibers and medical products, a company spokeswoman said. ''People that leave simply won't be replaced,'' she said.
About 2,000 workers have already left since the Brazilian President, Fernando Collor de Mello, instituted his anti-inflation austerity program last year. Another 1,500 are expected to leave in the next two years, the spokeswoman said.
Rhone-Poulenc's first-half profits were off 13 percent from a year earlier, partly because of a $58.7 million loss at Rhodia. It was the first loss recorded by the Brazilian division, which was a jewel in Rhone-Poulenc's crown in the 1980's. Rhodia once accounted for 10 percent of revenue and an impressive 25 percent of profits.
Other French companies have also suffered in Brazil because of the Government's austerity measures. They include the eyeglass specialist Essilor International S.A. and the auto parts producer Valeo S.A.
The Rhone-Poulenc spokeswoman said that the situation in Brazil had improved since midsummer but added that it would be three years before the company regained lost ground.
The job cuts at Rhodia will free money that cash-pressed Rhone-Poulenc can use to help pay for its $2 billion acquisition of the Rorer Group Inc., a pharmaceutical company based in the United States.
An economic slowdown in the United States has cast doubt on the profit-making potential of the new unit, Rhone-Poulenc Rorer S.A.
As part of its cash-raising strategy, the company recently sold its Paris headquarters to a group of French banks and its Spanish polyvinyl chloride business to a unit of Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine.

HEADLINE: Oil Rises $1.73 a Barrel, To Record High of $40.42

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices jumped back over $40 a barrel yesterday to a new record close in hectic futures trading. Analysts blamed dwindling United States stockpiles, looming cold weather and a British warning of a Persian Gulf conflagration.
''It's a market that reacts emotionally,'' said Bob Baker, an oil-trading specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ''It's going to stay that way as long as we have 200,000-plus troops out there.'' 
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price for November delivery of light, sweet crude - the low-sulfur benchmark grade of oil -jumped $1.73 a barrel to close at $40.42, eclipsing the previous record of $40.40 set on Tuesday. The prices for delivery in later months also advanced strongly.
The rise erased the decline of $1.71 a day earlier, when traders dumped oil contracts on an unfounded rumor about the death of Saddam Hussein. The Iraqi leader's seizure of neighboring Kuwait more than two months ago has doubled the price of oil since midsummer.
 
New Jump on Rumor
After the close of futures trading yesterday, prices rose 60 cents a barrel on the cash market because of a rumor that the Palestine Liberation Organization had launched a missile attack from Lebanon against Israeli settlements in the West Bank. The report was unfounded.
Refined products traded on the exchange also surged yesterday. The most notable increase was in wholesale home heating oil for November delivery, which jumped 3.80 cents a gallon, to $1.0485. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for November delivery rose 2.4 cents a gallon, to 96 cents, and natural gas rose 2 cents per 1,000 cubic feet, to $1.96.
Oil market strategists said buyers plunged in at the opening of trading, motivated partly by a report from the American Petroleum Institute released after the close of trading on Wednesday.
The institute, an industry trade group, said its weekly tally of domestic supplies showed a 4.2-million-barrel decline in crude stockpiles and a 1.5-million-barrel drop in distillates, which include heating oil. The declines were considered unusually steep, particularly when seasonal demand for energy to heat homes is increasing.
The report aggravated fears that the United States, which imports half its oil, was growing more vulnerable to shortages as the chances of a Persian Gulf war increased, which could cut off oil supplies from that area.
 
Briton Warns of Force
Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, heightened war fears in the oil pits by saying that force would be used to evict the Iraqis from Kuwait if they did not leave voluntarily.
He said that without a united front against Iraq, ''We shall be back in a world of anarchy punctuated by explosions of force.''
Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said the rhetoric unnerved professional traders, even though Mr. Hurd's remarks were basically no different from warnings to Iraq issued by the United States.
''Traders don't sit down and think about that type of thing,'' Mr. Blakeslee said. ''They don't have time.''

HEADLINE: The Credit Markets;
Treasuries Drop in Volatile Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell again in volatile trading yesterday, pushed lower by the same unsettling melange of factors that have dominated trading for some time.
Prices had moved higher during overnight trading in the Far East, helped by a report in The Washington Post yesterday that suggested that while Federal Reserve Board governors had agreed to lower short-term interest rates once a Federal budget agreement had passed, concerns about inflation would limit the size of the rate cut.
But the tone changed sharply once trading shifted to the United States, where Treasury prices moved lower in the wake of a plunging dollar, rising oil prices and uncertainty surrounding an auction of $5 billion of 30-year bonds for the Resolution Funding Corporation.
 
Not a Success
Worries about the Refcorp auction were heightened on Wednesday, when the Treasury struggled to sell $8.5 billion of seven-year notes. While the worst fears over the auction did not materialize, the sale was not an unqualified success, analysts and traders said. The new bonds were sold at an average yield of 9.33 percent. 
''The auction was not a disaster, but there is a sense that the street picked up the bulk of the issue,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Foreign participation at the Refcorp sale was virtually nil, traders said, but overseas investors have never been keen on Refcorp securities, largely because the market for them is quite illiquid when compared with Treasuries.
The Washington Post report of the Oct. 2 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making body, appeared to confirm the widespread expectation that a budget deal would induce the central bank to relax monetary policy. It also underscored serious concern among many policy makers about stoking inflation, particularly at a time of surging oil prices.
When asked for comment, a Fed spokesman said the account contained ''important inaccuracies'' but declined to specify them. Another Fed official who attended the meeting said it was ''disappointing'' that one or more sources had broken the normal Fed silence surrounding the committee's meetings.
 
'Junk Bonds' Decline
Elsewhere, a further drop in stock market prices, prompted in large part by a sharp cut in Chemical Banking's dividend, helped push down prices for high-yield ''junk bonds.'' Traders said that prices of most high-yield issues fell by about 3/4 point yesterday on thin volume.
Although the market's decline has pushed yields well above 20 percent, participants in the high-yield market said yesterday the current problems were a reflection of the concerns seen in all financial markets, particularly the stock market.
As the most speculative fixed-income instruments, prices of high-yield securities have been highly sensitive to the threats of war, inflation and recession, which have intensified since the onset of the Middle East crisis in early August.
''In my view, what has happened in our market is 100 percent related to the stock market,'' said David Fineman, a high-yield bond trader at Jefferies & Company in Los Angeles.
Tracing the latest downward spiral in the high-yield market to the beginning of August, when Iraq marched into Kuwait, Mr. Fineman said: ''If I see the price of oil exploding, I am very reticent to make bids for junk bonds. You would have a real solid rally in junk if there were a settlement in the Middle East.''
 
Increase Since August
Since the Aug. 2 invasion, the average yield on 20 widely held junk issues tracked by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities has risen by more than 5.5 percentage points, to 20.93 percent yesterday from 15.36 percent.
During the same period, the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, which dropped 42.82 points yesterday, has fallen more than 500 points, or about 18 percent.
''The high-yield market is very weak right now,'' said Peter Karches, head of high-yield trading and sales at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''But anything that helps the equity market would help the high-yield market.''
Treasury dealers also sold securities yesterday in preparation for what is likely to be an extremely bad report, expected this morning, on producer price inflation in September.
Largely because of the continued run-up in oil prices, analysts expect that September's Producer Price Index will show an increase that equals, or possibly exceeds, the huge 1.3 percent gain recorded in August. #30-Year Bonds Those concerns were reflected in the secondary market for Treasury securities, and by late yesterday the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 21/32, down 9/32, to yield 9.07 percent, compared with 9.05 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes fell 1/8 point, to a late offered price of 98 30/32, to yield 8.91 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.96 percent.
Meanwhile, short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.13 percent, down five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by eight basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.14 percent.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in very quiet trading. In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/4 point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Oct. 1. The report had no impact on fixed-income prices.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Downgradings at Record

 BODY:
The credit quality of American corporations declined at a record pace in the first three quarters of this year, Moody's Investors Service Inc. has reported, with a third of the downgradings affecting financial institutions like banks, savings and loans and insurance and finance companies.
The agency said on Tuesday that a rising number of defaults on corporate bonds are expected to continue for the next several quarters. 
There were 308 downgrades of American bond issuers in the first nine months of the year, compared with 339 downgrades in all of 1989. So far this year, the bond ratings of 79 corporations have been raised, far fewer than the 138 rating increases last year.
Moody's noted that so far this year, downgradings have outpaced upgradings by nearly 4 to 1, a record pace that compares with a ratio of nearly 3 to 1 during the 1982 recession, the previous record for the post-World War II period.
In dollar terms, the rating agency said, the worth of the downgraded securities totaled $263 billion in the first three quarters in 1990, or about a quarter of the American companies' total outstanding bonds in the domestic and international markets. The total worth of the rating increases was about $64 billion.
Moody's noted that so far this year, rising oil prices had not been a primary cause of the downgradings, although that could change if oil prices continued to rise sharply and remained high for a prolonged period, putting companies that are heavy uses of petroleum products at risk.
