HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Decline And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies on concern about the health of United States banks and the belief among foreign traders that the United States is headed for a sharp recession.
Gold finished mixed in world trading, while silver continued its slide to its lowest levels in 13 years.
The dollar fared well in European trading on increased anxieties over the Persian Gulf crisis. But it dropped in New York as concerns about United States banks intensified on the Chemical Bank's move to cut its common stock dividend to 25 cents a share after posting a third-quarter loss of $43.7 million. 
''It's down hard today,'' Marc Chandler, senior strategist with the consulting firm IDEA in New York, said of the dollar.
He said other factors influencing its drop included a general bearishness in the market, continued confusion in Federal budget negotiations and tensions in the Middle East.
''We also continue to hear talk of Japanese life insurance companies raising their dollar hedge ratios,'' Mr. Chandler said. ''That means they're selling more dollars to reduce their currency risk.''
The dollar ended the day off only slightly against the yen in New York trading but it weakened considerably against the pound sterling and the German mark.
The dollar closed in New York at 129.47 yen, down from Wednesday's 129.48. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.95 Japanese yen, unchanged from its closing rate on Tuesday before Wednesday's Sports Day national holiday. In London late yesterday the dollar closed at the same rate.
In London, one British pound cost $1.9640 late yesterday, cheaper for buyers than Wednesday's late $1.9755. But in New York, it cost $1.9775 to buy one pound, up from $1.9694 late Wednesday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.5138 marks, from 1.5278.
Other selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday rates, included: 1.2730 Swiss francs, down from 1.2810; 5.0705 French francs, down from 5.1145; 1,134.75 Italian lire, down from 1,145.00, and 1.1468 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1491.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose $1.60 to settle at $389.70 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $391.00, up $2.75 an ounce from late Wednesday.
Gold closed in London at a bid $389.75 a troy ounce, down from $390.25 late Wednesday. The late bid price in Zurich was $389.60, down from $390.75.
Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $390.05, down from $392.15.
Silver continued its slide on the Comex. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.235 a troy ounce, down further from Wednesday's sharp drop to $4.409 - its lowest level since August 1977. Silver traded late in London at a bid $4.28 a troy ounce, down from $4.53 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Announces Reductions Of $2.3 Billion in Capital Budget

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
In perhaps the most telling sign of the fiscal problems that are ahead for New York City, the Dinkins administration yesterday said that it would cut $2.3 billion from the nearly $16 billion it planned to spend on capital programs in the next three years.
The cuts would mean reductions of 31.5 percent in spending for areas like parks, libraries and highway and street reconstruction and 15.8 percent in spending for schools, bridges and housing. Most spending on jails, hospitals, mass transit, fire and police equipment, much of which comes in response to the law or court orders, would be exempt from the reductions.
The capital program, begun after the city recovered from the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, has largely been immune to cuts and has grown substantially, partly because of the severity of the city's infrastructure problems. In May, Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed a no-growth capital spending plan, and warned of the need for future cuts. 
 
Deferring Some Dreams
More than any other sign of economic prosperity, the rebirth of a capital-spending program signaled New York's faith in a bright fiscal future after the dark years of the 1970's. There were plans to spruce up parks and museums, reconstruct roads and repair bridges, renovate courtrooms and playgrounds. The city-financed capital commitment almost quadrupled between 1984 and the 1991 plan.
Officials said yesterday that some of those dreams would be deferred because of the cuts that would save $1.1 billion in interest and principal payments through fiscal year 2001 and more after that. While capital projects are paid for through long-term bonds, the interest and annual principal repayments come from current revenues, which are in decline.
''This is the first time capital spending has been reined in since the fiscal crisis,'' said Budget Director Philip R. Michael. ''Will there be dramatic differences between what could have been and what will be? Yes.'' ''In areas where there would have been roads, they won't be there,'' Mr. Michael said. ''There will be fewer miles of reconstruction of highways, fewer park renovations and fewer schools going up.''
 
Pressed for Details
The announcement of the cuts came only a day after members of the State Financial Control Board urged Mayor Dinkins to move more quickly to detail his plans for keeping the budget balanced. Concern over the city's finances grew last week after Mr. Dinkins, in swift sucession, announced a tentative 5.5 percent raise for teachers and hundreds of millions of dollars in proposed new taxes to expand the criminal-justice system.
The Mayor then detailed a projected budget gap of at least $1.4 billion for the fiscal year that starts next July 1, and the possibility of 15,000 city layoffs.
''It is, without a doubt, a very, very tough program,'' Mr. Dinkins said of the capital-spending cut. ''But even scaled down, it represents the largest public works program of any city in the nation, perhaps in the world.''
Mr. Dinkins said he would adopt a final plan by Dec. 15 for review by the public and the City Council. The plan is subject to the Council's approval.
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the City Council, said yesterday that the budget modifications appear prudent, but Council members have to review specific cuts before assessing the plan.
City officials said all the scheduled plans were important to a city with parks in disrepair and overcrowded schools. Although saying ''some of our municipal dreams will be deferred, but the most important will not be denied,'' Mr. Dinkins said the projects of greatest need will continue. He and Mr. Michael said it is too early to detail them. #20 Percent Cuts Sought ''What's important about this is it's the first recognition since 1982 that the long-term economic outlook isn't one that can sustain long-range capital spending as was planned,'' said Charles Brecher, director of research for the Citizens Budget Commission, a civic organization that monitors the finances of New York City and state.
The commission, which is financed by businesses, recently issued a report calling for the city to cut its capital commitments by 20 percent. Mr. Brecher said yesterday that the new proposals are in the right direction.
''It's a sad necessity, not something to be happy about,'' Mr. Brecher said.
Mr. Dinkins, looking drawn and tense, said yesterday that the retrenchment on capital-spending projects is a recognition that ''we cannot spend what we do not have.''
Mr. Dinkins said that when times were good, the capital program was a wish list. He said now is the time to begin turning things around.
The city placed spending programs in three categories: those exempt because of mandates or other special reasons; those designated for 15.8 percent spending reductions, and those specified for 31.5 percent reductions.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
World Bank May Grant Teheran First Loan Since 1979 Revolution

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The World Bank is expected to lend as much as $300 million to Iran next year, in the bank's first loan to the Teheran Government since before the 1979 Islamic revolution, American officials and banking specialists said today.
American officials said the Bush Administration hoped that the loan would offer it leverage to prevent Iran from violating the United Nations embargo imposed on Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait. The loan would be used to rebuild areas of Iran devastated by an earthquake last summer.
''If Iran were suddenly to break the embargo on Iraq, then obviously we'd oppose any World Bank lending to Iran,'' an American official said. ''For now, we will not oppose it.'' 
Although the United States does not have veto power on World Bank loans, it could almost certainly round up enough Western support to block a loan to Iran.
Banking specialists said Iran's request for the loan was an important signal of its intention to resume involvement in world financial markets, and of its desire to improve relations with the United States and other Western nations.
For the first 10 years after the fall of the Shah in 1979, Iran did not seek international loans, fearing that borrowing from the West could pose a threat to the nation's independence.
 
First Since Revolution
Iran has made requests for loans from private Western banks in the last year. Banking experts said they understood that the earthquake relief loan would be the first major substantial loan to Iran under the Islamic Government from the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank, the two giant international lending agencies.
Loans made by the World Bank, a Washington-based agency that is nominally part of the United Nations system and is formally known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, are largely underwritten by the United States and other Western nations.
''There is great psychological significance in this,'' said Sharif Ghalib, director of the Africa and Middle East department of the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based research organization. ''The loan itself is not as important as the signal it sends that Iran wishes return to a financial and technical relationship with the West.''
American officials and banking authorities said they understood that the loan would be approved by the World Bank later this year or early next year. It would be intended for housing reconstruction in a coastal area along the Caspian Sea, which was left in rubble after the June earthquake. Nearly 35,000 people are said to have died.
Peter Riddleberger, a spokesman for the World Bank, said it had recently sent a delegation to Iran ''to investigate the feasibility of an earthquake reconstruction loan.''
''Some of the members of that team are back in town now and are assessing their findings,'' he said. ''It seems like things are moving along at a fairly normal pace and perhaps by the end of the year, there would be a proposal for a reconstruction loan.''
He said he could not predict whether the loan would eventually be approved by the bank's executive board.
Loan decisions are based on a vote on World Bank member nations. The voting is weighted, and each member's share of the vote is roughly equivalent to its economic strength. The United States has about one-fifth of the vote.
In international financial circles, Iran is seen as a relatively good credit risk, especially after the dramatic jump in the price of oil that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August.
''Iran has a good history of making payments on its debt, even during the Iran-Iraq war,'' Mr. Ghalib said.
 
Break From Khomeini Policies
In a major break from the policies of the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died in June 1989, the Iranian Government announced last year that it would begin borrowing abroad for development projects.
Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Bush Administraton has sent a number of conciliatory messages to Iran through diplomatic channels and has urged Iran to adhere to the economic and military sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations.
While the United States has little first-hand information about Iran's intentions regarding the sanctions, the Administration is hoping that Teheran's interest in obtaining Western aid to rebuild its economy will override any impulse to break the embargo.
The Iranian Government has publicly vowed to support the sactions against the Iraqi Government of Saddam Hussein.
''The World Bank loan could be another carrot to the Iranians, another sign from the United States that we want to improve relations with Teheran and that we want their help in isolating Saddam,'' an Administration official said.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
HOUSE DEMOCRATS BACK DEFICIT PLAN FOR TAXES ON RICH

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Oct. 13

 BODY:
House Democrats on Friday embraced a deficit-reduction plan intended to portray their party as the champion of the poor and middle class, while a battered White House sought to reassert some influence over the budget process.
Early this morning in the Senate, where the Finance Committee chairman, Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, lacked the votes on his panel to pass a purely Democratic plan, members agreed to a bipartisan plan that would increase gasoline taxes by 9.5 cents, limit tax deductions for those earning more than $100,000 and raise the portion of wages subject to Medicare payroll taxes to $89,000 from the current $51,300.
The aim is to cut the Federal deficit by $40 billion in the 1991 fiscal year and $500 billion over the next five years.
 
White House Hopes
The Bush Administration hopes that the Finance Committee's bipartisan approach will become the vehicle for compromise when Congress resumes its budget deliberations next week. Congress faces a Friday deadline for completion of the most important tax-and-spending legislation in years. 
Exhausted by the budget deliberations that have all but consumed Congress and the White House for the last month, lawmakers headed home last night, and President Bush left at midafternoon for a weekend at Camp David. He used the Marine helicopter he shunned last weekend when he traveled from the Presidential retreat in Maryland by motorcade to cut costs when the Government was shut down for lack of spending legislation.
After a week of conflicting public pronouncements by President Bush about his position on tax rate increases, Administration officials found themselves caught between warring factions of House Republicans so bitterly divided that they have been unable to find common ground on any kind of alternative to the Democratic proposal.
 
Higher Taxes on Wealthy
The House Democratic plan, announced in its final form yesterday by the Ways and Means Committee chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, would increase a variety of taxes on the wealthy, including income taxes, and offer a novel type of capital gains tax cut for the middle class. While the wealthy would also derive some advantage from the proposal, the tax breaks are carefully aimed to benefit the middle class. The House plan would also avoid deep spending cuts in the Medicare program or any increases in gasoline taxes.
House Democratic strategists see their plan, which has attracted wide support among party members in the House, as a powerful bargaining weapon in future budget deliberations. It offers Democrats the political opportunity of forcing Mr. Bush and his party to be defenders of the wealthiest taxpayers as Congress tries to reach a consensus on the budget next week.
The capital gains provision in the House Democratic plan would allow individuals to exclude from taxes 50 percent of their profits on sales of real estate, timber, farms and small businesses, up to a lifetime limit of $200,000.
This tax break would not apply to stocks and bonds, but they would be covered by another provision intended specifically to benefit taxpayers with incomes under $100,000. The tax breaks would cost the Treasury $15.8 billion over five years. But this would be more than offset by the Democratic proposals for higher taxes on the wealthy. One provision is to impose a 10 percent surtax on people with incomes over $1 million and raise the top tax rate for families with incomes over $200,000 to 33 percent from the current 28 percent and increase the alternative minimum tax from the current 21 percent to 25 percent. The alternative minimum tax is applied to wealthy individuals whose deductions, exemptions and exclusions are so large that they would otherwise pay a lower tax.
 
Plea for 'Bare Bones' Plan
Hoping to stave off the Democratic plan, President Bush met at the White House yesterday with small groups of Republicans and Democrats to plead for what his spokesman described as a ''bare bones'' deficit reduction plan. ''What that means is something very close to the bipartisan budget agreement,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, referring to a plan negotiated by the Administration and top Congressional leaders and overwhelmingly rejected by the House last week.
''The Ways and Means Committee report that came out a couple of days ago is the closest to that and represents a good plan that we can work with,'' Mr. Fitzwater added. But that plan, adopted without recommendation by the tax panel, was intentionally crafted to clear the way for the partisan bonanza that Democratic leaders offered their rank-and-file members yesterday. Even some Republicans acknowledged it would be hard to resist the Rostenkowski package, especially just weeks before the Nov. 6 Congressional elections.
''For the first time, you're seeing the difference between the Democratic Party and what they want to do and the Republican Party and who they want to protect,'' Mr. Rostenkowski said. A senior House Democratic leadership aide, clearly relishing the prospect of taking the plan to the House floor next week with solid Democratic support, put it more bluntly. ''We're bonded again,'' he said.
While House Democrats gloated, their Republican counterparts made little headway on a plan of their own, with some factions arguing that their package should include a sharp cut in the capital gains tax rates and a small increase in top tax income rates for the wealthy. Other factions were pressing for deeper cuts in domestic spending programs other than Medicare.
''This is Beirut on the Potomac; there are more warring factions than I can count,'' said Representative Marge Roukema, a moderate Republican from New Jersey, who left a closed party conference early yesterday in frustration. ''If we're going to keep rethrashing issues and continuing to put the party in a position where we're certifiably giving huge tax breaks for the rich, I don't want to add to the confusion.''
Representative Don Sundquist, a Tennessee Republican who serves on the Ways and Means Committee, bemoaned the position his party has found itself in and said it was a mistake for the White House to have ever entered into negotiations with Congressional Democrats on a budget plan. ''It was a way of getting compromise and they used it for political advantage,'' he said.
Mr. Sundquist said the chance of getting a new bipartisan compromise ''decreases every day.'' If Republicans cannot put together a package that gets broad support, he added, ''I would encourage my colleagues to go to the voters and say, 'We're going to test the election on this.' ''
 
G.O.P. Candidates Hurt
But other Republicans did not find that prospect particularly inviting. At a White House meeting on Thursday, Representative Guy Vander Jagt, the Michigan Republican who heads the Congressional campaign effort for his party, told President Bush that polling data showed that many Republican challengers in House races had entered ''a free fall'' in their election campaigns.
The final plan Mr. Rostenkowski announced yesterday is intended to take advantage of the confusion over the Republicans' position on taxes by eliminating features of the rejected budget summit agreement that rank and file members in both parties had objected to and offering tax breaks for the middle class.
Democrats were eager to jettison the 12-cent-a-gallon increase in the Federal gas tax included in the budget agreement defeated by the House last week. It would have been one of the most visible elements of the plan - reminding voters everytime they drove up to a gas pump that Congress had raised taxes - and was viewed as disproportionately painful for low- and middle-income wage earners.
The 50 percent lifetime exclusion for $200,000 in capital gains is modeled after a system used in Canada. The exclusion would be available only to individuals 25 or older, and it would apply both to assets already owned and those newly acquired. Although the wealthy could also get some advantage from the plan, they would quickly reach the cap.
A separate provision would permit individuals to realize up to $1,000 each year in capital gains without having to pay any tax. This tax break would be available for all assets, including stocks and bonds, held for at least one year and would be phased out for individuals with incomes of $100,000 to $150,000. It would not count against the lifetime limit.
Capital gains are currently taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, 28 percent for most people. Although the House Democratic plan would raise the top tax rate for families earning above $200,000, to 33 percent from the current 28 percent, the maximum capital gains rate under the proposal would not exceed 28 percent.
Another provision incorporated in the plan yesterday would freeze for one year the arrangement in the current tax code that annually adjusts tax exemptions for inflation. On Thursday, Mr. Rostenkowski announced a similar freeze on the annual inflation adjustment for tax brackets.
 
Senate vs. House Plans
The plan approved by the Senate Finance Committee differs from the House plan in several important respects. It would include no capital gains reduction or increase in the top income tax rate. In addition to increasing the gasoline tax and raising the portion of wages subject to a Medicare payroll tax, it would impose a 5 percent floor on itemized deductions for taxpayers with incomes over $100,000. The plan also would raise the deductible Medicare recipients pay before their coverage takes over to $150 from the current $75. In addition, the panel has agreed on $3.5 billion in tax breaks for oil and gas producers that would be phased in if the price of oil drops below $34.
Overall, the House Democratic plan would raise more than $140 billion in new revenue over the next five years. The plan would raise taxes on cigarettes, beer, wine and spirits; impose a 10 percent luxury tax on expensive cars, boats, private airplanes, furs and jewelry, and increase the wage base for the payroll tax that finances part of the Medicare program to $100,000 from the current $51,300.
The Medicare programwould be cut by $43 billion. The spending cut would mean that the monthly premiums recipients pay would rise from $28.60 to $29.90 in 1991 and then rise at a pace slower than the expected rate of inflation for the next four years.

HEADLINE: Tunisians Discussed Gulf Solution in Baghdad

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To set the record straight on the mention in a Sept. 24 news article that ''a high-ranking delegation'' from Tunisia discussed ''economic cooperation'' in Baghdad:
The Tunisia delegation was led by Prime Minister Hamed Karoui. The purpose of the visit to Baghdad was to convey a written message from President Ben Ali concerning Tunisian proposals for a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis. The same proposals had recently been presented to many other governments in the world, including that of the United States.
At his arrival in Baghdad, the Prime Minister declared, ''President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali has entrusted me with conveying a written message to President Saddam Hussein pertaining to the gulf crisis in the framework of the search for a peaceful settlement of this issue.'' Following his meeting with the Iraqi leader, Mr. Karoui stated, ''We agreed on the necessity to find a peaceful solution to the crisis.''
No ''economic cooperation'' with Iraq was discussed during the visit, and it is important to emphasize in this respect Tunisia's continued adherence to the principles of the Charter of the United Nations and its respect for the resolutions of the Security Council on the Persian Gulf crisis, including Resolution 661 on the embargo.
 
ABDELAZIZ HAMZAOUI
Ambassador of Tunisia
to the United States
 Washington, Sept. 27, 1990

LENGTH: 498 words

HEADLINE: Helping Break the Ice in Korea

 BODY:
North Korea has started to break out of its long, icy alienation from the West. Kim Il Sung, the only leader the North has ever had, recently welcomed a high-level Japanese delegation as ''old friends'' and agreed to talks on establishing diplomatic ties.
By following in Japan's footsteps, Washington could widen the opening to the North. That, in turn, could relax hostility on the peninsula and encourage a broader range of contacts between North and South Korea. 
The end of the cold war has freed Korean diplomacy from its ideological straitjacket. Moscow was the first to move, establishing ties with the South that have quickly expanded to full diplomatic relations. Washington initiated discreet contact with the North in late 1988 but has let Tokyo take the lead in coaxing Pyongyang out of its self-imposed isolation. In response Pyongyang is freeing two Japanese seamen whose seven-year imprisonment on spy charges poisoned relations with Tokyo.
Now it's Washington's turn. The United States has much to gain from contact with the North. That could cool passions on the peninsula, long a flash point, and encourage the North to open its nuclear facilities to international inspection. It could also allow the U.S. to bring more of its 45,000 troops home, along with all their nuclear weapons. And it could permit a slowed tempo of naval operations offshore.
Pyongyang, which feels itself threatened by the American presence, should appreciate these steps. And its faltering economy may necessitate expanded exchange with the industrialized world.
Spartan self-sufficiency worked to a point for the North, but that point is long past. Lacking the arable land to feed its industrial workers, it is looking abroad for grain. And it has proceeded as far as it can on the road to industrialization without high-technology imports. Having grown at roughly 3 percent a year over the past decade, one-third the South's pace, it is now experiencing a fall in industrial production.
Great Leader Kim may fear that increased contact with the non-Communist world will loosen his grip. And his closed society is more vulnerable to the shock of recognition than China's. But a gradual opening up may be preferable to continuing economic erosion that eventually sets off a political landslide, as in East Germany or Romania.
South Korea is uneasy about Japan's approach to the North. But it can afford to be more self-confident. As a sign of that, Seoul is now willing to discuss North Korea's formula for sharing a United Nations seat and to negotiate on arms cuts. And it has begun relaxing oppressive laws against fraternization with the North. But some South Koreans still languish in prison for violating those outdated statutes. And Seoul is still too timid about encouraging people-to-people ties. The new fluidity in Korea diplomacy is a welcome result of a thaw in the Far East. Washington can do more to encourage further warming by expanding contacts with Pyongyang.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 300 words

HEADLINE: The Golden Door, Ajar

 BODY:
Congress, having transformed the law on illegal immigration in 1986, is on the verge of another remarkable achievement: the first major reform of legal immigration in 25 years.
Thanks to an extraordinary coalition of conservatives and liberals, the Senate and House have passed bills that would make it easier for families to reunite and for businesses to recruit workers. The bills honor America's history as a nation of immigrants, while recognizing the need for economic growth.
Under present policy, about 540,000 immigrants enter the country each year. About 90 percent of them are related to people already residing in the United States. That leaves about 54,000 slots for skilled workers and their dependents. If America is to meet global competition, it ought to be easier for the best and brightest workers to come here.
The House version was more generous. It allowed for 775,000 new immigrants each year, compared with 630,000 allowed by the Senate bill. Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming, however, refused to accept the higher number, and he got both sides to accept a cap of about 675,000 for the next four years.
Of that total, about 480,000 would qualify under various family preferences; 140,000 would be admitted as independents or skilled workers; 55,000 would be admitted from regions that are now underrepresented. In addition, procedures for securing various employment-related visas would be streamlined.
Congress can readjust the numbers in four years and may have to, in order to keep a growing number of family members from being squeezed out.
This sensible legislation retains the heart of American immigration policy by stressing family reunification and providing for skilled workers. The House and Senate deserve credit for keeping America's golden door open.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
It was once the case that when a nation went to war, religion, too, signed on for the duration. But during the Vietnam War and the drawn-out conflicts in Central America, America's religious leaders split. Some blessed the Government's ventures, while many were active in anti-war organizations.
The volunteer Army and rapid mobilization have put religious leaders at a disadvantage. Two months ago, the largest military buildup since Vietnam took place without America's religious leaders doing much more than nodding in somewhat tentative acquiescence. If they had doubts, these were overcome by recognition of the brutality of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and his country's invasion of Kuwait, and by the international consensus that President Bush put together in support of his policy. 
Now Christian leaders of many denominations are seriously discussing the moral issues raised by the our Persian Gulf intervention. Not a moment too soon, goes one reaction. Let's only hope that morality survives, goes another.
Both reactions are right. In the Persian Gulf, the United States faces excruciating moral decisions, and it needs all the guidance it can get. It faces an adversary who has proved himself ready to ignore whatever rules of warfare have managed to establish themselves. The temptation for the United States to do the same will be great.
But whether the churches are well equipped to give sound moral leadership is another matter.
Some of the positions staked out in recent weeks are grounded in established religious tradition. Catholic moralists took sharp objection, for example, when several top miltary officials suggested that American action against Iraq might open with a virtually unrestrained bombing campaign.
The principle that civilian populations should not be the target of military strikes was widely violated in terror bombing during World War II as well as at Hiroshima and Nagasaki. But it remains a central point in ''just war theory,'' the tradition that tries to distinguish between just and unjust warfare. It is a tradition that Catholic moralists have kept alive but one with strong secular roots and with parallels in other religious traditions.
By no means does everyone accept ''just war theory.'' And applying its principles involves judgments about concrete circumstances that are inevitably debatable. Is military force being used only as a ''last resort,'' for instance, or are the likely benefits of a military action ''proportional'' to the likely harm? But the theory's premises and its implications have been thoroughly spelled out over centuries of both religious and secular discussion.
Not so some of the other approaches that church leaders are now offering to testing the morality of the Persian Gulf policy. Consider three of the themes running through many critical examinations of that policy. One is the history of Western colonial powers and the United States in dominating and exploiting regions of the Middle East - and even of arming Saddam Hussein himself as a counter against Iran. Another is America's greedy, oil-guzzling and energy-wasting life style. A third is America's reliance on military might rather than diplomacy and economic sanctions.
One could debate some of the particulars of these indictments, but supposing that in very important respects they are true, it remains unclear what follows. In religious terms, the United States should repent its past and amend its present. But what does that mean specifically, here and now, for actions in the gulf?
Should awareness of past failings make us more self-critical about our present motives, more understanding of the way our presence is perceived as a threat - or should these failings perhaps disqualify the United States morally from acting in the region at all?
Presume that remedying energy overconsumption, and all the other things wrong with American society, is an overdue but nonetheless complicated and long-term process. Should America suspend efforts to insure oil supplies until those goals are achieved? Is the oil issue in the gulf a matter primarily of a few cents on a gallon of gas or of guaranteeing Americans a luxurious life style? Is the potential control of nearly half the world's petroleum supply by a ruthless dictator a legitimate matter of national interest and international order?
There are different plausible answers to these questions. But if themes like Western dominance in the Middle East or America's life style are to contribute to the moral discussion of gulf policy, then these further questions must be asked and the answers spelled out. One cannot slide by implication to a conclusion about the gulf crisis without making the intervening arguments explicit.
Two characteristics seem to mark the more outspoken religious critics of the gulf policy. The first is a deep revulsion, both moral and visceral, from any use of military force. The second is a deep distrust of the United States's capacity to act constructively overseas.
Both of these are defensible positions, especially in the face of a potential conflagration in the Middle East. But holding to them may not always or necessarily coincide with the most effective measures for countering Saddam Hussein - and when that looks like the case, the critics should candidly admit that they face a hard choice. They, above all, should know that this is not the best of all possible worlds.
Politicians already offer emotional appeals and short-hand conclusions. The churches can contribute disciplined moral reasoning that acknowledges premises, spells out arguments and confronts hard choices.

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: Four Years After Birth, Should 'the Bubble' Burst?

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
As members of Congress strain to produce a budget agreement, a tax-code anomaly called ''the bubble'' has become a fixation for lawmakers, and one of the questions asked most often on Capitol Hill these days is whether to pop it.
To many, the bubble is the marker of what is frequently viewed as an overly regressive income tax code created by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, because it imposes a lower rate of tax on the income of the very wealthy than on some income of the less well to do.
And it has become central to the current debate because many argue that bursting the bubble would be a quick and effective way of redistributing the tax burden more heavily to the nation's rich while at the same time generating large amounts of new revenue to lower the huge budget deficit.
 
A Capital Gains Tradeoff
Indeed, the idea of raising income taxes on the rich has become so attractive that many Democrats are willing to accept a lowering of the tax rate on capital gains - profits from investment, which are currently taxed as ordinary income - if they can win a bursting of the bubble. 
''What you see is a political tradeoff,'' said Henry J. Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington. ''You hope to trade more progressivity on the overall tax rates in exchange for less progressivity in the area of capital gains.''
But the rhetoric surrounding the push to pop the bubble is often larger than the regressive nature that its opponents attribute to it.
''Unfortunately, some people believe incorrectly that taxpayers subject to the 33 percent rate are being treated unfairly, compared to higher-income taxpayers whose top marginal rate is 28 percent,'' Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, wrote to a colleague earlier this year. ''In fact, the bubble does not reward the rich.''
Mr. Bradley's point addressed not only the nature of the bubble but also some tax benefits extended to those who fall within it but denied those with higher incomes.
 
How the Bubble Works
The bubble - so called because it lends that appearance on any graph illustrating the range of all income tax brackets - is a 33 percent rate of taxation that applies to part of the income of only the upper middle class and those who might be called the lower rung of the wealthy. A married couple who file jointly, for example, and who have $78,400 to $185,760 in taxable income - the figure remaining after all exemptions, deductions and adjustments are taken into account -pay a 15 percent rate on their first $32,450, 28 percent on the next $45,950 and 33 percent on the rest up to $185,760.
By contrast, a couple with taxable income of more than $185,760 pay a rate of only 28 percent. But that rate is a flat rate, applicable to every dollar of taxable income: such a couple receive no benefit from the 15 percent bracket. And unlike the couple in the bubble, who are allowed all personal exemptions in computing their taxable income, those who pay the 28 percent flat rate are allowed none.
As a result of all this, the effective tax rate - the proportion of income that is actually paid in taxes - is 28 percent for those in the upper bracket but only about 20 percent to about 25 percent for most of those in the bubble.
 
The Birth of the Bubble
The bubble sprang from the Tax Reform Act, Congress's effort four years ago to overhaul the tax system by creating fewer brackets, lowering the rate of the top ones and closing loopholes - and still have a plan that would be ''revenue neutral,'' providing neither an increase nor a decrease in Government tax revenue.
Previously, a smooth, upward-moving tax curve on successively higher incomes was accomplished by 15 different tax brackets. But limiting the number of brackets to two - at 15 and 28 percent - created problems when lawmakers sought at the same time to close off a number of loopholes.
According to tax specialists who worked on the legislation, what could not be done politically was to set a top tax rate above 28 percent. For example, no bubble would have been needed if the tax writers had been permitted to set the upper rate at 29.5 percent. But at the time, that rate was sufficiently unacceptable to a number of Republicans that any agreement would have collapsed.
Thus, to keep the bill revenue neutral, lawmakers agreed to add a surtax of five percentage points on those with taxable incomes of $78,400 to $185,760, so that their effective tax rates gradually moved toward 28 percent. So was the bubble born.
Now, however, the bubble has come to symbolize an agent for change. Bursting it, by extending the 33 percent bracket to those above the bubble, would accomplish a sorely needed goal: raising precious new revenue to reduce a behemoth deficit. And for liberals, it would realize one of their primary themes: placing a greater tax burden on the very rich. They argue that they see no reason why someone earning $3 million, for whom the loss of exemptions and the benefit of the 15 percent bracket is insignificant, should not pay an incrementally higher rate of tax than someone earning $300,000.
Many conservatives cringe at such suggestions. Defending a long-held tenet of Republican politics, they argue that if too heavy a tax burden is placed on the rich, savings and much needed investment will fall. The economic effects, they assert, could be enough to push the economy into a recession, causing widespread job losses for those of lesser income, the very group liberals say they want to protect.
This was a particulary effective argument for the Reagan Administration, which pushed through Congress some of the largest tax cuts in history. But many wonder whether the Bush Administration believes as strongly in the argument and whether the political pressure facing many Republicans will enable the White House to hold a hard line.
As a result, a number of tradeoffs that would exchange a tax cut in capital gains for a higher income tax rate on the wealthy are circulating.
In the House, the boldest plan has been proposed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee. Today he proposed major new taxes on the rich - a 10 percent surtax on those earning more than $1 million and extending the 33 percent rate to the upper-income bracket - as well as a capital gains rate cut that is geared almost entirely toward owners of small businesses and middle-income taxpayers. Mr. Rostenkowski's staff estimated that the bubble-bursting provision alone would add $44 billion to the Treasury over the next five years.
House Republicans, meanwhile, are discussing a plan, which has a very slim chance of passage, that would lower the capital gains tax to 15 percent while increasing the upper-income tax bracket to 31 percent. In the Senate, Republican opposition to an increase in the top tax rate has effectively blocked any tradeoff with a capital gains cut.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Egypt's Parliament Speaker Is Assassinated by Gunmen

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The Speaker of Egypt's Parliament was assassinated today outside a luxury hotel by the Nile. Police officials and witnesses said gunmen on motorcycles sprayed his chauffeured sedan with automatic-rifle fire before disappearing into the warrenlike streets of the Egyptian capital.
The Speaker, Rifaat al-Mahgoub, a 64-year-old lawyer, was the country's second-ranking official and the most prominent Egyptian political leader to be assassinated since Islamic fundamentalists gunned down President Anwar el-Sadat in October 1981.
There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, which also killed three of Mr. Mahgoub's guards, but the suspicion of many ordinary Egyptians fell on either Muslim fundamentalists or Palestinians armed and inspired by Iraqi agents. 
 
Opposition to Iraqi Invasion
Egypt, the leading Arab ally of the United States and the only Arab country formally at peace with Israel, has taken the lead in opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
On Wednesday, Interior Minister Abdel Halim Moussa said the authorities were investigating five cases in which terrorists ''of Palestinian and other Arab nationalities'' were caught entering Egypt with plans for ''the assassination and destabilization of Egypt's security.''
''They have confessed that they came to join other elements, living in Egypt for years, to commit their crimes,'' he said.
After today's killing, the minister told reporters, ''It could be an internal operation or an external one.''
Witnesses to Mr. Mahgoub's assassination and the police said two gunmen, on the rear seats of motorcycles driven by accomplices, ambushed his black Mercedes as it drove by the 28-story Semiramis Intercontinental Hotel, one of a string of high-rises on the east bank of the Nile, and a block from the United States Embassy. The hotel's guests include senior figures from Kuwait's Government-in-exile.
 
A Minute of Intense Shooting
''There was about a minute of very intensive firing, and we all threw ourselves to the ground,'' said a British guest at the Semiramis. Shortly after the shooting, the body of one bodyguard in the Mercedes lay in the front seat, and the body of a second guard hung from the door of a blue Peugeot escort vehicle about 200 yards away. Brass cartridge casings littered the streets.
Egypt's Middle East News Agency said the assailants later opened fire on police officers who tried to prevent them from crossing a bridge across the Nile as they sped off after the killing. But no other injuries were reported, and no arrests were reported either.
According to the Constitution, the Parliament Speaker is the second-ranking official in the country after the President. Mr. Mahgoub's real power was limited to the 458-seat Parliament, where he was viewed as a loyalist of President Hosni Mubarak. He had been Speaker since 1984.
Mr. Mahgoub had a law degree from Cairo University and a doctorate in economics from the Sorbonne. He became Minister for Presidential Affairs in the Sadat Cabinet in 1972 and was named Deputy Prime Minister three years later.
Western diplomats said his killing raised concerns about Egypt's internal security at a time when officials say the Government has been targeted along with other Arab governments opposed to Iraq for their support of United States policy in the Persian Gulf.
On Thursday, President Mubarak told reporters: ''We are not afraid of anything. We do not need any security assistance from abroad. We are more secure than ever before, because the security organizations in our country are on alert.''
 
Claims of Responsibility
Since the killing of Mr. Sadat, a variety of Arab nationalist and Islamic fundamentalist groups have taken responsibility for killings or attempted killings on Cairo's streets. Their targets have included Israeli and American diplomats as well as high-ranking Egyptians. In February, a Palestinian Islamic group in Lebanon took responsibility for an attack on a tour bus east of Cairo in which nine Israelis were shot to death. The assailants have never been found.
As the gulf crisis has unfolded, the Egyptian authorities have said members of a Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal, who is now reported to be based in Baghdad, have been seized trying to enter the country.
''Iraq is pushing forces to create a state instability for us, strike at some installations, throw some bombs and use arms to attack buses,'' Mr. Mubarak said in a speech on Oct. 4. ''We caught them. We will arrest the rest.''
The Egyptian authorities' fear, according to officials, is that a wave of terrorist attacks in Egypt could undermine Mr. Mubarak's position on the gulf crisis by forcing Egyptians to conclude that his policies had backfired.
But the Egyptian leader has shown no sign so far of modifying his opposition to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. A presidential statement tonight implicitly linked the assassination of Mr. Mahgoub to the perceived Iraqi effort to undermine Egypt's gulf role.
''This detestable crime, which stooped to the lowest depths of treachery and cowardice, can never affect our great people's determination to continue to give for the sake of God and the homeland and to protect the sanctities of the Arab and Muslim nations and safeguard their vital interests,'' it said.
The United States condemned the assassination as ''the most vile kind of terrorism,'' and President Bush telephoned Mr. Mubarak to convey his condolences.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
New Cars, Rebates And Warranties

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The 1991 automobile models have arrived amid economic conditions gloomy enough to dishearten buyers. But a silver lining for consumers is the significant cash rebates that have been available on many new models since Sept. 26, the day they were introduced.
In previous years the manufacturers were able to delay offering rebates on many new models for weeks or months in the hope that buyer demand would be strong enough to stave off rebates.
As usual, every car and truck sold as a 1991 model will be advertised as ''new and improved.'' But only a few represent distinct changes or improvements on their predecessors. Here is a look at some of what is new. 
 
The New G.M. Saturn
One of the most important new cars is the Saturn line of sporty compacts from the General Motors Corporation, which go on sale at a handful of new dealerships in the South and West on Oct. 25. A G.M. spokesman said Saturn dealers on the East Coast will not open until after January. As with all new cars, the rate of production is increasing very slowly.
Saturn is G.M.'s most ambitious effort to recapture buyers by duplicating the quality and performance of Japanese small cars. The basic Saturn costs less than $8,000, and most reviewers have been complimentary after driving early prototypes.
Other major developments from General Motors include a new and powerful 3.4-liter multivalve engine to be offered in certain versions of the Pontiac Grand Prix, the Chevrolet Lumina and the Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme. Until recently, domestic manufacturers have been reluctant to pursue this technology, which employs more than the normal two valves per piston and generally delivers more power from a smaller and lighter engine.
The Oldsmobile 98 and Buick Park Avenue from General Motors are restyled, while the Cadillac division has an improved V-8 engine that increases horsepower output to 200 from 180 while also slightly increasing fuel efficiency. In a few months Buick will bring out its full-size Roadmaster, similar to the Chevrolet Caprice introduced earlier this year.
 
Ford Escort, Mazda Protege
Earlier this year the Ford Motor Company introduced a new Escort that was completely redesigned in partnership with the Mazda Motor Corporation. The Escort, with a base price of $7,976, is very similar to the Mazda Protege, $9,359.
Ford brought out a four-door utility vehicle, the Explorer, $15,406, a few months ago. It will compete with G.M.'s new four-door Blazer, $15,308, and the ChryslerCorporation's Jeep Cherokee four-door at $13,992. These and other prices given here are for the lowest-priced models. Buyers typically will spend several hundred or several thousand dollars more.
Ford also has a new V-8 engine this year that cost about $1 billion to develop. It belongs to a family of new engines that will be lighter and more powerful than the engines they replace. At present, only a few are being made for the Lincoln Town Car.
Chrysler's new Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager minivans, $13,215, were introduced in the summer and remain the most popular of their type. The interiors are slightly restyled, and Chrysler has replaced some instruments, made the sliding door easier to use and adjusted the suspension to improve handling.
Some noteworthy enhancements for the 1991 models have nothing to do with metal, plastic or leather. Cadillac is dropping the cash deductible of $100 that applied to most of its warranties. Ford is doing the same for its Lincoln models, and is halving its $100 deductible on all other cars.
Until now, customers who needed repairs covered by their cars' warranties were compelled to pay a cash deductible for each repair, a requirement that alienated many owners, especially since most Japanese and European luxury models have warranties with no cash deductible. Dropping the deductible probably will raise the auto makers' warranty costs, but improved quality should eventually reduce them. At any rate, most dealers say that dropping or lowering the deductible is a good way to win back customers.
Among imports, the Toyota Tercel subcompact, $6,488, has been restyled inside and out. The Nissan Motor Corporation has a new Sentra model at $7,999, and an additional model for its Infiniti luxury line, the G20, $17,500. Hyundai, the South Korean auto maker, has added the two-door Scoupe (as in scoop), a sporty subcompact at $8,395, to its line.
From Europe, Volvo's 940 series, costing $27,855 to $32,950, now has the mechanical characteristics of the 760 series, but with a more rounded body.
The Honda Motor Company's new Acura NSX is a $60,000 high-performance sports car designed to be competitive with Ferraris, Porsches and Lamborghinis at a considerably lower price. Honda says only 3,000 Acura NSX's will be sold in this country.

GRAPHIC: The Saturn, at top, the car General Motors hopes will recapture buyers of imported cars (General Motors). Toyota has introduced a restyled Tercel, middle, (General Motors) and Ford has a new Escort, redesigned in partnership with Mazda. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
A Car Is Rated Most Trouble-Free, But How Good Is That?

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
The advertisement says that J. D. Power and Associates ranks the car as ''the most trouble-free'' in its class. That's good for the prospective buyer, right? Well, maybe. Or maybe it's just good for the automobile maker who is choosing to advertise only part of the information the Power survey provided.
Some manufacturers are using the results of the Power group's buyer satisfaction surveys in ways that may confuse consumers. And some consumer advocates are unhappy that the company refuses to provide information about cars that do poorly in the surveys. 
John D. Power 3d, president of the company, based in Agoura Hills, Calif., said the advertisements that use his studies were helpful to car buyers. But he acknowledged that his company stopped releasing negative data about new cars four years ago after automobile makers threatened to stop buying his surveys.
''Manufacturers are the ones who pay for the studies,'' Mr. Power said in a telephone interview, ''and we had a number of poorer performers tell us that if you are going to release this stuff to the public, why should we fund the study?''
 
The Surveys Used in Ads
The Power company conducts two surveys of customer satisfaction that are often used in advertising. They are the Initial Quality Survey and the Customer Satisfaction Index.
The Initial Quality Survey polls about 90,000 buyers of cars and utility vehicles. Their names are selected randomly from car registrations across the country in the first 60 to 90 days of ownership. About 35 percent respond. The survey, which covers individual models, focuses on such mechanical problems as engine and brake performance, squeaks, rattles, steering and handling. The questionnaires go out soon after new models reach showrooms in October and results are reported in February.
The Customer Satisfaction Index is based on car lines - all Buicks, for example - rather than on individual models. About 100,000 buyers chosen at random are polled about one year after they buy their vehicles, and about 35 percent respond. The survey looks at mechanical problems and services provided by dealers.
 
Quality of the Research
Several consumer advocates said that in general, they like the research techniques used by the Power company and its emphasis on buyer satisfaction.
''I think satisfaction in a car is really important, because performance is the same between many cars,'' said Robert Knoll, head of the auto test division of Consumer Reports magazine, which tests cars and also surveys owner satisfaction. Mr.Knoll said that with a few exceptions, the cars that receive high ratings from Power surveys also rank high in Consumer Reports' surveys.
Car makers definitely like the surveys. ''A win in one of their categories is regarded as a plus for the product,'' said J. David Hudgens, a spokesman for the General Motors Corporation. The impact on sales of a high rating can be substantial. For consumers, however, the Power studies can be confusing. The major surveys have more than 20 categories in which winners can claim bragging rights, everything from compact minivans to midsize specialty cars to sports cars. This year manufacturers are using Power findings to tout 12 models, a promotional flood that concerns even Mr. Power.
''We run the risk of putting ourselves out of the business of providing this information if it becomes irrelevant,'' said Mr. Power, who worked as a market researcher for the Ford Motor Company before he started his own business in 1971.
Consumer advocates are more worried about the impressions some advertisements may be leaving. They point out one for the Chevrolet Lumina that calls it ''the most trouble-free car in its class,'' citing Power's 1990 Initial Quality Survey. The claim is accurate, but the competition wasn't tough; the survey found that in the number of problems reported, the Lumina finished below the industry average. But the other domestic cars in Lumina's midsize specialty class scored even worse.
''It is very easy for advertisers to take these ratings out of context,'' said Jack Gillis, author of ''The Car Book'' (Harper & Row, $8.95), an annual publication that rates cars based on data collected by the Federal Government.
Four years ago the Power company began reviewing ads the car makers proposed to use, and charging the manufacturers sizable fees for the work. Mr. Power defends the Chevrolet Lumina promotion. ''The industry average is not bad,'' he said, ''so even if you are just below it doesn't mean the car is bad.''.
 
Bowing to Industry Pressure
Consumer advocates agree that the Power research techniques and results appear immune to industry influence. But with the industry supporting his work, Mr. Power is not as free as Consumer Reports, for one, which takes no money or advertising from car producers and refuses to let them use its ratings in promotions.
Mr. Gillis said, ''When you decide to sell information to the people you are reviewing, you destroy the arm's-length relationship.''
Mr. Power acknowledges that he has bowed to pressure from the industry at least once. Until four years ago, his company made public the names of cars that scored poorly on the surveys, and this valuable data made its way into Mr. Gillis's books and other publications.
The company stopped releasing the names of cars that buyers were unhappy with at the same time it began charging manufacturers fees to review their advertisements, but Mr. Powers said there was no connection between the moves.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Day Mixed; Trading Termed 'Nervous'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday in trading that currency dealers said was influenced by many factors, from uncertainty about the Federal budget negotiations to falling oil prices.
''This is just a very volatile market,'' said Lloyd G. Atkinson, chief economist with the Bank of Montreal. ''There's not much to make out of trends. It's just a very, very nervous market.''
Mr. Atkinson said foreign traders were shocked by developments in Washington, where budget negotiators have been unable to reach an agreement on a plan to reduce the deficit.
 
Bush's Shifting Stance
''I'm astounded in terms of the flip-flop that's going on on the part of George Bush,'' Mr. Atkinson said, referring to the President's shifting stance on raising taxes for the wealthy in exchange for a cut in the capital gains tax.
The dollar settled in New York at 129.05 Japanese yen, down from 129.47 on Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.65 yen to close at 129.30 yen. Later, in London, it fell to 128.65 yen. A British pound fetched $1.9675 in New York, less than the $1.9775 of late Thursday. But earlier in London, the pound rose to $1.9740, from $1.9640 late Thursday.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.5243 marks, from 1.5138.
 
Other Selected Rates
Other selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday rates were: 1.2860 Swiss francs, up from 1.2730; 5.1055 French francs, up from 5.0705; 1,142.25 Italian lire, up from 1,134.75, and 1.1471 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1468.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.5175 German marks, down from 1.5330; 1.2780 Swiss francs, down from 1.2910; 5.0855 French francs, down from 5.1292; 1.7110 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7280; 1,137.25 Italian lire, down from 1,147.25; 1.1470 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1512.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Prices Rebound a Bit; Some See Bottom of a Slide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver prices rose yesterday after hitting a 14-year low that some analysts said might have marked the bottom of a steep slide.
On other commodity markets, gold futures dropped and orange juice collapsed.
Silver settled 7 cents to 7.1 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for spot delivery up 7.1 cents at $4.306 an ounce. 
Gold ended $2.20 to $2.30 lower, with the spot October contract at $387.50 an ounce.
Spot silver opened at $4.20 on the Commodity Exchange after tumbling as low as $4.05 overnight on overseas markets. The overnight price represented the metal's lowest price since late 1976, when silver hit $3.80, according to the Commodity Exchange.
The fact that prices rebounded after nearing $4 may indicate the market is seeking or has found a bottom, analysts said.
Don Tierney, metals analyst with Fortune Commodities Inc. in New York, said it costs $4 to $4.50 an ounce to mine domestic silver.
''With the market holding above that magic $4 number, it will look attractive to traders looking for a new, cheap position,'' he said.
Bruno Zbinden, chief of precious metal trading for the Swiss Bank Corporation, said he would not rule out a price dip below $4 an ounce, ''but this is a level where investors should be able to buy silver and do nicely over the long term.''
Silver's plunge from about $4.70 an ounce began Tuesday, prompted by mounting fears that a recession would curtail industrial demand for the metal.
Some analysts said yesterday's gain of almost 33 points in the Dow Jones industrial average may have helped ease recession worries.
Orange juice futures plunged on the New York Cotton Exchange after the Agriculture Department released a Florida orange harvest projection on Thursday that was far above expectations.
The near-term contract, for delivery in November, opened down the permitted daily limit of 10 cents a pound, forcing a trading halt. Trading resumed with an expanded limit of 20 cents in the November contract.
Frozen concentrated orange juice for November delivery settled down 16.45 cents at $1.1345 a pound. All other delivery months fell their permitted limit of 5 cents.
The Agriculture Department estimated a Florida orange harvest of 165 million 90-pound boxes and a yield of 1.52 gallons a box compared with last year's frost-reduced harvest of 110.2 million boxes and yield of 1.23 gallons a box.

HEADLINE: Note and Bond Prices Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rebounded strongly yesterday, while bills posted only minimal changes.
The Treasury, meanwhile, announced that it planned to auction a record $10.75 billion of one-year bills on Thursday, assuming Congress raises the national debt ceiling.
Dealers said the strength of the Treasury issues yesterday largely reflected the lack of a big surprise in the Producer Price Index for September released by the Government before the New York market opened.
While the index of wholesale prices rose 1.6 percent last month, much of the increase was attributed to big jumps in oil and gasoline prices, which had been expected by market analysts. 
 
Benchmark Bond Yields 8.95%
Buoyed in part by weaker oil prices, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, were offered late in the day at 97 28/32, up 1 3/32, as the yield tumbled to 8.95 percent, from 9.07 percent the day before. But the bond's yield was still well above the 8.78 percent of a week ago.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 8 1/8 percent notes of 1992 rose 5/32, to 100 13/32, to yield 7.89 percent, and the new 8 3/4 percent notes of 1997 soared 17/32, to 100 14/ 32, as the yield dropped to 8.66 percent, from the average of 8.76 percent at the auction on Wednesday.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8 3/4's of August 2000, climbed 19/32, to 99 20/32, for a yield of 8.80 percent. A week ago, their yield was 8.63 percent.
''Leaving aside the daily flow of Mideast war and peace rumors, the Treasury bond market was somewhat oversold earlier in the week because of the Street's dismay at the budget wrangling in Washington,'' said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. ''The short end of the Treasury market continues to expect the Federal Reserve to ease the key funds rate by perhaps a quarter-point once a budget is enacted.''
 
Fed Funds Barely Move
As it was, the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans and is thus considered the bedrock cost of credit, traded at 7 15/16 percent for most of the session before closing at 7 7/8 percent, slightly below the Fed's perceived target of 8 percent.
Partly as a result, the discount rates on Treasury bills, which would be the most immediately affected by any cut or rise in the funds rate, showed minimal changes. The 90-day bills were unchanged at 7.15 percent; the six-month bills gained a basis point, or hundredths of a perentage point, at 7.15 percent, and the one-year bills rose three basis points, to 7.09 percent.
The record Treasury auction schedule for Thursday depends on Congress's raising the national debt ceiling from the present temporary level of $3.195 trillion. Mr. Chandross said that while a bill to raise the debt ceiling is currently tied up in the budget process, ''We can expect the debt ceiling to be raised, even if they don't get around to producing a budget deficit-reduction package.''
 
Inflation Data Played Down
Traders also shrugged off the Government's report of a 1.1 percent jump in September retail sales because the data were inflated, largely by sharply higher energy prices. But the sales data helped create a climate in which dealers slashed the prices of the high-yielding ''junk bonds'' of Macy's and Carter Hawley Hale department store chains.
Macy's 14 percent bonds of 1998 fell $30 for each $1,000 of face value, to $480; the 14's of 2001 lost $20, to $290; while the 14.5's of 1998 fell $30, to $480, and the 14.5's of 2001 slipped $20, to $290.
Dealers also reported that Carter Hawley Hale's 12 1/4 percent bonds of 1996 dropped $30, to $480, and the 12 1/2's of 2002 lost $20, to $410.
But dealers also noted that even the debt of high-grade corporations met with only tepid demand yesterday.

HEADLINE: Uruguay and Banks Reach Accord on Debt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Uruguay and its commercial bankers announced an initial agreement yesterday to reorganize the country's $1.6 billion in foreign bank loans, including provisions to reduce the country's debt.
The debt accord, announced in a statement released in New York, is the sixth reached under the Bush Administration's strategy, known as the Brady Plan, aimed at reducing the debt burden on developing countries. It is named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The first agreement with significant debt reduction was reached with Mexico last year. Just this week, bankers began what could be difficult negotiations with Brazil, the biggest debtor among developing countries. 
William R. Rhodes, senior executive-international at Citibank, the head of the bank advisory committee, said the agreement ''should strengthen the hand of the President of Uruguay in his effort to restructure the economy and privatize state companies.''
 
Options for Banks
Under the voluntary plan to which Uruguay agreed, banks can choose between two debt-reduction options or a plan to provide new loans.
One debt-reduction option reduces the interest rate on existing loans to 6.75 percent. The current rate is the London interbank offered rate (now around 8 percent), plus 13-sixteenths of a percentage point. Uruguay will also set up a fund that will guarantee the interest payments, an enhancement for the bankers that has become a fixture in Brady Plan deals.
Under the second debt-reduction option, Uruguay will propose to buy back existing loans at a discount. Loans to Uruguay are now trading at close to 50 cents on the dollar in the debt market. Bankers said Uruguay is likely to offer a slightly higher price to the banks.
Under the third option, banks can offer to make new loans to Uruguay. If they do, they will lend an amount equal to 20 percent of their outstanding loans. Unlike Venezuela, which negotiated a debt-reduction agreement this year, and Brazil, Uruguay was not behind in its interest payments, a factor that smoothed the negotiations. Bankers also stressed that the agreement is voluntary, leaving banks the alternative of choosing none of the options.
But Uruguayan officials said they thought most of the nearly 100 foreign banks would participate in the agreement. Peter McPherson, executive vice president of the Bank of America, said last night that the bank, which is one of Uruguay's largest creditors, would choose one of the three options.
Bankers have said that the deals reached with Mexico and Venezuela, although officially voluntary, all but required the banks to participate. Other countries that have reached agreements are Costa Rica, the Philippines and Morocco. Uruguay's total debt is about $4.5 billion, including that owed to governments, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Bankers said yesterday that the Brazilians, who began negotiations on Thursday, made an offer that was quickly ruled unacceptable. The proposal, which would cover the country's $60 billion in commercial bank debt, included the conversion of debt to 45-year bonds and a lottery that would determine which banks would be paid first.
The bankers were most annoyed that Brazil made no proposal to begin to pay some portion of the country's more than $8 billion in unpaid interest. The chief negotiator, Jorio Dauster, said no payments would be made until January at the earliest. In addition, one proposal made to the bankers included consolidating the unpaid interest with the existing debt.
